post_content: Today we were supposed to fly out to the cabin. The plan was to be at the Juneau airport early and pack the single engine plane with two SUV loads of provisions. We would then fly northwest for an hour, land on the beach, taxi up to the cabin and unload all the stuff we had been accumulating over the past several weeks....no, make that months. Well...Mother Nature has gotten involved in our best laid plans. She has decided to rain and snow and blow so that small planes can't fly. They may not fly for several days. Two days ago the weather was beautiful. Nature is so close all around up here. Yesterday We saw 12 Bald Eagles sitting in the same tree. The Mendenhall glacier is just four miles up the road. The air is so fresh here it seems the source of it must be very near by. This is the first "official" note I have entered in this electronic journal. I'll add to it from time to time. The plan is to share with my family and friends some of the wonderful things I come across here.

Today we are supposed to fly out to the cabin. The plan is to be at the Juneau Alaska airport early, pack the single engine plane with two SUV loads of provisions. We would then fly northwest for an hour, land on the beach, taxi up to the cabin and unload all the stuff we had been accumulating over the past several weeks....no, make that months. Well...Mother Nature has gotten involved in our best laid plans. She has decided to rain and snow and blow so that the small planes can't fly. They may not fly for several days. Two days ago the weather was beautiful. Nature is so close all around up here. We saw 12 Bald Eagles sitting in one tree. The Mendenhall glacier is just four miles up the road. The air is so fresh it seems the source of it must be very near by. This is the first "official" note I have entered in this electronic journal. I'll add to it from time to time. The plan is to share with my family and friends some of the wonderful things I come across here.

Today we were supposed to fly out to the cabin. The plan was to be at the Juneau airport early and pack the single engine plane with two SUV loads of provisions. We would then fly northwest for an hour, land on the beach, taxi up to the cabin and unload all the stuff we had been accumulating over the past several weeks....no, make that months. Well...Mother Nature has gotten involved in our best laid plans. She has decided to rain and snow and blow so that small planes can't fly. They may not fly for several days. Two days ago the weather was beautiful. Nature is so close all around up here. Yesterday We saw 12 Bald Eagles sitting in the same tree. The Mendenhall glacier is just four miles up the road. The air is so fresh here it seems the source of it must be very near by. This is the first "official" note I have entered in this electronic journal. I'll add to it from time to time. The plan is to share with my family and friends some of the wonderful things I come across here.

HEAT!!!

Thanks to my great neighbors, parts have been flown in, ladders borrowed, problems overcome, heat shields installed and the cabin is warm.  The wood stove works great.

It was really no big deal to have no heat in the cabin for a few days. Stay busy and you stay warm. When not busy add more clothes or go the the neighbor's cabin.

Today some fire wood needs to be cut. There are places along the beach and in the rivers where the currents leave hundreds of logs. The locals are particular about the kind of wood they burn. For now I'm interested in dry wood.

Looking out the window this morning the gulls are feasting on something in the river. Swarms of the birds are hovering over a spot. Then diving down for breakfast.

The barometer is falling like a rock. It might soon be a good day for inside jobs.
Sorry to have been out of touch.  I just got the internet working this morning.  I'll have an update  coming later today.  Now that this is working  I need to get some heat in the cabin.

MAY 15th. I have been keeping daily notes since May 4th but have not had internet access. Now that I do there are ten days of notes below. In the future there will not be nearly as much volume to read. Thanks for your interest. MAY 4TH Much has happened since I was able to add anything to this site. We were supposed to fly out to the cabin on May 1st. The weather was not cooperating so we stayed in Juneau another day. On the 2nd of May we were able to catch a flight to Gustavus and were treated to outstanding hospitality by our pilot and his wife. The clouds and fog were so dense visibility was near zero through a narrow pass called Icy Straights. The fog went all the way down to the surface of the sea….No place to be in a Cessna 206 single engine plane. On Friday the 3rd. the weather forecast was very iffy. We were not sure when we might be able to get to the cabin. Considering that and a bunch of other details like, “once we get there will Cheryl be able to get out in time to make her connections back home” we decided she should just come on back home and I would make it out to the cabin whenever the weather would allow. As nature would have it there was a break in weather and a narrow window opened and I got to the cabin about 3:00 Friday afternoon. It was raining. The weather service predicted 100% chance of rain, heavy at times. They were right. It rained, heavy at times, non-stop until 3:00 Saturday afternoon. I have been spending much of my time just watching the spectacle in front of the cabin. As I type this there are three flocks of migrating birds in my front yard. There are nearly 100 Canada geese just to the left. Directly in front of me there is a flock of 37 Sandhill cranes and a little beyond them must be 50 Snow geese. Throughout the day I have watched this spectacle. Frequently I see a few Greater White-fronted geese mixed in with the others.   Bald Eagles appear fairly often. You can tell when one is approaching. All the birds feeding take to the air in one huge mass. As soon as the eagle has passed they all come back and resume feeding…right in my front yard. I’m loving it. MAY 5TH Today would have been Mother’s birthday. She wouldn’t have liked it here but would have been happy that I’m able to enjoy all this nature. It has stopped raining and the clouds are a little higher today. Late in the afternoon I did hear a small plane fly by. That means the weather must be moderating some. Made good progress getting the outside cleaned up today. Over the years an assortment of plastic and fiberglass articles had accumulated. There were a few alder bushes that were blocking some of the view out the front. I had a heck of a bon fire going for a while. Some of that stuff made really dense black smoke. Not such a variety of waterfowl out front today. There was a large flock of Canada geese out front late. I’m guessing 250 birds. They graze back and forth less than 100 feet from the front door. As far as I can tell there is no one else here in the preserve. I check a neighboring cabin to see if their internet connection was working….it wasn’t. MAY 6TH Coolest morning yet. Thirty six outside. Forty seven inside. The stove works well and before long I’ll have it up in the middle 60s. There is some blue in the sky and I can see the mountains off in the east. There is beginning to be a tinge of green on the ground and the alders have little buds showing. Decided to go down to the mouth of the Alsek River to look for glass floats. These baseball size glass balls used to be used to float the fishing nets used by the Japanese fishing off shore. I found a few. On the way down the beech I saw my first bear of the season. At the mouth of the river a group of sea lions had gathered. The herd bull would frequently bellow or roar his presence. There seemed to be many young seals there too. MAY 7TH A beautiful blue sky morning with no wind. The heavy frost is quickly disappearing in the warm sunshine. Not many birds on the ground out front. It is unusual to look up into the sky and not see flocks of birds all heading the same way… North. As I type this an Osprey landed out front. The first humming bird just flew by. Got to get a feeder for them! Those sea lions mentioned yesterday…They are several miles away and I can hear them roaring here at the cabin. Borrowed a neighbor’s hummingbird feeder. They are not here yet so I didn’t think they would mind. I put the feeder up about ten this morning. By noon several pairs had found it. All the hummers I have seen up here are the Rufous hummingbirds. We see them passing through Colorado in July. I met another resident yesterday. I spent most of the day working on the storage area of the cabin. Hearing a little noise I discovered an Ermine (weasel) watching me. I hope she appreciates the redecorating. Also discovered the freezer freezes and the washing machine washes. MAY 8th A little chilly this morning, 30 outside and 40 inside. Another beautiful morning. I was up around 4:15. The hummingbirds were already buzzing around outside wondering where their feeder was! My neighbor flew down from Yakutat. He brought all the stuff I need to get the internet connection set up. He also brought provisions to begin stocking their cabin. He flew back to town and will return tomorrow with more supplies for his cabin. He will also bring the things to install the wood stove. I have been heating with an oil stove. With an endless supply of free fuel outside it seems silly to buy oil then have to fly it in. While we were standing outside another resident came up from out of the woods. It was a fair size brown bear (grizzly). He went back into the brush before I could get some good close-up pictures. MAY 9th High human traffic today. The neighbor flew back in with a friend of his. He brought all the parts needed to install the wood stove. Now I have to decide if I want to use the old wood stove that was stored here or get a new one. It’s not only the cost of the stove but getting it here will be expensive too. A pilot we flew with last year stopped by. He had been delivering fuel to a bear hunter’s camp. He was flying a neat little “cub” that had skis attached just above the wheels. He could land on the beach or in the snow. A little later two of the guides from the bear hunter camp stopped. Whew! I didn’t get as much work done as I hoped. Did get the attic emptied out. There was some high quality outdoor gear up there. A couple of wildlife things. The hummers are drinking over a quart of food a day. The weasel was back in the cabin last night. I nearly swatted him with my cap as it scurried across the floor. MAY 10th Last night I installed new gaskets in the hand pump by the sink. Whenever I needed more water I had to pump that handle at least 50 times (I actually counted). This morning on the 7th stroke water appeared. That is so neat. To not have to work up a sweat to get a cup of water. My neighbor has a portable saw mill. It comes in heal handy when you need more than a couple of boards that could be flown in on a small plane. Yesterday he found a fir log down on the beach over 40 feet long. Today we went down there, cut the log into 2 twenty footers rolled them onto an ingenious trailer and brought that huge log home to be sawed up into boards. This afternoon we got all the internet hardware mounted on the house and the wiring done. I still don’t have a connection to the internet. We think it is because there are some trees blocking the clear view of the sky the satellite dish needs. So tomorrow I’ll be turning trees into firewood. MAY 11th I went down to the mouth of the Alsek this morning to do a little more beachcombing. Found one glass float that had appeared with the tide. A little later my neighbor stopped in. He had also gone down there. He found another glass float not twenty feet from where I found mine. I expect I was so pleased to find one I didn’t bother to look around for another so close. The alder trees grow so quickly here they encroach on any clear space. So over the years they had invaded the space around the cabin clearing. I had been trimming them back for several days. Yesterday I spent quite a while burning them. Nearby, the little weasel was very busy hunting for something. My neighbor and his friend flew back to Yakutat around noon. He left the dog, Charlie, with me for the night. There had been a very light rain falling most of the day. When I went to bed it was pitch black inside. A little while later I could sense something very close. I turned on the light and Charlie was staring at me from a few inches away. Needless to say she wanted to be up off the floor. As far as I know she didn’t move all night….a good bed mate. MAY 12th I woke up this morning feeling an empty place. This is the first Mother’s Day in all these years that I have not been able to wish someone Happy Mother’s Day. To those Mothers who might read this …I hope you had a happy Mother’s Day. A light rain has fallen all day. So, very major progress was made today on organizing the living space at the cabin. By the end of the week I hope to have a wood stove working, the shop side of the cabin organized and the internet working. The rainy day has caused the humming birds to spend what seems like most of their time around the feeder. I filled the quart feeder after the birds went to bed last night. By 1:00 p.m. it was empty. It is nearly 8:30 p.m. now and I can’t see any food in it. They will have consumed over one half gallon of sugar water today. Charlie, the neighbor’s bear dog, is still with me. I get to keep her until the weather clears and the neighbors can get back down here. Thanks to Charlie’s being on guard she alerted me to a moose just across the river this morning. We watched her for a while till she crossed to our side and disappeared into the brush. MAY 13th About 12:30 this morning Charlie started having a fit. I grabbed a flashlight and let her out. She kept running around the outside of the cabin. The little LED flashlight didn’t help much in finding out what was out there. About a half hour later she was still very agitated. When I called her she came in and we settled down for the rest of the night. About 6:30 she started up again. I thought that is a lot of baking for the little weasel. Now Charlie was going under the cabin sounding more aggressive than ever. As I came back into the shop an Otter disappeared into a space along the wall. There turned out to be two otters. Between Charlie and I giving them so much grief they have moved on to a quieter spot. Good progress was made on cleaning up the accumulated stuff today. It rained on and off most of the day. Tomorrow if the weather cooperates I might start preparing to install the woodstove. I’m almost out of heating oil. MAY 14th Charlie got the morning off to good start for herself. She caught a sea gull out in front. I did get started on preparing for the wood stove. The cabin has a plywood floor. Some time back the previous owner bought some laminate flooring but didn’t get a chance to install it. I got about half the floor done today. It didn’t go down nearly as easily as the last time I worked with that kind of flooring. Maybe sitting around in high humidity for several years had something to do with it. Anyway, now that the floor is finished under where the wood stove will be I can proceed to figure out to protect the floor and wall from the heat it will put out. I’m fairly motivated in that I am out of heating oil. It was another rainy day. Fog came and went through the day. No small planes were flying. Because I am so near the ocean the temperatures stay very even. On a cloudy day like today the low might be 42 and the high for the day 48. All I have to do to stay warm is stay busy. Otherwise it requires several layers. Since I have no radio and no internet I don’t know what the forecast is. Sometimes my little weather station shows the pressure going up. That means fair weather ahead. Then it changes its mind. MAY 15th The friends who are also neighbors arrived today. Three trips in the plane from Yakutat to get their cabins stocked for the season. Dinner with them this evening featured Beer Batter halibut for an appetizer. Meatloaf and red potatoes, fresh salad. All this was accompanied by great conversation and Buffalo Trace bourbon. It was a great meal. I got the internet working late this morning. Now I can begin to learn how post pictures on this site so they are not upside down. We got the outside chimney installed for the wood stove. I should have heat in the cabin tomorrow before noon.

MAY 12th

I woke up this morning feeling an empty place. This is the first Mother’s Day in all these years that I have not been able to wish someone Happy Mother’s Day. To those Mothers who might read this …I hope you had a happy Mother’s Day.

A light rain has fallen all day. So, very major progress was made today on organizing the living space at the cabin. By the end of the week I hope to have a wood stove working, the shop side of the cabin organized and the internet working.

The rainy day has caused the humming birds to spend what seems like most of their time around the feeder. I filled the quart feeder after the birds went to bed last night. By 1:00 p.m. it was empty. It is nearly 8:30 p.m. now and I can’t see any food in it. They will have consumed over one half gallon of sugar water today.

Charlie, the neighbor’s bear dog, is still with me. I get to keep her until the weather clears and the neighbors can get back down here. Thanks to Charlie’s being on guard she alerted me to a moose just across the river this morning. We watched her for a while till she crossed to our side and disappeared into the brush.

MAY 13th

About 12:30 this morning Charlie started having a fit. I grabbed a flashlight and let her out. She kept running around the outside of the cabin. The little LED flashlight didn’t help much in finding out what was out there. About a half hour later she was still very agitated. When I called her she came in and we settled down for the rest of the night.

About 6:30 she started up again. I thought that is a lot of baking for the little weasel. Now Charlie was going under the cabin sounding more aggressive than ever. As I came back into the shop an Otter disappeared into a space along the wall. I bet it looked funny me sitting in a plastic chair, gun across my lap sipping coffee. Charlie did her job and the otter came out for the last time.

Now there seems to be yet another otter under there. I shot at it but it slipped back under the floor. Time and smell will tell if I hit it.

Good progress was made on cleaning up the accumulated stuff today. It rained on and off most of the day. Tomorrow if the weather cooperates I might start preparing to install the woodstove. I’m almost out of heating oil.

MAY 14th

Charlie got the morning off to good start for herself. She caught a sea gull out in front.

I did get started on preparing for the wood stove. The cabin has a plywood floor. Some time back the previous owner bought some laminate flooring but didn’t get a chance to install it. I got about half the floor done today. It didn’t go down nearly as easily as the last time I worked with that kind of flooring. Maybe sitting around in high humidity for several years had something to do with it. Anyway, now that the floor is finished under where the wood stove will be I can proceed to figure out to protect the floor and wall from the heat it will put out. I’m fairly motivated in that I am out of heating oil.

It was another rainy day. Fog came and went through the day. No small planes were flying. Because I am so near the ocean the temperatures stay very even. On a cloudy day like today the low might be 42 and the high for the day 48. All I have to do to stay warm is stay busy. Otherwise it requires several layers.

Since I have no radio and no internet I don’t know what the forecast is. Sometimes my little weather station shows the pressure going up. That means fair weather ahead. Then it changes its mind.

MAY 15th

The friends who are also neighbors arrived today. Three trips in the plane from Yakutat to get their cabins stocked for the season. Dinner with them this evening featured Beer Batter halibut for an appetizer. Meatloaf and red potatoes, fresh salad. All this was accompanied by great conversation and Buffalo Trace bourbon. It was a great meal.

I got the internet working late this morning. Now I can begin to learn how post pictures on this site so they are not upside down.

We got the outside chimney installed for the wood stove. I should have heat in the cabin tomorrow before noon.

MAY 7TH

A beautiful blue sky morning with no wind. The heavy frost is quickly disappearing in the warm sunshine. Not many birds on the ground out front. It is unusual to look up into the sky and not see flocks of birds all heading the same way… North. As I type this an Osprey landed out front. The first humming bird just flew by. Got to get a feeder for them! Those sea lions mentioned yesterday…They are several miles away and I can hear them roaring here at the cabin.

Borrowed a neighbor’s hummingbird feeder. They are not here yet so I didn’t think they would mind. I put the feeder up about ten this morning. By noon several pairs had found it. All the hummers I have seen up here are the Rufous hummingbirds. We see them passing through Colorado in July.

I met another resident yesterday. I spent most of the day working on the storage area of the cabin. Hearing a little noise I discovered an Ermine (weasel) watching me. I hope she appreciates the redecorating.

Also discovered the freezer freezes and the washing machine washes.

MAY 8th
A little chilly this morning, 30 outside and 40 inside. Another beautiful morning. I was up around 4:15. The hummingbirds were already buzzing around outside wondering where their feeder was!

My neighbor flew down from Yakutat. He brought all the stuff I need to get the internet connection set up. He also brought provisions to begin stocking their cabin. He flew back to town and will return tomorrow with more supplies for his cabin. He will also bring the things to install the wood stove. I have been heating with an oil stove. With an endless supply of free fuel outside it seems silly to buy oil then have to fly it in.

While we were standing outside another resident came up from out of the woods. It was a fair size brown bear (grizzly). He went back into the brush before I could get some good close-up pictures.

MAY 9th

High human traffic today. The neighbor flew back in with a friend of his. He brought all the parts needed to install the wood stove. Now I have to decide if I want to use the old wood stove that was stored here or get a new one. It’s not only the cost of the stove but getting it here will be expensive too. A pilot we flew with last year stopped by. He had been delivering fuel to a bear hunter’s camp. He was flying a neat little “cub” that had skis attached just above the wheels. He could land on the beach or in the snow. A little later two of the guides from the bear hunter camp stopped. Whew! I didn’t get as much work done as I hoped.

Did get the attic emptied out. There was some high quality outdoor gear up there.

A couple of wildlife things. The hummers are drinking over a quart of food a day. The weasel was back in the cabin last night. I nearly swatted him with my cap as it scurried across the floor.

MAY 10th

Last night I installed new gaskets in the hand pump by the sink. Whenever I needed more water I had to pump that handle at least 50 times (I actually counted). This morning on the 7th stroke water appeared. That is so neat. To not have to work up a sweat to get a cup of water.

My neighbor has a portable saw mill. It comes in heal handy when you need more than a couple of boards that could be flown in on a small plane. Yesterday he found a fir log down on the beach over 40 feet long. Today we went down there, cut the log into 2 twenty footers rolled them onto an ingenious trailer and brought that huge log home to be sawed up into boards.

This afternoon we got all the internet hardware mounted on the house and the wiring done. I still don’t have a connection to the internet. We think it is because there are some trees blocking the clear view of the sky the satellite dish needs. So tomorrow I’ll be turning trees into firewood.

MAY 11th
I went down to the mouth of the Alsek this morning to do a little more beachcombing. Found one glass float that had appeared with the tide. A little later my neighbor stopped in. He had also gone down there. He found another glass float not twenty feet from where I found mine. I expect I was so pleased to find one I didn’t bother to look around for another so close.

The alder trees grow so quickly here they encroach on any clear space. So over the years they had invaded the space around the cabin clearing. I had been trimming them back for several days. Yesterday I spent quite a while burning them.

Nearby, the little weasel was very busy hunting for something.

My neighbor and his friend flew back to Yakutat around noon. He left the dog, Charlie, with me for the night. There had been a very light rain falling most of the day. When I went to bed it was pitch black inside. A little while later I could sense something very close. I turned on the light and Charlie was staring at me from a few inches away. Needless to say she wanted to be up off the floor. As far as I know she didn’t move all night….a good bed mate.

MAY 12th

I woke up this morning feeling an empty place. This is the first Mother’s Day in all these years that I have not been able to wish someone Happy Mother’s Day. To those Mothers who might read this …I hope you had a happy Mother’s Day.

A light rain has fallen all day. So, very major progress was made today on organizing the living space at the cabin. By the end of the week I hope to have a wood stove working, the shop side of the cabin organized and the internet working.

The rainy day has caused the humming birds to spend what seems like most of their time around the feeder. I filled the quart feeder after the birds went to bed last night. By 1:00 p.m. it was empty. It is nearly 8:30 p.m. now and I can’t see any food in it. They will have consumed over one half gallon of sugar water today.

Charlie, the neighbor’s bear dog, is still with me. I get to keep her until the weather clears and the neighbors can get back down here. Thanks to Charlie’s being on guard she alerted me to a moose just across the river this morning. We watched her for a while till she crossed to our side and disappeared into the brush.

MAY 13th

About 12:30 this morning Charlie started having a fit. I grabbed a flashlight and let her out. She kept running around the outside of the cabin. The little LED flashlight didn’t help much in finding out what was out there. About a half hour later she was still very agitated. When I called her she came in and we settled down for the rest of the night.

About 6:30 she started up again. I thought that is a lot of baking for the little weasel. Now Charlie was going under the cabin sounding more aggressive than ever. As I came back into the shop an Otter disappeared into a space along the wall. I bet it looked funny me sitting in a plastic chair, gun across my lap sipping coffee. Charlie did her job and the otter came out for the last time.

Now there seems to be yet another otter under there. I shot at it but it slipped back under the floor. Time and smell will tell if I hit it.

Good progress was made on cleaning up the accumulated stuff today. It rained on and off most of the day. Tomorrow if the weather cooperates I might start preparing to install the woodstove. I’m almost out of heating oil.

MAY 14th

Charlie got the morning off to good start for herself. She caught a sea gull out in front.

I did get started on preparing for the wood stove. The cabin has a plywood floor. Some time back the previous owner bought some laminate flooring but didn’t get a chance to install it. I got about half the floor done today. It didn’t go down nearly as easily as the last time I worked with that kind of flooring. Maybe sitting around in high humidity for several years had something to do with it. Anyway, now that the floor is finished under where the wood stove will be I can proceed to figure out to protect the floor and wall from the heat it will put out. I’m fairly motivated in that I am out of heating oil.

It was another rainy day. Fog came and went through the day. No small planes were flying. Because I am so near the ocean the temperatures stay very even. On a cloudy day like today the low might be 42 and the high for the day 48. All I have to do to stay warm is stay busy. Otherwise it requires several layers.

Since I have no radio and no internet I don’t know what the forecast is. Sometimes my little weather station shows the pressure going up. That means fair weather ahead. Then it changes its mind.

MAY 15th

The friends who are also neighbors arrived today. Three trips in the plane from Yakutat to get their cabins stocked for the season. Dinner with them this evening featured Beer Batter halibut for an appetizer. Meatloaf and red potatoes, fresh salad. All this was accompanied by great conversation and Buffalo Trace bourbon. It was a great meal.

I got the internet working late this morning. Now I can begin to learn how post pictures on this site so they are not upside down.

We got the outside chimney installed for the wood stove. I should have heat in the cabin tomorrow before noon.

HEAT!!!

Thanks to my great neighbors, parts have been flown in, ladders borrowed, problems overcome, heat shields installed and the cabin is warm.  The wood stove works great.

It was really no big deal to have no heat in the cabin for a few days. Stay busy and you stay warm. When not busy add more clothes or go the the neighbor's cabin.

Today some fire wood needs to be cut. There are places along the beach and in the rivers where the currents leave hundreds of logs. The locals are particular about the kind of wood they burn. For now I'm interested in dry wood.

Looking out the window this morning the gulls are feasting on something in the river. Swarms of the birds are hovering over a spot. Then diving down for breakfast.

The barometer is falling like a rock. It might soon be a good day for inside jobs.

HEAT!!!

Thanks to my great neighbors, parts have been flown in, ladders borrowed, problems overcome, heat shields installed and the cabin is warm.  The wood stove works great.

It was really no big deal to have no heat in the cabin for a few days. Stay busy and you stay warm. When not busy add more clothes or go the the neighbor's cabin.

Today some fire wood needs to be cut. There are places along the beach and in the rivers where the currents leave hundreds of logs. The locals are particular about the kind of wood they burn. For now I'm interested in dry wood.

Looking out the window this morning the gulls are feasting on something in the river. Swarms of the birds are hovering over a spot. Then diving down for breakfast.

The barometer is falling like a rock. It might soon be a good day for inside jobs.

Bright sun this morning shinning down on an inch of new snow. By afternoon it was short shirt sleeve weather. All the snow was gone as soon as the sun hit it.

A bear was just across the river early today. It was just ambling along trying to find something to eat among the sea oats.  The otter has moved up the creek.  It was under Lisa's house this morning.  The weasel is back with me.  I have a trap set.

As the weather improved, and at low tide, I waded across the river and walked up the beach for a couple of miles. On the way back I found another glass float. A very small one this time.

I think I mentioned the hundreds of gulls that are feeding on something in the river. They seem to be catching a small slender fish similar to a grunion (large minnow in size). These little fish come in to spawn in the sand. There are literally millions of them. After they spawn they die and wash up all along the beach. There were so many a few days ago neighbors flying in could see the lines of them washed ashore. They provide a real feast for some of the wildlife.

Tonight I was invited to dinner at Pat and Lisa's cabin. Steak, potatoes broccoli, and a wonderful slaw. Everyone in this part of the preserve was there. All ten of us.

Tomorrow I have to make an unplanned trip to Anchorage to find a dentist. I broke a tooth and it is requesting attention. While there I will do some shopping for cabin maintenance stuff.

I have to do some laundry before Alaska airlines will let me on a plane so I better get with it.

MAY 15th. I have been keeping daily notes since May 4th but have not had internet access. Now that I do there are ten days of notes below. In the future there will not be nearly as much volume to read. Thanks for your interest.

MAY 4TH

Much has happened since I was able to add anything to this site. We were supposed to fly out to the cabin on May 1st. The weather was not cooperating so we stayed in Juneau another day. On the 2nd of May we were able to catch a flight to Gustavus and were treated to outstanding hospitality by our pilot and his wife. The clouds and fog were so dense visibility was near zero through a narrow pass called Icy Straights. The fog went all the way down to the surface of the sea….No place to be in a Cessna 206 single engine plane.

On Friday the 3rd. the weather forecast was very iffy. We were not sure when we might be able to get to the cabin. Considering that and a bunch of other details like, “once we get there will Cheryl be able to get out in time to make her connections back home” we decided she should just come on back home and I would make it out to the cabin whenever the weather would allow.

As nature would have it there was a break in weather and a narrow window opened and I got to the cabin about 3:00 Friday afternoon. It was raining. The weather service predicted 100% chance of rain, heavy at times. They were right. It rained, heavy at times, non-stop until 3:00 Saturday afternoon.

I have been spending much of my time just watching the spectacle in front of the cabin. As I type this there are three flocks of migrating birds in my front yard. There are nearly 100 Canada geese just to the left. Directly in front of me there is a flock of 37 Sandhill cranes and a little beyond them must be 50 Snow geese. Throughout the day I have watched this spectacle. Frequently I see a few Greater White-fronted geese mixed in with the others.

Bald Eagles appear fairly often. You can tell when one is approaching. All the birds feeding take to the air in one huge mass. As soon as the eagle has passed they all come back and resume feeding…right in my front yard.

I’m loving it.

MAY 5TH
Today would have been Mother’s birthday. She wouldn’t have liked it here but would have been happy that I’m able to enjoy all this nature.

It has stopped raining and the clouds are a little higher today. Late in the afternoon I did hear a small plane fly by. That means the weather must be moderating some.

Made good progress getting the outside cleaned up today. Over the years an assortment of plastic and fiberglass articles had accumulated. There were a few alder bushes that were blocking some of the view out the front. I had a heck of a bon fire going for a while. Some of that stuff made really dense black smoke.

Not such a variety of waterfowl out front today. There was a large flock of Canada geese out front late. I’m guessing 250 birds. They graze back and forth less than 100 feet from the front door.

As far as I can tell there is no one else here in the preserve. I check a neighboring cabin to see if their internet connection was working….it wasn’t.

MAY 6TH

Coolest morning yet. Thirty six outside. Forty seven inside. The stove works well and before long I’ll have it up in the middle 60s. There is some blue in the sky and I can see the mountains off in the east. There is beginning to be a tinge of green on the ground and the alders have little buds showing.

Decided to go down to the mouth of the Alsek River to look for glass floats. These baseball size glass balls used to be used to float the fishing nets used by the Japanese fishing off shore. I found a few.

On the way down the beech I saw my first bear of the season. At the mouth of the river a group of sea lions had gathered. The herd bull would frequently bellow or roar his presence. There seemed to be many young seals there too.

MAY 7TH

A beautiful blue sky morning with no wind. The heavy frost is quickly disappearing in the warm sunshine. Not many birds on the ground out front. It is unusual to look up into the sky and not see flocks of birds all heading the same way… North. As I type this an Osprey landed out front. The first humming bird just flew by. Got to get a feeder for them! Those sea lions mentioned yesterday…They are several miles away and I can hear them roaring here at the cabin.

Borrowed a neighbor’s hummingbird feeder. They are not here yet so I didn’t think they would mind. I put the feeder up about ten this morning. By noon several pairs had found it. All the hummers I have seen up here are the Rufous hummingbirds. We see them passing through Colorado in July.

I met another resident yesterday. I spent most of the day working on the storage area of the cabin. Hearing a little noise I discovered an Ermine (weasel) watching me. I hope she appreciates the redecorating.

Also discovered the freezer freezes and the washing machine washes.

With an endless supply of free fuel outside it seems silly to buy oil then have to fly it in.

While we were standing outside another resident came up from out of the woods. It was a fair size brown bear (grizzly). He went back into the brush before I could get some good close-up pictures.

High human traffic today. The neighbor flew back in with a friend of his. He brought all the parts needed to install the wood stove. Now I have to decide if I want to use the old wood stove that was stored here or get a new one. It’s not only the cost of the stove but getting it here will be expensive too. A pilot we flew with last year stopped by. He had been delivering fuel to a bear hunter’s camp. He was flying a neat little “cub” that had skis attached just above the wheels. He could land on the beach or in the snow. A little later two of the guides from the bear hunter camp stopped. Whew! I didn’t get as much work done as I hoped.

Did get the attic emptied out. There was some high quality outdoor gear up there.

A couple of wildlife things. The hummers are drinking over a quart of food a day. The weasel was back in the cabin last night. I nearly swatted him with my cap as it scurried across the floor.

MAY 10th

Last night I installed new gaskets in the hand pump by the sink. Whenever I needed more water I had to pump that handle at least 50 times (I actually counted). This morning on the 7th stroke water appeared. That is so neat. To not have to work up a sweat to get a cup of water.

My neighbor has a portable saw mill. It comes in heal handy when you need more than a couple of boards that could be flown in on a small plane. Yesterday he found a fir log down on the beach over 40 feet long. Today we went down there, cut the log into 2 twenty footers rolled them onto an ingenious trailer and brought that huge log home to be sawed up into boards.

This afternoon we got all the internet hardware mounted on the house and the wiring done. I still don’t have a connection to the internet. We think it is because there are some trees blocking the clear view of the sky the satellite dish needs. So tomorrow I’ll be turning trees into firewood.

MAY 11th
I went down to the mouth of the Alsek this morning to do a little more beachcombing. Found one glass float that had appeared with the tide. A little later my neighbor stopped in. He had also gone down there. He found another glass float not twenty feet from where I found mine. I expect I was so pleased to find one I didn’t bother to look around for another so close.

The alder trees grow so quickly here they encroach on any clear space. So over the years they had invaded the space around the cabin clearing. I had been trimming them back for several days. Yesterday I spent quite a while burning them.

Nearby, the little weasel was very busy hunting for something.

My neighbor and his friend flew back to Yakutat around noon. He left the dog, Charlie, with me for the night. There had been a very light rain falling most of the day. When I went to bed it was pitch black inside. A little while later I could sense something very close. I turned on the light and Charlie was staring at me from a few inches away. Needless to say she wanted to be up off the floor. As far as I know she didn’t move all night….a good bed mate.

MAY 12th

I woke up this morning feeling an empty place. This is the first Mother’s Day in all these years that I have not been able to wish someone Happy Mother’s Day. To those Mothers who might read this …I hope you had a happy Mother’s Day.

A light rain has fallen all day. So, very major progress was made today on organizing the living space at the cabin. By the end of the week I hope to have a wood stove working, the shop side of the cabin organized and the internet working.

The rainy day has caused the humming birds to spend what seems like most of their time around the feeder. I filled the quart feeder after the birds went to bed last night. By 1:00 p.m. it was empty. It is nearly 8:30 p.m. now and I can’t see any food in it. They will have consumed over one half gallon of sugar water today.

Charlie, the neighbor’s bear dog, is still with me. I get to keep her until the weather clears and the neighbors can get back down here. Thanks to Charlie’s being on guard she alerted me to a moose just across the river this morning. We watched her for a while till she crossed to our side and disappeared into the brush.

MAY 13th

About 12:30 this morning Charlie started having a fit. I grabbed a flashlight and let her out. She kept running around the outside of the cabin. The little LED flashlight didn’t help much in finding out what was out there. About a half hour later she was still very agitated. When I called her she came in and we settled down for the rest of the night.

About 6:30 she started up again. I thought that is a lot of baking for the little weasel. Now Charlie was going under the cabin sounding more aggressive than ever. As I came back into the shop an Otter disappeared into a space along the wall. I bet it looked funny me sitting in a plastic chair, gun across my lap sipping coffee. Charlie did her job and the otter came out for the last time.

Now there seems to be yet another otter under there. I shot at it but it slipped back under the floor. Time and smell will tell if I hit it.

Good progress was made on cleaning up the accumulated stuff today. It rained on and off most of the day. Tomorrow if the weather cooperates I might start preparing to install the woodstove. I’m almost out of heating oil.

MAY 14th

Charlie got the morning off to good start for herself. She caught a sea gull out in front.

I did get started on preparing for the wood stove. The cabin has a plywood floor. Some time back the previous owner bought some laminate flooring but didn’t get a chance to install it. I got about half the floor done today. It didn’t go down nearly as easily as the last time I worked with that kind of flooring. Maybe sitting around in high humidity for several years had something to do with it. Anyway, now that the floor is finished under where the wood stove will be I can proceed to figure out to protect the floor and wall from the heat it will put out. I’m fairly motivated in that I am out of heating oil.

It was another rainy day. Fog came and went through the day. No small planes were flying. Because I am so near the ocean the temperatures stay very even. On a cloudy day like today the low might be 42 and the high for the day 48. All I have to do to stay warm is stay busy. Otherwise it requires several layers.

Since I have no radio and no internet I don’t know what the forecast is. Sometimes my little weather station shows the pressure going up. That means fair weather ahead. Then it changes its mind.

MAY 15th

The friends who are also neighbors arrived today. Three trips in the plane from Yakutat to get their cabins stocked for the season. Dinner with them this evening featured Beer Batter halibut for an appetizer. Meatloaf and red potatoes, fresh salad. All this was accompanied by great conversation and Buffalo Trace bourbon. It was a great meal.

I got the internet working late this morning. Now I can begin to learn how post pictures on this site so they are not upside down.

We got the outside chimney installed for the wood stove. I should have heat in the cabin tomorrow before noon.

We live in an amazing time.  This morning I was in a fairly remote part of the world.  By 3:00 in the afternoon I was sitting in a dentists chair hundreds of miles away.

After the dentist did his job on the broken tooth, I said good bye to it and went shopping for cabin stuff.  It is no surprise the farther north one comes the more things cost.  The cost for a room for one night at a Hampton Inn was $270.00.  I didn't stay there.  The Super 8 where I finally landed was over a hundred dollars.  I admit the hot shower and plumbing were appreciated.

Tomorrow I'll fly back to Dry Bay.

A very beautiful day in Alaska. There are two jet flights into Yakutat each day. The morning, northbound, flight originates in Seattle, stops in Juneau, Yakutat, Cordova and ends in Anchorage. That same plane turns around, southbound, and makes those same stops on the way back to Seattle. I had a very busy morning getting a lot of shopping done for the cabin and caught the southbound back to Yakutat. It was clear all the way from Anchorage. I sat on the left side of the plane so I could see the continuous mountain ranges below. They all still have snow on them down to about 1,000 feet. As these warm days come more often one can see the snow line rise up the mountains each day. Between Anchorage and the cabin there must be at least 50 coastal glaciers. The rivers that flow from them to the sea are all a light gray color from the silt created by the glacier as it grinds across the stones. Those rivers all have icebergs in them. Some the size of garbage cans. Some appear to be as big as city blocks. The ice sheet at the head of some of these glaciers is the largest in North America. To see all that white snow and ice then land at the cabin which sits in a temperate rain forest....we live on an amazing planet. Neighbor, Harold met me at the airport and we flew on down to the cabin in his plane. The ghost of my extracted tooth was haunting me so I took some medicine to chase it away. The weasel was here and greeted me with some news. There is clear plastic stapled to the ceiling joists that holds the insulation up. I could see the weasel moving around on top of the clear plastic but below the insulation. As I watched I noticed some more movement above the plastic. She had a litter of little weasels up there. Harold's grandson and his girlfriend came over to see the litter. Harold's son, Pat, wanted me to catch the weasels and put them in another neighbor's house. I decided not to do that. We positioned a deep Rubbermaid tub under the nest and cut the plastic around the nest. The seven little weasels and the mother weasel all fell into the tub. We took them about a hundred yards from the cabin and turned the tub on its side. Out pops mom with a little weasel in her mouth. She ran into the woods with it. We left her alone and in maybe 15 minutes she had moved all seven of her pups(?) to some other place. I came back from Anchorage with the parts to install another well. This one will have an electric pump attached. There may be running water at the cabin soon. More about that another time. Thanks for the kind comments about these ramblings. I enjoy telling these stories.

Another beautiful day but windy,  the weather usually comes from the southeast but today the wind was steady from the west.

I made some progress getting the loft area of the cabin ready to remodel.  A couple of the neighbors have this saw mill I think was mentioned earlier.  The lumber I need for the modifications I want to make they will cut for me.  It's pretty neat.  If you need ten 2x4s just go out and make them.  Need a couple of 2x6 boards.. No problem.  I mentioned having some paneling flown in.  Pat looked at me and said " why not use some one by six boards?  We will just make them."  With that machine who needs a lumber yard?

Behind the cabin there is an old gravel runway.  It was built so the planes carrying the fish to the processors had a place to land.  It isn't used for that anymore.  These days the planes just land on the beach in front of the cabin.  The runway is kept trimmed by the people who live along side it.  It is lined on both sides by trees.  Tonight I was invited to a hot dog roast on the runway.  It was out of that west wind and a central place for those of us who are here could gather.

It was at the hot dog roast that I was informed on my first BIG mistake.  I had gone to the city and had returned with no beer.  Didn't matter that I Already had four bags to check.  Didn't matter that another checked bag would cost an additional $50.00.  It seems that if you are going to live in this small close knit community when you go "outside" you bring back some beer.

Last week at this time there were so many hummingbirds that one day they drank 3/4 of a gallon of sugar water in one day.  While I was in Anchorage the feeder ran out of food for them.  I filled it up again this morning.  All day I saw only two hummingbirds.  I guess they have moved on to wherever it is they go.   Spring is about to pop here.  I was told if I wanted to go exploring in the woods I'd better do it soon.  When the leaves start to come out it happens all at once.  There is so much daylight.  Only about four hours of each night are truly dark.  It is light outside when I go to bed and at four in morning the birds are already up and busy.

Today I seemed to notice more Bald Eagles hanging around.  It is easy to recognize them from a distance.  Their soaring flight on very large wings is beautiful.  

I think this wood burning stove and I are about to begin to understand each other.  It wants to be fed fairly dry wood fairly often.  I am learning how to get dry wood (my neighbors have it).

I frequently hear someone say "I found it on the beach".  How true that is. If one is patient and looks hard enough what you need, or can make do with, will probably wash ashore.  I needed a place to keep firewood dry outside.  Down near the river an old aluminum boat had washed up.  I sawed the bow and stern off.  The middle section is now hanging six feet up on the north side of the garage.  The two posts that support the outside edge came off the beach.  The pallet that is under the firewood came off the beach.  The beautiful rolling pin shaped glass fishing float I found today came "off the beach".  The logs my neighbors have been making lumber out of came, you guessed it, "off the beach".  Finally the fairly dry firewood the stove demands comes from off the beach or is the waste from the logs used at the saw mill.

While on the beach today I was surprised to see four other people.  These three young men and a young woman were walking from Yakutat to Hanes.  That is 152 as the crow flies miles.  They were carrying inflatable boats to cross the rivers and light tents for shelter.  Two of the guys were walking barefoot.  Gee whiz..I don't know what else to say about that except I wish them well.

Yesterday I was so worn out by the time I usually write things here I just couldn't.  

Ths morning munching on my Grape Nuts I noticed something moving over on the other side of the river.  A brown bear and her two cubs were foraging along the river bank. The cubs were almost as big as the sow.  It was fun to watch them.  They were very curious.  Together the cubs inspected the roots of a tree that had washed up on the bank.  One would move ahead of mom while the other one tended to lag behind.  Mom would frequently look around, checking on each cub, then go back to foraging.  From time to time she would look across the river toward the cabin.  I expect she has experience with the humans who live over here.  She kept her distance and is hopefully teaching her cubs to do the same.

I did four loads of laundry today.  It takes four and a half 5 gallon buckets of water for the wash cycle and another four and a half buckets for the rinse cycle.  I get my water from a well connected to a hand pump installed over the kitchen sink.  It takes forty strokes on the hand pump to fill each bucket.  That is 36 buckets of water for the four loads.  That is 1,440 strokes on that pump to get the clothes washed.  I got to get the electric pump going!  The washing machine is in the garage.  The first time I used it I caught the water expelled from the washer in buckets.  That was s sight to see.  The washer spitting out gallons of water nonstop and me switching buckets trying to not flood the garage.  The solution this time was to patch together some plastic pipe pieces.  Now the washer's hose goes into the first piece of plastic pipe.  Held there with duct tape.  That gets me out the garage door.  With fittings I can add more short pieces of pipe to get the wash water away from the garage.

I am going to have a few visitors this summer.  To accommodate them I felt I needed for them to have a separate sleeping space.  The garage side of the cabin has a 12 foot high ceiling that slopes down to about 7 on the outside wall.  Today I built a loft over part of that space.  I made the floor high enough so the space under the loft is still useable.  The ceiling in part of the loft is too low to do more than store things there.  That space will be just right for some of the seldom used garage stuff.

Tomorrow is my oldest son's birthday.  He will visit me here later this summer.  In the mean time I wish him much joy and happiness and lots of Amazon gift cards.  

In his honor I might cross the river again and do some beach combing.  A neighbor told me how to get the four wheeler across.  When the water gets too deep to ride the machine, just get off and float it on across to shallower water.  I can see how the four wheeler can float but I think I'll tie a rope to it in case it gets away from me.

The low tide tomorrow morning is almost 3 feet lower than normal.  I will have to watch how much time I spend on the other side.  After the low tide the water comes back in.  I don't want to have to wait over there for the next low tide.

Well the best laid plans sometimes come up hard against reality, or in this case safety.

I had planned to cross the river with the four wheeler this morning.  If the water was to deep the plan was to get off and float the wheeler into shallower water.  The lowest tide of the month was this morning.  What I didn't know was last night the third highest tide of the month had come in.  All that water gets pushed up into the rivers.  Even though there was a very low tide all the water pushed into the river was trying to get out.  When the water I was wading in got up to my waste and in a strong current I decided not to try and float the machine across.

As I rode down the beach later I saw what appeared to be a dead seal.  As I approached it was a bull sea lion.  Those guys a very large.  Weighing Way over a 1,000 pounds.  It still hasn't moved till I got within about 20 feet of it.  It woke up and lumbered into the ocean.  He looked to be in poor condition.  That made two old guys out there at once.

I came across another group of hikers on the beach.  Five women and one guy were spending their holiday weekend walking to Yakutat from somewhere southeast of here.  They had at least 50 miles to go and several large rivers to cross with their light weight inflatable boats.

Went looking for moose antlers later.  Thank goodness for the GPS.  All this country looks the same once you get into the bush.  There are no hills to help you keep oriented.  I thought I was walking straight away from the road.  The GPS showed me I had been making a gradual turn to the left.  I trusted the GPS and it took me back to the wheeler.  Without it I might still be out there walking in a big counter clockwise circle.

Late this afternoon I went down to the mouth of the East Alsek river.  A neighbor expects the king salmon to show up any day.  There are a few sockeye salmon in the river now.  Every few minutes one would make a splash on the surface.  It is about three weeks before the commercial fishing season opens on this river.  Neighbors are getting their nets and gear ready.  I need to add all that to my list of things to do.

Well the best laid plans sometimes come up hard with reality, or in this case safety.

I seem to be falling into a routine.  I get up in the mornings with a pretty full to do list in my mind.  After breakfast I seem to have trouble deciding which task to start on first.  Unable to decide on a task I just go play.  Today I drove down the beach to the mouth of the Alsek river to look for glass floats.  The Alsek is a glacier fed river.  The water is a light gray from all the silt the glacier creates.  Today there were several pieces of ice that had floated all the way from the glacier to the mouth of the river.  One of them was half the size of the four wheeler.  My neighbor collects some of the ice from the river to keep her food cold in coolers.  I found a rare amber colored glass float.  A Google search says the amber color is rare and the glass probably started out as a beer bottle. On the way back I saw something else unusual.  There was a beaver in the edge of the surf.  I thought beavers were strictly fresh water critters.  There wasn't a tree for this guy to chew on in sight. While typing this there is a bear across the creek in front of the cabin.  It is going the other way.  That is probably good. A couple of days ago I mentioned doing some laundry.  My neighbor's adult kids spend part of the fishing season on a very remote river.  To do their laundry they clean out the totes they usually haul fish in.  Then they pour several gallons of fresh water into the tote.  Add a little detergent, add the clothes then just drive around on the four wheeler pulling the tote.  The agitation caused by bumping along the riverbank gets the clothes "cleaner"! Looks like I have figured out how to add pictures.  This one was taken before the hummers took a break to go nesting.  The creek in front of the cabin I mentioned is in the background. This was the first bear I saw a couple of weeks ago. He is entering the brush just off to the right side of the cabin.

Not much going on today except for all the wheel spinning I did.  I added some old gas to the generator and changed its oil.  When I restarted it it ran for about five minutes and would stop.  There is a sensor that shuts the engine down if the oil level is low.  I checked that.  The oil was OK.  Then  I decided it must have been bad gas I had added.  After pumping the old "bad" gas out and refilling the tank she fired right up. Five minutes later it shut down again.  I drained the carburetor thinking there might have some bad gas accumulated there.  Same problem.  I checked the oil again. It appeared frothy.  I had used some premium aircraft oil that was here at the cabin.  I drained the "premium" oil and refilled with plane ole 30 weight.  The generator has been running fine ever since.

Today was the day to get the fishing boat running.  More wheel spinning.  I cleaned out a gas tank.  Added the oil and gas mixture in the proper ratios.  Put the tank in the boat.  It was the wrong kind of tank.  Found the right type tank but then couldn't get the gas to flow to the engine.  Figured that out and now it runs fine.

The boat has some air chambers welded into it to keep it afloat should you get swamped.  Some water had seeped into those chambers.  There are two bolts one removes to drain that water.  I took the bolts out.  The water drained but due to corrosion or who knows what they would not tighten back up in their holes.  Those two bolts are now held in place wit roofing sealer.

The air temperature and water temperature are such that a fog has suddenly appeared then will disappear just as quickly.  That has been going on all day.  There is no wind so this fog just happens.  It is kind of weird.  Right now I can't see the creek in front of the cabin.

Rain is in the forecast.  There are a few pressing outdoor chores I would like to get done then I won't feel bad about staying inside and doing some administrative stuff.  Counting my blessings and maybe a few sheep.

The official commercial fishing season in this area is always the first Sunday in June.  The fish and game people monitor how many fish are moving through the rivers and regulate the allowed fishing days after that official opening day.  So everyone around here is getting ready to go fishing on Sunday.  With a little help I think I might give it a try.

The wild strawberries are beginning to bloom.  The ground is nearly covered with them.  I noticed tonight how far the snow line has moved up the mountains.  The glaciers are very aparent now that the snow is retreating.

The weather is still beautiful.  Mid sixties during the day.  Very little wind.  It has been in the upper forties each morning.  The wood stove knocks the chill off in about ten minutes.

The biggest outdoor project left to do is build a new outhouse.  The one here is OK but...it tilts a little.  The view from in there is wonderful.  I enjoy it every morning.  One can't help but enjoy the view because the door is off its hinges and is sitting alongside the building.  I'm not sure the new one even needs a door.

Fitz asked about mowing the grass and snakes.  There are no snakes in Alaska.  The neighborhood has a beast of a flail mower you pull behind an ATV.  In front of the cabin above the high water line there are sea oats that give way to the strawberries and some low growing grass with moss mixed in.  Then as the ground gradually rises the Alders take over and after them the spruce trees.  It is hard to believe that when this cabin was built in the eighties there were no trees around here.

It has gotten so just before I start to write here I look around outside to see if there is any wildlife to report on. Today I saw what were probably the same two bears twice. I saw the bears the first time when I was putting my fishing boat in the water. It is a very heavy duty home made aluminum boat about 18 feet long. Up here there is an ingenious way of building the boats so a trailer is not required to move them across the land. Two automobile wheels on short stubby axles slide into pockets near the back of the boat. You back the boat into the water, slide the wheels out and you are on your way. To go across land again, just park the boat in shallow water, slide the wheels back in and go. Very simple...in my case the shallow water required was deeper than my boots were tall. No real problem since my wet feet were close to home. After running the boat up and down the river a couple of times I came back to shore a little to fast. One second I am headed toward the shallow water on shore. Next second I'm looking at the sky. The boat has a very wide flat bottom for stability. When it runs aground one stops in a lot less than a New York minute. Well the boat stopped and I didn't till the space between the front and back seat benches caught me. Not a big problem except I was so far ashore I needed help getting the boat back in the "shallow" water to get the wheels back on. My neighbor Pat came over to help me get my nets in order for the season opener for salmon on Sunday. It is very complicated. The regulations are reasonable considering the catch has to be managed so enough salmon get through to spawn and sustain the fishery. For a newbe like me trying to understand webbing, fathoms and mesh depth which can all vary depending on the water you are fishing and the targeted fish. I have thought enough about it today. Later we took my boat over to the Alsek river (a huge fast river). On the way one of those wheels fell off. We got it back on without a lot of trouble. As I approached the cabin coming back the two bears were on my side of the river. Charlie, the neighbor's bear dog spotted them. Charlie weighs maybe 50 pounds. She went tearing out after these two grizzly bears. At first they just watch her barreling toward themselves. Then they seem to think, "who is that little thing kidding"? But she is coming at them so fast and seems so determined the two bears turn tail and run right into and across the river. Charlie came back looking very proud of herself.

This will be a short one.  It has been raining all day.  I got a little done prepping  the fishing gear.  I have a dozen nets and at least that many anchors.  The nets are from fifty feet long to 150 feet long. The webbing is different sizes depending on what you are trying to catch. The webbing is a little to big for sockeye salmon but a couple of them will have to do for Sunday's opening. Two years ago today Nancy passed away. She was the best thing to ever happen in my life. I miss her so much.

The webbing is different sizes depending on what you are trying to catch. The webbing is a little to big for sockeye salmon but a couple of them will have to do for Sunday's opening. Two years ago today Nancy passed away. She was the best thing to ever happen in my life. I miss her so much.

All ready to go fishing tomorrow.  Those two totes behind the four wheeler contain two  20 fathom nets, anchors and buoys.  The white box on the front tote is to put in the boat. If I catch any fish they will go in there instead of sliding around on the bottom of the boat. My neighbors have a cabin on the on the other side of the Alsek river. The plan is for me to stay over there with them for this first opening. As soon as I get back over here to my cabin I will bring you up to date on how things went. Last evening. I was sitting inside the bigger window and saw something brown move right under the window. It took up a lot of space on the ground. First thought was bear. It turned out to be a swarm of otters. I couldn't get a good count cause they were moving so quickly. I know there were five and maybe seven. As I watched they all went under the cabin. I proceeded to make much stomping noise on the floor. I didn't see them leave but they have because I didn't hear or see them at all later. If they had settled in under there I was going borrow Charlie to go under there after them. This morning one of the world's great travelers stopped for a visit. An American Golden Plover was on the front yard. The breeding habitat of American Golden Plover is Arctic tundra from northern Canada and Alaska. They nest on the ground in a dry open area. They are migratory and winter in southern South America. They follow an elliptical migration path; northbound birds pass through Central America about January–April. In fall, they take a more easterly route, flying mostly over the western Atlantic and Caribbean Sea to the wintering grounds in Patagonia. The bird has one of the longest known migratory routes of over 25,000 miles. Of this, 2,400 miles is over open ocean where it cannot stop to feed or drink. It does this from body fat stores that it stocks up on prior to the flight. Most of this paragraph I pulled off the Internet. There is so much nature here. As I took the picture above there were six Bald Eagles having a discussion across the creek behind me. I'm still loving it!

It does this from body fat stores that it stocks up on prior to the flight. Most of this paragraph I pulled off the Internet.

There is so much nature here. As I took the picture above there were six Bald Eagles having a discussion across the creek behind me. I'm still loving it!

All ready to go fishing tomorrow.  Those two totes behind the four wheeler contain two  20 fathom nets, anchors and buoys.  The white box on the front tote is to put in the boat. If I catch any fish they will go in there instead of sliding around on the bottom of the boat. My neighbors have a cabin on the on the other side of the Alsek river. The plan is for me to stay over there with them for this first opening. As soon as I get back over here to my cabin I will bring you up to date on how things went. Last evening. I was sitting inside the bigger window and saw something brown move right under the window. It took up a lot of space on the ground. First thought was bear. It turned out to be a swarm of otters. I couldn't get a good count cause they were moving so quickly. I know there were five and maybe seven. As I watched they all went under the cabin. I proceeded to make much stomping noise on the floor. I didn't see them leave but they have because I didn't hear or see them at all later. If they had settled in under there I was going borrow Charlie to go under there after them. This morning one of the world's great travelers stopped for a visit. An American Golden Plover was on the front yard. The breeding habitat of American Golden Plover is Arctic tundra from northern Canada and Alaska. They nest on the ground in a dry open area. They are migratory and winter in southern South America. They follow an elliptical migration path; northbound birds pass through Central America about January–April. In fall, they take a more easterly route, flying mostly over the western Atlantic and Caribbean Sea to the wintering grounds in Patagonia. The bird has one of the longest known migratory routes of over 25,000 miles. Of this, 2,400 miles is over open ocean where it cannot stop to feed or drink. It does this from body fat stores that it stocks up on prior to the flight. Most of this paragraph I pulled off the Internet. There is so much nature here. As I took the picture above there were six Bald Eagles having a discussion across the creek behind me. I'm still loving it!

That is what a 32 pound King Salmon looks like.

Well opening day for commercial fishing on the Alsek river went pretty well.  The regulations permit one to start fishing at 12:01 p.m. on Sunday and you had to stop fishing with nets out of the water by 12:00 today.  That's the way it is every week while that river is open to fishing.  Each morning after an opening there is an announcement made at 9:00 informing fishermen if fishing will be allowed that day.  Sometimes you can fish for several days in a row.  That is seldom the case for the first week's opening.

"The Alsek River is a wilderness river flowing from Yukon into Northern British Columbia and into Alaska. The surrounding area from the Western edge of the Alsek to East of the East Alsek is known to locals as Dry Bay.  The Alsek and East Alsek rivers are a part of the Yakutat area limited entry set gillnet fishery. Both rivers produce King, Silver, and Sockeye commercially. Chum and Pink salmon can also be caught, but are not generally sought after due to their relative lack of worth/quality. These two rivers can be characterized as low volume fisheries, while the Alsek river in particular produces particularly high quality salmon due to its low temperature. The Alsek's silt content also prevents the sun from damaging the fish."  I did a little more research on the Alsek.  This afternoon its flow volume was 45,800 cubic feet of water per second.  For comparison at the same time the flow of the Colorado river at Durango was 1,300 CFS.  The Alsek is a BIG river.  Where we were fishing was in some sheltered water right at the mouth.  I could hear the surf in the Pacific as I sat in the boar waiting for a fish to hit the net.

Yesterday we dropped the nets in the water shortly after noon.  We stayed on the river till after eight last night.  This morning we left before 5:00 to resume fishing.  I was able to catch 4 sockeye yesterday and today brought in that fish I'm holding above as well as another King and a couple more sockeye.  My neighbors have a company that sells these fish directly to restaurants as far away as Newark, NJ.  That fish I caught this morning may well be in Newark Wednesday night.  I sell them the fish at the going rate right off my boat.  Then they clean them and pack them in Ice.  An air service will pick the packed fish up and take them to Yakutat.  There they are loaded onto one of the two jets that come through everyday, end up in Seattle where they are air freighted on to the restaurant.  Next Sunday we do it all again.  I expect in the next week of so there will be more days of fishing after each opening.

A cousin asked what happens to the parts of the fish that we don't keep?  Where my buyer cleans the fish is about a mile from the Pacific.  Today I took all the heads, guts etc. over to the beach and spread them out at the edge of the surf.  In less than 30 seconds after I pulled away ravens were there grabbing morsels.  In less than 90 seconds the first 4 Bald Eagles showed up.  After 5 minutes there must have been a dozen eagles swooping in to grab something.  Many of them would land but some of them would just glide in real low, grab something and fly off with it.  Another fisherman told me the eagles soon learn to associate the 4 wheeler on the beach at that spot with food.  When they learn that you can look up and down the coast and see eagles coming in from as far as you can see.

That is what a 32 pound King Salmon looks like.

Slow, cool, sometimes windy, rainy day here. I spent most of the morning catching up on paperwork and the computer.  I did some negotiating on a new four wheeler.  There are already three here at the cabin but two of them don't run and the Alders are about to grow up around them.

One of the neighbors was fishing the other day.  He hooked a good size salmon right at the mouth of the East Alsek river.  The fish headed back out to sea.  As the fish swam through the incoming waves along the beach, the fisherman could look into the vertical  surface of the wave, just before it broke, and see the fish he was fighting at his eye level. He said it was beautiful with the light coming through the wave, the silhouette of the fish suspended in the light green  water.   So I had to go try that this afternoon.

The King Salmon I caught the other day was big but some of them can be almost twice that big.  When you hook one of those big fish you had better have plenty of line on your reel cause the fish may run out 50 or more yards of line before you can turn it back toward you. The rod I took out with me came with the cabin.   As I cast it the first few times I noticed it wouldn't let the lure go out very far.  There probably wasn't 50 feet of line on the reel.  I did catch a nice Dolly Varden trout but the wind came up again, the water had white caps so I came back in and put a new line on the reel.

I left the boat in the river on the other side of Dry Bay.  Pulling it over there last week I had some trouble with one of the wheels.  Tomorrow I plan to go over there and bring the bad wheel back here to see what I need to do to repair it.  Later this week the weather is supposed to be nice.  If I get some of these odd jobs done maybe I'll be able to do some serious beachcombing.  Life is so tough here.  So many fun things to do.  The sun rises tomorrow at 4:07 and sets at 10:25.  It never does get really dark. Or, I should say, if it does get really dark its not for long and I sleep through it.

That image came from Google Earth.  On my computer if I click on the picture it enlarges.  That is Dog Salmon creek coming down from the top of the picture and merging with the East Alsek river.  The neighbors I refer to so often live in the cabin just above mine.  That is an unused air strip behind their cabin.  Now the planes just land in front of the cabins. Two kinds of geese were feeding in the front yard off and on during this day filled with showers.  Brant Geese and Greater White-fronted geese. The latter have beautiful coloration in their feathers. The rain kept me inside most of the day again.  I got the cook stove tuned up and tried the oven for the first time.  I know one reader who will be pleased to read I baked a loaf of bread.  I brought 25 pounds of flour up here.  Now that I have tasted success using some of it maybe buying that much was a good idea. The neighbor, whose cabin is just off the left side of the picture, has had a bear hanging around his place.  Tonight coming back from fishing (no luck) the bear was on the river bank in front of that same cabin.  I was maybe a hundred feet from the bear before I saw it.  One way to haze the bears and discourage them from hanging around too close is to make a lot of noise.  So not wanting to retreat and encourage the bear I down shifted and ran right at him.  He stood up to see what was causing all that noise, saw me coming at him, hollering and gunning the engine. I don't know what he thought but he went up the bank and disappeared into the brush.

Hauled wood today.  My neighbors to the North have the portable saw mill I mentioned earlier.  Their daughter and her husband are building a cabin nearby.  I will help them with the construction.  These people are so generous. The lumber in the picture, 20- 2x4s and 30 - 1x6 boards all sixteen feet long, sawn from logs salvaged along the river. Today we hauled six times that much lumber across Dry Bay to our cabin sites here on the East River.  Those boards are heavy duty.  When I say 1x6 that is the true dimension. A 1x6 you buy at a lumberyard is actually .75 inches by 5.5 inches. It's about six miles across Dry Bay to where we unloaded the boats. The boats are used to ferry the lumber from the other side of the Alsek river. that is where the better logs are. We use the same trailers shown in an earlier post without the fish totes on them. There is a maze of roads across Dry Bay. I made three trips across and used three different routes. You could call those trips a learning experience. Several times I found myself someplace other than where I thought I should be. On one return trip I thought I would keep to higher, drier ground. Well what goes up must come down. The slight drop in elevation concentrated the water in one spot. When I got 1.7 miles (I had the GPS) from the cabin I got stuck. I started to walk out for help but decided maybe the 4 wheeler would pull itself out if I unhooked the trailers. That worked. So two of us went back, roped the two wheelers together and got the load out of the soft spot. On the last trip over the bear that has been hanging around happened to be out in the open. I got to chase him for a few hundred yards. I wish the wheeler had a speedometer. I bet he was running 20 Mph while looking back to see if I was still after him. Consensus is that it is an adolescent bear and just hasn't figured out that the people who live in those big boxes we call cabins don't like bears in the yard. On the way back the bear was there again. Charlie and another bear dog spotted the bruin. Off they went one on each side of the bear. They harassed the beast till he went into the brush. Then the dogs trotted back to us looking so proud.
