I didn’t post anything yesterday. I stayed up at the mouth of the East River fishing later than usual and was just too tired. The surf was really pounding. It reminded me of the sounds a freight train makes when it has been stopped and then starts up again. As the couplings between the cars engage each other you can hear each car pick up the load of the following car. That clunk you hear that travels down the line of cars noise. Last night the waves coming ashore were sounding like that. Yesterday a guest at the neighbor’s house found a couple of glass fishing floats. One of them was 12 inches in diameter. Most of them are about 4 inches across. With all the wave action last night I thought there might be some good beachcombing this morning. There wasn’t a cloud in the sky early so by six thirty I was out the door. The power of all this water never ceases to amaze me. Today there were chunks of ice on the beach that had washed out into the ocean from the river, then back onto the beach some distance from the river’s mouth. One chunk was about half the size of my 4 wheeler. I did find three glass floats. Icouple of years ago I asked how you can tell if there are King Salmon in the river? I was told to look into the water and look for small logs. Those might be Kings. Today at the mouth of the East Alsek River there were logs in the river…. The fish I brought home was 42 inches long. I don’t know how long it took to land that fish. I had hooked a couple of others earlier and managed to land one of them. This fish felt different. To keep it from taking all the line off my reel I had to follow it down the river. I ended up a couple of hundred yards downstream from where I started. When I got back home the eagle was sitting in the tree in front of the house. I hope it keeps perching there. I like having my own Guard Eagle. The next commercial fishing opens tomorrow, Sunday. I will be going over to the other side of the Alsek River tonight. Hopefully there will be lots more fish to write about in a day or so.

post_content: Where to begin? Should I write about the bear stealing a salmon out of a cooler in the front yard? What about the bear coming back two times that night looking for more and eating part of the 4 wheeler seat. What about being positionally challenged on the Alsek river at 11:00 at night or the cross country walk that got me to the cabin after midnight, then getting up at 4:30 to go check the nets again. Maybe it should be about pulling 17 sockeye keepers out of my net in one pass. I could finish up by describing how I am determined to learn more about all the things my GPS can do for me. This was the second day the set gillnet fishing season has been open for the Alsek River this year. I fish two nets. I try and position them to catch the sockeye salmon heading upstream to spawn. There are also king Salmon on the river now and we catch a few of them along with the sockeye. The picture is the view I have while watching the net. That big mountain is Mount Fairweather. Canada is on the left side of the mountain's peak. Mount Fairweather is over 15,000 feet tall. The process of getting the fish from the river to your local fish market is not a long one but because the product is so fragile pretty complicated. I sell the fish to Alsek Fish. They are a small speciality supplier to markets and fine resturants across the lower 48 states. I deliver the fish hole and am paid by the pound. Different fish bring different prices. Alsek Fish cleans the fish, packs them in ice and air freights the fish to its final destination. Simple right? Noooooo. To get the fish from the river to the air freight office requires a chartered bush plane to fly them there after landing on the beach. The fish are packed in ice. That requires an ice making machine that depends on a generator for power. The bush plane has a charter fee. The fish are packed in special waxed cardboard boxes. Specific labels are required on each box of fish shipped. Alaska fish and game requires certain paperwork indicating where the fish were caught and by whom. In all this process I feel very lucky to be in on the fun part. Just catching the fish. I may fill in a few details on some of the other things I mentioned in the first paragraph some other time.

Where to begin? Should I write about the bear stealing a salmon out of a cooler in the front yard? What about the bear coming back two times that night looking for more and eating part of the 4 wheeler seat. What about being positionally challenged on the Alsek river at 11:00 at night or the cross country walk that got me to the cabin after midnight, then getting up at 4:30 to go check the nets again. Maybe it should be about pulling 17 sockeye keepers out of my net in one pass. I could finish up by describing how I am determined to learn more about all the things my GPS can do for me. This was the second day the set gillnet fishing season has been open for the Alsek River this year. I fish two nets. I try and position them to catch the sockeye salmon heading upstream to spawn. There are also king Salmon on the river now and we catch a few of them along with the sockeye. The picture is the view I have while watching the net. That big mountain is Mount Fairweather. Canada is on the left side of the mountain's peak. Mount Fairweather is over 15,000 feet tall. The process of getting the fish from the river to your local fish market is not a long one but because the product is so fragile pretty complicated. I sell the fish to Alsek Fish. They are a small speciality supplier to markets and fine resturants across the lower 48 states. I deliver the fish hole and am paid by the pound. Different fish bring different prices. Alsek Fish cleans the fish, packs them in ice and air freights the fish to its final destination. Simple right? Noooooo. To get the fish from the river to the air freight office requires a chartered bush plane to fly them there after landing on the beach. The fish are packed in ice. That requires an ice making machine that depends on a generator for power. The bush plane has a charter fee. The fish are packed in special waxed cardboard boxes. Specific labels are required on each box of fish shipped. Alaska fish and game requires certain paperwork indicating where the fish were caught and by whom. In all this process I feel very lucky to be in on the fun part. Just catching the fish. I may fill in a few details on some of the other things I mentioned in the first paragraph some other time.

Finally on the air with my VHF marine radio. One of the things on the back burner of my to do list was to get the VHF radio working. Today it happened. All I needed to do was go up on the roof and remount the antenna. My first transmission was "can anybody hear me"? Nothing came back. So then I tried "this is a radio check can anyone hear me?" A male voice came over the speaker and someone said " I can hear you John". Then the female voice of my neighbor's daughter said she could hear me from over at Muddy Creek. Muddy Creek is about six miles away so that is pretty good.

Much of the rest of the day was spent trying to coordinate the delivery of the new Honda ATV and generator. The new inverter I ordered from Amazon came today. Now I don't have to run the generator to use the Internet. The generator I have now uses twice as much fuel as the new one will and with the fuel supply running low I haven't been on line much.

The two local park rangers stopped by this afternoon. They gave me some advice on how to deal with the bears and what would constitute a good reason to shoot one. "If a bear is trying to enter the building you are occupying, we have no problem with you shooting that problem bear". I think the law says you have the right to defend your life and property. I bet there would be a lot of paperwork to do if all the bear was doing was eating the seat off your four wheeler.

Today I saw my first dandelions. That may give you an idea how much later spring is here than "down below" as the locals call the lower 48 states. I must have missed seeing them a few times because they were already very tall. The lupines are popping up all over and it looks like a bumper year for wild strawberries, The morel(?sp) mushrooms are up now.

A pretty productive day. A week or so ago I put a loft in the back part of the garage. Today I got it all boxed in and built a ladder to access the space from inside the cabin. Now when I have visitors they will have their own space.

My neighbor's daughter has a permit to build a cabin near by. Tomorrow I'm going to help her and her husband finish laying out the foundation logs. Then we will install the floor joists and the decking for the first floor. If all goes well by this time next week we will have walls up and maybe even the roof on.

I was going to go out on the beach and look for glass floats this morning but things got too busy.

Maybe tomorrow there will be more to report on.

That is what we got done today. It is the floor of the cabin i'm helping build. In the background you can see m ore of the wood that was sawn with the portable sawmill. The deck is sitting on two creosote logs that had washed on the beach. Each of these logs are about 25 feet long.

The number of ducks and geese migrating North have really slowed down. There have been some new birds showing up that forage in the grass. The barn swallows arrived last week. The hummingbirds are still scarce but I have been assured they will return in a big way when the hatchlings fledge. Some good news in that the new four wheeler I ordered is in Yakutat. I have chartered a plane to bring it down here to the cabin. I'm also getting six barrels of fuel some groceries and stuff from the hardware store. I better start catching more fish to pay for all this. I did take my rod down to the mouth of East River to night. I saw one King Salmon roll on the surface a couple of times but he must not have been hungry. I did catch 15 Sculpin. These little aggressive fish could hardly get the lure in their mouths but tonight they loved trying to eat what I was casting. Three of the little buggers stuck their fins in me as I was releasing them. Tomorrow I hope to scout out a couple more places to put my nets when the next commercial season opens.

This weather today was perfect. Low 70s, mild ocean breeze, not a cloud in the sky. I got going early. Looked for glass floats on the beach by the Alsek River. Went back across Dry Bay to meet another fisherman to check out a few new spots for the next opener. He wasn't home so I checked on my boat and brought the gas tank home to refill. I must have the leaks fixed in the boat because there was very little water to bail out after sitting at anchor for four days. The garage has two big "barn" doors that open wide enough to be able to bring the four wheelers in to work on them or to store them over the winter. A pair of Barn Swallows has decided they would like to nest in there. They are very persistent about this. I had to chase them out with a broom several times today. There is an unused runway behind my cabin. There are a couple of other cabins alongside the runway. Tonight there was a community hot dog roast beside the runway. Almost everyone on this side of Dry Bay was there...all ten of us. One of the men used my chainsaw to clear some of the brush along the side of the strip. He said there was one thing wrong with my new saw. It seems when doing something like clearing brush you work till you run out of gas. The problem with my new saw is the gas tank is too big. We had a lot of brush to burn. Hot dogs, all the fixings, potato salad, graham crackers and marshmallows for s'mores. The only problem was the bugs. They have arrived. If you get out of the breeze and disturb them in the vegetation be prepared to be irritated. Insect repellent doesn't seem to deter these bugs. It is almost eleven p.m. The sun has just gone down but it is very light out still. The sky is cloudless except for the contrails of jets going from Anchorage to Seattle. Those are the only jets that fly over here as far as I can tell. I bet all those people on those planes are sorry to be leaving.

Another beautiful day. I spent the morning with one of the old timer Dry Bay fishermen. He showed me some places to set my nets on this side of the Alsek. Then we took his boat way up the river. In some places we could see very troubled water. Big swirls and whorl pools. The current was very fast. He had a depth finder on his boat. The water was 40 to 70 feet deep along there. A couple of weeks ago I reported here that the Colorado River was flowing at 1,300 cubic feet per second. The Colorado is a big river in that part of the country. A while back the Alsek was flowing at over 150,000 CFM according to my friend. It is a very big river. On the boat tour this morning he told me about the wolf that would walk along the bank where ha fished nearly every day one season. Today he pointed out a couple of Bald Eagle nests in trees right at the edge of the river. When I got home this friendly bird was here to greet me. It looks like a dove but it has a squared off tail and a black band around its neck. The pictures I have of mourning doves don't have the black band and their tails are pointed. I appreciated this beautiful birds presence. Moving across the beaches you frequently cause the birds, eagles, ravens, gulls and other shore birds to take flight. The four wheeler doesn't have a speedometer so I don't know how fast I'm going but I figure at least thirty MPH. I think it surprises the birds when you pull up along side them as they think they are moving away from you. I call it "Racing Ravens". A big day tomorrow. A neighbor from Colorado is coming to help me for a few days. The chore list is getting longer every day even though I'm pretty busy trying to mark things off it. The plane I chartered will bring in the new four wheeler some plywood and lots of fuel as well as my neighbor. It will land right in front of the cabin. Late this afternoon I went King salmon fishing again. There were several in the river. One of them looked huge. A couple of them would follow my lure for a while then turn away. I did hook one sockeye but it got off. I'll just have to keep trying.

A big delivery today.  My neighbor from Boulder arrived along with a new four wheeler.  A couple of Dry Bay neighbors showed up and helped unload the newest toy.  It is convenient to have your air freight stop in front of your house. I have a lot to learn about this application.  As you can see below I learned how to make the pictures bigger after I uploaded the small one.  Now if I could learn how to put the text where I want it to be. After we got most of the big stuff put away we went across to the river and set a couple of nets.  Fishing was slow.  We only caught one sockeye.  The nets will be out all night.  Maybe we will have some fish in them come morning. I'll let you know.

Still another spectacular day at Dry Bay Alaska.  The temperature got up to 76 and the humidity was 37 percent.  Just enough breeze came up this afternoon to keep the bugs down.

We got a late start fishing yesterday.  This morning we left the cabin around 6 to check the nets.  It is a 20 minute four wheeler ride from the cabin to where I anchor the boat.  One net only had a couple of fish in it.  The other had a few more and one 20 pound King Salmon.  I made enough today to pay for the gas I used.

One of the fish in the net had been chewed on a little by a seal.  We brought it home and had it for dinner tonight.  It was delicious.

We tried some sport fishing later but all we caught were little sculpin.

Tomorrow will probably be spent working on the walls of the new cabin going up next door.  If this weather holds the owners will probably be sleeping in their new cabin by the weekend.

Information has come in on that bird I described a couple of days ago.  It is an Eurasian Collared Dove.  It is believed They were accidentally introduced to the US.  Their range is expanding very rapidly.  The National Geographic web site describes their range to be within the contenental United States.  Here they are in Southeast Alaska.

My neighbor from Boulder and I spent most of the day helping build the new cabin next door. We quit a little after six tonight. On the way back to our cabin he told me it had been a while since he had had a 9 Advil day....We worked really hard. We got one wall framed and up in place. The second wall is framed and lying on the floor, ready to raise tomorrow morning. With any luck we will get the other two walls up tomorrow. We were invited to dinner at the parents of the new cabin owners place tonight. Fresh King Salmon poached in foil with the perfect spices. Green beans and rice. The correct libations were available too. Another neighbor and his mother joined us. Mrs. M is 91 years old. She spends most of her summer up here. She will ride from place to place on the back of a four wheeler. Crossing the Alsek river in an open boat to hop on another four wheeler seems to suit her just fine. After dinner we enjoyed listening to tale after tale about life up here. My guest is interested in studying otters. Since there are no more otters under my cabin he was told of another unused cabin near by where a group of otters reside. I wouldn't be surprised if those otters have a visitor from Boulder soon. We didn't see it but as a plane landed in front of the cabin a bear ran off the runway into the brush across the creek. After all the noise we made pounding nails all day I wonder if the bear had come out of the bushes to see what was going on?

The weather has not been typical here. It has been many days since it rained. There is always a heavy dew in the mornings and all the plants are very lush right now . Some of the wildflowers are beginning to fade but others are just beginning to come out. The white lupines are not uncommon but compared to the blue ones they are a very small percentage of the total. In other words the blue lupines are everywhere. Acres and acres of them. The little shooting stars are past their prime but there are some places where their dark pink hue carpets the ground. Wild strawberries are blooming in every spot they can get a glimpse of the sky. The yellow Indian paintbrush have just come out and the side yard will be covered with daisies next week. There were at least 4 happy people at Dry Bay today. The young couple whose cabin I have been helping to build got to stand on their new second floor this afternoon. For me it was a special moment to see them up there experiencing the view for the first time from what will be their bedroom. I know it was a special moment for them too. They stood there, arms around each other feeling one of their dreams come true. Another happy person was my neighbor who is visiting. He caught his first Salmon with a rod and reel this evening. I don't know exactly what he was doing that I wasn't but he hooked twelve fish in his opinion, landed the one. I hooked the same log on the bottom of the river twice and that was it for me. I am supposed to guide some other fishermen later this summer. I guess if they catch all the fish they might think I'm a pretty good guide. If they expect me to show them how to catch the fish I may not last long as a guide The other pleased person here today was me. We got most of the remaining accumulated junk into a big pile and burnt it up. It is almost eleven as I type this and the stuff is still smoldering. By clearing out around the cabin I found a kayak buried under some of the unwanted stuff. It looks like it will float but I'm going to wait for the water to warm up some more before I try it out. a< href="http://www.notesfromalaska.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/image12.jpg">

Last evening I was too tired to post anything here. The commercial fishing opened up again at noon Sunday. The Alsek river is running very high due to the extremely long spell of dry, sunny weather. The snow in the mountains is melting faster than normal. That water accelerates the glacier's melting so many icebergs are coming down the river. Add to all that the super moon caused the highest tide swing (15 feet from high tide to the next low tide) since I have been here. All that water caused havoc with the fishing. The spots that usually hold fish don't. Trees floating down the river tear out the nets. A lot of limbs and twigs get caught in the nets causing the fish to avoid getting caught. I caught a dozen sockeye. Two of them were damaged in the net by seals. The buyer couldn't use them so I brought them home to eat. The last three nights my neighbor Rick or I have cleaned a salmon down at the creek in front of the cabin. A bald eagle sits down there waiting for us to toss a scrap into the water or up on the bank of the stream. As soon as we do the eagles pumps its wings a couple of times and glides over and snatches the morsel. It must have a nest near buy. It flies off in the same direction every time. In about one minute it returns looking for more. If there is another scrap nearby the bird has already seen it and is gliding straight toward it...ignoring me. The eagle swooshes right over my head, not ten feet off the ground. Even with my poor hearing I can hear the air passing over its wings as it goes by. By now other eagles have seen the commotion and have begun to gather. Also by now the scraps provided buy one salmon are nearly gone. It is a sight to see, these magnificent wild birds so close. Sometimes I think I'm pretty smart about figuring things out. Like the wire that serves as my clothesline. It was too short to reach the tree and even if it did it would sag. So I used one of those ratchet straps we use to tie things down on the trailer. It served as an extension to the wire so I could reach the tree and gave me a way to pull the wire tight. On the other hand I wrote recently about how much water I have to pump by hand to fill the washing machine. I think I wrote it took over 1,400 strokes at the hand pump to supply enough water to do three loads. Why am I pumping water with a hand pump when there is a creek running outside the door with pure, clear, clean, soft water running in it. I could take a trailer and tote down there, fill it with water, and bring it back to the cabin in less time than it has taken to type this paragraph. I think I won't mind doing laundry as much next time.

Last evening I was too tired to post anything here. The commercial fishing opened up again at noon Sunday. The Alsek river is running very high due to the extremely long spell of dry, sunny weather. The snow in the mountains is melting faster than normal. That water accelerates the glacier's melting so many icebergs are coming down the river. Add to all that the super moon caused the highest tide swing (15 feet from high tide to the next low tide) since I have been here. All that water caused havoc with the fishing. The spots that usually hold fish don't. Trees floating down the river tear out the nets. A lot of limbs and twigs get caught in the nets causing the fish to avoid getting caught. I caught a dozen sockeye. Two of them were damaged in the net by seals. The buyer couldn't use them so I brought them home to eat. I often start these posts saying something like "another great day here in Dry Bay, Alaska". Well it was another great day here in Dry Bay, Alaska. The tides have been very high the last few days. The highest tides can wash out of the sand dunes these antique floats that have been buried for many decades. Rick has been diligent in looking for those glass fishing floats. After a higher than normal tide he will go out and beachcomb looking for a float to bring back to Colorado. Yesterday he was about thirty minutes behind a neighbor who was also looking. The neighbor found one. If Rick had been a little earlier he would have found it sitting out there on the sand. Today Rick got up very early and was the first one down the beach. His quest for a glass ball to bring back to Colorado is now over. In fact he found two. He is a happy beachcomber. Last Sunday while we were fishing we stopped at an island where seagulls nest. There were many beautiful Glaucious-winged gulls nesting there. (Sorry my camera strap got into the picture.) The locals can collect the gull eggs to eat. I have had some and they are delicious. They are quite a bit larger than extra large chicken eggs. Rick's day continued to be successful. He smoked his first batch of salmon. His recipe included sprinkling some brown sugar on the filets before s oping them over an Alder fire. They turned out great. Late this evening he was going down to the creek on the four wheeler to clean the metal grills he had used to smoke the fish on. He stopped at the edge of the yard and walked back to the cabin. I asked him what was wrong. He just gestured for me to look over his shoulder. This guy has been hanging around lately. He has been minding his own business, not causing any trouble. After we took some pictures Rick started the wheeler up. When the bear heard it he immediately broke into a run for the bushes. That is what a good bear is supposed to do.

No pictures today.  I got a Father's Day gift on the mail plane yesterday.  I now have a shinny new circular saw.  Well it was shinny and new this morning.  Now it is an experienced saw.  It cut boards all day.  A lot of progress was made on the new cabin next door.  The saw and I tried to keep up to five others busy nailing down the boards that we had cut to length. 

Tomorrow if the weather is good we will get the roof rafters all up and maybe even start on the roofing.  

Early this morning and again late (10:30 p.m.) I went down the beach looking for glass floats.  Both trips were fruitless for finding floats but the ever changing sea shore continues to be a wonder to me.  The East Alsek river flows parallel to the ocean for a couple of miles before it makes a right angle turn into the sea. I haven't been here two months but in that time the little East Alsek river has eroded the ten foot tall bank where it turn to the sea by about eight feet.  An old green bucket had washed up on the top of the bank in some past storm.  That bucket has been my reference for noticing how much the bank has washed away.

Meanwhile the mighty Alsek river continues to make major changes to the area around its mouth.  I will post a picture soon.  There is a sand dune there that is probably 20 feet high from the water's edge.  Some days there is a beach thirty feet wide at the base of this sand dune.  Tonight there was no beach.  The current and tide had washed the beach away and a vertical wall of sand dropped directly into the river. 

Mentioned several times recently were the high tides and above average river flow because of the warm weather melting the mountain snow.  Tonight the beach was littered with many trees and grasses pulled off the banks of the river farther up stream.  A lot of glacier ice was also on the beach.  I brought some home to put in the cooler.  Got to keep those three apples in there cool.

Rick has one of those new little GoPro cameras that takes great movies.  Tonight he took some fish scraps down to the edge of the creek to see if he could capture an eagle swooping down to grab a bite.  It wasn't  long before he had his video.  If a morsel of fish had feelings it wouldn't know what hit it.  Those birds come in so fast and are so accurate in grabbing something off the surface it is amazing.  Rick has a video to prove it.

Woke up to a steady rain this morning.  I didn't think there would be any work going on outside at the new cabin so Rick and I tackled remodeling my kitchen.  We replaced the counter top with new plywood.  Added a cabinet to the right side of the cook stove and built up a wall behind the stove so you don't have to look at the back of the thing.

I did venture out about 8:30 to see if there were any fish down at the mouth of the East Alsek river.  No fish were there to be seen or caught.  I noticed a large number of gulls concentrated about a tenth of a mile off shore.  There were also probably 200 seals out there floating in a group.  I understand they sometimes do that by hooking their flippers together forming sort of a seal chain.  One seal connected to another just resting or hanging out.

On the way home I noticed quite a bit of work had been done on the new cabin today afterall.  Almost all the rafters are up.  Tomorrow I'll help them finish the rafters and maybe get the plywood up on the roof too.

Back to reporting another beautiful day in Dry Bay, Alaska. I left the cabin before 5:30 this morning to try and beat the other beachcombers to all the glass fishing floats I hoped to find. I should have stayed in bed. We wrapped up the kitchen reconstruction this morning. This afternoon we helped on the new cabin some more. Rick helped sheath the exterior walls and I framed in two large windows in what will be their living room. As I was making the cuts for the window opening Katilyn called her dog over and showed the dog that she would be able to see out. This is Katilyn, Brant and their dog Kirya. This is the couple I wrote about a few days ago and how much pleasure it brings me to see their joy in having their own place take shape. These young people have pulled logs out of the woods and off the beach to a sawmill. They ran the mill to cut every stick of lumber in that cabin. Kirya has already found a spot to rest on the living room floor to keep watch on everything. We are always welcome at the neighbors for meals but after working hard on the cabin an invitation to have pizza couldn't be passed up. Tonight Lisa fed 15 people pizza. At one point she had four cooking in her oven at one time. One of the fishermen has his 91 year old mother up here for a few weeks. She likes to do those word puzzles where a matrix of random letters have hidden words. She does the big ones where there may be 40 words to find. I helped her fond one word while she had found several on her own. Her name is Gwen and she is a wizard at the "find the words" puzzles. If you ever watch those nature shows where a feeding frenzy takes place with dolphins, or a pride of lions or vultures on a kill. It is sort of like that on Pizza night at Lisa's When Rick and I arrived there were already eight people there and ten (10) four wheelers in various states of repair in the yard. As the feeding got underway, people kept dropping in. Lisa is such a good neighbor when she realized one neighbor had not gotten the word about pizza night she took some over to him. Pizza night at Lisa's means country music on the satellite radio. With that many people carrying on several different conversations, my hearing aids tend to overheat.

If you have been following these rumblings you know I have been experiencing abnormally fine weather here. It was yet another beautiful day in Dry Bay, Alaska. Today we decided to cross the East River in the four wheelers and beachcomb that isolated 12 mile stretch of beach down to an obstruction called " the rocks" because they prevent you from taking the wheelers any farther. I asked the retired Vet I'd he would like to join us so the three of us on four wheelers started off. We had no trouble crossing the river. Last time we drowned my older Honda wheeler. This time no problem. About half way to the rocks you have to cross seal creek. The gulls and eagles were feeding on something right at the mouth of the creek. There were so many of these little fish concentrated in one place in the surf it was a dark color. Just beyond the rocks there is a roaring stream that is the outlet of a glacier fed lake. The color of the water is gray from the glacial silt. It is only about a mile from where we were to the lake so we went to see it. The easiest route to the lake is to walk on the bear trail that parallels the stream and beach. The beauty of the rain forest cannot be shown in a photograph but thanks to Rick, who's camera had not yet run out of battery, you can get a peek at it. The glacier lake was FULL of icebergs. This glacier is retreating and you could see where in the past it had scoured the mountain sides along its edges down to bedrock We didn't find any collectible treasures on the way down the beach but on the way back things became more interesting. At seal creek where all the little fish were spawning earlier there was a bear. When I came up on this guy he was walking along the edge of the surf. When he got to the place where the fish had been he just laid down in the water. Sometimes the waves washing over him would actually pick the bear up mad move him a little ways. Rick and I watched the bear lounge in the surf for a while. When the bear got up and started walking toward us I decided to take the initiative and started toward him on the wheeler. These bears don't have very good eyesight and the sound of the surf kept it from hearing us. So the only thing to do was get his attention. I don't like harassing the bears but better me harassing them than them harnessing me. I chased it across seal creek until it disappeared into the sea oats on the other side of the creek. On the way home I baptized the new Honda four wheeler. There is a step bank along the side of the East River. I had been past there three times already today but on my fourth pass I lost inertia and went head first into the river. My first thought was how warm the water was. Second thought was turn off the engine before it sucked water into it. My second thought was too slow. Rick, using the older Honda we baptized a couple of weeks ago, towed me back across the East River to the cabin. Before we could use the older machine to pull me we had to float the newly drowned Honda seventy five yards upstream in the river to a spot where the bank was not so steep and he could get me out. I reworked the new machine just like we did tho older one, changed the oil, checked the differentials for water, dried the air cleaner filter, etc. Now the new Honda can rest assured when it comes to the end of its life it will be saved and go to Honda four wheeler heaven.

The year 2013 is half over. As you will see below today was once again a beautiful day in Dry Bay, Alaska. Yesterday Rick and I made arrangements to go fishing with the retired veterinarian who has a cabin just down stream from mine. This gentleman (gentle man) has so many interests not the least of which is catching those hard to catch sockeye salmon. So at eight o'clock sharp this morning Rick, the Vet, his dog Bennie and I went fishing. Rick had already caught a few sockeye with his rod. I had not caught one yet. The Vet wrote the book on how to do it. Bennie's job was to keep an eye out for bears. That is the view I had all day fishing. Mount Fairweather dominates. Canada is on the left side of that mountain. If you zoom in there are three bears right at the edge of the water near the center of the picture. That sow and her two cubs have not been causing any problems. When we first arrived to fish this morning the two cubs were chasing each other up and down the edge of the water. So pristine. Some of the fish were pretty far along in their preparation to spawn. The fish right out of the ocean are very silvery. As they change into spawning mode the sockeye's bodies turn read and their heads green. We didn't keep those fish that were not still silvery. As I mentioned we left at eight. We got home a little after five. Everybody caught fish. It was a good day. Bennie did his job and alerted us when a forth bear showed up across the river from where we were fishing. The East Alsek River is a clear water stream. We could see literally dozens of big salmon in the water a rods length away. The Vet and I are the old timers on this side of Dry Bay. He and Bennie are practically inseparable. After standing in the river for a couple of hours waiting on his master, this is what Bennie likes to do. That is my official SNOOPY tackle box in the foreground. I like to look like I know what I'm doing out there. I think the orange color really sets me off as a wilderness fishing guide. Now the ice box is full of fish. Rick leaves on Wednesday. Between now and then he wants to smoke a bunch of these fish.

He and Bennie are practically inseparable. After standing in the river for a couple of hours waiting on his master, this is what Bennie likes to do. Tat is my official SNOOPY tackle box in the foreground. I like to look like I know what I'm doing out there. I think the orange color really sets me off as a fishing guide. Now the ice box is full of fish. Rick leaves on Wednesday. Between now and then he wants to smoke a bunch of these fish.

Today's post starts last night.  We had had a great day fishing and were winding down after cleaning the fish and putting them cooler.  

My cooler is really a freezer.  It works great but there are more things I just want to keep cool than there are things I want to freeze.  It is an old beast and uses a lot of electricity.  So I ride down to the handy beach and pick up some glacier ice that has washed in, bring it home put it in a pan in the unplugged freezer.  It makes a great cooler.

Anyhow, about ten last night Rick spots a bear sniffing around down by the creek where we had cleaned the fish.  It didn't stay too long and soon moved on up the river.  Not ten minuteslater a cow moose and her twin calves came out of the brush.  You could tell the cow knew there had been a bear around from her posture, scenting the air, looking in the direction the bear had gone. Her calves were very young.  They stayed very close to mom as she walked out into the river and stopped on a sand bar.  These sand bars appear as the tide goes out and the water drops.  As she stood there the calves nursed, one on each side.  I went to bed about ten thirty.

I got up this morning a little after six and the moose were still out there on the sand bar.  The mother moose was down and the calves were standing beside her.  I thought this is going to be interesting if the cow was stuck in the sand in the middle of the river.  The tide was coming in.  There is a hungry grizley who's favorite treat this time of year is moose calf.  The calves would nudge the cow but she just stayed down in the incoming water looking around.  This was all around 6:15 this morning.  I put the coffee on thinking what I should do...let nature take its course?  I'm part of nature.  I thought about riding down there on the Honda and that might alarm the cow enough that she could free herself.

At 6:30 I looked out and they were gone.  In talking to the locals these cows frequently drop their calves in the large open spaces that occure here at Dry Bay.  They have learned that they can see predators much better in these open areas than they could in the brush.  That cow with her new born twins took them to spend the night where she thought they would be safe.  On a sand bar in the middle of a river.  That's my slant on it anyway.

I had borrowed a piece of string from the my neighbor the Vet to use as a fish stringer yesterday.  I go by his cabin on the way to look for glass floats on the beach.  I found another glass float, delivered the piece of string and bartered five gallons of gas for use of the Vet's vacum packing food saver machine and some plastic bags.  Now I have some vacum packed sockeye in his freezer (his is new and doesn't use much electricity). 

Rick stayed close to the fish smoker all day.  The setup I have needs a little modifying so when you are smoking the fish you don't have to tend to the fire/smoke as frequently (every 30 minutes or so).  However, maybe I should leave well enough alone.  His smoked Salmon are delicious.

The extraordinary weather we have been having left last night. Woke up to a steady rain this morning. It continued to sprinkle and rain most of the day. One of the neighbors said I should go over and check on my boat. I hadn't been over to where it is anchored for nearly a week. Wen I got there it was pretty low in the water. I probably bailed out more than 50 gallons. She's riding high again. While I was tending to her I thought I'd start the outboard motor just to warm it up. That engine is very hard to start when it is cold. I'm about to spring for a new outboard, one with a battery to start it. The yard around the cabin is in full bloom right now. Tonight I asked v Rick if he would walk around outside and identify the various flowers that are blooming right now. The second picture is one of two clumps of wild iris blooming in the yard now. The first picture has most of the following blooming in it: Article Lupine, Yellow Indian Paintbrush, Western Columbine, Shooting Star, Chocolate Lily, Western Yarrow in a couple of colors, Daisy, Wild Strawberries, Cow Parsnip, Beach Peas, Wild Chives, Cinquisoil, Wild Iris, Dandelion, Pink Plumes, Wild Celery and Cloud Berry. Several of you know without my Colorado neighbor Rick there is no way I could have identified all those different flowering plants. That list doesn't even include the many varieties of grass out there in the yard. As we walked around outside, Charlie the neighbor's bear dog came over to see what we were doing. Since we were walking around and not climbing up on one of the Hondas she must have figured we were hunting something. If Charlie knew we were just hunting plants I bet she would have stayed home.

It's funny sometimes how things come around.  I was sitting here thinking about how to begin.  The first look out the win

It's funny sometimes how things come around. I was sitting here thinking about how to begin. The first look out the window this morning there were two bears out front. Sitting here now I looked out the window and there is another one across the creek. That makes four bears I have seen out front today. The first two were a male following a female. She was being coy with him. Sometimes she would run ahead. If he didn't pursue quickly enough she would sit down and wait for him. After a while they moved off in the direction they had come. A short time later this big brute came into view. He pretty much followed the same path the other two had taken. He went past the house from left to right then returned. Rick and I were photographing him. I whistled and yelled at this bear to try and get him to stand up. He would look our way but didn't think we were near as interesting as what he following. This bear's attitude was apparent. He was the boss. Rick headed back to Boulder today. Now that I don't have to keeping coming up with chores for us to do maybe I can get some rest. This evening I went down to the mouth of the Alsek. I don't know what was going on differently but the direction of the waves on the incoming tide were eroding this tall sand bank very rapidly. This huge dune is at least a mile long and where it drops off into the Alsek it is about 20 feet high. There are many logs buried in the side of the dune, washed in there decades ago during storms. Tonight the river current flowing out and incoming tide pushing in were having a battle at the base of this sand dune. I watched logs 15 feet long and 12 inches in diameter wash out of that wall of sand. Several times I watched large wedges of sand slide into the river. These slides of sand were much bigger than dump truck loads of sand. As one of them slipped into the water it took a full foot of the top of the dune with it. Tonight the mouth of the Alsek is about three miles away. If this pace of erosion keeps up next year the mouth will be 2 and a half miles from the cabin. That is not likely though. There is probably some park service regulation that will prevent it.

Describing today will begin at straight up midnight. I was up briefly and noticed something different outside in front of the cabin. Those two courting bears were bedded down right out front. She was making him sleep a safe distance away but it looked like they becoming more friendly. By six this morning they were gone. I need to cut more fire wood. I can get all the wood I need from the logs that wash up on the beach. It was a clear morning and I thought with all the erosion that was happening at the mouth of the river last evening there might be some good beach combing too. As you can see it was a good day. The big glass float is a pretty rare find. It is almost 11 inches in diameter. I didn't need that much glacier ice but I couldn't break it up on the beach so I just brought the whole chunk home. Starting at noon today all the people that I know of at Dry Bay gathered at one of the houses for a celebration. It was pot luck and turned out to be a big spread of food. There are some very good cooks here. Everything from raw oysters to chili. Cookies to hot cinnamon rolls. Several pasta salads, lamb cooked perfectly, as mentioned lots of GOOD food. I took a can of beans. I did add some dried onion flakes to spice'em up. There were 18 people there, 6 dogs and 15 Honda four wheelers.

Off and on rain today. Off just enough for you to decide to go outside and do something then it would start back with another chilly mist/rain. On the way down the river's side this morning I came across this family. Mom was very protective of her triplets. Her posture was warning enough to not come closer than about 150 yards. The stream behind her is wider and deeper than the one the cubs are crossing in the picture. I watched as she tried to get the cubs across that wider stream. About two thirds of the way across, she gathered the cubs together, changed her mind, and led the cubs back the way they had come. When they came out of the water there were only two cubs. I thought something had gone wrong and she was looking for the third cub. Suddenly the third cub dropped of the mother's back. It had clung to her rather than swim back out of the deeper water. The log the chain saw is sitting on is cedar. Very aromatic when split into firewood. Cedar isn't the best fire wood in that it burns up quickly. It is supposed to split easily (this log may prove to be the exception to that rule) And smells like the pencils we used to use in elementary school. (I bet a lot of the people who read this wonder what we used pencils for in grade school) It took two trips with the trailer to haul all that wood back to the cabin. A couple of times I have mentioned the variety of things you can find that wash up on the beach. There were a bunch of flyswatters shaped like football helmets out there a while back. I have the Pittsburg Steelers and Green Bay Packers swatters here at the cabin. I know where there are two umbrella handles if you need one. Two days ago I found this: You wonder what transpired so that the cover of a secret navel document ended up on the beach in Southeast Alaska.

A pretty calm day here today. I went across to check on my boat and bail out the rain water from the last couple of days. Every time I check on it I start the engine and let it run a short while. I won't be doing that much longer. When that old outboard is cold it is so slow to start. It does not have an electric starter. It is a fair workout pulling on the starter cord of a 75 horsepower engine about 35 times before she fires. When I got back to my neighbor's satellite phone I ordered a new outboard.....with an electric starter. Ever since I got here on May third I have been looking out the kitchen window at an old fiberglass boat. It has been sitting, bottom side up, in the same spot so long there is moss growing on the hull. I thought if I moved it to the other side of the cabin and raised it off the ground a few feet it would be a good place to park the Hondas out of the weather. So this afternoon I tied a rope to the far side, passed the rope over the boat and hooked it to the four wheeler. Now the boat is right side up and ready to be moved. No problem sliding it across the grass. The real work is about to begin though. I have to turn it back over so it is upside down then lift it a few feet off the ground. That old fiberglass eighteen foot boat is very heavy. More on this later......when I figure out what to do next. The humming birds are back. The new batch must have all fledged and they have discovered the free food at Guthrie's cabin. A real treat showed up a couple of weeks ago. It is a hummingbird I had never seen before. He drops by every few minutes. He is an Anna's hummingbird. The top of his head is red as well as his throat. I'm going to pull in some interesting information from the Internet about this beautiful bird. Anna's Hummingbird (Calypte anna) is a medium-sized hummingbird native to the west coast of North America. This bird was named after Anna Masséna, Duchess of Rivoli. Anna's Hummingbird is 3.9 to 4.3 inches (10 to 11 centimeters) long. It has a bronze-green back, a pale grey chest and belly, and green flanks. Its bill is long, straight and slender. The adult male has an iridescent crimson-red crown and throat, and a dark, slightly forked tail. Anna's is the only North American hummingbird species with a red crown. These birds feed on nectar from flowers using a long extendable tongue. They also consume small insects caught in flight. A PBS documentary that first aired January 10, 2010, shows how Anna's Hummingbirds eat flying insects. They aim for the flying insect, then open their beaks very wide. That technique has a greater success rate than trying to aim the end of a long beak at the insect. Unlike most hummingbirds, the male Anna's Hummingbird sings during courtship. The song is thin and squeaky. During the breeding season, males can be observed performing a remarkable display, called a display dive, on their territories. The males also use the dive display to drive away rivals or intruders of other species. When a female flies onto a male's territory, he rises up approximately 30 metres (98 ft) before diving over the recipient. As he approaches the bottom of the dive the males reach an average speed which is 385 body lengths per second. At the bottom of the dive the male travels 23 metres per second (51 mph), and produces a loud sound described by some as an "explosive squeak" with his outer tail-feathers. Anna's Hummingbirds are found along the western coast of North America, from southern Canada to northern Baja California, and inland to southern Arizona. They tend to be permanent residents within their range, and are very territorial. However, birds have been spotted far outside their range in such places as southern Alaska, Saskatchewan, New York, Florida, Louisiana and Newfoundland. Anna's hummingbirds are the only hummingbirds to spend the winter in northern climates; they are able to do this as there are enough winter flowers and food to support them. During cold temperatures, Anna's Hummingbirds gradually gain weight during the day as they convert sugar to fat. In addition, hummingbirds with inadequate stores of body fat or insufficient plumage are able to survive periods of sub-freezing weather by lowering their metabolic rate and entering a state of torpor. I'll be commercial fishing tomorrow and maybe Monday. Wish me luck. I need to find a way to pay for that new outboard.....the one with the electric starter.

The adult male has an iridescent crimson-red crown and throat, and a dark, slightly forked tail. Anna's is the only North American hummingbird species with a red crown. These birds feed on nectar from flowers using a long extendable tongue. They also consume small insects caught in flight. A PBS documentary that first aired January 10, 2010, shows how Anna's Hummingbirds eat flying insects. They aim for the flying insect, then open their beaks very wide. That technique has a greater success rate than trying to aim the end of a long beak at the insect. Unlike most hummingbirds, the male Anna's Hummingbird sings during courtship. The song is thin and squeaky. During the breeding season, males can be observed performing a remarkable display, called a display dive, on their territories. The males also use the dive display to drive away rivals or intruders of other species. When a female flies onto a male's territory, he rises up approximately 30 metres (98 ft) before diving over the recipient. As he approaches the bottom of the dive the males reach an average speed which is 385 body lengths per second. At the bottom of the dive the male travels 23 metres per second (51 mph), and produces a loud sound described by some as an "explosive squeak" with his outer tail-feathers. Anna's Hummingbirds are found along the western coast of North America, from southern Canada to northern Baja California, and inland to southern Arizona. They tend to be permanent residents within their range, and are very territorial. However, birds have been spotted far outside their range in such places as southern Alaska, Saskatchewan, New York, Florida, Louisiana and Newfoundland. Anna's hummingbirds are the only hummingbirds to spend the winter in northern climates; they are able to do this as there are enough winter flowers and food to support them. During cold temperatures, Anna's Hummingbirds gradually gain weight during the day as they convert sugar to fat. In addition, hummingbirds with inadequate stores of body fat or insufficient plumage are able to survive periods of sub-freezing weather by lowering their metabolic rate and entering a state of torpor. I'll be commercial fishing tomorrow and maybe Monday. Wish me luck. I need to find a way to pay for that new outboard.....the one with the electric starter.

Got up to a steady rain this morning.  Rode 4 miles on the Honda across Dry Bay in the rain.  Sat in the boat and watched my two fishing nets from noon till 7 in the rain.  Took my fish to the buyer in the rain.  Got home at 8:00 p.m. after a six mile ride in the rain.  I forgot to mention the rain gear I was wearing has a hole in the seat of the pants.  My mid section was very wet...all day.  I also forgot to mention the wind was gusting to almost 20 and averaged 11 mph most of the day.

I sold the three fish I caught for $21.00.  That probably paid for the gas I burned.

I will be back out there around six tomorrow morning.  More rain is forecast.

I can't wait to see what the nets hold tomorrow morning.  I'm loving it .... partly because I have another set of rain gear.

I got to my set nets shortly after the seals did this morning.  Two of the five fish in the net were half eaten.  The seals leave the part humans like the best.  I didn't save them though.

I thought about several words to describe my fishing this weekend.  Frustrated, disappointed, discouraged, embarresed.  The reason for the word search is the guy with nets all around mine caught over fifty fish.  I caught 7 that I could sell.  My neighbors who have a fish business caught a couple hundred.

So I came home and did a couple of things I am good at.  I took a nap and found another glass float.

Tomorrow I expect a chartered plane full of building materials to arrive.  Four of us have chartered the plane.  That keeps the cost down by dividing the fee.

At 5:30 this morning the sky was blue, there was a cool breeze, a great day to get a lot done outside after a few more winks. That blue sky must have been a dream. It misted and showered most of the day. Just as well since a load from the lumber yard in Hanes is due to arrive on a chartered flight early this afternoon. Five of us ended up using the charter. One neighbor just flew back into Dry Bay with his little dog. The other four of us all had some sort of building materials or urgently needed essentials like Pepsi Cola on the plane. My neighbor asked me over for dinner tonight. They had a fresh Sockeye that needed eating and a few oysters left from the Independence Day neighborhood party. The oysters are farm raised just up the way in Yakutat. Very mild and tasty. Excellent. No pearls though. As we were sitting down to dinner Lisa said there is a wolf outside! People went scurrying to be sure the dogs didn't go after it. The wolf would have loved to have dinner run right up to him. It had come up the other side of the creek from our cabins. It was just trotting along, stopping occasionally to sniff something. I copied this picture off the internet but the animal out front looked just like this picture. It stopped once to look our way then went on up the creek into the brush. That was the first wild wolf I have ever seen relatively close. My first impression was how long its legs are. There have been a few wolf footprints out on the beach. There feet are very large. The paw prints are as big as the main part of my hand. For me there is an aura, a cunning, in the wolf that I don't sense in other wild animals. Maybe it has to do with my fondness of dogs. Those loving companions that add so much to our daily lives all descend from the wild wolf...out front.

That new roof on the cabin next door is the reason I didn't post anything here yesterday. I was one tired old guy. Two of us were on the roof nailing down the sheathing while we kept a whole crew of people on the ground sending up more material. Well, it wasn't a very big crew on the ground but I know some of them will read this and may want to debate who was keeping who busy. This morning I went down to the mouth of the Alsek River to get some ice for the cooler. When I got back I took the fly rod out to play. It caught a nice sockeye salmon. This afternoon the neighbors saw the wolf mentioned a couple of days back. This time there were two others with it. I wish I could have seen the trio, one black, one gray, and a white one. As you can see some very large chunks come down from the glacier. The pieces in the photo would have been many times larger before they floated down. I frequently mention the mouth of that big river and all that goes on there with the battle between the river's current and the tides. The wall of sand, in the picture below, is constantly changing. Over the decades all sorts of stuff has been buried in those sand dunes. As the battle between the river and ocean keep occurring, twice a day, that buried material washes out. I have watched logs 20 feet long appear out of the dune then in a few days be gone as the sand that had them buried is washed away and the log is once again floating somewhere else.

Went over to the boat "harbor" this morning to check on the boat. Another "old timer" (he is nine days older than me) and I had propane tanks refilled in town a couple of weeks ago. They had been delivered back down here but were on the other side of the Alsek river. So this other old timer and I went across to get them. It has become much easier to do some chores if there are two of you to lift those heavy tanks. That's my boat in the background. This may be the last picture of it with that "old timer" hard to start outboard on it. Berries and Bears could be the theme here today. Some of the neighbors have been picking lots of wild strawberries. Several batches of jam have been made already. Those wild berries are not very big but have the most intense and pleasing sent and flavor. A half cup of the wild strawberries sitting in the kitchen will fill that room with their fragrance. The bear part is;  they like strawberries too. I have seen three today. One big fellow grazed in a berry patch just across the river this evening. The bear looked like a big bull in a field over there, head down, moving slowly through the patch of berries, vacuuming them up. Tonight I was sitting on the step out front watching the bear and this little guy stopped for a visit. He landed right beside me and clung to a board on the side of the house. Just beyond that hummer is a small patch of Western Columbine. Those flowers attract many of these little feathered jewels. I'm restricting them to 2 feeders full of sugar water a day. I tried to wait for a humming bird to stop at one of these columbines for a picture but no luck with that tonight. Maybe next time I'll be more patient.

If you were to listen to the local chatter today it would sound something like this; "Did you hear what the new guy did today?  Well he was going to do his laundry.  He took the Vet's advice and took his four wheeler and a trailer with a tote on it down to Dog Salmon creek.  His idea was to fill the tote with water to fill the washing machine, rather than having to pump all that water out of the kitchen sink.  He backed the trailer into the creek, threw about 30 five gallon buckets of water into the tote and started to pull out of the creek.  His new Honda wheeler immediately dug four holes into the sandy bottom and he was stuck.  Then the new guy proceeded to empty the water he had loaded into the tote back into the creek, thinking the lightened load would let him get unstuck.  That didn't work.  So then he unhooked the trailer and tote from the wheeler thinking he could get out that way.  Nope, the wheeler was buried down to the frame.  Then he saw some neighbors fishing nearby.  One of them helped him by pulling him and the trailer out of the creek.  I bet the new guy has learned to load the tote with water where there is a gravel bottom in the creek instead of sand."

I did get all the laundry done and it is much easier not having to pump the water.  Just go down to the creek with a tote, PARK ON A GRAVEL BAR, fill the tote with water, then add as needed to the washing machine.

The guy that pulled me out of the creek was the neighbor, the retired vet.  This man is a master fisherman on the East Alsek River.  Today the fish were there in good numbers.  I even managed to catch a few sockeye myself.  I also caught the first Pink Salmon of the season today.

The Alsek river is frequented by adventure rafters.  I understand they start out in Canada on what can be a two week long float down the river to Dry Bay, Alaska.  Here the rafters catch a bush plane back to civilization.  Often there is extra food at the end of their rafting trip.  We residents of Dry Bay get to share what they left behind.  This week I scored some bread, already cooked turkey sausage, and cereal.  Other neighbors got the fixings for pizza which will be shared with the community.  If those rafters knew how much fun will be had surrounding the stuff they left behind, I bet they would have stayed a few days longer.

That is a Dogfish Shark. I have done a little research: Although it’s not a very popular seafood species in the United States, spiny dogfish have been harvested off the West Coast for nearly 1,000 years, starting with the tribal fisheries in Puget Sound. There was a short-lived but intense fishery for spiny dogfish livers in the 1930s and 1940s. Because researchers had discovered that the livers of spiny dogfish contained high levels of vitamin A, there was a strong demand for use of the liver oils in pharmaceuticals, food processing, and animal feed. Harvests began to decline in 1945 as spiny dogfish abundance declined, and in 1950, the introduction of synthetic vitamins destroyed the market for spiny dogfish livers. Harvests were minimal after the liver fishery ended, and with low catch levels, spiny dogfish abundance increased again by the late 1950s. Today, there’s not much consumer demand for spiny dogfish. Off the West Coast and in Alaska, spiny dogfish are mostly caught as bycatch in fisheries for more commercially important species, and many fishermen throw them back because of their low value. Even though harvests are minimal, managers still limit the amount of spiny dogfish that can be harvested as a precaution against overfishing. These small sharks live for several decades. It takes six to eight years to reach sexual maturity. They reproduce very slowly, a litter of shark pups might only be 4. What I couldn't find on the internet was why they beach themselves. This morning in about a quarter mile I counted 112 of these fish along the beach. Beyond that quarter mile there were no more to be found. On a different note, this morning there were two adolescent bears across the river. I figure they are siblings. It was obvious they were in a good mood. They would chase each bother back and forth on the river bank. One of them went into the water to cool down. It just sat down for a few minutes then would stand up in the water and swat at it, shake its head then sit down again. In the mean time the one not in the water would rush toward the water, stop, stand up on his hind legs, spin around, drop back down on all fours and run in a circle. This went on for several minutes. Then the one in the water came out and they ran back up the river bank in the direction they had come. Ah to be young again!

I believe it was last night after I finished here the black wolf appeared and was hunting along the other side of the river. He was catching mice or voles in the tall grass. it would stand very still then jump into the air and I suppose come down on what ever was being hunted. As I watched with binoculars, I noticed a large bear feeding just a little farther back off the river. That scene was pure wilderness. This morning I saw five bears before breakfast. Two sows with three cubs. Later, motoring down the beach for some ice for the cooler I came across a family group of Brant Geese. These small geese (up to about 5 pounds) have very short bills. The group I was approaching were right at the edge of the surf. As I was about to pass them they took flight. I didn't think anything of that since all the birds you zoom by take off. I looked toward the surf a few seconds later and those geese were flying along beside me. When I sped up they kept up. If I slowed down they did too, even to the point where they would drop their feet preparing to land. I sped up again, they picked up their feet and kept up. Finally I just stopped about 50 feet from the surf's edge. The geese landed between me and the ocean. It was amazing. The following is from the internet: "It used to be a strictly coastal bird in winter, seldom leaving tidal estuaries, where it feeds on eel-grass and the seaweed. In recent decades, it has started using agricultural land a short distance inland, feeding extensively on grass and winter-sown cereals. This may be behaviour learnt by following other species of geese. Food resource pressure may also be important in forcing this change, as the world population has risen over tenfold to 400,000-500,000, possibly reaching the carrying capacity of the estuaries. In the breeding season, it uses low-lying wet coastal tundra for both breeding and feeding. The nest is bowl-shaped, lined with grass and down, in an elevated location, often in a small pond." Tomorrow my son and the new outboard arrive. I have to call the bush pilot in the morning. I am getting confusing and conflicting directions on where to meet the plane. I wouldn't want the pilot to leave the boy out there on a remote runway with only his guitar for bear protection. On second thought he could charm them with a tune.

I believe it was last night after I finished here the black wolf appeared and was hunting along the other side of the river. He was catching mice or voles in the tall grass. it would stand very still then jump into the air and I suppose come down on what ever was being hunted. As I watched with binoculars, I noticed a large bear feeding just a little farther back off the river. That scene was pure wilderness. This morning I saw five bears before breakfast. Two sows with three cubs. Later, motoring down the beach for some ice for the cooler I came across a family group of Brant Geese. These small geese (up to about 5 pounds) have very short bills. The group I was approaching were right at the edge of the surf. As I was about to pass them they took flight. I didn't think anything of that since all the birds you zoom by take off. I looked toward the surf a few seconds later and those geese were flying along beside me. When I sped up they kept up. If I slowed down they did too, even to the point where they would drop their feet preparing to land. I sped up again, they picked up their feet and kept up. Finally I just stopped about 50 feet from the surf's edge. The geese landed between me and the ocean. It was amazing. The following is from the internet: "It used to be a strictly coastal bird in winter, seldom leaving tidal estuaries, where it feeds on eel-grass and the seaweed. In recent decades, it has started using agricultural land a short distance inland, feeding extensively on grass and winter-sown cereals. This may be behaviour learnt by following other species of geese. Food resource pressure may also be important in forcing this change, as the world population has risen over tenfold to 400,000-500,000, possibly reaching the carrying capacity of the estuaries. In the breeding season, it uses low-lying wet coastal tundra for both breeding and feeding. The nest is bowl-shaped, lined with grass and down, in an elevated location, often in a small pond." Tomorrow my son and the new outboard arrive. I have to call the bush pilot in the morning. I am getting confusing and conflicting directions on where to meet the plane. I wouldn't want the pilot to leave the boy out there on a remote runway with his guitar for bear protection. On second thought he could charm them with a tune.
That picture was the highlight of my day.

It has been a very busy day.  My oldest son arrived in Yakutat yesterday. The complexities of being flown to a remote location were hidden from him. All he had to do was get on the plane when told to and get off when it landed. On this end I was told to be at a certain landing strip at a certain time. Two hours before I was supposed to be at this first strip I found out they were landing at a different one a short distance away. When the plane landed there, my son wasn't on it. The pilot had ferried a group of people to Hanes, Alaska and had not picked John up in Yakutat yet. At this second landing strip the pilot asked my if he could drop John off at still a third landing strip on the other side of the Alsek river. One of the other old timers there said he would take me across to meet John. So after all that we were able to get back to the cabin and some serious fishing. John caught this nice Sockeye and we both ended up catching several more. We let them all go but there is something special about catching these acrobatic fish with a fly rod. The Sockeye are still coming into the river in pretty good numbers. The fish and wildlife biologist flew over the East river on Sunday. There are 12,000 fish here now. There need to be 13,000 before they will open it to commercial fishing in another week or two.

My first born being from the eastern time zone and still adjusting to Alaska daylight savings time, was up at 4:00 this morning.  I couldn't get back to sleep either so with both of us up we got the wood stove going and proceeded to set a record for bear sightings.

John saw 16 different bears today.  I only saw 14 but I was watching where I was driving the Honda.

The new outboard is on the boat and ready to go.  One of the other old timer fishermen lives over near where we keep the boats on the Alsek.  He has a hoist so we took off the old outboard and installed the new one at his cabin with the hoist.

John continued to terrorize the sockeye salmon with his fly rod.  He has decided maybe he should take some of these fish back to home with him.  We have it worked out so he can vacuum pack and freeze them before he has to leave next week.

Later we got the new big window over the kitchen table installed.  That required moving some of the wiring but it all went smoothly.

Tomorrow several of us are going across the East river and down the beach to "the rocks"... That is the 12 mile strip of uninterrupted pristine wilderness beach I have mentioned before.

There will be some pretty big tides later this week.  A 12.5 foot swing between high and low tides will occur on Saturday.  Maybe we will have some luck beachcombing then.

Tomorrow several of us are going across the East river and down the beach to "the rocks"... That is the 12 mile strip of uninterrupted pristine wilderness beach I have mentioned before.

There will be some pretty big tides later this week.  A 12.5 foot swing between high and low tides will occur on Saturday.  Maybe we will have some luck beachcombing then.

It has been busy around here. The high tides have not washed any glass floats out of the dunes but we have been able to keep the cooler stocked with ice from the glacier. I think I mentioned before how long this very hard, clear ice lasts. Thursday night the First Dry Bay Music Festival was held in the neighbors yard. Lisa fixed 5 different huge pan pizzas. They were delicious. The bear biologist for this part of Alaska was there. She also plays the banjo really well. She and John kept about a dozen of us tapping our toes until today, Friday. There was a bon fire fueled with wood picked up on the beach. A good time was had by all. Even Charlie the bear dog relaxed and enjoyed the music. Several hours the last two days have been devoted to catching Salmon. The river is beginning to be full of Sockeye. We went down to the mouth twice today. Frequently we would see pods of Salmon coming in from the ocean. That is an awe inspiring sight. These fish coming in were spawned in this river 4 or 5 years ago. They have been swimming in the ocean most of that time but some internal clock and compass has brought then back to this river. They swim in out of the ocean with such determination. They remind me of athletes focused on their goal. Thousands and Thousands of them. So, the result of all this fishing is a five gallon bucket filled with boneless sockeye fillets. If john had a few more days here we would smoke some of the fish too. Maybe next trip.

A day to remember, today was.  Good stuff happened.  Scary things happened.  Luck came our way,.  Disaster was avoided. And my son and I still have all our parts and our health. My goal today was to get the new well in so I can plumb the cabin for running water.  The well is really just a pipe driven into the ground,  the bottom section of the pipe is called a sand point.  It is about four feet long and has many holes in it for the water to seep in.  On top of that there are three, three foot sections of pipe.  So all together there is a thirteen foot piece of pipe that needs to be driven into the ground.  The neighbors let us borrow a tool they made to do the job.  It is a pipe about four feet long. It is larger in diameter than the well pipe and had handles welded onto the sides. The closed end of this tool has about sixty pounds of steel welded into it. All together this pipe driver weighs about eighty pounds when you start using it. By the time you lift this thing, slide it down over the well pipe, and then slam it down on the well pipe about three hundred times it weighs at least 150 pounds. Thank heaven I had help. That is the first glass of water from the new well. The water is so cold condensation immediately appears on the glass. Next we went over to the harbor to bring the boat to the cabin. The East River may open to commercial fishing this week so I wanted the boat over here by the cabin. When the dealer prepped the motor to be shipped on a plane he had to drain all the combustible fluids out of the engine. When we installed the new motor on the boat and tested it I wasn't real happy with the low speed idle. N there was a little hose with a loose end inside the engine cover. Gas would come out of this hose when the engine was running. Another fisherman has the same outboard so we compared them. His engine had the little hose with the loose end in it also but it didn't leak gas....mystery! On the way back across Dry Bay the road is sometimes bumpy. At one especially bumpy spot I stopped to check to see if things were all right ini the boat. John ini the meantime is yelling "FIRE!!!!FIRE!!!". Smoke is coming out the bottom of the new outboard. Remember the gas leak? Turns out the bump had capsized the battery. It shorted out on the aluminum boat and caused a little ground wire on the engine to overheat and melt the insulation. A little flame and a little more smoke but no big problem for the brand new , (did I mention expensive?) outboard. The gas leaking out of the tube was because the dealer drained the gas from the engine but did not retighten the valve so whenever the engine was on it was squirting gas out the open valve. After dinner (John ate some of the camper food my daughter sent and I ate Grape Nuts) went fly fishing again. John had caught and released four before I got my first one hooked. While he was concentrating on one of his fish a bear had come out of the brush and approached the water's edge where he was fishing. John said he was close enough that he could see the bear's eyes. I bet the bear could see John's eyes too. They were twice as big as normal. Anyway all that sudden appearance of huge white eyes scared the bear away. Walking back to the wheelers a bit more luck came his way. The glasses he had lost in the water yesterday were there in the sand waiting for him. It is amazing after two tide cycles that had not been swept away or buried in the sand. It is going on eleven as I type this. It has been such a wonderful day to spend with him I hate to see it end.

Today was John's last day here at the cabin. He flies out tomorrow afternoon in with two other people and a load of fish. In Yakutat he will catch a jet back to civilization. One of the old timers I have referred to several times invited John to watch him do some commercial fishing with the gill nets. I used the word "watch" because to do any commercial fishing you must have a crew member license. For a quick introduction into set net fishing he didn't think a license was justified. While he was "watching" I did some chores around the cabin. For dinner we prepared the salmon he caught last night. Then we went out for one last bit of fishing. John hooked into a real fighter. The fish in the picture took almost all the line off his reel. He did finally land it and then released it to go on upstream to spawn and pass on those spirited genes. The East River just outside the door will be open for commercial fishing on Tuesday. Dry Bay will be a busy place tomorrow as all the fishermen get their gear over here from the Alsek river. The Vet and I are going to fish together. He will be getting his net together while I get the boat in the water. I need to check the engine out after yesterday's near disaster. We saw a couple of bears today, one park ranger and one bear biologist. None of them gave us any trouble.
