Today was a day of preparation. The Alaska department of Fish and Wildlife announced the East Alsek river will be open for commercial gillnet fishing tomorrow at noon for 48 hours. That means enough salmon have already moved up the river to sustain the population and enough are still coming into the river to allow harvesting some of them The preparation part; All the fishermen who were over on the Alsek river are coming over here to take advantage of two more days fishing, on an easy river, with lots of fish in it. There was a meeting today with the owner of the fish processing facility in Yakutat and the fishermen. The fishermen would like for the fish to be picked up at a landing strip right by the river. The processor has all his equipment in a facility several miles away and he wants the fishermen to haul all the fish to his place. There may be a little change in the processor's position but I think most of the fish will be hauled across dry bay to the processing facility. These fish, in the picture above, were caught over the weekend in the Alsek River. Below they are being loaded into the plane for the short flight to Yakutat where they will be dressed and shipped to locations all over the lower US.   This time of year it is not unusual for a small plane to land at one of the remote airstrips. When it stops out will pop some people with cameras, they walk around for a few minutes taking pictures then take off again. These sightseeing air excursions keep a lot of the bush pilots busy in the summer. This pilot got a little too far off the runway and his wheels sunk into the soft soil. Three of us attending the above meeting were able to push him around so he could take off again.     Another bit of preparation today was getting son John across the Alsek river to meet the plane that would take him to Yakutat so he could catch his flights back  home to Kentucky. I know he will be glad to get home and see his precious daughters. I also know he will miss walking out the front door to watch the grizzly bears or running to the river to catch another batch of sockeyes.  That's him in the green shirt with some neighbors and Charlie the bear dog.   I miss him.

It was a beautiful day.  Temps near 70. A very slight breeze. Perfect, because at noon a two day "opening" started for commercial gillnet fishing on the East Alsek river. I took that picture from the boat. That is my cabin in the background. A pretty short commute to work.  And a pretty commute too. Another old timer (the retired veterinarian) and I teamed up to fish one net. Before we got the 20 fathom net all pulled out into the river we had a fish in it. We did OK for newbees. As you can see in the picture below there is a lot of moss in the clear water of the river. One lesson we learned today is when the tide turns and starts pushing water back upstream, that moss that had been carried down stream comes back all at once. We had trouble pulling the net out of the water because it was so full of that heavy green moss. Another lesson was watch where you park the Hondas. The one in the top picture was in water half way up the wheels by the time we got the net out of the water. Some of these bigger tides come in real fast. These are the sockeye that were in the net when we pulled it for the last time as the tide came in. The fish today averaged a little over six and a half pounds each.  We also caught several pink salmon. There is not much of a market for pinks so we released all of them. Tomorrow at seven the Vet and I will meet at the boat and do it all again. With the two lessons we learned today, tomorrow should be an even better day.

It was a beautiful day.  Temps near 70. A very slight breeze. Perfect, because at noon a two day "opening" started for commercial gillnet fishing on the East Alsek river. I took that picture from the boat. That is my cabin in the background. A pretty short commute to work.  And a pretty commute too. Another old timer (the retired veterinarian) and I teamed up to fish one net. Before we got the 20 fathom net all pulled out into the river we had a fish in it. We did OK for newbees. As you can see in the picture below there is a lot of moss in the clear water of the river. One lesson we learned today is when the tide turns and starts pushing water back upstream, that moss that had been carried down stream comes back all at once. We had trouble pulling the net out of the water because it was so full of that heavy green moss. Another lesson was watch where you park the Hondas. The one in the top picture was in water half way up the wheels by the time we got the net out of the water. Some of these bigger tides come in real fast. These are the sockeye that were in the net when we pulled it for the last time as the tide came in. The fish today averaged a little over six and a half pounds each.  We also caught several pink salmon. There is not much of a market for pinks so we released all of them. Tomorrow at seven the Vet and I will meet at the boat and do it all again. With the two lessons we learned today, tomorrow should be an even better day.

Today was the second day of fishing on the East Alsek river.  The fishermen who have fished the river for years continue to do well.  A couple hundred fish yesterday and a couple hundred again today.  They are good at it.  They work very hard.  Some of them were still fishing at 1:30 this morning.

The vet and I are best at providing entertainment for the others.  I have a brand new Yamaha "high thrust" 50 horsepower outboard.  Electric start, power trim and tilt, a first class top of the line outboard. Today the water was so shallow I had to get out of the boat and pull it up river by the anchor rope to where we wanted to set the net.

The tides seem to determine when the fish move in this part of the river.  We sat watching the net for two and a half hours this morning. And caught six fish.  When the tide turned and we caught four times that many in five minutes.  That incoming tide also floods where we park the wheelers and totes to haul the fish.  So we can't stay and continue fishing.

So this afternoon we picked another place near the mouth of the river to fish.  The water is deeper there and I can actually use my new outboard the way it was ment to be used.

The tide turns at about 10 p.m. this evening so I am writing this earlier than usual.  I want to be at the new location on the net to see how the change in the river current affects the fishing down there.

The experienced fishermen are disappointed we are moving out of their sight.  I think they had planned on making a video to document what it is like the first year one decides to fish commercially.  They are very supportive and encouraging.  I remind them of all the lessons they had to learn, the hard way, just as I am now.  I am loving it.

This has been one of those "where to begin" days. One reason might be because yesterday didn't end until 1:40 this morning when I came in from fishing. The new fishing spot was a morale boost from the very beginning. The water is deep enough there to use the outboard with no problems. The river bank has enough slope that it is easy to step out of the boat and watch the net from the shore. We can drive the Hondas right up to where the net is set if we need to load or unload anything from the boat. The Vet and I decided to fish the new spot I mentioned yesterday, last evening. I wanted to see what would happen to the net when the tide turned and the fish started coming in. I didn't have to wait that long. We started catching fish right away. As it got later we kept wondering why the current in the river hadn't changed as the tide came in. It turned out we had misread the tide table. So we continued catching a few fish. Then the tide did turn. The expected influx of fish did happen and we finally had our hands full, picking fish out of the net in the wee hours of today. On the way over to deliver the fish to the buyer we had trouble with both trailers. One flat tire and one set of bad bearings. No real problem though. Two broken trailers can be made into one whole trailer that can carry the other broken trailer home. In the two days of fishing we caught a little over two hundred fish. They averaged around six pounds each. That is a lot of sockeye. The experienced guys on the river caught their fair share more than we did. It was a pretty good opening. On Sunday the river will be open for fishing again. We will be out there too but probably not as late as this morning. I did a little beach combing after checking the boat this evening. After a two week drought I found a couple of prizes tonight. I had checked the beach this morning and found nothing. All it takes is one tide and new things appear. Up here with all the wildlife your senses are tuned up a little. Not being at the top of the food chain hopefully makes one more aware of what is going on around you. I was pretty tired this afternoon. I lounged around the cabin in my slippers and decided to take a nap. I dozed on and off for an hour or so. Suddenly there was this noise. I jumped up and ran to the window to see if a bear was in one of the totes that had held the fish....no bear out that window. I checked outside the other windows....no animal to be seen. Then I realized I was walking around in one slipper. The other one had slipped off my foot and clunked on the floor. I got to keep my senses tuned though. There may be another loose slipper out there somewhere. I have to be ready for it.

After a day and a half of rain and mist the sun was back in a big way today.  There are lots of chores to do around the cabin in preparation for a special guest who arrives in a couple of weeks.

I got the new well plumbed to the washing machine this morning.  No more running to the creek for wash water.  I had hoped to get the hot water heater hooked up but ended up destroying it instead.  The old pipes had fused themselves to the heater and could not be removed.  So when I get back to civilization I'll buy a small one to install.  All the plumbing will be ready so it shouldn't take long to have hot and cold running water....and a shower!

I went across Dry Bay today to borrow some tools from one of the other fishermen.  On the way home I came across a couple riding bicycles.  They were riding from Yakutat to Juneau cross country.  A couple of hundred miles!  Their bikes had tires almost 4 inches wide.  Only one speed.  No special gears.  The front and rear wheels are interchangeable.  No fancy suspension.  Just a frame with huge tires.

I invited Cameron and Iris to stop for a cup of coffee.  They jumped at the chance to have something hot to drink since the rain had kept them from having a fire for two days.

They cross the many rivers with small inflatable boats.  It took them about ten minutes to break their bikes down, inflate the boats, strap everything down and paddle across the East Alsek river.  They thought the trip would take 12 to 14 days.  Cameron said it couldn't take longer than that because that is how long their food would last.

Tonight a neighbor and his daughter invited me over to their cabin for home made ice cream.  To my grateful surprise they had some leftover pizza too.  If you have never tried sauerkraut pizza it is VERY VERY good.  This pizza consisted of crust, mustard, cheese, sauerkraut and polish sausage on it.  Tonight was the second time I have had this kind of pizza and I highly recommend you try it sometime.  The ice cream was pretty good too.

The young woman who created this culinary treat is a Nurse Practicioner working in Montrose, Colorado.  She has been coming up here to help her Dad fish since she was a little girl almost twenty years ago.  

Sunday at noon the river is open to fishing again until Wednesday at noon.  Some of the fishermen from up at Yakutat may come down here to fish since the river is open to fishing for three days.  If that happens things might get a little crowded around the better fishing spots.

I'm usually sitting by a window facing the west when I type these posts.  As the days have gone by I can see the sun sliding south past some of the distant mountains.  In the wee hours of the morning you might even call it dark outside.

I'm usually sitting by a window facing the west when I type these posts.  As the days have gone by I can see the sun sliding south past some of the distant mountains.  In the wee hours of the morning you might even call it dark outside.

Thinking about what to post today I keep coming back to what a great bunch of people make up this community.  One of the fishermen helped out a mother and son by having the young man stay with him for several weeks.  More about Duke (not his real name, Forest Gump isn't his real name either) in another post sometime.

Another fisherman helps out his family by having his 91 year old mother stay with him.  It is impressive to see the two of them scouting the river for fish.  Her sitting behind him on a four wheeler.

Last week, delivering fish, both trailers broke down.  One neighbor lent me the tool I needed to get air back into the tires.  Another neighbor gave me two wheel hubs to replace the bad one on my second trailer.

The family that invited me have some home made ice cream last night, remembered my mentioning I was out of ice for the cooler.  When I got home from getting the parts for the trailer there were several big chunks of glacier ice in the front yard.

I mention the Vet frequently.  He will offer you anything you might need if he has one to offer.  His readily passes on tips on how to catch these elusive sockeye with a fly rod.  He still hooks more than anyone else though.

There are many more examples of how the twenty or so people who live in this 57,000 acre preserve help and support each other.

The fishing begins again tomorrow, Sunday, at noon.  We will be setting our net near the mouth of the river again.  There are some big changes going on down there due to the very high tides we have had lately.  The river flows parallel to the ocean for a couple of miles before abruptly turning left into the sea.  Imagine an "L" upside down.  In the last couple of days a new channel opened near the mouth so now there are two ways for the fish coming in to get into the long side of the "L" and swim upstream.  Each tide is changing the configuration down there.

If you have ever noticed the sun sparkling on little waves of water during a light breeze. There were so many fish milling around in the water at this new confluence this afternoon, the sun flashing on the silver sides of the salmon looked like that. 

I couldn't stand it.  Rushed home, grabbed the fly rod and zoomed back down the river....The tide had started pushing in, the fish were gone.  With all the Vet has taught me it was the fishes lucky day.

Not much luck fishing today. We moved the net to yet another spot. It started out with a bang. About 20 fish in just a few minutes but then nothing else fish wise. We did catch about a pickup truck load of moss though. I hope to be back out there before 5 in the morning at still another new spot. We keep the fish we catch on ice till we get them to the buyer. The buyer provides shaved ice to pack the fish in. The ice off the beach keeps the fish colder and I don't have to drive as far to get it. The tote behind the Honda was so full of ice the weight caused me to get stuck in the sand on the way back to where we were fishing. This chunk was taller than me. That is my cap perched on the edge.

Most of today was spent tending a gill net.  Some of that time was spent actually fishing. This diagram shows what the end of the gill net that is out in the river looks like. The other end is similar except it is usually anchored on shore. The nets we are fishing right now are 120 feet long. The illustration shows the net hanging vertically. The East River is so shallow most places the bottom of the net is lying on the bottom. The following is off the internet: Set gillnets consist of a single netting wall kept vertical by a float line and a weighted lead line. Small floats, usually shaped like eggs or cylinders and made of solid plastic, are evenly distributed along the float line. The lower line is made of lead cored rope. The net is set on the bottom, or at a distance above it and held in place with anchors or weights on both ends. On small boats gillnets are handled by hand. Larger boats use hydraulic net haulers or net drums. Set gillnets are widely used all over the world, and are employed both in inland and sea waters. We did catch a few fish today. This morning fishing by myself I got to untangle two separate logs that the net drifted across. Big ole logs...a bad situation. Also the float line broke.... another bad situation. I'll be out there tomorrow morning at 5:00...Loving it.

One thing I am learning this summer is how important it is to have a copy of the Tide Tables. These little books are about 4 inches wide and 6 inches tall. One page for each month contains all the information about the time of the two tide cycles each day and the height of the high and low tides. This morning's high tide was at 8:07 so we started fishing at 5:00. The fish tend to ride the incoming tide. They don't have to fight the river current that way. My fishing partner, the vet and his trusty sidekick Benni watched the net while I went looking for some glacier ice. (I happened to find a couple of glass floats along the way along with some ice.) Anyway things were real slow. The vet went home so I watched the net until almost 10:00. We caught six fish. This afternoon was different. We started fishing again at 4:00.By 7:30 we had 100 fish. A fish has just hit the middle of the net in the picture above. That splashing means we just made some money. Sometimes the fish enter the net in deeper water. There is no splashing then but the floats on the surface begin to dance and you know there is a fish down there under it. We were excited when four or five floats went completely under a couple of times. Just imagine how many fish that would mean were in the net.....WRONG... a seal had snuck in and was robbing the fish out of the net. It tore a hole about 18 inches in diameter in the net but didn't cause any other problem. That's my half of today's catch. That is Benni watching us load the totes.  Benni is in both these pictures.  He and the Vet are never far apart.  In the top picture he is to the left of the wheelers,  waiting patiently for us to come back to shore.  Those fish weighed 341 pounds. They may end up at a Whole Foods store by the end of the week. At $15.00 a pound for fresh wild caught Alaskan sockeye fillets, those fish we caught will sell for over $6,000.00. The going rate for fresh caught sockeye here at Dry Bay is $1.48 a pound.

A couple of surprises today: I got up early again to catch the incoming tide.  In hind sight I could have stayed in bed. The fishing wasn't very good for anybody. Getting up early did allow me to catch a glimpse of a wolf this side of the river. The tracks showed there were two of them patrolling the beach. Out on the beach I came across this surprise. An orange container that had something heavy in it. Inside there was a paper that read; EMERGENCY RATIONS FOR SHIPS O_YI TYPE NEVER GIVE UP! RESCUE IS COMING This survival food is to kept aboard ships consists of following two types of processed food; Nut flour-ration (food A) using grain and Seed-jelly ration (food B) using starch respectively as their main content. These foods can be eaten directly without heating or further special processing. CONTENTS NUT FLOUR RATION – 9 BAGS, SEED JELLY RATION – 3 BAGS, 9 MEALS TOTAL 2462 cal On the back side of the sheet was a form that could be filled out. It had blanks to be filled out including the name of the ship, a memo field and a place for ones name. It was manufactured by: YOSHIMURA TASUKE CO. LTD, Japan No telling how long that little container of rations had floated around in the pacific. The nut flour ration tastes a little almondy. It will be good with coffee. The seed jelly has the texture of fudge but resembles strawberry preserves in flavor. Another surprise was a package that came in the mail with the four heavy duty carabiners inside. These can be very useful with all the ropes that go along with net fishing. There was no note in the box. Whoever sent these useful devices, thank you very much.

The seed jelly has the texture of fudge but resembles strawberry preserves in flavor. Another surprise was a package came in the mail with the four heavy duty carabiners inside. These can be very useful with all the ropes that go along with net fishing. There was no note in the box. Whoever sent these useful devices, thank you very much.
This is a test.

I have been having software issues. The iPad acts differently with this wordpress program than the laptop does. I took a picture of the delicious meal the neighbors brought over last night. I took the pic with the iPad. I wanted to show all you folks back home what beer battered king salmon and fresh caught halibut over fluffy rice with a home made rubarb sauce on top looked like. That was followed with delicious carrot cake. (I think) Anyway, after breakfast of pancakes and lunch of pancakes it was truly appreciated. The picture came over OK but there are issues with entering text. No real problem though. My trusty tech support team back home is on it. I spent some time digging a hole in the yard, filled it with gravel and ran the drain from the shower and washer into it. I put the sod back over the hole and admired my minimal impact on the local environment. After two large loads of laundry I noticed a new feature in my yard. A miniature old faithful fountain has appeared! Imagine that. Cut up a twenty foot log for firewood. I have learned that shorter pieces are a lot easier to split. I was a little worried about this log because there appeared to be many knots in the wood. That could make it hard to split. I don't know what kind of tree it was but the knots are no problem. It is a relief when you want a warm fire to not have to work up a sweat just to split the wood to get the fire.

This being my first full season here at Dry Bay most everything is new. Shades of the past this morning though. Years ago whenever an IBM executive would come to town there would be a meeting so he or she could take the pulse of what was going on out there "in the field". They would listen to what we had to say and then go back to where they came from. Today the local ranger's boss came down to the Dry Bay ranger station for his annual visit. A really nice guy. He listened to what we had to say. He observed how the local ranger fielded the questions we had. He acknowledged the complexities of the government's many departments and their respective responsibilities and how frustrating it all can be. When it was all said and done there are a few "to do's" and in my opinion a little hope that the lines of communication will improve. Back to the shades of the past. Coffee and cookies assured a good turnout for the meeting. After a lunch consisting of about eight cookies with M&Ms in them I started on another project here at the cabin. Well near the cabin. That pile of sand and stones on the right center of the picture came out of a hole in the foreground that has the wood frame around it. The quaint structure in the background has a hole under it. And one inside it too. If I can remember some of my carpenter skills there may be a new one holer finished before my next guest arrives. The view from the new outhouse will be as good as the one from the old one. The new structure will probably have a door on it though. However with no door there is plenty of ventilation....a good thing.

Today was one of those days.  I borrowed the neighborhood flailing mower.  It broke down.  Now the yard is 3/4 mowed.  I tried to move the old fiberglass boat from in back of the house.  It is so heavy the Honda got stuck in the side yard trying to pull it.  Now there are four holes that need filling.  I went out along old tide lines picking up wood to build a hot fire outside to burn up some old wet logs that used to surround the bon fire pit.  I got the fire going...then it started to rain...no more hot fire.  The internet is so sloooooooow.  I should take my computer to another cabin that has internet to see if I can narrow down where the problem is. 

On a more positive note.  The silver salmon seem to be coming down the coast and into the rivers in good numbers.  That means some good sport fishing is about to be had.  Several visitors today gave me some good advice on the correspondence I need to prepare as a result of yesterdays meeting at the ranger station.  Another set of visitors told me about a place near by where you can watch the salmon spawn.  Some great photographs can be made of all the wildlife the spawning fish attract.

Other positive things; one of the visitors wants the old fiberglass boat!  I understood him to say he would pick it up by the end of the week and I got the new hot water heater installed.  It works great.  The next thing I have to do is connect it to something besides a bucket.

Commercial fishing begins again tomorrow at noon ending Wednesday at noon.  If the fishing is good I'll be spending a lot of time in the boat.  If not, the cabin's lack of plumbing will be addressed.

The first Sunday in August is usually when the family reunion is held.  I was able to attend last year.  This year I was there in spirit.  I believe I am the second oldest male among the multiple generations that make up the annual reunion.  The third oldest male in the group did me a favor by posting a note about this journal for the family to see. Thanks Tom.

It is almost eight in the evening.  I one hour I will be back out on the net.  The vet and I had a good afternoon fishing.  We caught over six hundred pounds of sockeye.  Again, compared to some of the pros, we are not in the same league.  But we are pleased.

On the way to sell the fish I had a flat tire on the tote trailer.  I knew the vet would come along in a few minutes.  He had already turned in his fish.  We put my fish in the trailer he was using, attached it to my Honda, put the broken down trailer on top of the good one and off we went. I bet I looked a little like Jed Clampett on the Beverly Hillbillies.  All dressed in rain gear putting along with this upside down trailer strapped to a right side up trailer which was full of fish.  On second thought, Jed would have had a nice looking girl with him......I will have one with me next week.  Wonder if she can change a flat?

I found another glass ball today.  Before the fishing started the kitchen and shower faucets got installed.  With another couple hours work there should be hot and cold water in the kitchen and a real shower in the workshop side of the cabin.  For the first time since April I won't have to wash my clothes in cold water.

A good day today! Caught a few fish this morning. It stopped misting around noon. Got a nice check for fish sold last week. Took a short nap and took a hot shower. That last item, the hot shower, is no big deal to 98% of you who might read this. The other two percent are neighbors here at Dry Bay and understand. It has taken me almost exactly three months for me to take that shower here at the cabin. When I bought the place the fiberglass shower stall was buried in the back corner of the workshop. It took a month to clear out all the other stuff to get to it. The shower had been damaged in a couple for places so I needed a fiberglass repair kit. I bought that and the valve while in Anchorage in June. The pump I mail ordered drew too much current for bank of batteries so I had to send that back and order another one on-line. In early July the plastic tubing and all the connectors and fittings arrived. I needed to install another well to get adequate water for the shower and washer. John and I got that done in mid July. To drain the water from the shower and washer I needed to dig a trench for the pipe that runs out to the French drain that looks like the miniature "Old Faithful" when a large load of water Is discharged from the washer. The hot water heater arrived last week so finally all the pieces were here to plumb in the shower. Now the shower in in the front corner of the workshop. The water is hot enough to keep the cool air off your skin while out there. It is a short dash back inside to the wood stove to dry off. Now I have another decision to make...do I want to smell like Irish Spring or Dial?

No post here on the sixth.  I didn't think splitting wood and re-arranging the cabin would make very interesting reading.  Today's adventures were pretty mild too.

As the fishing begins to slow down here on the East Alsek river for some other things begin to kick into gear.  Most of the fishermen are leaving the river soon to (a) go back to their homes in the lower states.  (b) fish in other rivers. (c) get ready to host clients at sport fishing camps.

I am getting ready to go down to Juneau to meet my sweetheart.  We will be back up here in Dry Bay in a few days.  She plans to stay a couple of weeks.  Now you know why getting the hot water heater and shower installed was a priority.

The last two weeks there have been some noticeable changes outside.  There used to be dozens of hummingbirds.  Now I only see one a couple of times each day.  I hope it can find its way south.  The others have all gone that way already.  I'm beginning to see family groups of geese flying south.  There are new birds showing up that were not here a few days ago.  It is darker outside now at 10 p.m. than it was at midnight a while back. In the evenings the sun, as it sets, is creeping noticeably farther south each day. 

I'm having a hard time with the idea of this incredible summer I have had beginning to wind down.  I'm glad I get to share some of this spectacular place with someone I care about one more time this year.

It misted and rained off and on most of the day. Around six this evening the rain gods gave in to the bug gods. It stopped raining and all the bugs came out to celebrate. They are never too bad here at the cabin but if you get out of the breeze and into some vegetation...it is a short trip for some ...but they will drive you crazy. For the first time since May third the table is clear. All the electronics required for the satellite Internet, various battery chargers, computers, cameras and VHF radio gadgets have found a new place to rest. Now I guess I'll have to start sitting down at the table to eat. I moved the boat into shallow water this afternoon. I would rather the tide left it on the sandy shore rather than have some log floating down the river tear it up or pull the anchor and the boat wash out into the Pacific Ocean. While down that way I found another glass ball. One of the other fishermen is heading home tomorrow. While here he lives in a unique structure. I helped him close things down this afternoon. In the picture notice the jacks at the front and rear corners of the building. With those jacks he can raise and lower the upper (blue) part of the building. Inside there is plenty of head room. In the picture below we have lowered it. He has things arranged so that in the winter he has room to store his tote trailer and three Honda ATVs inside. It didn't take an hour to do the conversion. All he had to do after this picture was board up the windows. I'm still not sure how I'm getting out of here for the flight to Juneau tomorrow. But as long as I do it is all good.

I'm in Juneau tonight.  Meeting my sweetie tomorrow and plan on painting the town.  At least we will stop by the super Walmart.

yesterday was the last day of fishing on the East River until next week.  The number of fish have really dropped off.  People are hoping some new fish will push in but historically it is about time for the sockeye to give way to the silver salmon.

I was able to hitch a ride on the plane that hauls the fish from Dry Bay to Yakutat.  That saved a few bucks.  At the airport I found out I had booked my flight to Juneau for tomorrow.  That cost a few bucks.  So for the day I broke even on that part.

I checked into the motel and noticed several things I found to be humorous.  The carpet on the floors.  I have been walking around on plywood floors and had forgotten how carpet feels under bare feet.  What I have been feeling is sandy plywood.  There were three people in line at the registration desk.  Where I have been there are no lines to get into.

My birthday celebration meal consisted of two hamburgers...it had been a while.  In the fish plane mail delivery I received a book.  "GLACIER WOLF" there was no information on who may have sent it.  If that person happens to read this, thank you very much.  A nice birthday surprise.  Another birthday gift...the rental car guy noticed on my drivers license it is my birthday...he gave me a five percent discount. Another nice thought.  In six more years I won't have to take my shoes off to get through airport security.

I'm in Juneau tonight.  Meeting my sweetie tomorrow and plan on painting the town.  At least we will stop by the super Walmart.

I was able to hitch a ride on the plane that hauls the fish from Dry Bay to Yakutat.  That saved a few bucks.  At the airport I found out I had booked my flight to Juneau for tomorrow.  That cost a few bucks.  So for the day I broke even on that part.

I checked into the motel and noticed several things I found to be humorous.  The carpet on the floors.  I have been walking around on plywood floors and had forgotten how carpet feels under bare feet.  What I have been feeling is sandy plywood.  There were three people in line at the registration desk.  Where I have been there are no lines to get into.

My birthday celebration meal consisted of two hamburgers...it had been a while.  In the fish plane mail delivery I received a book.  "GLACIER WOLF" there was no information on who may have sent it.  If that person happens to read this, thank you very much.  A nice birthday surprise.  Another birthday gift...the rental car guy noticed on my drivers license it is my birthday...he gave me a five percent discount.  

Another nice thought.  In six more years I won't have to take my shoes off to get through airport security.

The day is winding down. We have been going nearly non-stop. Shopping for myself and two other Dry Bay residents. Because we need some of the same things, i.e. wheel bearings, one store might have three sets, another, two sets and still one more another set. We needed six sets between us. Of course I went to all three stores trying to find six sets in one place. I'm getting to know Juneau pretty well. Yesterday afternoon we went out to the Mendenhall Glacier. The sockeye are spawning in a stream at the visitor center right now. We listened to a couple of very informative Ranger presentations about the salmon and their amazing life cycle. There is a viewing area there where we could watch the fish actually spawning. The raised walkway along the stream also has a bear viewing area. A black bear sow was there snacking on the bounty the salmon provide. Today we visited the salmon hatchery near downtown Juneau. A young man who is studying hatchery managment at the university in Fairbanks, gave us a tour. This place started out as an experiment and has grown as you can see. Now, they process several million wild salmon each year. www.dipac.net is their web address. There is a free tour but for ten bucks we got to see the whole process. Starting with the harvesting of eggs and milt fron the returning adults to the incubation of the eggs, the reintroduction of the fry to the wild and then the harvesting of those released fish four or five years later to start the whole cycle over again. In the top picture the sparkle in the white water on the left side of the photo are hundreds of salmon waiting to come up the 450 foot fish ladder. The lower picture are the fish in one of the square "steps" on the ladder. As the years have flown by I keep being reminded that the more one knows about something the more one knows there is to know. I thought i knew a bit about salmon. The presentations the young tour guide gave today and the ranger's yesterday reinforced that thought...... and that thought applies to everything in my life...

As the years have flown by I keep being reminded that the more one knows about something the more one knows there is to know. I thought i knew a bit about salmon. The presentations the young tour guide gave today and the ranger's yesterday reinforced that thought...... and that thought applies to everything in my life...

The day is winding down. We have been going nearly non-stop. Shopping for myself and two other Dry Bay residents. Because we need some of the same things, i.e. wheel bearings, one store might have three sets, another, two sets and still one more another set. We needed six sets between us. Of course I went to all three stores trying to find six sets in one place. I'm getting to know Juneau pretty well. Yesterday afternoon we went out to the Mendenhall Glacier. The sockeye are spawning in a stream at the visitor center right now. We listened to a couple of very informative Ranger presentations about the salmon and their amazing life cycle. There is a viewing area there where we could watch the fish actually spawning. The raised walkway along the stream also has a bear viewing area. A black bear sow was there snacking on the bounty the salmon provide. Today we visited the salmon hatchery near downtown Juneau. A young man who is studying hatchery managment at the university in Fairbanks, gave us a tour. This place started out as an experiment and has grown as you can see. Now, they process several million wild salmon each year. www.dipac.net is their web address. There is a free tour but for ten bucks we got to see the whole process. Starting with the harvesting of eggs and milt fron the returning adults to the incubation of the eggs, the reintroduction of the fry to the wild and then the harvesting of those released fish four or five years later to start the whole cycle over again. In the top picture the sparkle in the white water on the left side of the photo are hundreds of salmon waiting to come up the 450 foot fish ladder. The lower picture are the fish in one of the square "steps" on the ladder. As the years have flown by I keep being reminded that the more one knows about something the more one knows there is to know. I thought i knew a bit about salmon. The presentations the young tour guide gave today and the ranger's yesterday reinforced that thought...... and that thought applies to everything in my life...

Things they are a changing. Cheryl is buzzing through the cabin helping me get to some of the things I had not paid any attention to. I really appreciate her help and suggestions. The closest neighbors, whom I have referred to so often here, are pulling out in the next couple of days. They have a sport fishing business up the coast a ways and they need to get it ready. Their first clients of the season will arrive in a couple of weeks. In their typical generous fashion they hosted a pizza party for the neighborhood tonight. With all they have to do to get ready to go, they host a neighborhood party to close out the season here....Great People. Stocking up on provisions in Juneau went well. Getting them here to Dry Bay didn't go as smoothly. Alaska Airlines allows 3 free bags per passenger for in state trips. The only exceptions are over sized and over weight bags. We bought one of those large marine coolers. I thought it was pretty heavy when I went to check in. It weighed 127 pounds. That meant I had to run out and buy another tote to put some of the food stuff in. Now, between us we checked 5 bags but 3 of them were over 50 pounds. Those three bags cost $150.00 in added fees. The short flight from Juneau to Yakutat left time for only a couple of card games on the iPad. Guess who left their iPad in the pocket of the seat in front of him. We did catch a fish plane flight back to Dry Bay so that part of the trip went off without any hitches. Yesterday afternoon Cheryl found another glass ball on the beach. She is also starting a collection of "special and unusual" bottles that wash up out of the pacific. Today we took both wheelers across the East River and went the 12 miles down the outer beach to the "rocks" We didn't find any treasures but we did come across some huge trees that had washed ashore. One of them had this really beautiful root system. It was so intricate. The roots had surrounded many rock and the sand and surf had polished it to an almost furniture smooth finish. On the way back we came upon a neighbor and his girlfriend out there. Their Honda had broken down and they couldn't raise anyone on the VHF radio. We towed them back down the beach and across the East River. This same neighbor has had a pretty good season fishing. I asked him where I might catch a fish for dinner. He put me on a spot where I caught the first silver salmon of the season with a fly rod. If my friend keeps up the good work, I might even show her where that spot is.

We just got back from a wonderful dinner with another couple here at Dry Bay. Steaks, salad, special potatoes and dessert. It was a long way from Grape Nuts. With Cheryl here my Grape Nuts cache may last until next year. I just counted. I only have eleven and a half boxes left. Today's plan was to finish some letters to the park service about Dry Bay residents concerns then begin work on the new outhouse. I got started on the letters, then a neighbor stopped in. After a nice visit we thought maybe last night's high tide may have washed in a glass ball so we went beachcombing. No joy with the glass ball but we did load up on glacier ice for the coolers. Each tide brings in new things to explore on the beach. The tides also re-arrange all the stuff already on the beaches. Today there was this log with a different texture and color than most I see out there. Some of this wood would make beautiful furniture. Tomorrow though, with the tides, it may not be there... never to be seen again Back at the cabin I called the vet to see if he needed some ice for his coolers. He came over for the surplus ice and talked us into going fishing. We caught a couple. I released them. Maybe next time I commercial fish I will keep a few to smoke and send home to Colorado. By late afternoon I did get the letters finished. We traveled the back trails to the neighbors for dinner. The way home seemed much shorter. Maybe the two bourbon and waters had something to do with that. Now to get started on the new outhouse....maybe tomorrow!

Woke up to a light mist this morning that turned into light rain most of the day.  Late this afternoon it cleared up a little.

We went down to the river this morning to put the wheels under the boat and relocate it for the next fishing opening.  The water was so far out and the boat so far up on the bank there was no way we could push it into the water.  So we went beach combing instead.  I usually drive the wheeler just below the line of debris the tide leaves behind  that is where it leaves some of the glass floats we look for.  Cheryl usually rides above the tide line looking from that side.  We found one float that had been washed up near where she found her first one on Tuesday.  On the way back to the cabin, riding below the tide line there was another glass float.  It wasn't 10 feet from the tracks I had left going the other way earlier.  During that short while that second float had washed ashore.  I felt like the ocean had given us a special gift.

The tide had still not come in far enough to push the boat into the water so we came home, did some chores, I took a nap and did a little fishing.  I caught a large Chum Salmon and had a Sockeye on for a little while.  Between its jumps and summersaults it threw the hook.  I would have let it go anyway.

The tide this evening was much higher so after dinner we were able to get the boat far enough into the water to get the wheels under it and pull it back to the cabin.

I got all the wood split that was cut.  Another couple of logs should be enough to last until I am ready to leave.  I want to have some stashed away so next spring when I come up there will be some dry wood to get me going then too.   I watched few more geese  heading down the coast this evening as I was fishing.  Every day now I see a few lines of geese moving south across the sky.  Before long it will be a constant sight, millions of birds of every description heading in the same direction.  This old bird has to face the fact that in six weeks or so he will have to head that way too.  I'm not looking forward to the trip.

The day started out beautiful then it clouded up then turned nice again then rained then, as I type this, it is cloudy with an occasional drop from the sky. Today's to do list: Put the registration letters on the boat, check the fishing net and load it in the boat, fix the kitchen outlets that don't work, place a marker on the riverbank staking out my spot, move the boat to the river, work on the outhouse. In the part of the day described in the first sentence as "then it turned nice again" we decided to go up to a place near the head waters of the East Alsek River where the salmon spawn.  It is about a 20 minute ride on the wheeler. There the stream flattens out and is very shallow. There were thousands of Sockeye milling around, seeking mates and spawning. We didn't think to wear waders but there was so much to see we just walked out into the water that was over our boots to watch this marvel of nature unfold. Males chasing females, pairs mating, females protecting their reeds (nests), spent fish slowing dying: This old guy, his race having been run,  hung in the quiet water by my boot for a minute or so then, without any more energy to spend, drifted off down stream. Down stream there was a lot going on. We first noticed two bears, then another pair came into view, then they all ran off in the same direction. Out of the brush on the left a huge brown bear came into view. I understand they have their favorite fishing spots and I guess the others were in his spot. The first four bears may have been sows with cubs. There is commercial fishing to do tomorrow. If the fish are in I will keep busy with that for a few days. If it is slow we will go back up to the spawning grounds, maybe take a plastic chair and a tripod for the camera, wear waders, sit in the middle of this beautiful stream and let nature sweep us away. It is so beautiful....the outhouse can wait...

No luck this morning finding any treasures or any glacier ice at the mouth of the river this morning,  I had hoped to pick up some ice to keep the fish I intended to catch cold.  Since there was a 10 foot tide last night I was surprised we had no luck.  An even higher tide comes in tonight and there was a pretty stiff wind this morning.  Maybe those two things will make tomorrow a more productive day for us beachcombers.

I had a pretty good day fishing.  Caught 29 salmon that were saleable and probably another dozen Pink salmon.  There is no market for them down here.  It costs more to ship them out than they are selling for in town.  So the eagles and gulls are happy.

A bear showed up while I was sitting in the boat watching the net.  He was pretty far away and seemed to realize with a human tending the net he should wait till later to see if the eagles and gulls had left anything for him.

At the fish plant tonight I think we made some progress in having a couple of barrels of gas delivered.  This is the last week Yakutat Seafood is buying fish down here this year.  If I don't get the gasoline in the next couple of days I may have to start rationing myself.  I had hoped to have the extra fuel in reserve so next spring when I come back there would be a supply on hand.

Their decision to close their operation here early this year has thrown a wrench in the plans of several fishermen.  Some will move on to other things sooner than planned.  Another couple of men will just go back home in the lower states earlier than usual.  I'm staying on for a while.  If you have been following these musings you know I may finally get around to building that new outhouse after all.

It was 48 degrees this morning when I got up.  This afternoon there was a legitimate downpour for about 15 minutes.  Guess who was trying to get the net stowed and the fish moved in all that.  Everything turned out OK though.

It is a shame there is such a weak market for Pink Salmon.  The fishing was good this morning.  This afternoon I caught the same number of Chum salmon ($.48 per pound) as I did sockeye ($1.48 per pound) and as many Pink Salmon as the other two combined ($0.00 per pound).  I changed nets this morning.  Using a larger size (5.5" vs 5.25") mesh lets smaller fish swim through the net.  The larger mesh also makes it some easier to get the Pinks out of the net.  No telling how many Pinks I would have had to pick if I had stayed with the smaller mesh.

The biggest catch of the day in volume and in weight was moss.  The clear water and the very warm weather we have been having has caused the river to produce an enormous crop of moss.  As the tide goes in and out, along with the river's current the net catches moss from both directions.  The river actually flows backwards when there is a strong incoming tide.  So, the moss that flowed down stream on an outgoing tide, comes back upstream on the next incoming tide.  There is so much sometime all you do is pull the boat back and forth along the net shaking the moss out of the net.  When the net is clogged with moss it is VERY heavy and the fish just won't go into the net.

Bottom line is today was my last day of commercial fishing for this year.  Cheryl and I hope to catch enough sockeye sport fishing to smoke a batch.  The way the sockeye run has dropped off I may end up smoking silver salmon.  That will be OK but they are not as tasty as the sockeye.

I got a note today that a man whom I admired and who also dearly loved the outdoors passed away.  Peter Weil will be missed.

Forty five this morning. Had the window by the bed open last night. It was hard to get out from under the blanket to get the wood stove and coffee going. Three of us had been commercial fishing this week. Yesterday was my last day. The fishing was slow and with Cheryl here I thought we could be spending our time in better ways. More about that shortly. Today is apparently the last day for the other two fishermen. On the commercial side there just are not enough fish moving up the river to make it worth while. However, on the sport fishing side things were different for us. We went upstream from where the commercial fishing is allowed. There is a large confluence of two streams there that make a shallow lake. It is probably a half mile across in one place. That water was full of fish. The fishing was difficult. The water is about three feet deep and the moss is about one foot deep. So you have two feet of clear water to swim your fly or lure through without getting all tangled up in the moss. We finally got it figured out with the right weight lure and retrieve speed. We will probably go back up there....nope we will go back up there in the next day or so. This time we will try to use lures that float on the surface. The silver (Coho) salmon we were catching were particular about what color fly we were using. If it was bright pink they would attack it. Other colors they tended to ignore. One of the fly rods we were using is a 5 weight. What that means is it is designed to be used on fish in the 1 to 5 pound range (my opinion). These salmon today were running up to 12 pounds. On that light tackle it took a while to land these guys. Cheryl did a great job all around. Casting, hooking, landing and releasing the fish we didn't want to keep. We stopped fishing when we had eight. Fileted them at the cabin and had beer battered salmon with rice and vegies for dinner. Very very good. The plan is to smoke the rest. It is going to be hard to stay at the cabin and tend the smoker with all those other fish up there. Life is so tough sometime. One other thing.  While we were fishing there was a bear on the other side of the lake.  It was fishing too.  The bear would walk along in the water then suddenly charge ahead, water flying in every direction then it would walk again.  I'm sure it was chasing fish.  It was too far away to be able to tell if he caught any.  I bet it did though.  Why spend all that energy with no reward.

It was supposed to be rainy today but it just looked like rain most of the time.

We got some neighborly things done today.  The neighbor who has had his 92 year old Mom with him most of the summer asked if Cheryl would help her take a shower here since they don't have one at their cabin.  She is a really sweet lady.  ( Both the Mom and Cheryl) She, the Mom,  flies back south tomorrow.   Cheryl also prepared another wonderful salmon dinner for the Vet and me tonight.  There are so few of us left here it seems our cabin has become the community gathering spot.

We caught our limit of silvers again today.  Cheryl limited out first and she also caught the biggest fish.  I thought today when I quit taking her fish off the hook I might be able to overcome her angling advantage over me.  Not so.  She still out fished me.  I enjoy listening to her tell the fish she is being as gentle as she can be while taking the hook out.  She and the fish also converse, or seemingly so, when she is releasing one back into the river.  They both enjoy that.

Another sign of fall.  Today. several flocks of ducks in addition to the geese were flying south.  Other wildlife sightings include a curious weasel holding a vole.  It stood up in the middle of the road as I approached on the Honda.  It seemed to be saying "what are you doing on my road...what ever....I'm too busy to hang around here" and it scurried on off into the brush.  There were several seals in the surf today.  One was almost completely out of the water.  It had a salmon in its mouth.  The next wave came in and it was gone.

A couple of needed deliveries arrived.  The battery has supposedly been returned from the hardware store.  I will know for sure when I return the empty drums the gas was delivered in.  Best news of all the missing/lost iPad has been found and is back here in the cabin.

Today or tomorrow a sort of milestone will be reached for this site.  The one thousandth visit to NOTES FROM ALASKA will have happened.  I have enjoyed reliving most days here at the computer.  I appreciate the kind words some of your comments have contained.

It was supposed to be rainy today but it just looked like rain most of the time.

We got some neighborly things done today.  The neighbor who has had his 92 year old Mom with him most of the summer asked if Cheryl would help her take a shower here since they don't have one at their cabin.  She is a really sweet lady.  ( Both the Mom and Cheryl) She, the Mom,  flies back south tomorrow.   Cheryl also prepared another wonderful salmon dinner for the Vet and me tonight.  There are so few of us left here it seems our cabin has become the community gathering spot.

We caught our limit of silvers again today.  Cheryl limited out first and she also caught the biggest fish.  I thought today when I quit taking her fish off the hook I might be able to overcome her angling advantage over me.  Not so.  She still out fished me.  I enjoy listening to her tell the fish she is being as gentle as she can be while taking the hook out.  She and the fish also converse, or seemingly so, when she is releasing one back into the river.  They both enjoy that.

I may have picked up a bad habit today. I started smoking. When you inhale that delicious aroma, well there is nothing like it. I coughed a little at first but the benefit is worth a little discomfort. The very idea of my next smoke makes me want plan ahead for it so I can experience it more fully. I admit I felt like I needed a shower afterward because of the smoke in my clothes. This was one of those flavored smokes....Alder...Our first sample of the smoked salmon was fantastic. This is the second time the smoker has been used this year. It is a plywood cube about 4 feet on each side. Colorado neighbor, Rick, used it earlier. With this smoker you build the fire in an improvised (old Honda wheel) container directly under the fish which are on racks near the top of the cube. So to add wood to the little smoking fire you have to open the door. When that happens all the smoke comes pouring out, the little fire may flair up and you are blind for a few seconds from all the escaping smoke. I think I will work on a scheme where the fire is outside the smoker but through a chimney arrangement the smoke and heat goes through the cube. I'll get right on it after the outhouse is built. A couple of the old timers still here have stopped by each of the last two mornings. They have been moving their boats and gear from over here on the East River back over to the Alsek. That is where the next commercial fishing will be next June. Yesterday after coffee and strategizing with them Cheryl and I went beachcombing. She found another glass float. I went back up to the spawning grounds in the afternoon. Didn't see any bears but there are still hundreds of spawning sockeye. Today it was misting when we got up and continued to rain harder and harder all day. The wind has been gusting at 20 mph, averaging about 11 mph all day. It was a good day to stay near the cabin and smoke. There was a very high tide this afternoon and the south wind added to it. The water in front of the cabin had not been this high since last spring. It was so blustery today the migrating ducks settled in out in front of the cabin rather than fight the headwind.

This morning we vacuumed the salmon that got smoked yesterday afternoon and evening. The high tides and the erosion they cause called us back out onto the beach to beachcomb. I don't know why that is so relaxing and if you find something interesting even more so. Cheryl found this one and just a few yards from where I found one to. When we got back to the cabin one of the neighbors came by. He asked if we had heard the latest about Cheryl's flight out on Monday. We had not. Yesterday I sent a note to the bush pilot asking to reconfirm the time she would be picked up. Turned out the office staff and the pilot were not on the same page. The earliest they could pick her up was Wednesday afternoon. Having no sat phone, all I could do was email or use Skype to contact them. After some juggling of things the office asked if we could be ready to go at 4:00 this afternoon. To quote Cheryl, "a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush" we said we could be ready. When asked where the pilot should meet us we checked the tide tables and discovered there was no way he could land in front of the cabin as hoped. (see the pic from yesterday) There would be way too much water on the beach runway. So that meant we needed to drive over to the fish plant across Dry Bay. The high tide also meant we had to go the long way. A forty minute ride. It was already after two. She got her stuff together and I packed the cooler with fish. Earlier I had sold the old outboard to a guy in Yakutat. How to get it to him was a problem. Since Cheryl was being picked up in a larger plane there was room for the outboard too. There is no way I could lift a 75 hp outboard almost 5 feet into the air by myself. I got on the VHF radio and in just a few minutes a couple of neighbors showed up. By now it was raining steadily. It was after three. We had to take the long way to the plant to meet the pilot at four. In case the plane was early, one neighbor blasted off to let the pilot know we were on the way. The other neighbor followed behind Cheryl and me, watching to be sure nothing fell off the trailer I was pulling, with the outboard on it. We got to the plant with a little time to spare. Then we started waiting. The clouds had gotten lower and it was raining harder by now. Four thirty came and went. We had no way to get in touch with anyone since the fish plant is closed for the season. We heard a plane coming..it just flew on by. We were wondering if the weather was so bad the pilot had turned back. Do we keep waiting or go back home? Finally at nearly five we could tell from the sound our plane was coming in. Some dear friends in Yakutat picked up Cheryl. I thought they would just take her the short distance to the terminal and she would be on her way to Colorado. Not to be. It seems an Alaskan cruise ship has broken down south of here and some 3,100 people are trying to get home. From the news I read some planes have been chartered to get those folks out. As of this writing what I thought would be an easy ticket exchange might turn into an extended stay in Yakutat for Cheryl. I will probably know something specific tomorrow. We are fortunate the friends in Yakutat have a freezer. Sixty or seventy pounds of fish can't stay frozen on a cooler forever.

In the last two days it has rained over three inches and it is raining now.  However there were enough breaks in the rain to get a few things done.  

I returned all the stuff I had borrowed from the neighbors.  That last trip to Juneau enabled me to buy what I had used, bearings, plumbing and electrical parts etc. It was no problem returning things to those neighbors who have already left.  Everyone just closes up their cabins and arrange some way to keep the doors from blowing open.  No locks required.  We are so remote here there would be no point in locking things up.  A lock or boarded window would just slow a thief down a little.  No one has ever had a problem with things disappearing.

Yesterday and again today I found gaffs that had washed ashore.  These tools are used by fishermen to pull fish aboard the fishing boats at sea.  Wooden handles about two feet long with a stainless steel, pointed hook on the end.

The one neighbor who was home gave me some firewood.  Using his trailer I made a wrong turn crossing a slough and stuck the wheeler in some wet sand.  The machine was down to the frame in the quicksand with this trailer full of wood behind it.  Fortunately the trailer was still on a solid surface of gravel.  By unhooking the trailer I got the wheeler unstuck by lifting alternately the front then the back of the machine.  By raising it just a little enough of the liquid sand would run under the wheels that I could get it out.  From a new spot I  pulled the trailer backwards till I could get hooked back up again. 

Just before I got stuck I was able to watch a single Trumpter Swan across the slough for a few minutes.  The camera is acting up so the pictures I took are poor.  I may go back with the better camera and try again.

Cheryl is in the air somewhere over British Columbia as I type this.  She was able to change tickets at no cost and will arrive back in Boulder a day earlier than planned.  Neighbor Joe stopped by for a few minutes late this afternoon.  As he was leaving the jet Cheryl is on flew over.  We waved but between the clouds and her altitude she probably didn't see us.

The weasel was hunting around the wood pile this afternoon.  The little stream in front of the cabin is Dog Salmon Creek.  Today I saw three salmon summing up it to spawn.  According to the old timers the silver salmon should start coming in in big numbers over the next few days.  It will be enjoyable to have these magnificent fish swim by the front door.  I am one lucky guy.

A nice day mostly.  A little shower this afternoon while I was fishing, just enough to force the rain gear out of the tote on the back of the wheeler.

I thought the fishing would be especially good at first.  I caught two nice silvers in the first 15 minutes.  A half hour later, after changing flies, another couple of hits.  Kept changing flies and catching a couple then they would get lock jaw.  I threw a pink top water bug at them for a while.  It is really exciting to see a wave of water, like an underwater torpedo or miniature submarine, racing toward your fly.  Several did this afternoon but would turn away at the last second.  I guess they were not into pink today.

I did hook a world record silver though.  I'm sure it was the world record.  It was a very large fish.  It gave me the best fight of the day.  Long runs, taking lots of line off the reel.  A very bright and silvery fish.  He was so big when he would run toward me I was looking for a way to get out of his way.  Huge fish....He got away.  I did end up catching and releasing six or seven.

Back at the cabin I checked the river out front.  One of the neighbors from across Dry Bay has a sport fishing facility.  He has an arrangement with an outfitter in Canada (Canada is only about 40 miles away by air).  This Canadian outfitter has clients from all over Europe.  Today he had six guys from Germany fishing here.  You know it must be an expensive trip to come here from Europe.  Those men, I am sure, are used to life's finer things.  Here they are riding in a wooden trailer, open to the elements, being pulled by a Honda.  At least the trailer had springs so the ride couldn't have been too rough.

Got an earlier start than normal today. I decided I would finish the outside of the new windows before I would go play. No fishing, no beach combing, no visiting, just finish the outside of the Windows. A couple of times I thought about looking up the definition of self - discipline to see if there was a way, a loophole, I could use to sneak away. One of the other fishermen came by. He can usually count on a cup of coffee and some conversation. I think we were both hoping it would rain so we could change our work plans but alas it did not. What I did manage to finish was replace/repair the shingles around each of the five first floor windows. Getting the old windows out required removing the shingles that surrounded them. Now there is only one window to go. I need a ladder to reach it. Another day like today and it will be done too. There were no fish down at the mouth of the East River this afternoon. Up stream a little ways I hooked up with a "runner". That fish hit the fly as soon as it hit the water and it never slowed down till it had nearly all the line off the reel. I did manage to get him turned then he threw the hook. I was using a sapphire blue fly my Utah brother-in-law tied. Very pretty and sparkly...on a barbless hook. No wonder that, probably another world record, fish got away. Farther upstream, right in front of the cabin I caught three more. I had to keep one but the uninjured ones I returned to the stream. These fish were riding the incoming tide. Fresh out of the ocean they were returning to where they were born about four years ago, letting the incoming tide help them on their way. As the tide came in the pod of fish I had been casting to moved on. The peak of Mount Saint Elias is over 18,000 feet high. Mount Saint Elias, also designated Boundary Peak 186, is the second highest mountain in both Canada and the United States, being situated on the Yukon and Alaska border. On clear days I can see it out the front window. Today I could see it for a while. It was covered with snow. In June the sun sets well to the right of Saint Elias as I look out the window. Now the sun sets far to the left of the mountain. I am noticing all these hints Mother Nature is giving me about the season here being almost over. I am try to ignore them.

Woke up during the night to a hard rain on the metal roof of the cabin.  Sunrise brought a nice day.  The next couple of days are supposed to be that way too.  Then, if the forecast is correct, a spell of sixty per cent or greater chance of rain for several days in a row.

I picked up some more glacier ice first thing this morning.  That clear ice will last nearly ten days in the new chest type cooler.  That makes not having a refrigerator no big deal.  I can keep anything cold that needs to be cold with ice from the glacier.

There were a few fish moving in the river.  I cast a few times.  Caught one nice male silver salmon.  I gave it to the Vet.  He and his trusty companion, Bennie, were fishing nearby.

In about ten days all the other fishermen will have left for other places.  In a way I'm looking forward to having all this beautiful place to myself.  In another way I will miss the banter that goes on when two or three of us get together.  

I started on the new outhouse today.  I started by building a frame of pressure treated wood around the four foot deep hole I dug a few weeks ago.  I hadn't even nailed the four pieces of wood together before I fell into the hole.  Glad I was working on the new privy and not repairing the old one!

This morning about 2:00 I got up and noticed the strange light outside. It was a soft blue light. It was bright enough that I could see things around the outside of the cabin even though there was no moon. The night was very, exceptionally clear. The bluish light was starlight. I went outside and could see the Milky Way stretch across the sky above. One cold winter night years ago Peter and I could see the Milky Way from the deck in Colorado. Last night was the second time I recall ever seeing it. Our planet is just one in the millions that make up our galaxy. I was seeing in the Milky Way just a part of our neighborhood. Makes one feel sort of small. Good progress in the "privy" today. If I don't have too many interruptions (two unplanned coffee breaks and one urgent fishing report today) I may get the roof started tomorrow. I really don't mind the interruptions. A discussion in one of the coffee breaks resulted in my decision to install a FDS* in the outhouse. I had been considering an FDS* but the fine tuning of the design was completed during the coffee breaks. I had to wait to take action on the urgent fishing report. Determined to get the third wall of the structure covered I was finally able to hit the river about 5:30. Large pods of fish were moving upstream. I lost count of how many the Vet and I caught. One of the other old timers was watching us fish. There were so many fish coming through I told this observer "I'm going to catch a fish in the next two casts." I didn't need to make the second cast. I cast a floating fly at them for a while. I had several fish attack the fly but failed to hook any of them. Cheryl took this picture last week. My cabin is just off the right side of this shot. This afternoon I was caching these fish just a few yards from where the eagle is sitting. This would have been a good day for anyone reading this to have been here.     *Fecal Deflection System makes sure everything goes to the bottom of the hole.... patent not pending

Got a good start to the day by catching Cheryl on a video hook-up. Back on the outhouse by nine. By five the roof was nearly done and it is about ready to test. I do need to cut a hole in it before the test though. If the weather cooperates I'll put the metal roof on it tomorrow, cut in a couple of windows and build the door. Pictures will be along shortly. That is where the fishing has been good until today. The Vet is in the background and Wild Flower (VHF radio handle) in front. My cabin is in the background on the left...There were probably 15 fish between Wild Flower and me when I took this picture. None of them would bite. I tried another spot upstream. No luck there either. I did see a mother grizzly and cub on the way back home. They were near where the picture above was taken. The clouds eased in late this afternoon. This picture doesn't show the mountains behind the cabin as green as they actually are. One of these days I'm going to leave the rod at home and just take the good camera. Maybe then I can capture a little more of the beauty here.

Got a good start to the day by catching Cheryl on a video hook-up. Back on the outhouse by nine. By five the roof was nearly done and it is about ready to test. I do need to cut a hole in it before the test though. If the weather cooperates I'll put the metal roof on it tomorrow, cut in a couple of windows and build the door. Pictures will be along shortly. That is where the fishing has been good until today. The Vet is in the background and Wild Flower (VHF radio handle) in front. My cabin is in the background on the left...There were probably 15 fish between Wild Flower and me when I took this picture. None of them would bite. I tried another spot upstream. No luck there either. I did see a mother grizzly and cub on the way back home. They were near where the picture above was taken. The clouds eased in late this afternoon. This picture doesn't show the mountains behind the cabin as green as they actually are. One of these days I'm going to leave the rod at home and just take the good camera. Maybe then I can capture a little more of the beauty here.

Yesterday was one of the nicest days we have had all summer weather wise.  Today has been the worst by far.  It has rained steadily all day with some spells of very heavy rain.  I'm guessing at least two inches have fallen.

Wild Flower, Hazel Creek, Good Times and I were treated to dinner at the Vet's cabin this evening.  The Vet's VHF handle is "The Old Fart".  Pork Chops, Chicken Fingers, potatoes and gravy, corn, two kinds of homemade bread and tapioca pudding for dessert. It was delicious and very much appreciated by all of us. I told the others I would host a meal before they leave on Wednesday.  The entry would be Grape Nuts.  I think they all said they would be leaving before I could get things ready and to not bother.

The fall bear hunting season starts tomorrow.  That means there might be a little more plane traffic in the area.  The hunting laws prohibit shooting game the same day you fly.  But the guides use their planes to narrow down where to hunt the following day.  

Good Times is hosting the first annual football bash at his cabin tomorrow night.  Good Times has a big screen TV.  We don't know who is playing.  We don't know what time the game might start. The bash was to start at 6:00 but at dinner tonight the fact that we are 4 hours earlier than Eastern time caused the bash time to be moved to 4:00.  I'm taking an unopened bottle of Maker's Mark Kentucky Bourbon.  It is about 4 miles through the Alder brush on an narrow trail to Good Time's cabin.  I should probably go easy on the MM cause it will be dark by the time I head home.

The rain kept me inside today.  The electrical wiring in the cabin was very, very basic.  One wire connected all the lights and outlets with no fuse in the system.  Now there is a circuit breaker panel and the lights and outlets are on separate circuits.  It still wouldn't pass Boulders building code but it is much better and safer than before.

Just checked the forecast. Sixty per cent chance of rain tomorrow but clearing to twenty percent chance on Monday.  I may be able to get the outhouse done then.

Hard rain through the night but none after dawn.  The last two days we got 3 & 3/4 inches.  I went down the beach looking for ice and a glass float.  No joy on either item.

The new outhouse now has a roof.  Tomorrow it might be finished.

Yesterday I described the wonderful meal the Vet prepared.  Today "Good Times" had us over to watch football and have dinner.  Scallops wrapped in bacon, tenderloin, rice, fresh tomatoes and apple-berry pie for dessert. Very delicious.  Denver was playing Phoenix.  One of the men, from Phoenix, wanted to bet on the outcome.  I passed.  Good thing too.  It seems the game was played last Thursday and he already knew the outcome.

Three of the fishermen will fly out for the season Thursday morning.  The plane will pick them up here in front of my cabin.  That means they will be bringing all the stuff they are taking out over here on Wednesday.  They will each close up their cabins early Thursday morning and meet here. I will be blessed/cursed with their extra perishable food. Since I will be the last one out of here I may end up hauling all that extra food to Yakutat where I'm sure there are some people who could use it.

As I left for the football bash, there were two Bald Eagles in the air right out in front of the cabin. I don't know if they were in a dispute, playing or courting.  To see these large raptors, their talons locked together, tumbling through the sky....  As they flew one would seem to be dominate then the other one would gain some advantage.  In my mind's eye this lasted a while.  In real time it was only seconds.  Have been sitting here replaying that in my mind for the last fifteen minutes.  I'm sorry I can't pull the words out to describe how spectacular that sight was.

Thursday might also be the day I can prepare a meal for the guys who are leaving.  Bacon, Eggs, maybe some grits and Grape Nuts for the topping.

We have been so lucky here this year. The weather has been nearly perfect most of the time. The proximity to the Pacific Ocean keeps the temperature very moderate. Some days the low might be 52 and the high 58. On really sunny days it might be 15 degrees warmer just a couple of miles back away from the beach. The Gala Grand Opening of the new outhouse got postponed for a day. In the picture below there are two KUBOTA vehicles. These utility machines are fancy ATVs with a cab, windshield and short hauling bed in back. The one farther away with the people is stuck. Down to the frame in sand. The nearer one has been trying to pull the one stuck out with a winch. The rope out the back of the close one is connected to an anchor to keep in in place. None of that worked. We were able to move the stuck machine only a little. The way we finally got it out was to take my trusty Honda around in front of the disabled machine and push while the second Kubota pulled with the winch.  The stream on the far right in both these pictures is the East Alsek river.  Thousands of pounds of Sockeye Salmon were caught in this stream right where the first machine is mired down. Wild Flower is packing his cabin up for the winter and is using one of my Hondas so he can store his while everything is dry. On the way over to his cabin I spotted these five Trumpeter Swans in the slough near his cabin. There will be more and more of these wild swans passing through in the next few weeks. Back to the Gala.. All I have to do to finish this project is cut some plexiglass for the two windows and come up with some sort of ventilation. I have a questionnaire out to see if there should be a crescent moon in the door. If you have an opinion let me know.
