Today was the big day. The grand opening of the newest outhouse in the Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve. There had been a little test yesterday, a number one test if you catch my drift, but today she is fully initiated. There was a small ceremony as the previous facility departed. Some of the features of this latest model include a padded seat (warms up quicker than hard seats) ample room inside to adjust clothes and a covered entryway so removal of rain gear doesn't get the inside of the facility all wet. The sides feature parallel viewing windows. Why windows? asked an observant reader in the Atlanta area. Two main reasons and one other not so main. One; its dark in there with the door closed. Two; when you are in there and you hear a strange, unfamiliar noise outside, (this is brown bear and wolf country) it is comforting to be able to see what might have made that noise without opening the door when your pants are down around your ankles. Three; I had a spare piece of plexiglass. As the fire roared in the background, there was an unexpected bit of pyrotechnics . Apparently, no telling how long ago, someone lost or left a bullet in the outhouse. When you are not expecting an explosion while burning down an old outhouse all sorts of thoughts collide in your mind. The first one I can recall was "OH SHIT". But there was only the one explosion and no "fallout". It was raining as all this was going on. The rain increased as the day went by. At times one could hear the sheets of rain sweep across the cabin roof from back to front. Tomorrow the three fishermen who are leaving will drop off their perishable food and the things they packed to take home. Around 9:30 Thursday the plane will pick them up. I will provide breakfast since they will have closed up their cabins and I will have the only working kitchen. An hour later. Now I have a place to put the dirt that came from under the new outhouse.  I think I'll add a little star to the door too.

The wind was blowing a steady 20+ this morning early.  Yesterday there were no gulls or eagles to be seen out front.  The rain and wind must have kept them in some sheltered spot.  Today they must have sensed the weather improving because they were back.  In the strong wind it was interesting to see how they took off.  All a bird had to do was spread its wings and they would go straight up into the air.  Once up 10 feet or so they would try and fly forward but it was a struggle for them.

The three fishermen flying out tomorrow have all their things stored in the workshop ready for the bush pilot to pick them up at 9;30 tomorrow.  I am to cook breakfast for them since they have cleaned out their freezers and coolers.  All that food is here now.

BUT WAIT....THIS JUST IN....  At 5:18 this afternoon an email was sent to me explaining the new pickup time will be 2:00 p.m.  I didn't check my messages till after eight this evening.  There was some busy radio traffic getting everybody up to date on the new plans.  This is the same air charter service that canceled Cheryl's confirmed flight.  This lack of ability to keep a commitment to paying customers is going to backfire on these people.

The list I'm working off of these days has chores that need to be done before I close this place down for the winter.  I'm quizzing the old timers about how to keep the hand operated water pump from freezing, do the 4 car batteries that supply power to the cabin need any special attention,  what is the best way to take down the internet dish,  do I need to change the oil in the wheelers before I leave, do you dilute the anti-freeze you put in the washing machine?  Stuff I haven't had to think about before.

It has been interesting watching these three men getting ready to leave.  One is still running around trying to get everything done that should have been done weeks ago.  Another is visiting those of us who are staying, saying good by with story telling and reliving the summer.  The third is riding around on the wheeler, paying a last visit to some of the beautiful places he won't see again for seven months.  When I ask them how they feel about leaving  the answers can be summed up with "I'm ready to go but I hate to leave".  I know their feeling...

A pretty good day weather wise. The forecast was 60% chance but it held off until eight this evening. Right on time at two this afternoon the beautiful restored de Havilland Bever plane landed in front of the cabin. These planes went out of production in 1967 but hundreds of them are still flying. Designed as a bush plane its powerful rotary engine allowed for a short takeoff and landing. The plane's design is not made for speed but load hauling capability. When asked if that was a disadvantage an engineer explained all it had to be was faster than a sled dog. Its arrival turned into a community event. Mail and parts were received and the three fishermen departed. All this took maybe ten minutes and there was no line at airport security. I believe some time ago I mentioned a green bucket that was along the side of the East River near the mouth. When I got here in May the bucket was about eight feet from the edge of a drop off into the river. On August 17th I took this picture of that bucket. It was about two feet from the edge then. Last night the high tide and river's currents caused the bucket to drop off into the river. In four months the river moved northwest eight feet. Farther up the beach the Alsek river is moving southeast at an even faster clip. This may continue or some storm or earth quake may change all this overnight. A month ago there was a meeting between the Dry Bay fishermen and the Park Rangers. As a result a couple of letters were written asking for permission to erect wood storage facilities at those cabins that needed a place to store firewood. The letters also asked that park management come to the meeting next spring to her first hand concerns about safety, road maintenance and various other issues. Today I received their response....The request for wood storage structures has been approved and the Superintendent will meet with us next spring!!!

Today was a good day to have a cabin to stay inside of.  The wind has been averaging over 25 mph all day.  I thought the swans had moved down here from back in the sloughs.  Nope.  Those large white things out on the river were white caps on the waves.

I saw sea gulls get blown over backward as they would try and take off.  Those that did head into the wind correctly just flew backward a short way then they would land again.  Most of the day they just sat real low on the beach, headed into the wind with their heads tucked away under a wing.

I went out to start the generator and again to turn it off.  That was the extent of my outside activity today.  Inside I wired the storage side of the cabin for electricity.  Now I can run the washer and freezer without using an extension cord.  I still need the generator to power them but I can hook it up to the house circuits now.

This afternoon was spent doing paperwork.  Not much to report there except everything balanced.  That's a good thing.

When people complain about storms I would like to invite them into a Tsiu storm. ... I'm sitting here this afternoon in 45-50 knot winds picking up wet sand & sand blasting everything , 4-5 inches of rain, people digging their boats out of sand. Of course I'm nice and cozy with my cocoa and hot stove but that's only because you literally shouldn't be going outside for any other reason then an emergency. Not even Keelah wants outside

Before this storm is over we will have received ten inches of rain in three days.   The rain and the higher than normal tides caused the beach in front of the cabin to become a lake today.  The water was higher than I have seen it since May.  There are flood warnings out for some areas with roads and bridges and such.  That doesn't apply to Dry Bay.  No roads and bridges and such here.

I'm not complaining though, just making an observation.  My neighbor's daughter and her husband are fishing on the Tsiu (sigh u) river on the other side of Yakutat.  It is a small river with lots and lots of salmon to catch.  It is also one of the places where the terrain makes it subject to awful storms.  Yesterday she posted the following on Facebook:

"When people complain about storms I would like to invite them into a Tsiu storm. ... I'm sitting here this afternoon in 45-50 knot winds picking up wet sand & sand blasting everything , 4-5 inches of rain, people digging their boats out of sand. Of course I'm nice and cozy with my cocoa and hot stove but that's only because you literally shouldn't be going outside for any other reason then an emergency. Not even Keelah (their bear dog) wants outside." 

If I thought complaining would cause the weather to improve I would but for now I'll just be glad I'm not up on the Tsiu.

Before this storm is over we will have received ten inches of rain in three days.   The rain and the higher than normal tides caused the beach in front of the cabin to become a lake today.  The water was higher than I have seen it since May.  There are flood warnings out for some areas with roads and bridges and such.  That doesn't apply to Dry Bay.  No roads and bridges and such here.

I'm calling that picture "After the Storm". Heavy rain, strong winds, three days in a row. A Coloradoan's song popped into my head this morning; Sunshine on my shoulders makes me happy. It did. Thanks John Denver. The water was up into the grass this morning as I was visiting with Cheryl on a video hookup. About 8:45 the plane that came to pick up the Vet and his two friends arrived. It circled a couple of times down by Mike's Cabin then started making passes over my place. I signed off with Cheryl and via the VHF radio asked the pilot if he wanted me to run the Honda out into the water to show him how deep it was so he could land. He said no but could I get in touch with Mike. Mike had closed down his cabin and there was no radio contact. Then the pilot proceeded to land in front of my cabin. I hooked up one of the trailers, put a tote on it, and proceeded toward the flooding creek in front of the house. The normally shallow crossing point was so deep I strapped the tote to the trailer so it would not float off.  If the water had been any deeper I would have had to dismount and float the Honda and trailer across. At Mike's we filled the tote with luggage and boxes of frozen fish. One of the guests and I went back to creek with this first load. I waded the creek and walked back to the my cabin and got the second Honda and another trailer and tote. We carried the lighter bags across the creek and floated the heavier stuff across in the tote. Now I had half the stuff on the side of the creek with the plane and the guest had an empty tote to use to get the rest of the fish and luggage. Same routine this second time. The only thing left to bring across was one of the guests who had on boots but didn't have waders. Mike had this guy step into an empty tote and he pushed the guest and the tote across the creek. I went back to them  and loaded the tote while the man waited in a spot of shallower water, he hopped back into the tote and was delivered, dry feet and all, to the plane( I think his boots were tall enough to keep his feet dry).... Now I have one Honda on each side of the creek. Up here a guy can't have too many Hondas. Spent the afternoon laying the rest of the laminate flooring. I put down about half of it in May and since I couldn't go anywhere because of the high water I finally finished the job. Was enjoying a libation while I watched the sun go down this afternoon. Sat the empty cup on the step of the workshop. I stepped away to get a better camera angle and the cup came tumbling down the steps into the yard. Guess who is back? These little critters are so curious and so fast. An old guy chasing one with a broom must be great sport for them. Exasperating for the old guy. If the water goes down enough tonight, tomorrow I will put the waders back on, wade the creek, get the Honda and do some serious beachcombing. The rain, wind and high tides surely have left some treasures out there for me.

The rain held off till mid-afternoon. That allowed the beachcombing expedition to proceed as planned. The beach had more logs and trees washed up on it than any other time this year. The Alsek river was running very fast carrying a tree past every few minutes. This ball was the only one I found at the mouth of the river. I was surprised there weren't more considering the tides, wind and rain we had. The story was a little different upstream a ways. There is a large sand spit the currents of the river have created. We frequently find some treasures there. Today was a good day to look there. I found three more floats. One of them was a small "rolling pin". They are pretty rare. On the way back to the cabin a couple of gaffs appeared. It looks like Patience and Skylaw each lost one.  The orange rocket thing is a  DATUM MARKER BUOY.  It is a search and rescue device that is able to track water current, direction and speed.  The Coast Guard deploys them from boats, planes or helicopters as needed to aid in locating an object or person in the ocean.  The fins are Styrofoam to keep the buoy afloat in a vertical position so the black antenna is always out of the water.  It can be dropped from as high as 500 feet at speeds up to 200 mph.  it has a transmit range of 25,000 miles and can operate for up 48 hours on the five D cell batteries it contains. (internet info) A label on the device said the batteries were installed on Feb. 5, 2013. From the barnacles it probably has been floating in the Pacific for some time. I don't expect the Coast Guard will come looking for it.

A light misting rain was falling this morning but it stopped about ten.  

I have this list of things I would like to get done before I leave for the season.  Today I was able to cross several things off.  The biggest one and one that had been bothering me the most turned out to be no big deal.  Over the years and through several owners the  location of the stove used for heat was moved at least 4 times.  Each of those locations resulted in a hole being made in the wall to accommodate the flue pipe.  The outside of the cabin had patches of plywood and or tin covering the holes.  Now the plywood and tin patches are history.  There were enough unused cedar shingles in the workshop to cover the four holes.  Now the cabin looks a little less severely rustic.  More like .... really rustic.

This week there have been Sandhill Cranes and a Great Blue Heron out front.  They have moved on.  I saw the heron head south.  I bet the cranes did too.

The forecast for tonight and all day tomorrow is 100% chance of heavy rain.  I have saved an inside job for that sort of day.  I am going to try and otter proof the workshop.  There is an opening about 5 inches wide all around the edge of the shop floor.  I hope to close all that up.

Tonight I found an unopened bag of trail mix.  The kind with M&Ms in it.  We had picked it up when in Juneau last month.  I wonder how long it will last if I am stuck inside because of the heavy rain?

Not much to report.  Spent way too much time trying to adapt a piece of netting I found to display some of the glass floats.  It was a piece of cargo net that was in such poor condition it was discarded.  Makes you wonder was it thrown from a ship at sea or did it float in from some harbor?  

The shop is now Otter resistant.  I hate to say Otter proof cause that is sure to invite trouble sometime in the months I will be away.  Those guys can make a real mess of things not to mention the smell they leave behind.  

The next couple of days are supposed to be cloudy but little or no rain.  There are a few more outside chores to do but they may have to wait.  Fishing, beachcombing  and photography have been neglect too long....Somebody's got to do it.

I take back all the complaining I did about the rain. Many of you know my full time residence is in Boulder Colorado. As I type this Boulder is shut down because of an extremely heavy rain storm. Boulder averages about 18 inches of rain each year. The last couple of days some parts of the area got eleven inches. People in my neighborhood can not get out because of washed out roads. All the rain here just kept me indoors and that was my choice. Not so for the people at home. Today was bright and sunny here. Beachcombing was high on my list for this morning. When I got to one of the better spots I found someone had been there before me. I believe this is a small wolf track. The animal checked all the likely spots for a glass float but neither one of us found one. At the next spot things were a little different. Notice my footprint in the left of the picture. I had missed the float on my way down the beach but happened to notice it tucked away in the roots of this tree on my way back.  I found three today.  One of them is perfectly clear.  No blemish from rolling around on the sand. Several times I have mentioned how dramatic the changes can be on the beach when the tides are high.  When I took this picture I was standing on the sand at the same level as the brush in the background.  The bench of smooth sand starting at the right edge of the photo is where I would have been standing before the last round of ten foot tides. Above the bench and below the top of this "wall" of sand are many little layers of sand.  This stratification shows how over the years different tides, storms and winds have laid down layers of sand.  In some places this "wall" is 20 or more feet high.  It is hard to see in the picture but some of these layers are primarily  gravel.  I wonder what happened up stream to cause this? More ducks and geese southbound this afternoon.  Those I watched were booking it while the weather is good.  No lingering to feed or rest today.  In the little creek out in front of the cabin I had noticed a few salmon milling around where it merges with the East Alsek River.  This evening I was able to watch Pink Salmon spawning in this little stream.  The female would lay over on her side and rapidly fan her tail on the gravely bottom to clear a spot for her eggs.  The males were near by, ready to do their part.  If the water were a little lower there would probably be bears out there watching too.

Another nice day here. Was able to exchange some emails with Cheryl. Everything seems fine at home except there is no power, the roads are all washed out, the power company can't get to the downed lines etc. because the roads are not there...washed away. Cheryl is beginning to ration the dog's food. I think she is supplementing their dry food with steaks from the freezer. Last night I was up at about 3:30. It was so clear I went outside for a while to just look at the stars. The milky way looked like a whiff of a cloud up there. The planets glowed steadily and the millions of other solar systems filled the sky with their radiance. No moon. None needed. I could walk around and see by starlight. Very special. This morning there were 4 more Sandhill Cranes out front. How can you find a glass ball while beachcombing and the ball not be on the beach? That's how. Find one suspended between two logs. Saw a couple of bears nearby today. The one in the picture was a fair size bear. It had some sort of growth on his snout. It didn't seem to keep him from finding salmon in the river though. He was a couple hundred yards away. About that far away off to the right of this picture were some sport fishermen. This was a good bear. He minded his own business and the humans did the same. After the fishermen flew off I went over to try my luck. There were lots of fish moving through. You might catch a couple in as many casts then nothing till another pod of fish would pass through. When a group of fish would be swimming through they would hit almost any fly you threw at them. I tied on a fly that floats on the surface, a popper. First cast I caught this beauty. With a surface lure you can see the fish take the bait. Sometimes they rush in, making a wake as they approach the fly. Other times they would come up from below, Jaws like. One second the bug is floating out on the end of your line, in a split second it is gone and your line is moving off in some other direction. I released all the fish. Next time the fishing is as good as it was tonight I am going to cut the hook off the fly and just enjoy the excitement of seeing the fish strike. Am I lucky/spoiled or what....

I had not planned for this wonderful summer in Dry Bay to end this way.

Last Wednesday it started to rain in Boulder, Colorado where my home is. This unprecedented storm dumped as much rain in the next four days as we normally get in some years.  Many of the roads are washed out.  Others are impassable because of rock and mud slides.  Some mountain communities  are completely cutoff with no utilities including water available.

The Sheriff  and fire departments encouraged all residents in my neighborhood and those surrounding to evacuate once egress-able routes were opened.  Once one did leave there was no way to return.  Cheryl decided she should leave and stay with a friend of her's in a nearby town.  With that information received via email I decided I had better get back to Boulder.

Had the one last neighbor I could reach with the VHF radio call the bush flying service on their sat phone and arrange for me to be picked up at four Saturday afternoon.  I got to Seattle about midnight and got back into Denver at six Sunday night.

We are staying in Longmont, Colorado where there is currently no Internet service due to the flood.  I will post this when I get to a place where I can.

For me it was a painful way to have to end my summer at the cabin.  Rushing to get everything closed up and winterized.  Unable to ease back into a mind set that accepts long lines, poor service, traffic, crowds.   I feel like I must have left all my patience with this real world some place where I haven't been able to find it yet.

When I can get back home I'll send out another note to close this season of Notes from Alaska.

Sitting here in a maple chair instead of a metal folding chair painted bright green.  The computer is on a granite counter instead of a piece of unpainted plywood.  I'm not concerned about the power the light above me is using, not on batteries tonight.  I'm not concerned about an occasional noise.  It was the dog asleep on the rug, not a weasel.  For dinner tonight there were several different things on my plate instead of the one thing I heated in a pot.  The washed clothes are in the dryer instead of hanging on strings strung throughout the room.  I took a hot shower and didn't have to listen to the 12 volt pump running.  When I press "enter" on the keyboard something happens without waiting.

I'm having a hard time adjusting to all this.

The officials allowed people who live in the flooded areas around Boulder back into their homes today.  We were lucky to be able to stay with a friend of Cheryl's instead of having to rent a room someplace.  By 10:30 this morning we had been to the store for provisions, stopped and picked up the 30 pounds of frozen salmon we had stashed in another friends freezer, had negotiated the morning traffic and a security roadblock.  In our neighborhood we walked past a washed out spot on the road to our house.  The plan was to get the Honda ATV and trailer, go back to the car and haul all the stuff in the car home.  The Honda had a dead battery.  So while Cheryl said Hail Marys (she isn't even Catholic) I drove the car around the washout home.

All the streams have new features now.  It looks like the creek below the house was four or five feet deep at one time.  Normally it is just a trickle this time of year.

But back to thoughts of the summer.  One of my favorite memories was of the Cow moose spending the night on a sand bar in the middle of the East River.  She stayed out there with her twin baby calves in order to see any predator that might be around.  Another favorite was the group of Brant geese that flew along side me as I went down the beach on the wheeler.  They stayed abreast of me for quite a ways.  When I would change speeds so would they.  When I stopped they landed beside me.  That was really special.

If you have been following this you know how much I have marveled at the wonders of nature I witnessed. But I must not wind this journal down without acknowledging the people that shared Dry Bay, Alaska with me.  They bailed me out more times than they should have.  They kept me from needing to be bailed out more than that.  When I did screw up they would smile and say, "we have all done that, sometimes more than once."

So with that in mind I plan to be back up there next May.  I need to keep practicing.  Maybe someday I will be known as a commercial fisherman in Dry Bay, Alaska.

A very beautiful day in Alaska.  There are two jet flights into Yakutat each day.  The morning, northbound, flight originates in Seattle, stops in Juneau, Yakutat, Cordova and ends in Anchorage.  That same plane turns around, southbound, and makes those same stops on the way back to Seattle.  I had a very busy morning getting a lot of shopping done for the cabin and caught the southbound back to Yakutat.

It was clear all the way from Anchorage.  I sat on the left side of the plane so I could see the continuous mountain ranges below.  They all still have snow on them down to about 1,000 feet.  As these warm days come more often one can see the snow line rise up the mountains each day.  Between Anchorage and the cabin there must be at least 50 coastal glaciers.  The rivers that flow from them to the sea are all a light gray color from the silt created by the glacier as it grinds across the stones.  Those rivers all have icebergs in them.  Some the size of garbage cans.  Some appear to be as big as city blocks.  The ice sheet at the head of some of these glaciers is the largest in North America.  To see all that white snow and ice then land at the cabin which sits in a temperate rain forest....we live on an amazing planet.

Neighbor, Harold met me at the airport and we flew on down to the cabin in his plane. The ghost of my extracted tooth was haunting me so I took some medicine to chase it away.  The weasel was here and greeted me with some news.  There is clear plastic stapled to the ceiling joists that holds the insulation up.  I could see the weasel moving around on top of the clear plastic but below the insulation.  As I watched I noticed some more movement above the plastic.

She had a litter of little weasels up there.  Harold's grandson and his girlfriend came over to see the litter.  Harold's son, Pat, wanted me to catch the weasels and put them in another neighbor's house.  I decided not to do that.

We positioned a deep Rubbermaid tub under the nest and cut the plastic around the nest.  The seven little weasels and the mother weasel all fell into the tub.  We took them about a hundred yards from the cabin and turned the tub on its side.  Out pops mom with a little weasel in her mouth.  She ran into the woods with it.  We left her alone and in maybe 15 minutes she had moved all seven of her pups(?) to some other place.

I came back from Anchorage with the parts to install another well.  This one will have an electric pump attached.  There may be running water at the cabin soon.  More about that another time.

Thanks for the kind comments about these ramblings.  I enjoy telling these stories.

Not much going on today except for all the wheel spinning I did.  I added some old gas to the generator and changed its oil.  When I restarted it it ran for about five minutes and would stop.  There is a sensor that shuts the engine down if the oil level is low.  I checked that.  The oil was OK.  Then  I decided it must have been bad gas I had added.  After pumping the old "bad" gas out and refilling the tank she fired right up. Five minutes later it shut down again.  I drained the carburetor thinking there might have some bad gas accumulated there.  Same problem.  I checked the oil again. It appeared frothy.  I had used some premium aircraft oil that was here at the cabin.  I drained the "premium" oil and refilled with plane ole 30 weight.  The generator has been running fine ever since.

Today was the day to get the fishing boat running.  More wheel spinning.  I cleaned out a gas tank.  Added the oil and gas mixture in the proper ratios.  Put the tank in the boat.  It was the wrong kind of tank.  Found the right type tank but then couldn't get the gas to flow to the engine.  Figured that out and now it runs fine.

The boat has some air chambers welded into it to keep it afloat should you get swamped.  Some water had seeped into those chambers.  There are two bolts one removes to drain that water.  I took the bolts out.  The water drained but due to corrosion or who knows what they would not tighten back up in their holes.  Those two bolts are now held in place wit roofing sealer.

The air temperature and water temperature are such that a fog has suddenly appeared then will disappear just as quickly.  That has been going on all day.  There is no wind so this fog just happens.  It is kind of weird.  Right now I can't see the creek in front of the cabin.

Rain is in the forecast.  There are a few pressing outdoor chores I would like to get done then I won't feel bad about staying inside and doing some administrative stuff.  Counting my blessings and maybe a few sheep.

It has gotten so just before I start to write here I look around outside to see if there is any wildlife to report on. Today I saw what were probably the same two bears twice. I saw the bears the first time when I was putting my fishing boat in the water. It is a very heavy duty home made aluminum boat about 18 feet long. Up here there is an ingenious way of building the boats so a trailer is not required to move them across the land. Two automobile wheels on short stubby axles slide into pockets near the back of the boat. You back the boat into the water, slide the wheels out and you are on your way. To go across land again, just park the boat in shallow water, slide the wheels back in and go. Very simple...in my case the shallow water required was deeper than my boots were tall. No real problem since my wet feet were close to home. After running the boat up and down the river a couple of times I came back to shore a little to fast. One second I am headed toward the shallow water on shore. Next second I'm looking at the sky. The boat has a very wide flat bottom for stability. When it runs aground one stops in a lot less than a New York minute. Well the boat stopped and I didn't till the space between the front and back seat benches caught me. Not a big problem except I was so far ashore I needed help getting the boat back in the "shallow" water to get the wheels back on. My neighbor Pat came over to help me get my nets in order for the season opener for salmon on Sunday. It is very complicated. The regulations are reasonable considering the catch has to be managed so enough salmon get through to spawn and sustain the fishery. For a newbe like me trying to understand webbing, fathoms and mesh depth which can all vary depending on the water you are fishing and the targeted fish. I have thought enough about it today. Later we took my boat over to the Alsek river (a huge fast river). On the way one of those wheels fell off. We got it back on without a lot of trouble. As I approached the cabin coming back the two bears were on my side of the river. Charlie, the neighbor's bear dog spotted them. Charlie weighs maybe 50 pounds. She went tearing out after these two grizzly bears. At first they just watch her barreling toward themselves. Then they seem to think, "who is that little thing kidding"? But she is coming at them so fast and seems so determined the two bears turn tail and run right into and across the river. Charlie came back looking very proud of herself.

Today we were supposed to fly out to the cabin. The plan was to be at the Juneau airport early and pack the single engine plane with two SUV loads of provisions. We would then fly northwest for an hour, land on the beach, taxi up to the cabin and unload all the stuff we had been accumulating over the past several weeks....no, make that months. Well...Mother Nature has gotten involved in our best laid plans. She has decided to rain and snow and blow so that small planes can't fly. They may not fly for several days. Two days ago the weather was beautiful. Nature is so close all around up here. Yesterday We saw 12 Bald Eagles sitting in the same tree. The Mendenhall glacier is just four miles up the road. The air is so fresh here it seems the source of it must be very near by. This is the first "official" note I have entered in this electronic journal. I'll add to it from time to time. The plan is to share with my family and friends some of the wonderful things I come across here.

MAY 15th. I have been keeping daily notes since May 4th but have not had internet access. Now that I do there are ten days of notes below. In the future there will not be nearly as much volume to read. Thanks for your interest.

MAY 4TH

Much has happened since I was able to add anything to this site. We were supposed to fly out to the cabin on May 1st. The weather was not cooperating so we stayed in Juneau another day. On the 2nd of May we were able to catch a flight to Gustavus and were treated to outstanding hospitality by our pilot and his wife. The clouds and fog were so dense visibility was near zero through a narrow pass called Icy Straights. The fog went all the way down to the surface of the sea….No place to be in a Cessna 206 single engine plane.

On Friday the 3rd. the weather forecast was very iffy. We were not sure when we might be able to get to the cabin. Considering that and a bunch of other details like, “once we get there will Cheryl be able to get out in time to make her connections back home” we decided she should just come on back home and I would make it out to the cabin whenever the weather would allow.

As nature would have it there was a break in weather and a narrow window opened and I got to the cabin about 3:00 Friday afternoon. It was raining. The weather service predicted 100% chance of rain, heavy at times. They were right. It rained, heavy at times, non-stop until 3:00 Saturday afternoon.

I have been spending much of my time just watching the spectacle in front of the cabin. As I type this there are three flocks of migrating birds in my front yard. There are nearly 100 Canada geese just to the left. Directly in front of me there is a flock of 37 Sandhill cranes and a little beyond them must be 50 Snow geese. Throughout the day I have watched this spectacle. Frequently I see a few Greater White-fronted geese mixed in with the others.

Bald Eagles appear fairly often. You can tell when one is approaching. All the birds feeding take to the air in one huge mass. As soon as the eagle has passed they all come back and resume feeding…right in my front yard.

I’m loving it.

MAY 5TH
Today would have been Mother’s birthday. She wouldn’t have liked it here but would have been happy that I’m able to enjoy all this nature.

It has stopped raining and the clouds are a little higher today. Late in the afternoon I did hear a small plane fly by. That means the weather must be moderating some.

Made good progress getting the outside cleaned up today. Over the years an assortment of plastic and fiberglass articles had accumulated. There were a few alder bushes that were blocking some of the view out the front. I had a heck of a bon fire going for a while. Some of that stuff made really dense black smoke.

Not such a variety of waterfowl out front today. There was a large flock of Canada geese out front late. I’m guessing 250 birds. They graze back and forth less than 100 feet from the front door.

As far as I can tell there is no one else here in the preserve. I check a neighboring cabin to see if their internet connection was working….it wasn’t.

MAY 6TH

Coolest morning yet. Thirty six outside. Forty seven inside. The stove works well and before long I’ll have it up in the middle 60s. There is some blue in the sky and I can see the mountains off in the east. There is beginning to be a tinge of green on the ground and the alders have little buds showing.

Decided to go down to the mouth of the Alsek River to look for glass floats. These baseball size glass balls used to be used to float the fishing nets used by the Japanese fishing off shore. I found a few.

On the way down the beech I saw my first bear of the season. At the mouth of the river a group of sea lions had gathered. The herd bull would frequently bellow or roar his presence. There seemed to be many young seals there too.

MAY 7TH

A beautiful blue sky morning with no wind. The heavy frost is quickly disappearing in the warm sunshine. Not many birds on the ground out front. It is unusual to look up into the sky and not see flocks of birds all heading the same way… North. As I type this an Osprey landed out front. The first humming bird just flew by. Got to get a feeder for them! Those sea lions mentioned yesterday…They are several miles away and I can hear them roaring here at the cabin.

Borrowed a neighbor’s hummingbird feeder. They are not here yet so I didn’t think they would mind. I put the feeder up about ten this morning. By noon several pairs had found it. All the hummers I have seen up here are the Rufous hummingbirds. We see them passing through Colorado in July.

I met another resident yesterday. I spent most of the day working on the storage area of the cabin. Hearing a little noise I discovered an Ermine (weasel) watching me. I hope she appreciates the redecorating.

Also discovered the freezer freezes and the washing machine washes.

MAY 8th
A little chilly this morning, 30 outside and 40 inside. Another beautiful morning. I was up around 4:15. The hummingbirds were already buzzing around outside wondering where their feeder was!

My neighbor flew down from Yakutat. He brought all the stuff I need to get the internet connection set up. He also brought provisions to begin stocking their cabin. He flew back to town and will return tomorrow with more supplies for his cabin. He will also bring the things to install the wood stove. I have been heating with an oil stove. With an endless supply of free fuel outside it seems silly to buy oil then have to fly it in.

While we were standing outside another resident came up from out of the woods. It was a fair size brown bear (grizzly). He went back into the brush before I could get some good close-up pictures.

MAY 9th

High human traffic today. The neighbor flew back in with a friend of his. He brought all the parts needed to install the wood stove. Now I have to decide if I want to use the old wood stove that was stored here or get a new one. It’s not only the cost of the stove but getting it here will be expensive too. A pilot we flew with last year stopped by. He had been delivering fuel to a bear hunter’s camp. He was flying a neat little “cub” that had skis attached just above the wheels. He could land on the beach or in the snow. A little later two of the guides from the bear hunter camp stopped. Whew! I didn’t get as much work done as I hoped.

Did get the attic emptied out. There was some high quality outdoor gear up there.

A couple of wildlife things. The hummers are drinking over a quart of food a day. The weasel was back in the cabin last night. I nearly swatted him with my cap as it scurried across the floor.

MAY 10th

Last night I installed new gaskets in the hand pump by the sink. Whenever I needed more water I had to pump that handle at least 50 times (I actually counted). This morning on the 7th stroke water appeared. That is so neat. To not have to work up a sweat to get a cup of water.

My neighbor has a portable saw mill. It comes in heal handy when you need more than a couple of boards that could be flown in on a small plane. Yesterday he found a fir log down on the beach over 40 feet long. Today we went down there, cut the log into 2 twenty footers rolled them onto an ingenious trailer and brought that huge log home to be sawed up into boards.

This afternoon we got all the internet hardware mounted on the house and the wiring done. I still don’t have a connection to the internet. We think it is because there are some trees blocking the clear view of the sky the satellite dish needs. So tomorrow I’ll be turning trees into firewood.

MAY 11th
I went down to the mouth of the Alsek this morning to do a little more beachcombing. Found one glass float that had appeared with the tide. A little later my neighbor stopped in. He had also gone down there. He found another glass float not twenty feet from where I found mine. I expect I was so pleased to find one I didn’t bother to look around for another so close.

The alder trees grow so quickly here they encroach on any clear space. So over the years they had invaded the space around the cabin clearing. I had been trimming them back for several days. Yesterday I spent quite a while burning them.

Nearby, the little weasel was very busy hunting for something.

My neighbor and his friend flew back to Yakutat around noon. He left the dog, Charlie, with me for the night. There had been a very light rain falling most of the day. When I went to bed it was pitch black inside. A little while later I could sense something very close. I turned on the light and Charlie was staring at me from a few inches away. Needless to say she wanted to be up off the floor. As far as I know she didn’t move all night….a good bed mate.

MAY 12th

I woke up this morning feeling an empty place. This is the first Mother’s Day in all these years that I have not been able to wish someone Happy Mother’s Day. To those Mothers who might read this …I hope you had a happy Mother’s Day.

A light rain has fallen all day. So, very major progress was made today on organizing the living space at the cabin. By the end of the week I hope to have a wood stove working, the shop side of the cabin organized and the internet working.

The rainy day has caused the humming birds to spend what seems like most of their time around the feeder. I filled the quart feeder after the birds went to bed last night. By 1:00 p.m. it was empty. It is nearly 8:30 p.m. now and I can’t see any food in it. They will have consumed over one half gallon of sugar water today.

Charlie, the neighbor’s bear dog, is still with me. I get to keep her until the weather clears and the neighbors can get back down here. Thanks to Charlie’s being on guard she alerted me to a moose just across the river this morning. We watched her for a while till she crossed to our side and disappeared into the brush.

MAY 13th

About 12:30 this morning Charlie started having a fit. I grabbed a flashlight and let her out. She kept running around the outside of the cabin. The little LED flashlight didn’t help much in finding out what was out there. About a half hour later she was still very agitated. When I called her she came in and we settled down for the rest of the night.

About 6:30 she started up again. I thought that is a lot of baking for the little weasel. Now Charlie was going under the cabin sounding more aggressive than ever. As I came back into the shop an Otter disappeared into a space along the wall. There turned out to be two otters.  Between Charlie and I giving them so much grief they have moved on to a quieter spot.

Good progress was made on cleaning up the accumulated stuff today. It rained on and off most of the day. Tomorrow if the weather cooperates I might start preparing to install the woodstove. I’m almost out of heating oil.

MAY 14th

Charlie got the morning off to good start for herself. She caught a sea gull out in front.

I did get started on preparing for the wood stove. The cabin has a plywood floor. Some time back the previous owner bought some laminate flooring but didn’t get a chance to install it. I got about half the floor done today. It didn’t go down nearly as easily as the last time I worked with that kind of flooring. Maybe sitting around in high humidity for several years had something to do with it. Anyway, now that the floor is finished under where the wood stove will be I can proceed to figure out to protect the floor and wall from the heat it will put out. I’m fairly motivated in that I am out of heating oil.

It was another rainy day. Fog came and went through the day. No small planes were flying. Because I am so near the ocean the temperatures stay very even. On a cloudy day like today the low might be 42 and the high for the day 48. All I have to do to stay warm is stay busy. Otherwise it requires several layers.

Since I have no radio and no internet I don’t know what the forecast is. Sometimes my little weather station shows the pressure going up. That means fair weather ahead. Then it changes its mind.

MAY 15th

The friends who are also neighbors arrived today. Three trips in the plane from Yakutat to get their cabins stocked for the season. Dinner with them this evening featured Beer Batter halibut for an appetizer. Meatloaf and red potatoes, fresh salad. All this was accompanied by great conversation and Buffalo Trace bourbon. It was a great meal.

I got the internet working late this morning. Now I can begin to learn how post pictures on this site so they are not upside down.

We got the outside chimney installed for the wood stove. I should have heat in the cabin tomorrow before noon.

Bright sun this morning shinning down on an inch of new snow. By afternoon it was short shirt sleeve weather. All the snow was gone as soon as the sun hit it.

A bear was just across the river early today. It was just ambling along trying to find something to eat among the sea oats.  The otter has moved up the creek.  It was under Lisa's house this morning.  The weasel is back with me.  I have a trap set.

As the weather improved, and at low tide, I waded across the river and walked up the beach for a couple of miles. On the way back I found another glass float. A very small one this time.

I think I mentioned the hundreds of gulls that are feeding on something in the river. They seem to be catching a small slender fish similar to a grunion (large minnow in size). These little fish come in to spawn in the sand. There are literally millions of them. After they spawn they die and wash up all along the beach. There were so many a few days ago neighbors flying in could see the lines of them washed ashore. They provide a real feast for some of the wildlife.

Tonight I was invited to dinner at Pat and Lisa's cabin. Steak, potatoes broccoli, and a wonderful slaw. Everyone in this part of the preserve was there. All ten of us.

Tomorrow I have to make an unplanned trip to Anchorage to find a dentist. I broke a tooth and it is requesting attention. While there I will do some shopping for cabin maintenance stuff.

I have to do some laundry before Alaska airlines will let me on a plane so I better get with it.

A very beautiful day in Alaska. There are two jet flights into Yakutat each day. The morning, northbound, flight originates in Seattle, stops in Juneau, Yakutat, Cordova and ends in Anchorage. That same plane turns around, southbound, and makes those same stops on the way back to Seattle. I had a very busy morning getting a lot of shopping done for the cabin and caught the southbound back to Yakutat. It was clear all the way from Anchorage. I sat on the left side of the plane so I could see the continuous mountain ranges below. They all still have snow on them down to about 1,000 feet. As these warm days come more often one can see the snow line rise up the mountains each day. Between Anchorage and the cabin there must be at least 50 coastal glaciers. The rivers that flow from them to the sea are all a light gray color from the silt created by the glacier as it grinds across the stones. Those rivers all have icebergs in them. Some the size of garbage cans. Some appear to be as big as city blocks. The ice sheet at the head of some of these glaciers is the largest in North America. To see all that white snow and ice then land at the cabin which sits in a temperate rain forest....we live on an amazing planet. Neighbor, Harold met me at the airport and we flew on down to the cabin in his plane. The ghost of my extracted tooth was haunting me so I took some medicine to chase it away. The weasel was here and greeted me with some news. There is clear plastic stapled to the ceiling joists that holds the insulation up. I could see the weasel moving around on top of the clear plastic but below the insulation. As I watched I noticed some more movement above the plastic. She had a litter of little weasels up there. Harold's grandson and his girlfriend came over to see the litter. Harold's son, Pat, wanted me to catch the weasels and put them in another neighbor's house. I decided not to do that. We positioned a deep Rubbermaid tub under the nest and cut the plastic around the nest. The seven little weasels and the mother weasel all fell into the tub. We took them about a hundred yards from the cabin and turned the tub on its side. Out pops mom with a little weasel in her mouth. She ran into the woods with it. We left her alone and in maybe 15 minutes she had moved all seven of her pups(?) to some other place. I came back from Anchorage with the parts to install another well. This one will have an electric pump attached. There may be running water at the cabin soon. More about that another time. Thanks for the kind comments about these ramblings. I enjoy telling these stories.

It has gotten so just before I start to write here I look around outside to see if there is any wildlife to report on. Today I saw what were probably the same two bears twice. I saw the bears the first time when I was putting my fishing boat in the water. It is a very heavy duty home made aluminum boat about 18 feet long. Up here there is an ingenious way of building the boats so a trailer is not required to move them across the land. Two automobile wheels on short stubby axles slide into pockets near the back of the boat. You back the boat into the water, slide the wheels out and you are on your way. To go across land again, just park the boat in shallow water, slide the wheels back in and go. Very simple...in my case the shallow water required was deeper than my boots were tall. No real problem since my wet feet were close to home. After running the boat up and down the river a couple of times I came back to shore a little to fast. One second I am headed toward the shallow water on shore. Next second I'm looking at the sky. The boat has a very wide flat bottom for stability. When it runs aground one stops in a lot less than a New York minute. Well the boat stopped and I didn't till the space between the front and back seat benches caught me. Not a big problem except I was so far ashore I needed help getting the boat back in the "shallow" water to get the wheels back on. My neighbor Pat came over to help me get my nets in order for the season opener for salmon on Sunday. It is very complicated. The regulations are reasonable considering the catch has to be managed so enough salmon get through to spawn and sustain the fishery. For a newbe like me trying to understand webbing, fathoms and mesh depth which can all vary depending on the water you are fishing and the targeted fish. I have thought enough about it today. Later we took my boat over to the Alsek river (a huge fast river). On the way one of those wheels fell off. We got it back on without a lot of trouble. As I approached the cabin coming back the two bears were on my side of the river. Charlie, the neighbor's bear dog spotted them. Charlie weighs maybe 50 pounds. She went tearing out after these two grizzly bears. At first they just watch her barreling toward themselves. Then they seem to think, "who is that little thing kidding"? But she is coming at them so fast and seems so determined the two bears turn tail and run right into and across the river. Charlie came back looking very proud of herself.

This will be a short one.  It has been raining all day.  I got a little done prepping  the fishing gear.  I have a dozen nets and at least that many anchors.  The nets are from fifty feet long to 150 feet long. The webbing is different sizes depending on what you are trying to catch. The webbing is a little to big for sockeye salmon but a couple of them will have to do for Sunday's opening. Two years ago today Nancy passed away. She was the best thing to ever happen in my life. I miss her so much.

This will be a short one.  It has been raining all day.  I got a little done prepping  the fishing gear.  I have a dozen nets and at least that many anchors.  The nets are from fifty feet long to 150 feet long. The webbing is different sizes depending on what you are trying to catch. The webbing is a little to big for sockeye salmon but a couple of them will have to do for Sunday's opening. Two years ago today Nancy passed away. She was the best thing to ever happen in my life. I miss her so much.

All ready to go fishing tomorrow.  Those two totes behind the four wheeler contain two  20 fathom nets, anchors and buoys.  The white box on the front tote is to put in the boat. If I catch any fish they will go in there instead of sliding around on the bottom of the boat. My neighbors have a cabin on the on the other side of the Alsek river. The plan is for me to stay over there with them for this first opening. As soon as I get back over here to my cabin I will bring you up to date on how things went. Last evening. I was sitting inside the bigger window and saw something brown move right under the window. It took up a lot of space on the ground. First thought was bear. It turned out to be a swarm of otters. I couldn't get a good count cause they were moving so quickly. I know there were five and maybe seven. As I watched they all went under the cabin. I proceeded to make much stomping noise on the floor. I didn't see them leave but they have because I didn't hear or see them at all later. If they had settled in under there I was going borrow Charlie to go under there after them. This morning one of the world's great travelers stopped for a visit. An American Golden Plover was on the front yard. The breeding habitat of American Golden Plover is Arctic tundra from northern Canada and Alaska. They nest on the ground in a dry open area. They are migratory and winter in southern South America. They follow an elliptical migration path; northbound birds pass through Central America about January–April. In fall, they take a more easterly route, flying mostly over the western Atlantic and Caribbean Sea to the wintering grounds in Patagonia. The bird has one of the longest known migratory routes of over 25,000 miles. Of this, 2,400 miles is over open ocean where it cannot stop to feed or drink. It does this from body fat stores that it stocks up on prior to the flight. Most of this paragraph I pulled off the Internet. There is so much nature here. As I took the picture above there were six Bald Eagles having a discussion across the creek behind me. I'm still loving it!

The bird has one of the longest known migratory routes of over 25,000 miles. Of this, 2,400 miles is over open ocean where it cannot stop to feed or drink. It does this from body fat stores that it stocks up on prior to the flight. Most of this paragraph I pulled off the Internet. There is so much nature here. As I took the picture above there were six Bald Eagles having a discussion across the creek behind me. I'm still loving it!

That is what a 32 pound King Salmon looks like.

Well opening day for commercial fishing on the Alsek river went pretty well.  The regulations permit one to start fishing at 12:01 p.m. on Sunday and you had to stop fishing with nets out of the water by 12:00 today.  That's the way it is every week while that river is open to fishing.  Each morning after an opening there is an announcement made at 9:00 informing fishermen if fishing will be allowed that day.  Sometimes you can fish for several days in a row.  That is seldom the case for the first week's opening.

"The Alsek River is a wilderness river flowing from Yukon into Northern British Columbia and into Alaska. The surrounding area from the Western edge of the Alsek to East of the East Alsek is known to locals as Dry Bay.  The Alsek and East Alsek rivers are a part of the Yakutat area limited entry set gillnet fishery. Both rivers produce King, Silver, and Sockeye commercially. Chum and Pink salmon can also be caught, but are not generally sought after due to their relative lack of worth/quality. These two rivers can be characterized as low volume fisheries, while the Alsek river in particular produces particularly high quality salmon due to its low temperature. The Alsek's silt content also prevents the sun from damaging the fish."  I did a little more research on the Alsek.  This afternoon its flow volume was 45,800 cubic feet of water per second.  For comparison at the same time the flow of the Colorado river at Durango was 1,300 CFS.  The Alsek is a BIG river.  Where we were fishing was in some sheltered water right at the mouth.  I could hear the surf in the Pacific as I sat in the boar waiting for a fish to hit the net.

Yesterday we dropped the nets in the water shortly after noon.  We stayed on the river till after eight last night.  This morning we left before 5:00 to resume fishing.  I was able to catch 4 sockeye yesterday and today brought in that fish I'm holding above as well as another King and a couple more sockeye.  My neighbors have a company that sells these fish directly to restaurants as far away as Newark, NJ.  That fish I caught this morning may well be in Newark Wednesday night.  I sell them the fish at the going rate right off my boat.  Then they clean them and pack them in Ice.  An air service will pick the packed fish up and take them to Yakutat.  There they are loaded onto one of the two jets that come through everyday, end up in Seattle where they are air freighted on to the restaurant.  Next Sunday we do it all again.  I expect in the next week of so there will be more days of fishing after each opening.

A cousin asked what happens to the parts of the fish that we don't keep?  Where my buyer cleans the fish is about a mile from the Pacific.  Today I took all the heads, guts etc. over to the beach and spread them out at the edge of the surf.  In less than 30 seconds after I pulled away ravens were there grabbing morsels.  In less than 90 seconds the first 4 Bald Eagles showed up.  After 5 minutes there must have been a dozen eagles swooping in to grab something.  Many of them would land but some of them would just glide in real low, grab something and fly off with it.  Another fisherman told me the eagles soon learn to associate the 4 wheeler on the beach at that spot with food.  When they learn that you can look up and down the coast and see eagles coming in from as far as you can see.

That image came from Google Earth.  On my computer if I click on the picture it enlarges.  That is Dog Salmon creek coming down from the top of the picture and merging with the East Alsek river.  The neighbors I refer to so often live in the cabin just above mine.  That is an unused air strip behind their cabin.  Now the planes just land in front of the cabins. Two kinds of geese were feeding in the front yard off and on during this day filled with showers.  Brant Geese and Greater White-fronted geese. The latter have beautiful coloration in their feathers. The rain kept me inside most of the day again.  I got the cook stove tuned up and tried the oven for the first time.  I know one reader who will be pleased to read I baked a loaf of bread.  I brought 25 pounds of flour up here.  Now that I have tasted success using some of it maybe buying that much was a good idea. The neighbor, whose cabin is just off the left side of the picture, has had a bear hanging around his place.  Tonight coming back from fishing (no luck) the bear was on the river bank in front of that same cabin.  I was maybe a hundred feet from the bear before I saw it.  One way to haze the bears and discourage them from hanging around too close is to make a lot of noise.  So not wanting to retreat and encourage the bear I down shifted and ran right at him.  He stood up to see what was causing all that noise, saw me coming at him, hollering and gunning the engine. I don't know what he thought but he went up the bank and disappeared into the brush.

Hauled wood today.  My neighbors to the North have the portable saw mill I mentioned earlier.  Their daughter and her husband are building a cabin nearby.  I will help them with the construction.  These people are so generous. The lumber in the picture, 20- 2x4s and 30 - 1x6 boards all sixteen feet long, sawn from logs salvaged along the river. Today we hauled six times that much lumber across Dry Bay to our cabin sites here on the East River.  Those boards are heavy duty.  When I say 1x6 that is the true dimension. A 1x6 you buy at a lumberyard is actually .75 inches by 5.5 inches.

It's about six miles across Dry Bay to where we unloaded the boats. The boats are used to ferry the lumber from the other side of the Alsek river. that is where the better logs are. We use the same trailers shown in an earlier post without the fish totes on them. There is a maze of roads across Dry Bay. I made three trips across and used three different routes. You could call those trips a learning experience. Several times I found myself someplace other than where I thought I should be. On one return trip I thought I would keep to higher, drier ground. Well what goes up must come down. The slight drop in elevation concentrated the water in one spot. When I got 1.7 miles (I had the GPS) from the cabin I got stuck. I started to walk out for help but decided maybe the 4 wheeler would pull itself out if I unhooked the trailers. That worked. So two of us went back, roped the two wheelers together and got the load out of the soft spot.

On the last trip over the bear that has been hanging around happened to be out in the open. I got to chase him for a few hundred yards. I wish the wheeler had a speedometer. I bet he was running 20 Mph while looking back to see if I was still after him. Consensus is that it is an adolescent bear and just hasn't figured out that the people who live in those big boxes we call cabins don't like bears in the yard. On the way back the bear was there again. Charlie and another bear dog spotted the bruin. Off they went one on each side of the bear. They harassed the beast till he went into the brush. Then the dogs trotted back to us looking so proud.

Where to begin? Should I write about the bear stealing a salmon out of a cooler in the front yard? What about the bear coming back two times that night looking for more and eating part of the 4 wheeler seat. What about being positionally challenged on the Alsek river at 11:00 at night or the cross country walk that got me to the cabin after midnight, then getting up at 4:30 to go check the nets again. Maybe it should be about pulling 17 sockeye keepers out of my net in one pass. I could finish up by describing how I am determined to learn more about all the things my GPS can do for me.

This was the second day the set gillnet fishing season has been open for the Alsek River this year. I fish two nets. I try and position them to catch the sockeye salmon heading upstream to spawn. There are also king Salmon on the river now and we catch a few of them along with the sockeye.

 

The picture is the view I have while watching the net. That big mountain is Mount Fairweather. Canada is on the left side of the mountain's peak. Mount Fairweather is over 15,000 feet tall.

The process of getting the fish from the river to your local fish market is not a long one but because the product is so fragile pretty complicated.

I sell the fish to Alsek Fish. They are a small speciality supplier to markets and fine resturants across the lower 48 states. I deliver the fish hole and am paid by the pound. Different fish bring different prices. Alsek Fish cleans the fish, packs them in ice and air freights the fish to its final destination. Simple right? Noooooo. To get the fish from the river to the air freight office requires a chartered bush plane to fly them there after landing on the beach. The fish are packed in ice. That requires an ice making machine that depends on a generator for power. The bush plane has a charter fee. The fish are packed in special waxed cardboard boxes. Specific labels are required on each box of fish shipped. Alaska fish and game requires certain paperwork indicating where the fish were caught and by whom. In all this process I feel very lucky to be in on the fun part. Just catching the fish.

I may fill in a few details on some of the other things I mentioned in the first paragraph some other time.

That is what we got done today. It is the floor of the cabin i'm helping build. In the background you can see m ore of the wood that was sawn with the portable sawmill. The deck is sitting on two creosote logs that had washed on the beach. Each of these logs are about 25 feet long.

The number of ducks and geese migrating North have really slowed down. There have been some new birds showing up that forage in the grass. The barn swallows arrived last week. The hummingbirds are still scarce but I have been assured they will return in a big way when the hatchlings fledge. Some good news in that the new four wheeler I ordered is in Yakutat. I have chartered a plane to bring it down here to the cabin. I'm also getting six barrels of fuel some groceries and stuff from the hardware store. I better start catching more fish to pay for all this. I did take my rod down to the mouth of East River to night. I saw one King Salmon roll on the surface a couple of times but he must not have been hungry. I did catch 15 Sculpin. These little aggressive fish could hardly get the lure in their mouths but tonight they loved trying to eat what I was casting. Three of the little buggers stuck their fins in me as I was releasing them. Tomorrow I hope to scout out a couple more places to put my nets when the next commercial season opens.

Another beautiful day. I spent the morning with one of the old timer Dry Bay fishermen. He showed me some places to set my nets on this side of the Alsek. Then we took his boat way up the river. In some places we could see very troubled water. Big swirls and whorl pools. The current was very fast. He had a depth finder on his boat. The water was 40 to 70 feet deep along there. A couple of weeks ago I reported here that the Colorado River was flowing at 1,300 cubic feet per second. The Colorado is a big river in that part of the country. A while back the Alsek was flowing at over 150,000 CFM according to my friend. It is a very big river. On the boat tour this morning he told me about the wolf that would walk along the bank where ha fished nearly every day one season. Today he pointed out a couple of Bald Eagle nests in trees right at the edge of the river. , When I got home this friendly bird was here to greet me. It looks like a dove but it has a squared off tail and a black band around its neck. The pictures I have of mourning doves don't have the black band and their tails are pointed. I appreciated this beautiful birds presence. Moving across the beaches you frequently cause the birds, eagles, ravens, gulls and other shore birds to take flight. The four wheeler doesn't have a speedometer so I don't know how fast I'm going but I figure at least thirty MPH. I think it surprises the birds when you pull up along side them as they think they are moving away from you. I call it "Racing Ravens". A big day tomorrow. A neighbor from Colorado is coming to help me for a few days. The chore list is getting longer every day even though I'm pretty busy trying to mark things off it. The plane I chartered will bring in the new four wheeler some plywood and lots of fuel as well as my neighbor. It will land right in front of the cabin. Late this afternoon I went King salmon fishing again. There were several in the river. One of them looked huge. A couple of them would follow my lure for a while then turn away. I did hook one sockeye but it got off. I'll just have to keep trying.

A big delivery today.  My neighbor from Boulder arrived along with a new four wheeler.  A couple of Dry Bay neighbors showed up and helped unload the newest toy.  It is convenient to have your air freight stop in front of your house. I have a lot to learn about this application.  As you can see below I learned how to make the pictures bigger after I uploaded the small one.  Now if I could learn how to put the text where I want it to be. After we got most of the big stuff put away we went across to the river and set a couple of nets.  Fishing was slow.  We only caught one sockeye.  The nets will be out all night.  Maybe we will have some fish in them come morning. I'll let you know.

I'll let you know.

My neighbor from Boulder and I spent most of the day helping build the new cabin next door. We quit a little after six tonight. On the way back to our cabin he told me it had been a while since he had had a 9 Advil day....We worked really hard. We got one wall framed and up in place. The second wall is framed and lying on the floor, ready to raise tomorrow morning. With any luck we will get the other two walls up tomorrow. We were invited to dinner at the parents of the new cabin owners place tonight. Fresh King Salmon poached in foil with the perfect spices. Green beans and rice. The correct libations were available too. Another neighbor and his mother joined us. Mrs. M is 91 years old. She spends most of her summer up here. She will ride from place to place on the back of a four wheeler. Crossing the Alsek river in an open boat to hop on another four wheeler seems to suit her just fine. After dinner we enjoyed listening to tale after tale about life up here. My guest is interested in studying otters. Since there are no more otters under my cabin he was told of another unused cabin near by where a group of otters reside. I wouldn't be surprised if those otters have a visitor from Boulder soon. We didn't see it but as a plane landed in front of the cabin a bear ran off the runway into the brush across the creek. After all the noise we made pounding nails all day I wonder if the bear had come out of the bushes to see what was going on?

I didn’t post anything yesterday. I stayed up at the mouth of the East River fishing later than usual and was just too tired. The surf was really pounding. It reminded me of the sounds a freight train makes when it has been stopped and then starts up again. As the couplings between the cars engage each other you can hear each car pick up the load of the following car. That clunk you hear that travels down the line of cars noise. Last night the waves coming ashore were sounding like that. Yesterday a guest at the neighbor’s house found a couple of glass fishing floats. One of them was 12 inches in diameter. Most of them are about 4 inches across. With all the wave action last night I thought there might be some good beachcombing this morning. There wasn’t a cloud in the sky early so by six thirty I was out the door. The power of all this water never ceases to amaze me. Today there were chunks of ice on the beach that had washed out into the ocean from the river, then back onto the beach some distance from the river’s mouth. One chunk was about half the size of my 4 wheeler. I did find three glass floats. Icouple of years ago I asked how you can tell if there are King Salmon in the river? I was told to look into the water and look for small logs. Those might be Kings. Today at the mouth of the East Alsek River there were logs in the river…. The fish I brought home was 42 inches long. I don’t know how long it took to land that fish. I had hooked a couple of others earlier and managed to land one of them. This fish felt different. To keep it from taking all the line off my reel I had to follow it down the river. I ended up a couple of hundred yards downstream from where I started. When I got back home the eagle was sitting in the tree in front of the house. I hope it keeps perching there. I like having my own Guard Eagle. The next commercial fishing opens tomorrow, Sunday. I will be going over to the other side of the Alsek River tonight. Hopefully there will be lots more fish to write about in a day or so.

Today we were supposed to fly out to the cabin. The plan was to be at the Juneau airport early and pack the single engine plane with two SUV loads of provisions. We would then fly northwest for an hour, land on the beach, taxi up to the cabin and unload all the stuff we had been accumulating over the past several weeks....no, make that months. Well...Mother Nature has gotten involved in our best laid plans. She has decided to rain and snow and blow so that small planes can't fly. They may not fly for several days. Two days ago the weather was beautiful. Nature is so close all around up here. Yesterday We saw 12 Bald Eagles sitting in the same tree. The Mendenhall glacier is just four miles up the road. The air is so fresh here it seems the source of it must be very near by. This is the first "official" note I have entered in this electronic journal. I'll add to it from time to time. The plan is to share with my family and friends some of the wonderful things I come across here.

I seem to be falling into a routine.  I get up in the mornings with a pretty full to do list in my mind.  After breakfast I seem to have trouble deciding which task to start on first.  Unable to decide on a task I just go play.  Today I drove down the beach to the mouth of the Alsek river to look for glass floats.  The Alsek is a glacier fed river.  The water is a light gray from all the silt the glacier creates.  Today there were several pieces of ice that had floated all the way from the glacier to the mouth of the river.  One of them was half the size of the four wheeler.  My neighbor collects some of the ice from the river to keep her food cold in coolers.  I found a rare amber colored glass float.  A Google search says the amber color is rare and the glass probably started out as a beer bottle. On the way back I saw something else unusual.  There was a beaver in the edge of the surf.  I thought beavers were strictly fresh water critters.  There wasn't a tree for this guy to chew on in sight. While typing this there is a bear across the creek in front of the cabin.  It is going the other way.  That is probably good. A couple of days ago I mentioned doing some laundry.  My neighbor's adult kids spend part of the fishing season on a very remote river.  To do their laundry they clean out the totes they usually haul fish in.  Then they pour several gallons of fresh water into the tote.  Add a little detergent, add the clothes then just drive around on the four wheeler pulling the tote.  The agitation caused by bumping along the riverbank gets the clothes "cleaner"! Looks like I have figured out how to add pictures.  This one was taken before the hummers took a break to go nesting.  The creek in front of the cabin I mentioned is in the background. This was the first bear I saw a couple of weeks ago. He is entering the brush just off to the right side of the cabin.

I seem to be falling into a routine.  I get up in the mornings with a pretty full to do list in my mind.  After breakfast I seem to have trouble deciding which task to start on first.  Unable to decide on a task I just go play.  Today I drove down the beach to the mouth of the Alsek river to look for glass floats.  The Alsek is a glacier fed river.  The water is a light gray from all the silt the glacier creates.  Today there were several pieces of ice that had floated all the way from the glacier to the mouth of the river.  One of them was half the size of the four wheeler.  My neighbor collects some of the ice from the river to keep her food cold in coolers.  I found a rare amber colored glass float.  A Google search says the amber color is rare and the glass probably started out as a beer bottle. On the way back I saw something else unusual.  There was a beaver in the edge of the surf.  I thought beavers were strictly fresh water critters.  There wasn't a tree for this guy to chew on in sight. While typing this there is a bear across the creek in front of the cabin.  It is going the other way.  That is probably good. Looks like I have figured out how to add pictures.  This one was taken before the hummers took a break to go nesting.  The creek in front of the cabin I mentioned is in the background. This was the first bear I saw a couple of weeks ago. He is entering the brush just off to the right side of the cabin.

I didn’t post anything yesterday. I stayed up at the mouth of the East River fishing later than usual and was just too tired. The surf was really pounding. It reminded me of the sounds a freight train makes when it has been stopped and then starts up again. As the couplings between the cars engage each other you can hear each car pick up the load of the following car. That clunk you hear that travels down the line of cars noise. Last night the waves coming ashore were sounding like that. Yesterday a guest at the neighbor’s house found a couple of glass fishing floats. One of them was 12 inches in diameter. Most of them are about 4 inches across. With all the wave action last night I thought there might be some good beachcombing this morning. There wasn’t a cloud in the sky early so by six thirty I was out the door. The power of all this water never ceases to amaze me. Today there were chunks of ice on the beach that had washed out into the ocean from the river, then back onto the beach some distance from the river’s mouth. One chunk was about half the size of my 4 wheeler. I did find three glass floats. Icouple of years ago I asked how you can tell if there are King Salmon in the river? I was told to look into the water and look for small logs. Those might be Kings. Today at the mouth of the East Alsek River there were logs in the river…. The fish I brought home was 42 inches long. I don’t know how long it took to land that fish. I had hooked a couple of others earlier and managed to land one of them. This fish felt different. To keep it from taking all the line off my reel I had to follow it down the river. I ended up a couple of hundred yards downstream from where I started. When I got back home the eagle was sitting in the tree in front of the house. I hope it keeps perching there. I like having my own Guard Eagle. The next commercial fishing opens tomorrow, Sunday. I will be going over to the other side of the Alsek River tonight. Hopefully there will be lots more fish to write about in a day or so.
