This weather today was perfect. Low 70s, mild ocean breeze, not a cloud in the sky. I got going early. Looked for glass floats on the beach by the Alsek River. Went back across Dry Bay to meet another fisherman to check out a few new spots for the next opener. He wasn't home so I checked on my boat and brought the gas tank home to refill. I must have the leaks fixed in the boat because there was very little water to bail out after sitting at anchor for four days. The garage has two big "barn" doors that open wide enough to be able to bring the four wheelers in to work on them or to store them over the winter. A pair of Barn Swallows has decided they would like to nest in there. They are very persistent about this. I had to chase them out with a broom several times today. There is an unused runway behind my cabin. There are a couple of other cabins alongside the runway. Tonight there was a community hot dog roast beside the runway. Almost everyone on this side of Dry Bay was there...all ten of us. One of the men used my chainsaw to clear some of the brush along the side of the strip. He said there was one thing wrong with my new saw. It seems when doing something like clearing brush you work till you run out of gas. The problem with my new saw is the gas tank is too big. We had a lot of brush to burn. Hot dogs, all the fixings, potato salad, graham crackers and marshmallows for s'mores. The only problem was the bugs. They have arrived. If you get out of the breeze and disturb them in the vegetation be prepared to be irritated. Insect repellent doesn't seem to deter these bugs. It is almost eleven p.m. The sun has just gone down but it is very light out still. The sky is cloudless except for the contrails of jets going from Anchorage to Seattle. Those are the only jets that fly over here as far as I can tell. I bet all those people on those planes are sorry to be leaving.

My neighbor from Boulder and I spent most of the day helping build the new cabin next door. We quit a little after six tonight. On the way back to our cabin he told me it had been a while since he had had a 9 Advil day....We worked really hard. We got one wall framed and up in place. The second wall is framed and lying on the floor, ready to raise tomorrow morning. With any luck we will get the other two walls up tomorrow. We were invited to dinner at the parents of the new cabin owners place tonight. Fresh King Salmon poached in foil with the perfect spices. Green beans and rice. The correct libations were available too. Another neighbor and his mother joined us. Mrs. M is 91 years old. She spends most of her summer up here. She will ride from place to place on the back of a four wheeler. Crossing the Alsek river in an open boat to hop on another four wheeler seems to suit her just fine. After dinner we enjoyed listening to tale after tale about life up here. My guest is interested in studying otters. Since there are no more otters under my cabin he was told of another unused cabin near by where a group of otters reside. I wouldn't be surprised if those otters have a visitor from Boulder soon. We didn't see it but as a plane landed in front of the cabin a bear ran off the runway into the brush across the creek. After all the noise we made pounding nails all day I wonder if the bear had come out of the bushes to see what was going on?

The weather has not been typical here. It has been many days since it rained. There is always a heavy dew in the mornings and all the plants are very lush right now . Some of the wildflowers are beginning to fade but others are just beginning to come out. The white lupines are not uncommon but compared to the blue ones they are a very small percentage of the total. In other words the blue lupines are everywhere. Acres and acres of them. The little shooting stars are past their prime but there are some places where their dark pink hue carpets the ground. Wild strawberries are blooming in every spot they can get a glimpse of the sky. The yellow Indian paintbrush have just come out and the side yard will be covered with daisies next week. There were at least 4 happy people at Dry Bay today. The young couple whose cabin I have been helping to build got to stand on their new second floor this afternoon. For me it was a special moment to see them up there experiencing the view for the first time from what will be their bedroom. I know it was a special moment for them too. They stood there, arms around each other feeling one of their dreams come true. Another happy person was my neighbor who is visiting. He caught his first Salmon with a rod and reel this evening. I don't know exactly what he was doing that I wasn't but he hooked twelve fish in his opinion, landed the one. I hooked the same log on the bottom of the river twice and that was it for me. I am supposed to guide some other fishermen later this summer. I guess if they catch all the fish they might think I'm a pretty good guide. If they expect me to show them how to catch the fish I may not last long as a guide The other pleased person here today was me. We got most of the remaining accumulated junk into a big pile and burnt it up. It is almost eleven as I type this and the stuff is still smoldering. By clearing out around the cabin I found a kayak buried under some of the unwanted stuff. It looks like it will float but I'm going to wait for the water to warm up some more before I try it out. a< href="http://www.notesfromalaska.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/image12.jpg">

Last evening I was too tired to post anything here. The commercial fishing opened up again at noon Sunday. The Alsek river is running very high due to the extremely long spell of dry, sunny weather. The snow in the mountains is melting faster than normal. That water accelerates the glacier's melting so many icebergs are coming down the river. Add to all that the super moon caused the highest tide swing (15 feet from high tide to the next low tide) since I have been here. All that water caused havoc with the fishing. The spots that usually hold fish don't. Trees floating down the river tear out the nets. A lot of limbs and twigs get caught in the nets causing the fish to avoid getting caught. I caught a dozen sockeye. Two of them were damaged in the net by seals. The buyer couldn't use them so I brought them home to eat. The last three nights my neighbor Rick or I have cleaned a salmon down at the creek in front of the cabin. A bald eagle sits down there waiting for us to toss a scrap into the water or up on the bank of the stream. As soon as we do the eagles pumps its wings a couple of times and glides over and snatches the morsel. It must have a nest near buy. It flies off in the same direction every time. In about one minute it returns looking for more. If there is another scrap nearby the bird has already seen it and is gliding straight toward it...ignoring me. The eagle swooshes right over my head, not ten feet off the ground. Even with my poor hearing I can hear the air passing over its wings as it goes by. By now other eagles have seen the commotion and have begun to gather. Also by now the scraps provided buy one salmon are nearly gone. It is a sight to see, these magnificent wild birds so close. Sometimes I think I'm pretty smart about figuring things out. Like the wire that serves as my clothesline. It was too short to reach the tree and even if it did it would sag. So I used one of those ratchet straps we use to tie things down on the trailer. It served as an extension to the wire so I could reach the tree and gave me a way to pull the wire tight. On the other hand I wrote recently about how much water I have to pump by hand to fill the washing machine. I think I wrote it took over 1,400 strokes at the hand pump to supply enough water to do three loads. Why am I pumping water with a hand pump when there is a creek running outside the door with pure, clear, clean, soft water running in it. I could take a trailer and tote down there, fill it with water, and bring it back to the cabin in less time than it has taken to type this paragraph. I think I won't mind doing laundry as much next time.

The extraordinary weather we have been having left last night. Woke up to a steady rain this morning. It continued to sprinkle and rain most of the day. One of the neighbors said I should go over and check on my boat. I hadn't been over to where it is anchored for nearly a week. Wen I got there it was pretty low in the water. I probably bailed out more than 50 gallons. She's riding high again. While I was tending to her I thought I'd start the outboard motor just to warm it up. That engine is very hard to start when it is cold. I'm about to spring for a new outboard, one with a battery to start it. The yard around the cabin is in full bloom right now. Tonight I asked v Rick if he would walk around outside and identify the various flowers that are blooming right now. The second picture is one of two clumps of wild iris blooming in the yard now. The first picture has most of the following blooming in it: Article Lupine, Yellow Indian Paintbrush, Western Columbine, Shooting Star, Chocolate Lily, Western Yarrow in a couple of colors, Daisy, Wild Strawberries, Cow Parsnip, Beach Peas, Wild Chives, Cinquisoil, Wild Iris, Dandelion, Pink Plumes, Wild Celery and Cloud Berry. Several of you know without my Colorado neighbor Rick there is no way I could have identified all those different flowering plants. That list doesn't even include the many varieties of grass out there in the yard. As we walked around outside, Charlie the neighbor's bear dog came over to see what we were doing. Since we were walking around and not climbing up on one of the Hondas she must have figured we were hunting something. If Charlie knew we were just hunting plants I bet she would have stayed home.

A pretty calm day here today. I went across to check on my boat and bail out the rain water from the last couple of days. Every time I check on it I start the engine and let it run a short while. I won't be doing that much longer. When that old outboard is cold it is so slow to start. It does not have an electric starter. It is a fair workout pulling on the starter cord of a 75 horsepower engine about 35 times before she fires. When I got back to my neighbor's satellite phone I ordered a new outboard.....with an electric starter. Ever since I got here on May third I have been looking out the kitchen window at an old fiberglass boat. It has been sitting, bottom side up, in the same spot so long there is moss growing on the hull. I thought if I moved it to the other side of the cabin and raised it off the ground a few feet it would be a good place to park the Hondas out of the weather. So this afternoon I tied a rope to the far side, passed the rope over the boat and hooked it to the four wheeler. Now the boat is right side up and ready to be moved. No problem sliding it across the grass. The real work is about to begin though. I have to turn it back over so it is upside down then lift it a few feet off the ground. That old fiberglass eighteen foot boat is very heavy. More on this later......when I figure out what to do next. The humming birds are back. The new batch must have all fledged and they have discovered the free food at Guthrie's cabin. A real treat showed up a couple of weeks ago. It is a hummingbird I had never seen before. He drops by every few minutes. He is an Anna's hummingbird. The top of his head is red as well as his throat. I'm going to pull in some interesting information from the Internet about this beautiful bird. Anna's Hummingbird (Calypte anna) is a medium-sized hummingbird native to the west coast of North America. This bird was named after Anna Masséna, Duchess of Rivoli. Anna's Hummingbird is 3.9 to 4.3 inches (10 to 11 centimeters) long. It has a bronze-green back, a pale grey chest and belly, and green flanks. Its bill is long, straight and slender. The adult male has an iridescent crimson-red crown and throat, and a dark, slightly forked tail. Anna's is the only North American hummingbird species with a red crown. These birds feed on nectar from flowers using a long extendable tongue. They also consume small insects caught in flight. A PBS documentary that first aired January 10, 2010, shows how Anna's Hummingbirds eat flying insects. They aim for the flying insect, then open their beaks very wide. That technique has a greater success rate than trying to aim the end of a long beak at the insect. Unlike most hummingbirds, the male Anna's Hummingbird sings during courtship. The song is thin and squeaky. During the breeding season, males can be observed performing a remarkable display, called a display dive, on their territories. The males also use the dive display to drive away rivals or intruders of other species. When a female flies onto a male's territory, he rises up approximately 30 metres (98 ft) before diving over the recipient. As he approaches the bottom of the dive the males reach an average speed which is 385 body lengths per second. At the bottom of the dive the male travels 23 metres per second (51 mph), and produces a loud sound described by some as an "explosive squeak" with his outer tail-feathers. Anna's Hummingbirds are found along the western coast of North America, from southern Canada to northern Baja California, and inland to southern Arizona. They tend to be permanent residents within their range, and are very territorial. However, birds have been spotted far outside their range in such places as southern Alaska, Saskatchewan, New York, Florida, Louisiana and Newfoundland. Anna's hummingbirds are the only hummingbirds to spend the winter in northern climates; they are able to do this as there are enough winter flowers and food to support them. During cold temperatures, Anna's Hummingbirds gradually gain weight during the day as they convert sugar to fat. In addition, hummingbirds with inadequate stores of body fat or insufficient plumage are able to survive periods of sub-freezing weather by lowering their metabolic rate and entering a state of torpor. I'll be commercial fishing tomorrow and maybe Monday. Wish me luck. I need to find a way to pay for that new outboard.....the one with the electric starter.

When a female flies onto a male's territory, he rises up approximately 30 metres (98 ft) before diving over the recipient. As he approaches the bottom of the dive the males reach an average speed which is 385 body lengths per second. At the bottom of the dive the male travels 23 metres per second (51 mph), and produces a loud sound described by some as an "explosive squeak" with his outer tail-feathers. Anna's Hummingbirds are found along the western coast of North America, from southern Canada to northern Baja California, and inland to southern Arizona. They tend to be permanent residents within their range, and are very territorial. However, birds have been spotted far outside their range in such places as southern Alaska, Saskatchewan, New York, Florida, Louisiana and Newfoundland. Anna's hummingbirds are the only hummingbirds to spend the winter in northern climates; they are able to do this as there are enough winter flowers and food to support them. During cold temperatures, Anna's Hummingbirds gradually gain weight during the day as they convert sugar to fat. In addition, hummingbirds with inadequate stores of body fat or insufficient plumage are able to survive periods of sub-freezing weather by lowering their metabolic rate and entering a state of torpor. I'll be commercial fishing tomorrow and maybe Monday. Wish me luck. I need to find a way to pay for that new outboard.....the one with the electric starter.

A pretty calm day here today. I went across to check on my boat and bail out the rain water from the last couple of days. Every time I check on it I start the engine and let it run a short while. I won't be doing that much longer. When that old outboard is cold it is so slow to start. It does not have an electric starter. It is a fair workout pulling on the starter cord of a 75 horsepower engine about 35 times before she fires. When I got back to my neighbor's satellite phone I ordered a new outboard.....with an electric starter. Ever since I got here on May third I have been looking out the kitchen window at an old fiberglass boat. It has been sitting, bottom side up, in the same spot so long there is moss growing on the hull. I thought if I moved it to the other side of the cabin and raised it off the ground a few feet it would be a good place to park the Hondas out of the weather. So this afternoon I tied a rope to the far side, passed the rope over the boat and hooked it to the four wheeler. Now the boat is right side up and ready to be moved. No problem sliding it across the grass. The real work is about to begin though. I have to turn it back over so it is upside down then lift it a few feet off the ground. That old fiberglass eighteen foot boat is very heavy. More on this later......when I figure out what to do next. The humming birds are back. The new batch must have all fledged and they have discovered the free food at Guthrie's cabin. A real treat showed up a couple of weeks ago. It is a hummingbird I had never seen before. He drops by every few minutes. He is an Anna's hummingbird. The top of his head is red as well as his throat. I'm going to pull in some interesting information from the Internet about this beautiful bird. Anna's Hummingbird (Calypte anna) is a medium-sized hummingbird native to the west coast of North America. This bird was named after Anna Masséna, Duchess of Rivoli. Anna's Hummingbird is 3.9 to 4.3 inches (10 to 11 centimeters) long. It has a bronze-green back, a pale grey chest and belly, and green flanks. Its bill is long, straight and slender. The adult male has an iridescent crimson-red crown and throat, and a dark, slightly forked tail. Anna's is the only North American hummingbird species with a red crown. These birds feed on nectar from flowers using a long extendable tongue. They also consume small insects caught in flight. A PBS documentary that first aired January 10, 2010, shows how Anna's Hummingbirds eat flying insects. They aim for the flying insect, then open their beaks very wide. That technique has a greater success rate than trying to aim the end of a long beak at the insect. Unlike most hummingbirds, the male Anna's Hummingbird sings during courtship. The song is thin and squeaky. During the breeding season, males can be observed performing a remarkable display, called a display dive, on their territories. The males also use the dive display to drive away rivals or intruders of other species. When a female flies onto a male's territory, he rises up approximately 30 metres (98 ft) before diving over the recipient. As he approaches the bottom of the dive the males reach an average speed which is 385 body lengths per second. At the bottom of the dive the male travels 23 metres per second (51 mph), and produces a loud sound described by some as an "explosive squeak" with his outer tail-feathers. Anna's Hummingbirds are found along the western coast of North America, from southern Canada to northern Baja California, and inland to southern Arizona. They tend to be permanent residents within their range, and are very territorial. However, birds have been spotted far outside their range in such places as southern Alaska, Saskatchewan, New York, Florida, Louisiana and Newfoundland. Anna's hummingbirds are the only hummingbirds to spend the winter in northern climates; they are able to do this as there are enough winter flowers and food to support them. During cold temperatures, Anna's Hummingbirds gradually gain weight during the day as they convert sugar to fat. In addition, hummingbirds with inadequate stores of body fat or insufficient plumage are able to survive periods of sub-freezing weather by lowering their metabolic rate and entering a state of torpor. I'll be commercial fishing tomorrow and maybe Monday. Wish me luck. I need to find a way to pay for that new outboard.....the one with the electric starter.

That new roof on the cabin next door is the reason I didn't post anything here yesterday. I was one tired old guy. Two of us were on the roof nailing down the sheathing while we kept a whole crew of people on the ground sending up more material. Well, it wasn't a very big crew on the ground but I know some of them will read this and may want to debate who was keeping who busy. This morning I went down to the mouth of the Alsek River to get some ice for the cooler. When I got back I took the fly rod out to play. It caught a nice sockeye salmon. This afternoon the neighbors saw the wolf mentioned a couple of days back. This time there were two others with it. I wish I could have seen the trio, one black, one gray, and a white one. As you can see some very large chunks come down from the glacier. The pieces in the photo would have been many times larger before they floated down. I frequently mention the mouth of that big river and all that goes on there with the battle between the river's current and the tides. The wall of sand, in the picture below, is constantly changing. Over the decades all sorts of stuff has been buried in those sand dunes. As the battle between the river and ocean keep occurring, twice a day, that buried material washes out. I have watched logs 20 feet long appear out of the dune then in a few days be gone as the sand that had them buried is washed away and the log is once again floating somewhere else.

I believe it was last night after I finished here the black wolf appeared and was hunting along the other side of the river. He was catching mice or voles in the tall grass. it would stand very still then jump into the air and I suppose come down on what ever was being hunted. As I watched with binoculars, I noticed a large bear feeding just a little farther back off the river. That scene was pure wilderness. This morning I saw five bears before breakfast. Two sows with three cubs. Later, motoring down the beach for some ice for the cooler I came across a family group of Brant Geese. These small geese (up to about 5 pounds) have very short bills. The group I was approaching were right at the edge of the surf. As I was about to pass them they took flight. I didn't think anything of that since all the birds you zoom by take off. I looked toward the surf a few seconds later and those geese were flying along beside me. When I sped up they kept up. If I slowed down they did too, even to the point where they would drop their feet preparing to land. I sped up again, they picked up their feet and kept up. Finally I just stopped about 50 feet from the surf's edge. The geese landed between me and the ocean. It was amazing. The following is from the internet: "It used to be a strictly coastal bird in winter, seldom leaving tidal estuaries, where it feeds on eel-grass and the seaweed. In recent decades, it has started using agricultural land a short distance inland, feeding extensively on grass and winter-sown cereals. This may be behaviour learnt by following other species of geese. Food resource pressure may also be important in forcing this change, as the world population has risen over tenfold to 400,000-500,000, possibly reaching the carrying capacity of the estuaries. In the breeding season, it uses low-lying wet coastal tundra for both breeding and feeding. The nest is bowl-shaped, lined with grass and down, in an elevated location, often in a small pond." Tomorrow my son and the new outboard arrive. I have to call the bush pilot in the morning. I am getting confusing and conflicting directions on where to meet the plane. I wouldn't want the pilot to leave the boy out there on a remote runway with only his guitar for bear protection. On second thought he could charm them with a tune.

A day to remember, today was.  Good stuff happened.  Scary things happened.  Luck came our way,.  Disaster was avoided. And my son and I still have all our parts and our health. My goal today was to get the new well in so I can plumb the cabin for running water.  The well is really just a pipe driven into the ground,  the bottom section of the pipe is called a sand point.  It is about four feet long and has many holes in it for the water to seep in.  On top of that there are three, three foot sections of pipe.  So all together there is a thirteen foot piece of pipe that needs to be driven into the ground.  The neighbors let us borrow a tool they made to do the job.  It is a pipe about four feet long. It is larger in diameter than the well pipe and had handles welded onto the sides. The closed end of this tool has about sixty pounds of steel welded into it. All together this pipe driver weighs about eighty pounds when you start using it. By the time you lift this thing, slide it down over the well pipe, and then slam it down on the well pipe about three hundred times it weighs at least 150 pounds. Thank heaven I had help. That is the first glass of water from the new well. The water is so cold condensation immediately appears on the glass. Next we went over to the harbor to bring the boat to the cabin. The East River may open to commercial fishing this week so I wanted the boat over here by the cabin. When the dealer prepped the motor to be shipped on a plane he had to drain all the combustible fluids out of the engine. When we installed the new motor on the boat and tested it I wasn't real happy with the low speed idle. N there was a little hose with a loose end inside the engine cover. Gas would come out of this hose when the engine was running. Another fisherman has the same outboard so we compared them. His engine had the little hose with the loose end in it also but it didn't leak gas....mystery! On the way back across Dry Bay the road is sometimes bumpy. At one especially bumpy spot I stopped to check to see if things were all right ini the boat. John ini the meantime is yelling "FIRE!!!!FIRE!!!". Smoke is coming out the bottom of the new outboard. Remember the gas leak? Turns out the bump had capsized the battery. It shorted out on the aluminum boat and caused a little ground wire on the engine to overheat and melt the insulation. A little flame and a little more smoke but no big problem for the brand new , (did I mention expensive?) outboard. The gas leaking out of the tube was because the dealer drained the gas from the engine but did not retighten the valve so whenever the engine was on it was squirting gas out the open valve. After dinner (John ate some of the camper food my daughter sent and I ate Grape Nuts) went fly fishing again. John had caught and released four before I got my first one hooked. While he was concentrating on one of his fish a bear had come out of the brush and approached the water's edge where he was fishing. John said he was close enough that he could see the bear's eyes. I bet the bear could see John's eyes too. They were twice as big as normal. Anyway all that sudden appearance of huge white eyes scared the bear away. Walking back to the wheelers a bit more luck came his way. The glasses he had lost in the water yesterday were there in the sand waiting for him. It is amazing after two tide cycles that had not been swept away or buried in the sand. It is going on eleven as I type this. It has been such a wonderful day to spend with him I hate to see it end.

This has been one of those "where to begin" days. One reason might be because yesterday didn't end until 1:40 this morning when I came in from fishing. The new fishing spot was a morale boost from the very beginning. The water is deep enough there to use the outboard with no problems. The river bank has enough slope that it is easy to step out of the boat and watch the net from the shore. We can drive the Hondas right up to where the net is set if we need to load or unload anything from the boat. The Vet and I decided to fish the new spot I mentioned yesterday, last evening. I wanted to see what would happen to the net when the tide turned and the fish started coming in. I didn't have to wait that long. We started catching fish right away. As it got later we kept wondering why the current in the river hadn't changed as the tide came in. It turned out we had misread the tide table. So we continued catching a few fish. Then the tide did turn. The expected influx of fish did happen and we finally had our hands full, picking fish out of the net in the wee hours of today. On the way over to deliver the fish to the buyer we had trouble with both trailers. One flat tire and one set of bad bearings. No real problem though. Two broken trailers can be made into one whole trailer that can carry the other broken trailer home. In the two days of fishing we caught a little over two hundred fish. They averaged around six pounds each. That is a lot of sockeye. The experienced guys on the river caught their fair share more than we did. It was a pretty good opening. On Sunday the river will be open for fishing again. We will be out there too but probably not as late as this morning. I did a little beach combing after checking the boat this evening. After a two week drought I found a couple of prizes tonight. I had checked the beach this morning and found nothing. All it takes is one tide and new things appear. Up here with all the wildlife your senses are tuned up a little. Not being at the top of the food chain hopefully makes one more aware of what is going on around you. I was pretty tired this afternoon. I lounged around the cabin in my slippers and decided to take a nap. I dozed on and off for an hour or so. Suddenly there was this noise. I jumped up and ran to the window to see if a bear was in one of the totes that had held the fish....no bear out that window. I checked outside the other windows....no animal to be seen. Then I realized I was walking around in one slipper. The other one had slipped off my foot and clunked on the floor. I got to keep my senses tuned though. There may be another loose slipper out there somewhere. I have to be ready for it.

A nice day mostly.  A little shower this afternoon while I was fishing, just enough to force the rain gear out of the tote on the back of the wheeler.

I thought the fishing would be especially good at first.  I caught two nice silvers in the first 15 minutes.  A half hour later, after changing flies, another couple of hits.  Kept changing flies and catching a couple then they would get lock jaw.  I threw a pink top water bug at them for a while.  It is really exciting to see a wave of water, like an underwater torpedo or miniature submarine, racing toward your fly.  Several did this afternoon but would turn away at the last second.  I guess they were not into pink today.

I did hook a world record silver though.  I'm sure it was the world record.  It was a very large fish.  It gave me the best fight of the day.  Long runs, taking lots of line off the reel.  A very bright and silvery fish.  He was so big when he would run toward me I was looking for a way to get out of his way.  Huge fish....He got away.  I did end up catching and releasing six or seven.

Back at the cabin I checked the river out front.  One of the neighbors from across Dry Bay has a sport fishing facility.  He has an arrangement with an outfitter in Canada (Canada is only about 40 miles away by air).  This Canadian outfitter has clients from all over Europe.  Today he had six guys from Germany fishing here.  You know it must be an expensive trip to come here from Europe.  Those men, I am sure, are used to life's finer things.  Here they are riding in a wooden trailer, open to the elements, being pulled by a Honda.  At least the trailer had springs so the ride couldn't have been too rough.

This morning we vacuumed the salmon that got smoked yesterday afternoon and evening. The high tides and the erosion they cause called us back out onto the beach to beachcomb. I don't know why that is so relaxing and if you find something interesting even more so. Cheryl found this one and just a few yards from where I found one to. When we got back to the cabin one of the neighbors came by. He asked if we had heard the latest about Cheryl's flight out on Monday. We had not. Yesterday I sent a note to the bush pilot asking to reconfirm the time she would be picked up. Turned out the office staff and the pilot were not on the same page. The earliest they could pick her up was Wednesday afternoon. Having no sat phone, all I could do was email or use Skype to contact them. After some juggling of things the office asked if we could be ready to go at 4:00 this afternoon. To quote Cheryl, "a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush" we said we could be ready. When asked where the pilot should meet us we checked the tide tables and discovered there was no way he could land in front of the cabin as hoped. (see the pic from yesterday) There would be way too much water on the beach runway. So that meant we needed to drive over to the fish plant across Dry Bay. The high tide also meant we had to go the long way. A forty minute ride. It was already after two. She got her stuff together and I packed the cooler with fish. Earlier I had sold the old outboard to a guy in Yakutat. How to get it to him was a problem. Since Cheryl was being picked up in a larger plane there was room for the outboard too. There is no way I could lift a 75 hp outboard almost 5 feet into the air by myself. I got on the VHF radio and in just a few minutes a couple of neighbors showed up. By now it was raining steadily. It was after three. We had to take the long way to the plant to meet the pilot at four. In case the plane was early, one neighbor blasted off to let the pilot know we were on the way. The other neighbor followed behind Cheryl and me, watching to be sure nothing fell off the trailer I was pulling, with the outboard on it. We got to the plant with a little time to spare. Then we started waiting. The clouds had gotten lower and it was raining harder by now. Four thirty came and went. We had no way to get in touch with anyone since the fish plant is closed for the season. We heard a plane coming..it just flew on by. We were wondering if the weather was so bad the pilot had turned back. Do we keep waiting or go back home? Finally at nearly five we could tell from the sound our plane was coming in. Some dear friends in Yakutat picked up Cheryl. I thought they would just take her the short distance to the terminal and she would be on her way to Colorado. Not to be. It seems an Alaskan cruise ship has broken down south of here and some 3,100 people are trying to get home. From the news I read some planes have been chartered to get those folks out. As of this writing what I thought would be an easy ticket exchange might turn into an extended stay in Yakutat for Cheryl. I will probably know something specific tomorrow. We are fortunate the friends in Yakutat have a freezer. Sixty or seventy pounds of fish can't stay frozen on a cooler forever.

Got an earlier start than normal today. I decided I would finish the outside of the new windows before I would go play. No fishing, no beach combing, no visiting, just finish the outside of the Windows. A couple of times I thought about looking up the definition of self - discipline to see if there was a way, a loophole, I could use to sneak away. One of the other fishermen came by. He can usually count on a cup of coffee and some conversation. I think we were both hoping it would rain so we could change our work plans but alas it did not. What I did manage to finish was replace/repair the shingles around each of the five first floor windows. Getting the old windows out required removing the shingles that surrounded them. Now there is only one window to go. I need a ladder to reach it. Another day like today and it will be done too. There were no fish down at the mouth of the East River this afternoon. Up stream a little ways I hooked up with a "runner". That fish hit the fly as soon as it hit the water and it never slowed down till it had nearly all the line off the reel. I did manage to get him turned then he threw the hook. I was using a sapphire blue fly my Utah brother-in-law tied. Very pretty and sparkly...on a barbless hook. No wonder that, probably another world record, fish got away. Farther upstream, right in front of the cabin I caught three more. I had to keep one but the uninjured ones I returned to the stream. These fish were riding the incoming tide. Fresh out of the ocean they were returning to where they were born about four years ago, letting the incoming tide help them on their way. As the tide came in the pod of fish I had been casting to moved on. The peak of Mount Saint Elias is over 18,000 feet high. Mount Saint Elias, also designated Boundary Peak 186, is the second highest mountain in both Canada and the United States, being situated on the Yukon and Alaska border. On clear days I can see it out the front window. Today I could see it for a while. It was covered with snow. In June the sun sets well to the right of Saint Elias as I look out the window. Now the sun sets far to the left of the mountain. I am noticing all these hints Mother Nature is giving me about the season here being almost over. I am try to ignore them.

This morning about 2:00 I got up and noticed the strange light outside. It was a soft blue light. It was bright enough that I could see things around the outside of the cabin even though there was no moon. The night was very, exceptionally clear. The bluish light was starlight. I went outside and could see the Milky Way stretch across the sky above. One cold winter night years ago Peter and I could see the Milky Way from the deck in Colorado. Last night was the second time I recall ever seeing it. Our planet is just one in the millions that make up our galaxy. I was seeing in the Milky Way just a part of our neighborhood. Makes one feel sort of small. Good progress in the "privy" today. If I don't have too many interruptions (two unplanned coffee breaks and one urgent fishing report today) I may get the roof started tomorrow. I really don't mind the interruptions. A discussion in one of the coffee breaks resulted in my decision to install a FDS* in the outhouse. I had been considering an FDS* but the fine tuning of the design was completed during the coffee breaks. I had to wait to take action on the urgent fishing report. Determined to get the third wall of the structure covered I was finally able to hit the river about 5:30. Large pods of fish were moving upstream. I lost count of how many the Vet and I caught. One of the other old timers was watching us fish. There were so many fish coming through I told this observer "I'm going to catch a fish in the next two casts." I didn't need to make the second cast. I cast a floating fly at them for a while. I had several fish attack the fly but failed to hook any of them. Cheryl took this picture last week. My cabin is just off the left side of this shot. This afternoon I was caching these fish just a few yards from where the eagle is sitting. This would have been a good day for anyone reading this to have been here.     *Fecal Deflection System makes sure everything goes to the bottom of the hole.... patent not pending

MAY 15th. I have been keeping daily notes since May 4th but have not had internet access. Now that I do there are ten days of notes below. In the future there will not be nearly as much volume to read. Thanks for your interest. MAY 4TH Much has happened since I was able to add anything to this site. We were supposed to fly out to the cabin on May 1st. The weather was not cooperating so we stayed in Juneau another day. On the 2nd of May we were able to catch a flight to Gustavus and were treated to outstanding hospitality by our pilot and his wife. The clouds and fog were so dense visibility was near zero through a narrow pass called Icy Straights. The fog went all the way down to the surface of the sea….No place to be in a Cessna 206 single engine plane. On Friday the 3rd. the weather forecast was very iffy. We were not sure when we might be able to get to the cabin. Considering that and a bunch of other details like, “once we get there will Cheryl be able to get out in time to make her connections back home” we decided she should just come on back home and I would make it out to the cabin whenever the weather would allow. As nature would have it there was a break in weather and a narrow window opened and I got to the cabin about 3:00 Friday afternoon. It was raining. The weather service predicted 100% chance of rain, heavy at times. They were right. It rained, heavy at times, non-stop until 3:00 Saturday afternoon. I have been spending much of my time just watching the spectacle in front of the cabin. As I type this there are three flocks of migrating birds in my front yard. There are nearly 100 Canada geese just to the left. Directly in front of me there is a flock of 37 Sandhill cranes and a little beyond them must be 50 Snow geese. Throughout the day I have watched this spectacle. Frequently I see a few Greater White-fronted geese mixed in with the others.   Bald Eagles appear fairly often. You can tell when one is approaching. All the birds feeding take to the air in one huge mass. As soon as the eagle has passed they all come back and resume feeding…right in my front yard. I’m loving it. MAY 5TH Today would have been Mother’s birthday. She wouldn’t have liked it here but would have been happy that I’m able to enjoy all this nature. It has stopped raining and the clouds are a little higher today. Late in the afternoon I did hear a small plane fly by. That means the weather must be moderating some. Made good progress getting the outside cleaned up today. Over the years an assortment of plastic and fiberglass articles had accumulated. There were a few alder bushes that were blocking some of the view out the front. I had a heck of a bon fire going for a while. Some of that stuff made really dense black smoke. Not such a variety of waterfowl out front today. There was a large flock of Canada geese out front late. I’m guessing 250 birds. They graze back and forth less than 100 feet from the front door. As far as I can tell there is no one else here in the preserve. I check a neighboring cabin to see if their internet connection was working….it wasn’t. MAY 6TH Coolest morning yet. Thirty six outside. Forty seven inside. The stove works well and before long I’ll have it up in the middle 60s. There is some blue in the sky and I can see the mountains off in the east. There is beginning to be a tinge of green on the ground and the alders have little buds showing. Decided to go down to the mouth of the Alsek River to look for glass floats. These baseball size glass balls used to be used to float the fishing nets used by the Japanese fishing off shore. I found a few. On the way down the beech I saw my first bear of the season. At the mouth of the river a group of sea lions had gathered. The herd bull would frequently bellow or roar his presence. There seemed to be many young seals there too. MAY 7TH A beautiful blue sky morning with no wind. The heavy frost is quickly disappearing in the warm sunshine. Not many birds on the ground out front. It is unusual to look up into the sky and not see flocks of birds all heading the same way… North. As I type this an Osprey landed out front. The first humming bird just flew by. Got to get a feeder for them! Those sea lions mentioned yesterday…They are several miles away and I can hear them roaring here at the cabin. Borrowed a neighbor’s hummingbird feeder. They are not here yet so I didn’t think they would mind. I put the feeder up about ten this morning. By noon several pairs had found it. All the hummers I have seen up here are the Rufous hummingbirds. We see them passing through Colorado in July. I met another resident yesterday. I spent most of the day working on the storage area of the cabin. Hearing a little noise I discovered an Ermine (weasel) watching me. I hope she appreciates the redecorating. Also discovered the freezer freezes and the washing machine washes. MAY 8th A little chilly this morning, 30 outside and 40 inside. Another beautiful morning. I was up around 4:15. The hummingbirds were already buzzing around outside wondering where their feeder was! My neighbor flew down from Yakutat. He brought all the stuff I need to get the internet connection set up. He also brought provisions to begin stocking their cabin. He flew back to town and will return tomorrow with more supplies for his cabin. He will also bring the things to install the wood stove. I have been heating with an oil stove. With an endless supply of free fuel outside it seems silly to buy oil then have to fly it in. While we were standing outside another resident came up from out of the woods. It was a fair size brown bear (grizzly). He went back into the brush before I could get some good close-up pictures. MAY 9th High human traffic today. The neighbor flew back in with a friend of his. He brought all the parts needed to install the wood stove. Now I have to decide if I want to use the old wood stove that was stored here or get a new one. It’s not only the cost of the stove but getting it here will be expensive too. A pilot we flew with last year stopped by. He had been delivering fuel to a bear hunter’s camp. He was flying a neat little “cub” that had skis attached just above the wheels. He could land on the beach or in the snow. A little later two of the guides from the bear hunter camp stopped. Whew! I didn’t get as much work done as I hoped. Did get the attic emptied out. There was some high quality outdoor gear up there. A couple of wildlife things. The hummers are drinking over a quart of food a day. The weasel was back in the cabin last night. I nearly swatted him with my cap as it scurried across the floor. MAY 10th Last night I installed new gaskets in the hand pump by the sink. Whenever I needed more water I had to pump that handle at least 50 times (I actually counted). This morning on the 7th stroke water appeared. That is so neat. To not have to work up a sweat to get a cup of water. My neighbor has a portable saw mill. It comes in heal handy when you need more than a couple of boards that could be flown in on a small plane. Yesterday he found a fir log down on the beach over 40 feet long. Today we went down there, cut the log into 2 twenty footers rolled them onto an ingenious trailer and brought that huge log home to be sawed up into boards. This afternoon we got all the internet hardware mounted on the house and the wiring done. I still don’t have a connection to the internet. We think it is because there are some trees blocking the clear view of the sky the satellite dish needs. So tomorrow I’ll be turning trees into firewood. MAY 11th I went down to the mouth of the Alsek this morning to do a little more beachcombing. Found one glass float that had appeared with the tide. A little later my neighbor stopped in. He had also gone down there. He found another glass float not twenty feet from where I found mine. I expect I was so pleased to find one I didn’t bother to look around for another so close. The alder trees grow so quickly here they encroach on any clear space. So over the years they had invaded the space around the cabin clearing. I had been trimming them back for several days. Yesterday I spent quite a while burning them. Nearby, the little weasel was very busy hunting for something. My neighbor and his friend flew back to Yakutat around noon. He left the dog, Charlie, with me for the night. There had been a very light rain falling most of the day. When I went to bed it was pitch black inside. A little while later I could sense something very close. I turned on the light and Charlie was staring at me from a few inches away. Needless to say she wanted to be up off the floor. As far as I know she didn’t move all night….a good bed mate. MAY 12th I woke up this morning feeling an empty place. This is the first Mother’s Day in all these years that I have not been able to wish someone Happy Mother’s Day. To those Mothers who might read this …I hope you had a happy Mother’s Day. A light rain has fallen all day. So, very major progress was made today on organizing the living space at the cabin. By the end of the week I hope to have a wood stove working, the shop side of the cabin organized and the internet working. The rainy day has caused the humming birds to spend what seems like most of their time around the feeder. I filled the quart feeder after the birds went to bed last night. By 1:00 p.m. it was empty. It is nearly 8:30 p.m. now and I can’t see any food in it. They will have consumed over one half gallon of sugar water today. Charlie, the neighbor’s bear dog, is still with me. I get to keep her until the weather clears and the neighbors can get back down here. Thanks to Charlie’s being on guard she alerted me to a moose just across the river this morning. We watched her for a while till she crossed to our side and disappeared into the brush. MAY 13th About 12:30 this morning Charlie started having a fit. I grabbed a flashlight and let her out. She kept running around the outside of the cabin. The little LED flashlight didn’t help much in finding out what was out there. About a half hour later she was still very agitated. When I called her she came in and we settled down for the rest of the night. About 6:30 she started up again. I thought that is a lot of baking for the little weasel. Now Charlie was going under the cabin sounding more aggressive than ever. As I came back into the shop an Otter disappeared into a space along the wall. There turned out to be two otters. Between Charlie and I giving them so much grief they have moved on to a quieter spot. Good progress was made on cleaning up the accumulated stuff today. It rained on and off most of the day. Tomorrow if the weather cooperates I might start preparing to install the woodstove. I’m almost out of heating oil. MAY 14th Charlie got the morning off to good start for herself. She caught a sea gull out in front. I did get started on preparing for the wood stove. The cabin has a plywood floor. Some time back the previous owner bought some laminate flooring but didn’t get a chance to install it. I got about half the floor done today. It didn’t go down nearly as easily as the last time I worked with that kind of flooring. Maybe sitting around in high humidity for several years had something to do with it. Anyway, now that the floor is finished under where the wood stove will be I can proceed to figure out to protect the floor and wall from the heat it will put out. I’m fairly motivated in that I am out of heating oil. It was another rainy day. Fog came and went through the day. No small planes were flying. Because I am so near the ocean the temperatures stay very even. On a cloudy day like today the low might be 42 and the high for the day 48. All I have to do to stay warm is stay busy. Otherwise it requires several layers. Since I have no radio and no internet I don’t know what the forecast is. Sometimes my little weather station shows the pressure going up. That means fair weather ahead. Then it changes its mind. MAY 15th The friends who are also neighbors arrived today. Three trips in the plane from Yakutat to get their cabins stocked for the season. Dinner with them this evening featured Beer Batter halibut for an appetizer. Meatloaf and red potatoes, fresh salad. All this was accompanied by great conversation and Buffalo Trace bourbon. It was a great meal. I got the internet working late this morning. Now I can begin to learn how post pictures on this site so they are not upside down. We got the outside chimney installed for the wood stove. I should have heat in the cabin tomorrow before noon.

On the road again, on my way back to the cabin in Dry Bay, Alaska.  I'm driving this time.  I wanted to take Louis, my 13 year old faithful mixed breed companion with me.  I didn't think he could take all the takeoffs and landings required should we have flown all the way.  As it is we will drive to Haines.  The trip will be about 2,800 miles.  

When we get to Haines we will take the ferry down to Juneau and stock up on supplies from Costco, Home Depot etc.  After another ferry ride back to Haines we will charter a bush plane to take us over to the cabin.

Today we drove 570 miles to get to our destination 520 miles from home.  The plan was to take some back roads out of Wyoming into Idaho.  As we cruised along on amazingly straight two lane roads there appeared to be a road block ahead.  I have been read how some cars with Colorado tags have been stopped and checked for drugs since pot is now legal at home.  Not a problem for us.  It turned out there had been a gas leak on down the road, an explosion had caused a whole town to be evacuated.  All traffic was being turned around and sent back the 25 miles to the interstate.

Since the last post we have left the country and are now resting up after four 500 mile days in my little red truck.  Tonight we are in 100 Mile House B.C., Canada.  The proprietor explained the name of this village came from the fact that it is located 100 miles from the point where the steamboat put people ashore as they traveled north.  I'm too tired tonight to investigate the naming of the town any further.

Louis and I spent our second night on the road in Caldwell, ID where we picked up another Dry Bay fisherman.  His handle is Wildflower.  He has been fishing up there for 27 years.  Last night we stayed with his daughter and her family in northern Washington.

The country we have been traveling through is amazingly beautiful.  The huge rolling hills almost seem to hang over the road as it meanders through the valleys between them.  The spring colors are so vivid they look like God is practicing his Photoshop skills by enhancing to purity and unblemished images beyond the windshield.

Coming through customs was not a problem except it took quite a while.  It seems they need a lot of documentation completed if you are traveling through with a firearm.   In hindsight it would have been easier and cheaper to have mailed the small bore rifle to Alaska.

Louis is traveling beautifully.  Wildflower ate all the gummy bears today but he made up for it by helping with the driving.  We have finished the first James Patterson book on tape.  John Grissom might be next.  Louis might enjoy one I saw at a truck stop featuring sounds of the far north.  Probably more enjoyable than the sounds he hears coming from the two old guys in the front seats.

Another long day driving. Tonight finds us in Pink Mountain on the Alaska Highway. The population of Pink Mountain is less than 100. It snowed here today. Yesterday the road out of here was closed because of the snow. We made it to Dawson Springs in the early afternoon. It was too early to stop driving so we kept going farther and farther up the Alaska Highway till after 12 hours in the truck we decided to call it quits here in Pink Mountain. I got to meet a British Columbia Highway Patrolman this morning. He said I was going 90 in a 60 zone. After I explained to him I was only the pilot that Wildflower was in charge of administrative details he let us go with just a warning. By the way, 90 here in BC is 54 mph in American. 60 here is about 36 back home. We kept the Red Beast under control the rest of the day. Louis is continuing to be the best traveler of the three of us. He never complains. He stays out of the political conversations. He always expresses his appreciation for the little treats that come his way from any of the A&W Root Beer stops we make along the way.

Louis is continuing to be the best traveler of the three of us. He never complains. He stays out of the political conversations. He always expresses his appreciation for the little treats that come his way from any of the A&W Root Beer stops we make along the way.

We got an earlier start today. By the end of the day we had driven over six hundred miles. We left British Columbia behind and are in Teslin, Yukon Territory tonight about 350 miles from Haines, AK. I have contacted Paul, our bush pilot. The plan is to unload the truck at his hanger tomorrow afternoon. We have decided to do our shopping in Haines rather than go down to Juneau and back on the ferry. If all goes well we will be in our cabins over in Dry Bay Wednesday night. On the drive today we saw lots of wildlife! This Stone Sheep cooperated, stood still and gave us plenty of time to take pictures. This Caribou Wasn't as cooperative. Mom and her calf were enjoying the sunny afternoon.  I bet we saw 50 Bison along the road.   An article in the local paper said the herd is about 1,200 strong.  The article said that was 200 animals too many! This was a view we saw repeatedly during today's drive.  Not these same mountains but similar views, frequently with a lake or river in the foreground.  The highway for the most part is in very good condition. I'm looking forward to the return trip.  It is very early spring up here.  My hope is that fall won't be too far along when I head back.  it would be nice to see these miles and miles of natural beauty in her fall colors.

It has been a couple of days since I posted anything here.  Yesterday the 29th we made it into Haines after driving through more of the Yukon and back into British Columbia.    We saw some more caribou a few rabbits and a bunch of ground squirrels.  The terrain varied remarkably from high plains to rolling hills to very craggy mountains then we got to Haines.

Several years ago there was a book published entitled, If You Lived Here, I'd Know Your Name: News from Small-Town Alaska [Heather Lende].  The cover of the book showed a bull moose looking through an open doorway into a person’s home.  It was a great story about the goings on around Haines, AK.

I haven’t been to many of the smaller towns in Alaska but Haines has the friendliest people.  Everyone I saw looked me in the eye and smiled.  The clerks at the stores were friendly and helpful.  As I shopped for groceries I must have asked one guy, who was trying to stock shelves, for directions to the matches, blueberry pie filling, tang, sliced peaches and four or five other things on separate occasions.  Every time he stopped what he was doing and showed me where the item was.  At the lumber yard the same thing happened.  They even made some special cuts on a sheet of plywood and didn’t charge me for it.

Our original plan was to take the ferry down to Juneau to do the shopping but we figured by the time we paid for rooms a couple of nights and the cost of the round trip ferry ride we should just find what we needed in Haines and get on out here to Dry Bay and our cabins.

The flight over the mountains was amazing.  Paul the bush pilot said he would rather make two trips in his smaller plane and charge us the same as if we made one trip in the Beaver.  That worked out well in that on my load he actually taxied up into the yard in front of my cabin.  That made unloading very easy.  Wildflower’s cabin is about five miles away on the other side of Dry Bay.  On that load he landed near the other cabin.  It was much easier on both of us that way.

Louis, my dog, had never flown before.  He started out in the back of the small plane’s cargo area.  Before we finished taxing out for the takeoff he had crawled over all the stuff and was in my lap.  The rest of the one hour flight was very pleasant… for all three of us.

At the cabin everything seems to be in good shape.  There must have been a bad storm during the winter.  Lots of trees have their tops broken out.  Many of the trails are not passable without taking along an ax or saw to clear the limbs out of the way.  The beaches have been rearranged too.  What used to be nearly vertical sand dunes are now a sloping beaches.  The former sloping beaches now have five and six foot vertical faces at the high tide line.

I expected to have a problem getting reconnected to the internet.  That turned out to not be a problem.  However…..the water pump doesn’t pump water and this writer left the cables to the iPad and smart phone back in Boulder.  I have a spare water pump and Amazon will ship the needed cables to me in a jiffy.

Some beautiful photographs are stored on those devices but I can’t get them off till the cables come.  I could email them to myself if the batteries weren’t dead.  Beside the beautiful scenery I got pictures of several hundred Steller Sea Lions that are hanging out down near the mouth of one of the rivers near the cabin.  I’ll pass those along when the needed cables arrive.

Today started out well.  The brand new stainless steel 12 cup coffee pot works great.  It is the old fashioned kind that has the little basket you put the grounds in and heat the water on the stove.  After a few minutes it starts making a gurgling sound.  Steam starts coming out of the pour spout and that fills the cabin with an aroma that causes one to get the cup ready so not a moment is lost when you decide the coffee is strong enough.  It was great coffee.  

Louis and I went for a short walk around outside this morning.  He looked to the west and started barking.  I couldn’t see anything and he soon settled down.  Later I drove up the beach to look for treasures that might have washed ashore on the tide.

No treasure but Louis’s barking was valid.  Just across the creek from the cabin there were fresh tracks of four wolves.  These tracks were not there yesterday afternoon.  The wolves went down toward the mouth of the river for about a mile then turned back into the brush.  Two moose had also been over there since yesterday as well as one set of bear tracks.  I didn’t lay eyes on any of these critters but their tracks prove they were around last night.

The first humming bird stopped by today.  She visited the feeder several times throughout the day.  In a week or so there will be dozens of these little beauties buzzing around out front.  Once I looked out and a Bald Eagle flew right past the window.  There are not many eagles around yet but I expect there will be plenty as the fish start coming into the streams.

The spare pump works just fine.  One other item I needed to check out was the washing machine.  I put antifreeze in the pump last September to keep it from freezing.   To be sure there were no leaks I ran a load of dirty clothes through.  It worked just fine.  Later the clothes drying on the line outside surprised Louis.  He barked at them flapping in the breeze.  He is so much company….he protects me from anything strange…like unknown things flapping in the breeze.

Got the day started by finishing yesterday’s coffee. It was OK. My grandmother said coffee should be strong enough so you couldn’t see your spoon in it. Today the tip of my spoon disappeared instantly upon submersion. Treasurer hunting took me across the East Alsek River this morning. I left before high tide. The water was still too deep to ride the wheeler all the way across. When I stepped off the machine the current was swift enough that the Honda wanted to tip over. After getting that under control we were able to get back into shallower water and proceed on to the Pacific Ocean. This Old Stellar Sea Lion bull washed in on last night’s tide. He was over 9 feet long. For comparison the Honda is about 6.5 feet long. I tried to roll the old guy over for a better picture but there was no way. He must have weighed well over a thousand pounds. I rode as far as I could down the beach until I was stopped by a rock formation. That is about 12 miles one way. The only tracks I saw were made by bears and only a couple of them. I was sure I would find some old glass fishing floats on the long stretch of beach. My guess is no one had been down there since last fall sometime. I did find a fiberglass boat about 18 feet long and a couple of other interesting things. That’s a whale vertebrae along with a fishing gaff, an interesting bottle and another coffee mug for the cabin. Louis was glad to see me when I got home. After a treat he resumed his normal spot, guarding the door.

Another chore day here. Louis and I got the new wood stove installed. I've been looking for a long pole to mount the VHF marine radio antenna on. Today I came across one on the beach that should work nicely. Dug a hole to anchor the base in the ground,then strapped it to the house higher up. Now I need some help mounting the antenna on top of it. I don't want to be standing on the step ladder on the slanted surface of the roof without having someone nearby to call 911. A long time friend who lives a ways north of Dallas suggested I add some maps to these notes for reference. So here we go Bill: If you go to Google Maps and enter the following in the "directions to box" 59.106074, -138.477199 the map should zoom into Alaska. Choose the satilite view.  The green arrow is my cabin. At least it is when I do that on my computer. The following pictures were made by my neighbor Rick. They may make some of the sentences I type make more sense.   If the Google Maps location worked for you then this is what the cabin looks like as you fly in in a bush plane.  You would land right at the edge of the grass in front of the cabin.  That is Dog Salmon Creek in the foreground.  The Ease Alsek River is just off the right edge of the picture and the ocean is beyond that to the right.   This is a high altitude shot.  The yellow lines are indications of where Rick was a couple of days last summer.  He loaded information from his GPS into Google and those uploaded tracks are the yellow lines.  The line extending toward the lower center of the picture ends at the rocks where I was yesterday.  The other end of that line which ends abruptly in the foggy area is the mouth of the mighty Alsek river. Thanks Bill for the suggestion and my very best wishes for you and your family.

Not much happened yesterday.  Not much until Louis and I stepped outside just before going to bed.

Earlier in the day I did go down to the mouth of the Alsek.  No luck beachcombing but there was one chunk of glacier ice.  I brought it home and now the cooler has a way to keep things cool.  I had the first Kentucky Bourbon and water chilled with glacier ice of the season yesterday.  Have been needing a long straight pole to mount the VHF radio antenna on.  I found a couple that had washed ashore and drug them home behind the Honda.

So just before we retired we stepped outside.  Louis went around the south side of the cabin and immediately went stiff then began to bark his serious bark.  There was a mama grizzly in the side yard with twin cubs.  We both started barking seriously.  Mama stood up on her hind legs and checked us out.  I guess she and the cubs had a quick conference and decided to turn tail.  They crashed off into the alders and didn’t return as far as we know.

Today we looked for moose antlers out in the brush for an hour or so.  I called wildflower and asked him if he would come over and help me get the new VHF antenna installed.  All I needed him to do was eyeball the position of the antenna from the ground to be sure it was vertical.  The other thing I needed him for was to call the coast guard in case I fell off the roof.

To pay back the favor we spent a couple of hours clearing the windfalls off the trail back to his cabin.  As mentioned before there was a heck of a storm here a month or so ago.  The tops are blown out of many trees across the whole area.  Our guess is an ice storm preceded a strong wind.

Tomorrow the plan is to get the solar panel installed.  Its job is to help keep the bank of 12 volt batteries charged.  Wish me luck.  I’ll be back on the roof.

Seven days ago Louis and I flew in here to the cabin from Haines. One would expect frequent rains here in Southeast Alaska. Last evening it barely misted a little. Other than that there has been no precipitation. The weather has been perfect. This evening one can’t see the tops of the mountains because of low clouds. The forecast calls for a 40% chance of rain later in the week. This afternoon I went exploring back in the bush. There are some beautiful meadows hidden from view along the trails. Some of the meadows have what should be a small stream running through the middle. Because it is so dry there are pools of water but no water connecting the pools. Each of these pools has several minnow size fish in them. I bet some of them are tiny salmon. A good rain might help some of them escape into larger water, grow up and make more salmon. While out exploring I came across this wolf skull. To give it some scale the squares in the tablecloth are almost one inch on each side. The teeth are not worn very much indicating it wasn’t an old animal. Makes you wonder what happened to it. Today’s objective was accomplished. There is now a solar panel on the roof charging the batteries. When I came in this afternoon the device that controls the charging indicated the batteries were completely charged. If I am reading the little LED indicators correctly this thing will save many hours of running the generators. I won’t mind if it does rain tomorrow. I’m way behind on administrative stuff.

May 7th Down the beach again this morning. This time scouting for fire wood. There are several areas where during storms with wind and high water logs pile up along the river’s bank. One of these places is across the Alsek River from where the Stellar Sea Lions congregate this time of year. The day I took this picture there were probably a couple hundred of them down there. Today about half that many. You can hear these animals roar and bark miles away if the wind is right. My side of the river is where I find fire wood. This tree is over one hundred feet long not counting the top which was broken off.  I was looking for something a little closer to the cabin and bigger in diameter.   A little closer to the cabin I cut up this spruce log for the stove. It took two trips to haul these sawn up pieces back to the cabin. I think I have decided to cut up slightly smaller diameter trees next time. It takes a lot of work to split up these big trees into fire wood size. On or two of those pieces will heat the cabin all day though after it is split.

Not much happened yesterday except I split the three loads of firewood cut the day before. Late in the evening Louis and I were watching the day wind down and we noticed flocks of Snow Geese flying in a northerly direction down the East Alsek River. These birds would circle around a spot on the beach several times before landing. No telling how far they had flown that day. Anyway I expected them to begin feeding in the grass along the shore of the river. Nope, they must have been worn out in that almost all of them tucked their heads under a wing and went wherever geese go when they are really tired. Today started out like yesterday. Went down the river and cut another load of firewood. On the way I ran into Wildflower. He suggested we go and salvage that boat I found washed ashore down by the rocks a few days ago. We found a shallower place to cross the East River and we could just ride the Hondas across. He pulled his boat trailer and we blasted down the beach nearly the entire twelve miles to the boat. As you can see it was another beautiful day. That’s Mt. Fairweather in the background. My wheeler tracks from the earlier trip in the foreground. We thought this would be about a 12 foot boat. Note the timestamp on the picture is 4:35. The picture below was taken at 6:18 and the boat has grown to about 18 or 20 feet in length and very deep in the sand. We did discover some markings on the side of the boat. It appears it a Japanese vessel from the registration numbers and markings. We tried several ways to pry the boat loose from the sand. Finally we got the bow end free but the stern is still stuck. By now both us old guys were pretty much beat and we decided to call it a day at 7:15. We left the trailer down there with the boat. The plan is to resume the attack in the morning. You can see from the sand on her hull how much of the boat was covered with sand. That’s wildflower holding on to his Honda. He was so tired he was about to tip over ….So was I! A  distraction while digging was the activity out in the ocean.  The noisy Sea Lions were around and for the first time for me  I saw whales migrating up the coast.  It was easy to spot the vapor as they exhaled and rolled back under the waves. We saw two different groups and no telling how many went by while we had our heads down in the sand.

We found a shallower place to cross the East River and we could just ride the Hondas across. He pulled his boat trailer and we blasted down the beach nearly the entire twelve miles to the boat. As you can see it was another beautiful day. That’s Mt. Fairweather in the background. My wheeler tracks from the earlier trip in the foreground. We thought this would be about a 12 foot boat. Note the timestamp on the picture is 4:35. The picture below was taken at 6:18 and the boat has grown to about 18 or 20 feet in length and very deep in the sand. We did discover some markings on the side of the boat. It appears it a Japanese vessel from the registration numbers and markings. We tried several ways to pry the boat loose from the sand. Finally we got the bow end free but the stern is still stuck. By now both us old guys were pretty much beat and we decided to call it a day at 7:15. We left the trailer down there with the boat. The plan is to resume the attack in the morning. You can see from the sand on her hull how much of the boat was covered with sand. That’s wildflower holding on to his Honda. He was so tired he was about to tip over ….So was I! A  distraction while digging was the activity out in the ocean.  The noisy Sea Lions were around and for the first time for me  I saw whales migrating up the coast.  It was easy to spot the vapor as they exhaled and rolled back under the waves. We saw two different groups and no telling how many went by while we had our heads down in the sand.

Wildflower showed up before nine this morning all raring to go finish salvaging the boat.  We tried another slightly different place to cross the river with the Hondas.  To check out a different route we wade across first to check the depth of the water.  Apparently we got our bearings a little off.  About two thirds of the way across his machine started drifting off downstream with him on it.  He did manage to get back into shallower water and all the way across with no other problem.  I wasn’t so lucky.  I tried to avoid where he lost traction and ended up in a deeper hole.  The Honda drowned.  We had to pull it out of the water, take the sparkplug out, dry things off then proceed down to the boat.

I took pictures of us turning the boat over so the right side was up.  I took pictures of how we managed to get it up on the boat trailer.  (It was very difficult.  That boat is REAL heavy)  In the soft sand we managed to get both wheelers stuck down onto their frames several times. Got pictures of that.  The end result was the weight of the boat, the soft sand and the thin tires on the boat trailer made it impossible for us to bring it home.  It was nearly as hard to get the boat back off the trailer as it was to get it on there.  We had to hook one Honda to the boat trailer and the other to the boat.  By pulling in both directions at the same time we finally were able to start home, boatless.  Two long days trying to get that thing back to the cabin and it now sits about 30 feet from where it started.  It is right side up now and on top of the sand.

On the way back we watched the Sea Lions and hundreds of gulls feeding on something right at the edge of the surf.    I got a picture of them.  There were lots of Bald Eagles out there too.  At one point there were about twenty flying up the beach in front of me.

I got a good shot of Wildflower coming back across the river.  The Hondas push a large wave of water in front of them as they enter the shallower water. It is impressive.

I was reviewing all the nice pictures I shot today and did something wrong.  I guess I was tired.  The camera displayed a message saying “are you sure?”  I said yes.  All the pictures are gone.

Mother’s Day.  An ordinary Sunday in May, set aside in our country, to recognize a person in all our individual lives that we owe at least a little admiration.  Worded that so those people who don’t get along with their mothers will have less to argue with me about.  Some of you have already seen what I posted on Facebook. “I think mothers are the most influential people on our planet”.  I’m glad I had one. Being Sunday and Mother’s Day Louis and I took it pretty easy.  Only got two small chores done.  The boat now has a battery in it.  The hummingbirds have a new batch of food cooling off outside.  That’s it. We did take a long walk; Here Louis is checking out the bear and wolf tracks in the sand across the creek.  There was one spot where a wolf must have left it’s sent.  Louis left his too.  I didn't have it in  me. On the southern facing, sunny spots the wild strawberries are beginning to bloom.  It looks like there will be a good crop this year. The last few days fooling with that damn boat I felt Louis wasn’t getting the attention he should.  So I added some art work to the cabin.  I thought a picture of his forefathers might be good for his morale. I told him those four wolves in the foreground were the ones whose tracks I saw out front last week. I think he likes that.

Well things are about to get crowded around here. Kati, Brandt, Baby Fathom (two months old) and their dog arrived this afternoon. Tomorrow Joe and his 92 year old Mom arrive as well as the matriarch of Dry Bay, Lisa. The rest of the Robbins clan will probably swoop in any time now. Louis met Brandt’s dog and they got along just fine. You can see how my day was spent. I figure I have plenty of wood cut for a while. I need to split the last four loads before I am really done. I sleep well after busting those log rounds into 8 pieces each. The trailer and tote in the background will only hold eight of the pieces you see cut in the foreground. That one log with the rope on it filled the tote three times. It still hasn’t rained. The tide was out when I took this picture. Normally there would be more water in that slough. It is so dry the ground is beginning to crack open in some places.  Another sign of the mild weather.  The snow line on the mountains is moving up more each day. The seasonal Park Ranger (Kaie) stopped by. She and two guys flew in today to begin clearing the trails of all the down trees.
