May 13th This morning I planned to split all the loads of wood I cut yesterday and I figured I had all day to get it done. Then Wildflower pulled up. He wondered if I would like to help him get his boat in the water. After that we would check out some places to set our nets when the season opens on June first. Wildflower has been coming up here and fishing for over 25 years. I was happy that he asked me to partner with him for fishing on the Alsek River this year. Neither one of us are spring chickens any more. He is older than me (10 days) and obviously has a lot more experience. I however have a fuller beard and other important qualities which don’t come to mind right now but I’m sure they are there somewhere. This is a picture of one of the places where we will set a net. Along here today there were at least a dozen Bald Eagles. In one spot I could see three eagle nests. The second picture is yet another shot of Mount Fairweather. I needed some ice for the cooler so while we were on the river we grabbed a couple of chunks of glacier ice. What we found was crystal clear. Old ice he called it. Newer ice near the surface of the glacier is cloudy and softer. As we went up and down the river the air temperature would vary dramatically. Wildflower has a device on his boat that tells him the water temp. In several places the water was less than 33.5 degrees. A person wouldn’t last long if he fell overboard.

Woke up to misting rain this morning. It has kept it up most of the day. Not enough is falling to keep one inside but there is no bright sunshine for the first time this month. I decided to paint the old freezer. Last year I bought a gallon of that new latex paint with the primer already added in. The instructions on the can said I could use it on metal. I thought if the new bright white coat of paint looked good enough I would move the unit into the kitchen area of the cabin. Louis and I sanded most of the rusty places off the exterior. I pried open the previously unopened can of fancy paint. There was a thin layer of whiteish water on top of a mass of goo that was the consistency of thin concrete. The internet offered no help in recovering the paint. I did notice a note on the can that said "protect from freezing". I guess it got below freezing here in Alaska last winter! I now feel I have mastered splitting wood the old fashioned way. My sister sent me a quote from Harrison Ford. He said "Wood you cut and chop yourself always seems to burn faster." I agree. Anyhow, I believe I am set for firewood till this time next year.

Another beautiful day here.  Low 70s with just a few friend

Another beautiful day here.  The only clouds were friendly ones.  It was a good day to start getting the fishing nets organized.  If I had typed this early this morning I would have said something about organizing the nets today.  As things turned out it is a lot bigger job than anticipated.

At 6 this evening the job is about half done.  Some of the nets need to be patched.  Some need to be replaced.  The rest will probably be fine to use depending on the targeted fish.  If I have more energy tomorrow I'll add some pictures and more information on how one targets a fish 25 fathoms (120  feet) away under about six feet of water.

Another beautiful day here.  The only clouds were friendly ones.  It was a good day to start getting the fishing nets organized.  If I had typed this early this morning I would have said something about organizing the nets today.  As things turned out it is a lot bigger job than anticipated.

At 6 this evening the job is about half done.  Some of the nets need to be patched.  Some need to be replaced.  The rest will probably be fine to use depending on the targeted fish.  If I have more energy tomorrow I'll add some pictures and more information on how one targets a fish 25 fathoms (120  feet) away under about six feet of water.

The weather has been perfect. The forecast calls for more typical weather starting Sunday night (read rain) but short sleeves and shorts are not normal attire here in May. A couple of special things happened at Dry Bay today. A Great Grandfather met his Great Granddaughter for the first time this morning. It was a special time. Another not so special but never the less important event was the first landing of my neighbor’s new plane. Yesterday we got a start on getting the fishing nets ready. Made more progress today. Got the nets all identified as to size, length and depth. The fishing regulations on the rivers I fish specify how many fathoms (length) of net I can have in the water at one time. They specify the minimum and maximum length of the nets. Size has to do with the opening of the webbing the net is made of. Smaller fish can swim right through a net sized to catch a larger fish. A large fish can’t get far enough into a smaller webbing to be caught. Depth is the number webs from the top to the bottom of the net. So yesterday when I mentioned targeting a fish 120 feet away that referred to the maximum length (25 fathoms) net I can fish. A web opening of 6.5 inches will hold a good size King Salmon but a Sockeye will be able to swim through it. Wildflower has made this rack that looks like a hitching post. By draping the nets over the two racks it makes it a lot easier to examine the net for holes and to repair any that are found.

Yesterday was pretty quiet so nothing got posted here.  After working on sorting the nets for a couple of days, decisions were made about which ones to save/repair and those that ended up in the burn pile.  Four of the ones to be repaired got loaded into the two totes and hauled over to Wildflower’s rack. Today had a little more going on so here we go.  Mid-morning I blasted off to Wildflower’s place to start helping repair the nets.  He patiently showed me over and over how to throw a half hitch knot onto the lead line of the net.  After the first half hitch you wrap the cord used to hold the net on the lead line around twice then add another half hitch.  After that you carefully move down the line three webs and do it all over again.  Remember how some of these nets are 120 feet long and besides the bottom lead line there is the same thing to do on the float line in addition to keeping the floats evenly spaced.  That's a lot of half hitches!  This particular net needed to have the weighted line at the bottom of the net (lead line) patched on both ends.  The float line was OK. As we got the first end finished the VHF radio came to life.  One of the bush pilots radioed in that he was about to land on the strip about a mile from Wildflower’s cabin.  The plane was delivering the first of two loads of gear for two fish camps over on that side of Dry Bay. Hans can pack a lot of stuff into that DeHaveland Otter.  The other load was bigger than this one.  It had the parts to build two tote trailers like those in the first picture above as well as the totes themselves and a new Honda ATV like you see in that same picture. I bailed out on finishing the net we had started and headed home.  On the way I checked out a trail through the bush that will be easier for me to move the boat over to the Alsek River next week.  As I approached the cabin I saw… this large flock (couple of hundred) of Snow Geese grazing in the grasses out in front of my cabin.  They must have been enjoying the salad.  I flushed them as I crossed Dog Salmon Creek but they settled right back down after I passed.  Mixed in with all the Snows were some Lesser Canada Geese, White Fronted Geese and there were a couple of Emperor Geese in there too. As this is being typed Louis is barking outside.  He has gotten pretty comfortable with the space around the cabin.  He has a regular circuit he patrols when he goes out.  The reason for the barking are the geese.  They usually are not out there and anything different in his patrol area causes him to sound an alarm that means; “John! Something is different out here.  You better have a look!”. I did have a look.  The geese have moved across the sand and are almost into the grass in front.  They are beautiful. They don't seem to mind an old dog fussing at them.  They don't mind Louis either.

The weather forecaster was correct.  It started intermittent rain about three this morning.  As the day went on it became heavy at times then late this afternoon it has stopped.  There has been a steady 15 to 20 mph wind all day.  It is still very cloudy.  You can see the bottom of the mountains but the clouds are very thick above that. Because of the weather all I got done today was hang a thermometer.  It took four nails.  There was a lot of activity outside today in spite of the wind and rain. Each spring thousands if not millions of small sardine size fish come up the river in schools.  There are so many of these fish in the water there are darker areas where they are swimming.  I first noticed the activity because of a congregation of eagles. In the picture there are 18 Bald Eagles.  These huge raptors would hover in the wind mimicking humming birds, then drop down into the shallow water to catch the fish.  At one point I counted 26 eagles over that school of fish Downstream the gulls had their own school of fish to feed on.  I rode over there on the Honda.  The wind at my back the gulls ignored me as they held steady, facing into the wind and me.  From the splashing water and whitecaps you can see how strong the wind was. The eagles had moved on so another gang of gulls were working on that school.  With that side view of the action you could see the fish the gulls were catching.  As I watched, a gull would spread its wings and let the wind lift it off the water.  Sometimes the bird would drop the fish it had in its beak and dive back for another. The gull in the upper right of the picture has a fish.  Frenzy seems to be the proper word for what I witnessed.  A new sight for me but it has been happening here for thousands of years.  All of this happened just out my front door.  At one time I bet there were a thousand gull resting out there. Late this afternoon Louis and I took a walk over to the creek just to chase the Snow geese into the air.  My neighbor was nearby cleaning some Sockeye he had caught.  The neighbor is an Alaskan Native and can fish earlier than nonresidents.  He gave me a fillet.  .  In about ten minutes it was in the 400 degree oven with just a little seasoning on it.  Eighteen minutes later Louis got down off the bed and came over to see what was cooking.  It was delicious.

The weather forecaster was correct.  It started intermittent rain about three this morning.  As the day went on it became heavy at times then late this afternoon it has stopped.  There has been a steady 15 to 20 mph wind all day.  It is still very cloudy.  You can see the bottom of the mountains but the clouds are very thick above that. Because of the weather all I got done today was hang a thermometer.  It took four nails.  There was a lot of activity outside today in spite of the wind and rain. Each spring thousands if not millions of small sardine size fish come up the river in schools.  There are so many of these fish in the water there are darker areas where they are swimming.  I first noticed the activity because of a congregation of eagles. In the picture there are 18 Bald Eagles.  These huge raptors would hover in the wind mimicking humming birds, then drop down into the shallow water to catch the fish.  At one point I counted 26 eagles over that school of fish Downstream the gulls had their own school of fish to feed on.  I rode over there on the Honda.  The wind at my back the gulls ignored me as they held steady, facing into the wind and me.  From the splashing water and whitecaps you can see how strong the wind was. The eagles had moved on so another gang of gulls were working on that school.  With that side view of the action you could see the fish the gulls were catching.  As I watched, a gull would spread its wings and let the wind lift it off the water.  Sometimes the bird would drop the fish it had in its beak and dive back for another. The gull in the upper right of the picture has a fish.  Frenzy seems to be the proper word for what I witnessed.  A new sight for me but it has been happening here for thousands of years.  All of this happened just out my front door.  At one time I bet there were a thousand gull resting out there. Late this afternoon Louis and I took a walk over to the creek just to chase the Snow geese into the air.  My neighbor was nearby cleaning some Sockeye he had caught.  The neighbor is an Alaskan Native and can fish earlier than nonresidents.  He gave me a fillet.  .  In about ten minutes it was in the 400 degree oven with just a little seasoning on it.  Eighteen minutes later Louis got down off the bed and came over to see what was cooking.  It was delicious.

King Salmon began the day, were in the middle of the day and the day wound down with King Salmon. This morning Louis and I finished the last of the Cream of Wheat and were getting ready to go out when our neighbor showed up.  He brought over a plate of King Salmon and an omelet made with Sea Gull eggs.  It was delicious and much appreciated. The neighbor suggested I might have better fishing if I went to the river three or four hours before low tide instead of at the low tide.  In his words "fish the outgoing tide".  I did that and caught two nice Kings in the first twenty minutes.  After that one could see these big fish in the water but they quit biting.  Lock Jaw!  I released both fish.  I don't want to have to run the generator to keep them frozen and a King Salmon can feed nearly 20 people.  Tonight Lisa cooked a King caught yesterday.  It fed 11 adults and more than half of it was left over.  Unless I have some way to dispose of the fish I shouldn't keep them. So with that said you can see my day began and ended eating King Salmon and the middle of the day was spent catching them. In the picture, three month old Fathom Iris Graber is sizing up one of the Kings that used to live nearby.  She's pumping her little fist with approval.

Happy Memorial Day to you all especially those reading this that have served our country and in turn, some way, all of us.  It is an especially memorable May 26th for me in that several years ago on this day my first son was born.  It has been several years but I remember it like yesterday.  I bought those cigars that say "It's a Boy" and gave them to friends.  In those days one of them smoked the stinking thing inside the IBM office where I worked at the time.  Yes, it has been several years. Yesterday Wildflower, another fisherman and I went exploring farther up the Alsek River checking out spots to put our nets.  The first day of commercial fishing is next Sunday.  One can feel the tension rising as everyone is getting all the gear ready for the opener.  At the little harbor where we anchor the boats there was an otter sunning itself when we arrived. Last night we had three visitors.   Louis spotted them and tore out across the beach after them.  I was concerned that mama might turn on him but he was making so much noise barking and he wasn't closing the gap between himself and the bears very quickly.  Considering that, mama just disappeared into the brush.  When she did Louis came home acting very proud of himself!  These are probably the same three bears that were in the side yard earlier this month. Today I had four chores I wanted to get done.  1.  Fix the pump I use to get gas out of the barrels into the Hondas.  I broke off a bolt getting it apart so now I just tip the barrel over and pour the gas into a bucket then into the Honda.  This new way is much faster.  2.  Investigate why one of the wheels on a tote trailer seemed stiff.  When I turned the trailer over to check it out, it seemed to have gotten better on its own.  Maybe it was just stiff from the winter.  3. Change the oil in the new Honda.  Check.  4. Bake some more bread. That is a teaspoon in the pan.  There are six cups of flour in those two slices of bread which are supposed to be loaves.  I think my yeast died. Having at least addressed the four chores I decided to go fishing.  I caught two more Kings.  This big male was almost 4 feet long.    That's my boot in the water just below his head.  He was a big fish.  I let him and the other fish go.

No post yesterday because not much happened.  I didn't catch any King Salmon.  I don't think anyone else did either.  A friend asked if a fly rod was my weapon of choice.  I'm afraid one of those strong fish would just swim away with all the line on my reel.  The park ranger, Jim, uses a fly rod.  It is a bit heftier than the ones I have here.  I have been using a medium weight spinning outfit. The other thing that I remember happening was the Barn Swallows showed up.  They are a little earlier than last year.  They make themselves noticed by insisting on trying to swoop into the workshop looking for a place to build their mud nest.  Last year trying to keep them out I hung a fishing net across the open doorway.  Those swallows are so agile they would fly through the webbing of the net.  This year I drove a nail above the center of the door opening and hung my big raincoat from it.  As the coat moves around in the breeze it must look like me because the birds are staying out.  In another attempt to deter them last year, my neighbor from Boulder made a nesting platform for them and hung it on the north side of the cabin.  The swallows ending up building their nest on the east side. Today there was a little more going on.  Early, Louis and I rode down the river looking for some more good logs to build the wood storage shed.  I got him to ride down and back on the Honda with me.  He doesn't like getting on it but seems to enjoy the ride.  He sometimes has trouble getting settled on the back of the machine.  This afternoon he helped me build a bigger platform, one with a raised edge to give him something to brace against as we motor along.  I'll take a picture some day.  While down there we saw a really mangy looking coyote.  Louis chased it a short distance. Later in the morning did catch two more King Salmon.  I let another one get away due to rod and reel operator carelessness.  Gave one to a neighbor and let the third one go. One of the fishermen with a cabin nearby lives near Phoenix.  I went by his place today just to check on it.  No problem to report.  While I was over that way I did a little exploring on trails I had never been over before.  There were two grizzlies in a beautiful meadow.  I must have interrupted whatever they were up to.  It is impressive how quickly those bears can disappear into the brush.  Not far from there I found a moose antler. This picture was taken in the side yard.  The antler is resting among a few of the millions of Strawberry blooms and nearly as many Shooting Stars that adorn our part of Alaska in the spring.  A new blossom just starting to show up are the dark blue Wild Blue Flax below the left side of the antler.  A few Artic Lupine are starting to bloom.  In a couple of weeks there will be acres and acres of them too.

Yesterday and today were a little slow.  Slow fishing, no luck.  Slow internet, did get the checkbook balanced though.  Slow dog. Louis stayed on the bed all day.  Slow man, it took five hours to dig a log out of the sand, loaded on the trailer and delivered.  Wildflower has been getting the fishing nets repaired.  He wants the subject log to serve as the foundation for his wood shed.  It is a BIG creosote log. The needed rain and kinds foul weather showed up as the log was being extracted from the beach.  Rain, wind and a little fog.  This is not ubusual weather here on the edge of the Gulf of Alaska.  So that is my transition to the following copied off the internet.   The Gulf of Alaska is an arm of the Pacific Ocean defined by the curve of the southern coast of Alaska, stretching from the Alaska Peninsula and Kodiak Island in the west to the Alexander Archipelago in the east, where Glacier Bay and the Inside Passage are found. The entire shoreline of the Gulf is a rugged combination of forest, mountain, and a number of tidewater glaciers. Alaska's largest glaciers, the Malaspina Glacier and Bering Glacier spill out onto the coastal plain along the Gulf of Alaska. The coast is also heavily indented, with Cook Inlet and Prince William Sound the two largest connected bodies of water, but also including Yakutat Bay and Cross Sound. Lituya Bay is the site of the largest recorded tsunami (a wave over 1,500 feet high) in history and is a popular sheltered anchorage for fishing boats The Gulf is a great generator of storms. In addition to dumping vast quantities of snow and ice on southern Alaska, resulting in some of the largest concentrations south of the Arctic Circle, many of the storms move south along the coasts of British Columbia, Washington, Oregon, and as far south as Southern California (primarily during El Nino events). Much of the seasonal rainfall and snowfall in the Pacific Northwest and Southwestern United States comes from the Gulf of Alaska.   The Gulf of Alaska has also been known as the place where 2 oceans meet. Photographer Kent Smith snapped this photo of glacial waters from Alaska rivers merging with the darker blue waters of the Gulf of Alaska while on a cruise on July 10, 2010.   This picture of the Gulf of Alaska has been on the Internet for the last few year shows a strange natural phenomenon that occurs when heavy, sediment-laden water from glacial valleys and rivers pours into the open ocean. There in the gulf, the two types of water run into each other, a light, almost electric blue merging with a darker slate-blue. Informally dubbed “the place where two oceans meet,” the explanation for the photo is a simple one, though there are many misconceptions about it, including that catchy title.and the two types of water as being completely incapable of ever mixing, instead perpetually butting against each other like a boundary on a map.   That original photo, however, originates from a 2007 research cruise of oceanographers studying the role that iron plays in the Gulf of Alaska, and how that iron reaches certain areas in the northern Pacific. Ken Bruland, professor of ocean sciences at University of California-Santa Cruz, was on that cruise. In fact, he was the one who snapped the pic. He said the purpose of the cruise was to examine how huge eddies -- slow moving currents -- ranging into the hundreds of kilometers in diameter, swirl out from the Alaska coast into the Gulf of Alaska.   “Glacier rivers in the summertime are like buzzsaws eroding away the mountains there,” Bruland said. “In the process, they lift up all this material -- they call it glacial flour -- that can be carried out.” Once these glacial rivers pour out into the larger body of water, they’re picked up by ocean currents, moving east to west, and begin to circulate there. This is one of the primary methods that iron -- found in the clay and sediment of the glacial runoff -- is transported to iron-deprived regions in the middle of the Gulf of Alaska. As for that specific photo, Bruland said that it shows the plume of water pouring out from one of these sediment-rich rivers and meeting with the general ocean water. It’s also a falsehood that these two types of water don’t mix at all, he said.   “They do eventually mix, but you do come across these really strong gradients at these specific moments in time,” he said. Such borders are never static, he added, as they move around and disappear altogether, depending on the level of sediment and the whims of the water.   But rivers aren’t the only way that glacier sediment finds its way into the Gulf of Alaska -- occasionally strong winds can whip up enough silt to create a cloud of dust that’s visible even from space as its being carried out to sea. Copyright © 2014 Alaska Dispatch. All Rights Reserved. It is not unusual to see this plume right here at Dry Bay.  There are glacier fed rivers on both sides of us.  If you dip a glass of that glacial water out of the river the "flower" will settle out and perfectly clear water will be on top.  If you are really thirsty though you can just drink the water right out of the river.  The glacial flower is good fiber for one's system.

Nancy was so beautiful.  So strong.  She didn't write this prayer but I can feel her wanting me to do as it says. These were her words.  This is where she wanted to be...down by the creek below our house.  So be it.

Nancy was so beautiful.  So strong.  She didn't write this prayer but I can feel her wanting me to do as it says. These were her words.  This is where she wanted to be...down by the creek below our house.  So be it.

Well this year's first commercial fishing opening is history.  There is an old saying that when the tide comes in all the boats rise.  The tide of fish came in equally this year.  It seems the river and fish were kind to all the fishermen.  Everybody seems satisfied.  Wildflower and I caught over 1,500 pounds of salmon in the 48 hours of this first opener. That big guy is a King Salmon (24 pounds) the others are all Sockeye.  The sockeye are running a little over 6 pounds each. You can see  marks around the backs of some of the fish.  That is how far the fish got into the net before it was stuck.  At your local super market look at the whole salmon advertised as fresh wild salmon.  Those same marks will be on most of those fish too if they were caught in gill nets.  Some wild salmon are caught in the open ocean with other methods but those caught in gill nets will probably have those marks. My gracious neighbors fed a bunch of us tonight.  We had lamb, potatoes, fresh baked bread and chopped up brussels sprouts cooked with chopped up apples.  Man! After eating Grape Nuts for at least one meal each day lately this was fantastic. Before I have commented on what a close knit little community this is.  The guy in the picture, lets call him Joe, could use a little help around his cabin from time to time.  The hosts of the dinner sent away to Amazon for a tool they thought he could use.  He was very surprised.  That is Kaytlynn in the background trying to suppress a Bahawhaw. This is the bear that changed its mind about coming towards the cabin couple of days ago.  When he got within about two hundred yards of the cabin it turned around and went back into the brush.  I guess it remembered Louis, the famous bear dog, lives here.

This is the bear that changed its mind about coming towards the cabin couple of days ago.  When he got within about two hundred yards of the cabin it turned around and went back into the brush.  I guess it remembered Louis, the famous bear dog, lives here.

Today started off in an unusual way.  Louis sleeps on the bottom of the bed with me.  We have all watched dogs when they dream.  Their legs act like they would like to run but don’t quite.  Their ears and noses twitch.  Sometimes Louis will yelp little sounds like he has almost caught whatever he is chasing in his dream.  Sometimes those movements wake me up but not like last night.

 

The twitching went on for longer than usual and their frequency was different.  I raised up in bed to see if Louis was OK.  He was sound asleep.  The rocking chair was rocking back and forth.  The towel hanging near the stove to dry was swaying back and forth.  There is little rack over the stove where I hang wet gloves to dry them out.  They were dancing.  We were having an earthquake.  This went on for several seconds.  Long enough for me to wake completely up and think about tsunamis.  Then all was quiet.  I wondered if the VHF radio would come alive with some sort of announcement.  It didn’t.  Louis never woke up.

This morning I checked the internet.  The epicenter was about 20 miles from here in the direction of Haines.  It was a 5.8 quake.  Big enough to make the national news I subscribe to.

School must be out up here.  Less, the bush pilot mentioned earlier, brought an outfitter friend and his family down to fish for the Kings in the river.  Less and I watched a fish attack the lure Sarah was using.  We could see the chrome flashing in the water.  Then this big brown shape appeared behind the lure and it disappeared.  The next thing was he and I both saying “he got it”.  Then in about a half second Sarah’s rod bent way over and she yelled “I got one”.  Then there was a pop.  The fish broke off.  Later we could see the lure, still in the fishes mouth, sparkle in the water.  I guess he got tired of the jewelry though.  In a few minutes that same fish exploded out of the water in four terrific leaps and threw the flashing lure back at us.

Back to school letting out.  This evening another small plane kept circling around near the mouth of the river.  It landed not far from the cabin.  I went over and met Melissa, Crawford and daughter Scarlett.  They are going to camp out just across the creek from here for a couple of days.  They came well equipped.  An electric fence to erect around their tent.  Their tent they explained was a killer of a tent.  They had never set it up before.  Their plan is to do a little fishing.  I lent them one of the Hondas so they won’t have to walk so far to the fishing spot.  Scarlett has just become a third grader.

Most of the day was spent doing chores.  Two loads of fishy clothes, returned borrowed things, installed a new drum of fuel on the rack, watched a grizzly watch me, vacuum packed the salmon I caught a couple of days ago and shared my dinner with Louis.

Planned today so I could be on the river at the right part of the tide for the best King fishing.  Lately that has been about three hours before low tide.  About a half mile from the place I wanted to fish I ran out of gas.  The river has several sand bars down near the mouth so I thought I would take a shortcut across the sand bars to the "prime" spot.  Well the little sloughs between the main channel and sand bars were much deeper than my boots are tall.  The half mile turned out to be somewhat farther than that.  It wasn't long before the Carr family, who were airplane camping, came along with the Honda I lent them.  I confiscated it, came home got some gas, and now all is well again. Their daughter Scarlett and I got along well.  I enjoyed playing Granddaddy and she enjoy helping me fish.  The rod I was using was more her size.  Scarlett caught her first fish using it. Earlier there was a visitor across the river.  This wolf watched us as it trotted along but seemed to know we were far enough away to not be a threat.  Or maybe it was a young wolf who didn't know what a hazard humans can be toward his kind. There are a few Sockeye in the East River now.  No luck casting to them but I did get a good look at the wolf's tracks on that side of the river.  Its paw prints are as big as the palm paet of my hand.

Its Friday.  It seems Fridays usually come with some routine things to do and some things that one wanted to get done all week but become more urgent as the week's end closes in. Slim Pickins  asked me if I would help him address a bat problem in an older building his family owns.  To shorten this part of tonight's post I'll just say we removed ALL the insulation in the attic of the building. (it was hot up there)  We learned to keep the disturbed bats from flying all through the second floor rooms it was best to shut the doors of each room.  Then one stood a better chance of swatting the bats with a broom as they flew by in that smaller area.  One soon learned the critters tended to fly in a repeating pattern.  When you could figure out each bats flying pattern it was pretty easy to hit a hit instead of striking out with the broom. Weather permitting, most Friday evenings are spent clearing an old runway that runs behind several of the cabins.  The trees and brush have been encroaching onto the runway making it dicey to land a plane there.  So every Friday we get together and clear some of it.  The way it works is two people run chain saws until they have both gone through a tank of fuel.  The rest of us drag the downed brush and trees into a big pile and burn it.  The resulting bonfire is a perfect place for a hot dog roast complete with potato salad and somemors (?)   You can see the clumps of brush down either side of the runway that still have to be cleared. There are about 12 Hondas and one Yamaha ATV  here.  Nearly a traffic jam. The baby in the top picture is not 90 days old.  The lady in the chair in the yellow jacket is 92.  The lower picture bay Fathom with Mom and Grandmom.  Note the brown boots.  EVERYBODY in Alaska has at least one pair. That's Slim Pickins and baby Fathom.  I'm not sure about who the other two are.  Probably interlopers crashing bonfire for the free grub.

Rain, Rain, Rain more Rain.  That’s OK though it is supposed to rain here.

Yesterday at the bonfire Wildflower and I decided to get a head start on tomorrow’s opener by laying out nets on the shore where we plane to fish tomorrow.  There won’t be much tide tonight so they should be OK.

On the way over there I was travelling with the wind at my back.  That meant no rain was blowing down my shirt front.  Traveling along one of the backwater sloughs an otter popped out and ran across the trail.  That one was followed by six more.  They loped along one after the other like a brown slinky toy.  Reminded me of pearls on a string the way they followed each other.

I reduced an iceberg in size by chopping some much needed ice for the cooler from along its margins.  Not wanting to come home to the empty cabin too soon I stopped by an island where the sea gulls nest.  Most of the nests have three eggs in them now.  There are even some chicks in a few of them.  The gulls usually lay three eggs before they start to sit on them.  If the nest has only one or two eggs in it one can know she is not finished laying.  As said earlier, most nests have three eggs.  There will be a lot more gulls around before summer’s end.  Travelling home the wind and rain had picked up and were now in my face.  You can only pull the drawstring so tight on your hood to keep the rain out.

The highlight of the day happened about thirty minutes ago.  Louis had been holding the bed down all day and he decided he needed to take me for a walk.  We went around the side of the cabin and down a trail that leads out to the river.  About a quarter mile into the hike we reached a little clearing at EXACTLY the same time a grizzly did.  This bear was less than 50 feet away.  About the time I thought “that’s a bear” Louis was in full voice explaining to me in his “John, this is serious” voice.  In a lot less time than it takes to type this he had the bear on its way into the brush on the other side of the trail.  Then the second bear came out.  A cub!  Most bad bear encounters up here involve someone or something getting between the Mama bear and her cub.  There we were, Mama on the right side of the trail, Louis and I separated by 50 feet or so in the middle of the trail and the cub on the left side of the trail.  The cub solved the problem for us.  Like a fur covered chocolate brown donut hole the size of a large beach ball the cub caught up with Mama and they vanished.

Louis was so proud.  He had had a close encounter of the bear kind and was still around to bark about it.  I’m proud of my bear dog too.

Typing this early Tuesday morning.  Didn't have the energy to type on Monday about Sunday night. Earlier Saturday evening Louis and I had that bear encounter.  Yesterday morning when I went out to the Honda to load it up for the trip to the river, I noticed a little change in the seat. A bear had come by and took a bite out of it.  This machine was parked about 15 feet from the door to the cabin.  The visitor also turned over the burn barrel and left a deposit for us in the side yard.  I thought it was the same bears we had run into Saturday night.  A neighbor also had the seat on his ATV bitten.  Doing bear crime detective work takes diligence.  None of us, the neighbor, Louis or myself had heard a sound during the night.  Later in the day the neighbor ran into the culprit.  It was not the sow and cub from Saturday's encounter but a single bear.  He thinks it is an adolescent male.  It was wearing a brown outfit, including a hoodie that covered his face.  We now know who to look for should any more mysterious pranks occur.  The seat is serviceable now thanks to duct tape. The fishing was good yesterday.  The weather was awful.  It rained all day, temp. was in the low 50s.  Today there is a 40% chance of rain.  That is encouraging.  We caught good numbers of sockeye.  Only a couple of big kings and more immature kings than Wildflower had ever caught in his 28 years up here.  These immature king salmon are called "jacks".  Jacks bring just $1.00 a pound.  We may keep some of them in the future and smoke them for ourselves.

Back on the river this morning at 7:00 am.  This commercial fishing opener lasted two days and all fishing stopped today at twelve noon sharp.  As the morning went by you hear the outboard engines on the fishermen’s boats across the river. I couldn’t see across them this big river but could hear them.  Some of them were going upstream to clear their nets of fish.  Some were headed downstream, taking their catch to the buyer.  Others were relocating nets to what they hoped would be more productive spots next week, when the fishing begins again, Sunday at noon.

There was a grizzly on the trail this morning as I went across to the river.  He loped along in front of me looking back over first one shoulder then the other.  After about a hundred yards he went to the right and the path I was on went left.  As soon as he saw I wasn’t chasing him any longer he stopped and watched the noisy four wheeled beast move away.

For us the fishing was excellent.  For others the river and fishes were not as kind.  Fishing is kinda like life in some ways.  Good fortune doesn’t always fall where we think it should.  I guess the trick is to recognize it when it falls on oneself and appreciate the good fortune of others when it falls on them.

It is what it is.

The day began with a high but dense cloud cover.  Around ten the neighbors with the new cabin asked if I would help them put up some felt paper around the upper levels of their cabin.  We had just gotten a good start when it started to rain.  So much for that outside job. Park Service Ranger Kae stopped by and asked if I would like to tag along on a trip to evaluate the condition of a trail that has been closed for years.  This trail used to lead to near the head waters of the Doame River.  Years ago the Doame River emptied into the Pacific Ocean.  After a few earthquakes the river changed course and now flows into the East Alsek River, the same river that runs by my cabin. We rode the Hondas several miles on maintained trails, then another mile or so on an overgrown seldom used trail to where it ended at the edge of the river.  Now it was time to put on chest waders and wade across to the beginning of the closed/abandoned trail.  We were not sure where the trail was but soon found the parallel ruts left by ATVs years ago. One story I heard about why the trail was closed goes like this.  Beavers dammed up some of the tributaries of the Doame.  When their dams burst the flood ran down the ruts of the ATV trail and created new small streams.  Well the salmon started spawning in those new streams.  So to protect the salmon habitat the trail was closed.  As far as I know there is only one seldom used cabin back in there and there is an easier way to get to that cabin than on the trail anyway.  If this story is true, the salmon won and the people didn’t lose much if anything. In some places it was impossible to follow the old trail because of fallen trees and invasive Alders.  In other places it looked like this: This part of the Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve has some pretty old growth trees.  Many of them have become draped in moss.  The wildflowers sheltered by these monarchs are beautiful.  The rain, wind and poor light didn’t lend itself to many photographs but I did snap a few.   Please excuse the rain drop. Tomorrow will probably include getting ready to fish again on Sunday.  My daughter coordinated sending me a new weather station.  That will be fun to install….if it is not raining too hard.

It’s hard to decide where to begin writing today.  During the night when I looked out the water was nearly to the grass in front of the cabin.  There was an 11.62 foot tide last night.  I think that was the biggest tide since I have been here this year.  It cleared the beaches of what had accumulated on them.  No beachcombing treasures were left behind this time. Wildflower and I moved a couple of nets around out on the river.  We are ready to get back into commercial fishing mode tomorrow at noon. Daughter Ann sent me a fancy weather station.  EXACTLY the one I had hoped she would.  You readers may know more about the weather here than you care to from now in.  I.E. 73 inside, 53 outside, average wind 4.7 from the South dew point is 43 no rain since I installed it this afternoon.  Thank You Annie. Walking Louis this evening I remembered to take the camera. The grizzly bears use those long claws to dig up roots and little critters they want to eat.  The picture below is a typical hole one of those guys will excavate. These Chocolate Lilies are blooming all over this week. there are probably a hundred right around the cabin.  All those white blossoms in the background are strawberry flowers. I couldn't find the name of this beauty.  It is blooming along the trail behind the cabin. When I come across a heart shaped rock I think of only about two dozen things in the first second or two.  Family, loves lost, loves won, hoped for loves, and loves best left behind.  These loves are usually people but are also places and things.  I am lucky in that those first couple of seconds are filled with mostly positive loves.  Happy Father’s Day to all you men reading this.  If you get a chance, go out and look for a heart shaped something.  Spend a couple of seconds looking at it.

Gee, I did not remember how hard it can rain here.  Add that to the high tide and the normal way to the river isn't passable this morning.  My new weather station says it has rained 1.5 inches since midnight.  If it wasn't for the nets in the water I would just crank up the wood stove and go back to bed with Louis.  This fishing opener will expire tomorrow at noon.  That is one day longer than last week.  The extended openers means there are a lot of fish in the river.  Enough to allow plenty of them to move on upstream to spawn.  It also means some tired old fishermen are gulping down aspirin and ibuprofen.  Picking the tangled fish out of the nets is hard on your back, shoulders and hands.  But somebody's got to do it.  I'm glad I can.

The fishing has been very good.  Wildflower and I have put several hundred salmon in the boat that weighed over 2,000 pounds since Sunday at noon.  That doesn't count this mornings catch.  That's a lot of fish but some fishermen are doing better than that with fewer nets.  Location, Location, Location applies to net placement too.

I jumped another bear yesterday morning as I went toward the river.  Because of the higher tides I couldn't cross a slough where I usually do.  When your Honda starts to float downstream one must quickly decide;  Do I go where the tide takes me or do I get the hell out of there and back to shallower water?  I'm going to take the long way around this morning.

Gee, I did not remember how hard it can rain here.  Add that to the high tide and the normal way to the river isn't passable this morning.  My new weather station says it has rained 1.5 inches since midnight.  If it wasn't for the nets in the water I would just crank up the wood stove and go back to bed with Louis.  This fishing opener will expire tomorrow at noon.  That is one day longer than last week.  The extended openers means there are a lot of fish in the river.  Enough to allow plenty of them to move on upstream to spawn.  It also means some tired old fishermen are gulping down aspirin and ibuprofen.  Picking the tangled fish out of the nets is hard on your back, shoulders and hands.  But somebody's got to do it.  I'm glad I can.

The fishing has been very good.  Wildflower and I have put several hundred salmon in the boat that weighed over 2,000 pounds since Sunday at noon.  That doesn't count this mornings catch.  That's a lot of fish but some fishermen are doing better than that with fewer nets.  Location, Location, Location applies to net placement too.

I jumped another bear yesterday morning as I went toward the river.  Because of the higher tides I couldn't cross a slough where I usually do.  When your Honda starts to float downstream one must quickly decide;  Do I go where the tide takes me or do I get the hell out of there and back to shallower water?  I'm going to take the long way around this morning.

Another commercial fishing opener is over.  Wildflower said today, "you know it has been a good opener when you are glad it's over."  (Translation;   the weather was bad we are both exhausted but, we caught some fish and we made some money.  Now we can rest.)  Together in three days we caught over 570 fish that weighed over 3,700 pounds. A couple of extra events were added to this opener.  I already mentioned going afloat on the Honda when the high tide made the slough deeper than expected.  Today motoring down Muddy Creek in the skiff I ran over a submerged log.  Wildflower was holding on for dear life as the boat suddenly changed speed and direction.  Now the motor is making a strange sound when I raise or lower it.  More on this later.  Then there was the encounter with the patrolling parasitic jaegers. These birds are nesting along side the road to the boat harbor.  When you approach them from either direction they lift off the ground like a couple of F-15s going on alert over the White House.   To them, I am  the invader (me on the Honda)  They soar up to about thirty feet then turn, radar locked on, and dive at the intruder.  One of the pair is usually coming in from straight ahead.  The other one is preforming a flanking maneuver and coming in from the rear quarter.  Of course you are focused on the one about to stab you in the forehead with its beak.  The flanking bird has designs on the back of your head.  They zoom by so close you can see the little claws on their feet.   I got the following off WIKIPEDIA: The parasitic jaeger, also known as the arctic skua or parasitic skua, (Stercorarius parasiticus) is a seabird in the skua family Stercorariidae. This species breeds in the north of Eurasia and North America, with significant populations as far south as northern Scotland. It nests on dry tundra, higher fells and islands, laying up to four olive-brown eggs. It is usually silent except for mewing and wailing notes while on the breeding grounds. Like other skuas, it will fly at the head of a human or fox approaching its nest. Although it cannot inflict serious damage, it is a frightening and painful experience. It is a migrant, wintering at sea in the tropics and southern oceans. In the British Isles, they breed in Shetland and Orkney, the Outer Hebrides, Sutherland, Caithness, and some islands in Argyll. This bird will feed on rodents, small birds and insects but also robs gulls and terns of their catches. Like the larger skua species, it continues this piratical behaviour throughout the year, showing great agility as it harasses its victims.
A parasitic jaeger pursuing a kittiwake
Identification is complicated by similarities to long-tailed jaeger and pomarine skua, and the existence of three colour morphs. Small for a skua, the parasitic jaeger measures 41–48 cm (16–19 in) in length, 107–125 cm (42–49 in) in wingspan and weighs 300–650 g (0.66–1.43 lb).[2][3] The tail streamer of the breeding adult accounts for about 7 cm (2.8 in) of their length. Light-morph adults have a brown back, mainly white underparts and dark primary wing feathers with a white "flash". The head and neck are yellowish-white with a black cap and there is a pointed central tail projection. Dark-morph adults are dark brown, and intermediate-phase birds are dark with somewhat paler underparts, head and neck. All morphs have the white wing flash.
An immature
Juveniles are even more problematic, and are difficult to separate from long-tailed jaegers. They are bulkier, shorter-winged, and less tern-like than that species, but show the same wide range of plumage variation. The flight is more falcon-like. However, they are usually warmer toned than Long-tailed, with browner shades, rather than grey. The call of these birds which is most often heard is a nasal mewing sound, repeated a few times in display, whereas its alarm call is a shorter sound. I managed to fire off a few fingered gesture at the oncoming F-15 but the flanking defender overcame my blind side defenses and popped me right on the top of my bald head.  I did have the hood of my rain gear over my head.  That might have prevented any structural damage but the noise of the birds beak, feet, wings, whatever was really loud and unexpected.  This all happens over a part of the trail where you can't go very fast.  I bet the jaegers get a kick out of all this.  We are probably more fun to attack than a plane old sea gull.

I spent today trying to do laundry and trying to figure  out why the washing machine wouldn't fill with water.  That wasn't nearly as much fun as yesterday when we went out taking pictures of the amazing wildflowers that are blooming now.  The Lupines in the picture cover acres of the meadows that are along some of the trails.  These are much taller than the Texas Blue Bonnets.  There are a few scattered around among the millions that are pure white. Louis was along with me.  He enjoys the long walks.  His coat is getting longer and he gets hot..  A couple of times he would just lay down in the water to cool off. The hummingbirds are later this year than last.  They are drinking this feeder dry about every eight hours. I was having a conversation with one of the Park Rangers yesterday.  It amazes me how much detail they know about the areas they patrol.  For example in the picture below;   Note the little yellow flowers on the left side of the picture.  The state of Alaska ( or some department in the state government) manage the regulations, usage etc. of the waters of the state with a few exceptions.  The land is often managed by some other entente like the BLM or National forest.  Those little flowers are called CINQUEFOIL.  They grow along the margin of the high tides.  The area on the right of the picture has no Cinquefoil so that is within the tidal zone and managed by the state.  Where the Cinquefoil are growing, that land is managed by someone else.  In some cases one can't tread on the managed land where the Cinquefoil grow but can use the area where the Cinquefoil do not grow.  I think its pretty cool to let nature draw the boundaries. We don't usually have a bug problem here because of the steady ocean breeze but just in case I bought a mosquito net to put over the open door.  That is a regular padlock hasp on the door. The locals tell me the ones I might catch are pretty good fried.

Here we go again.  The days will start getting shorter.  Don't usually notice it till August when it will actually be dark when I go to bed.  Last night there were hummingbirds on the feeder when I went to bed around 10:30.  At four this morning they were out there again.  In a few weeks they will have headed off to Costa Rica and lines of other birds will be migrating back down the coast.

I saw four bears yesterday.  A sow and twin cubs when I was on the way back from the river.  As I approached them on the trail she stood up to get a better view of me.  They were ion a slight knoll standing among the blooming purple Lupines.  The snow capped peaks were behind them.  It would have been a terrific photograph.  I had the camera in my pocket but by the time I got it out and turned on they were gone.  I rode the wheeler over to where they had been but the Alder brush had swallowed them up.

Last evening the fly rod took me down to the East River to limber up a little.  It wanted to be sure I remembered how to use it.  Louis went along too.  He is easily spooked by strange noises.  He didn't like the noise the rod makes while casting so he soon returned to the cabin.  On my way back there was a bear eating Cow Parsnip about a hundred yards away.  I said hello.  It didn't even stand up to wave back.  He just turned around and continued eating, ignoring me.

I few days ago I sent a note to nine people I know well enough to beg.  In the note explained that a guy from Kentucky, out here in the wilderness, needs to be reminded of home from time to time.  The note went on to describe how a bottle of Bourbon lasts only a few days here.  Visitors come by and kind of expect a guy from KY to have some flavoring for their drink of water.  Anyway, in the note, I spelled out if those nine  people each sent me two bottles I might have enough "flavoring" to get me through the summer.

Earlier this year my kid sister had used one of those post office flat rate boxes to send a me a sample of Kentucky's finest.  In my note I suggested the others use that method to ship their "gifts".  I have a Dear Cousin all the way over in Florida who actually read the note and sent along a box FULL of my requested thirst quencher.  I copied my sister on the note thanking my cousin for her generosity.  Guess what my sister did.   She sent me a note back asking if she could arrange for me to join AA when I get back to Colorado.

If my sister ever comes up here for a visit I'm going to pitch her tent in some Cow Parsnip.

Today began at five.  The commercial fishing “openers” begin on Sunday at twelve noon sharp.  The department of fish and wildlife have some formula to determine if enough fish are in the river to allow continued fishing past Monday at noon.  At nine on Monday an announcement is made over the VHF radio letting all of us know if the fishing will be extended one, two or three days.  Today there was no extension so that meant all the fishing gear had to be pulled out of the river by noon.  As I understand it, depending on the number of fishermen fishing and the number of fish being sold a determination can be made as to the health of the fishery at any point in time and if continued fishing should be allowed.  The reason for the early start on Monday is to report any fish caught overnight.  The more fish reported the more likely the opener will be extended.

Well several fishermen were not catching many fish this opener so the formula told fish and game to not extend the opener past noon today.  Last week we were allowed to fish for three days.  This week just the one.  Wildflower and I caught a couple hundred pounds of fish but nothing like the earlier catches.  A neighbor showed me a real simple way to cook the salmon.  Cut the fillets into strips one inch square.  In a plastic bag put the fish, spices or seasoning you like to use.  Shake the bag to coat the strips.  Fry the strips in a little oil.  It is so easy even I can do it.  The left over strips make a great addition to an omelet the next day

The weather yesterday and today was crummy.  A light misting rain fell most of the time.  It wasn’t too bad though since there was little or no wind.  The temperature was in the mid-50s.  But there was some fog.

As mentioned several times here, the Alsek River is fed in part by a couple of glaciers.  The water where we fish is a silvery gray due to the large amount of glacial powder suspended in it.  Frequently icebergs come down the river.  The temperature of the water is in the mid-thirties.  There are places in the river where there are whirlpools spinning trapped icebergs around and around.  Some places are very deep yet the water boils up from some unseen obstruction or maybe it is just the powerful current making the turbulence.

Looking across more than the mile width of the river this morning, there was a layer of fog about three to four feet thick starting at the surface.  We drive our boats standing up.  It was easy to see over the fog standing but you couldn’t see the water.  Was that a log?  Nope just a wave!  How about that, an iceberg?  Nope just a reflection!  Is that twig in the water attached to a submerged tree?  The fog looked like the top of a layer of clouds we have all seen as we look out the window of an airliner passes through.  The fog is interesting to watch as it caresses the water.  The fog seems to sooth the appearance of the dangerous current under it.

The black wolf trotted by again just now.  Louis saw it and was barking.  That is what got our attention.  One of the men from the fish plant was here using the internet.  He jumped on his Honda and took off after the wolf trying to get a picture.  He did get a couple of long range shots but the wolf easily kept the space between them from closing.

The article below was sent to me by a friend.  It goes into more detail than my recent post about the weather created by the Gulf of Alaska.  Please forgive the weird spacing. One reader asked about the size of the net I use to catch mosquitoes.  I use that size because the ones it catches fry up the best.  The bigger ones are too tough.    
 
 

Gulf of Alaska Storms

As summer wanes and the sun's influence on high Northern Hemisphere latitudes diminishes, the prime global breeding grounds for northern winter storms renew their vigour. One can be found in the North Atlantic Ocean between the coasts of Greenland and Iceland, the appropriately named Icelandic Low. The second lies in the North Pacific off the coast of Alaska between the Aleutian Islands archipelago and the southern Alaska coast. It goes by the names the Aleutian Low and the Gulf of Alaska Low. These low pressure zones are semipermanent features of the global weather map and general circulation patterns that diminish in extent and depth during the warm season and intensify during the cold months.
The Aleutian Low and the eastern North Pacific High found to the south have a cyclic relationship during the course of the year which impacts the weather along the west coasts of Canada and the United States and into the northern portions of the western Cordilleran. Since this is also a prime source region for Pacific maritime air masses, the weather patterns across the continent are also affected. Within the subpolar zone, warm air moving north from the tropics and cold air moving south from the Arctic clash, a conflict that is strongest during the cold half of the year and weakest during the warm season months. After an active winter, the Aleutian Low diminishes slightly in March and by April is sending fewer storms outward. The feature virtually disappears in July, appearing as a trough of low pressure rather than a tight low-pressure cell. As solar energy falling on the arctic regions diminishes, the Aleutian Low again strengthens in September, ready to produce a litter of winter storms. The clash between cold and mild air generates spinning, low-pressure cells that grow to energetic youth over the Gulf of Alaska. As a result, meteorologists call the region a "center of action" for North Pacific maritime and coastal storms. The Aleutian Low region is characterized by barometric pressure readings of 101.3 kPa or less, high humidity, and generally complete cloud covers. When a newly born storm spins up, the region experiences strong winds and heavy precipitation, most falling as rain, despite the high latitude. By November, the Aleutian Low average surface pressure has dropped to 100.2 kPa, a level it maintains for much of the winter. The Gulf of Alaska lies in the arched bite of the State, south of Anchorage between the Kenai Peninsula and Kodiak Island and the eastern panhandle. The northern coast of the gulf is fortressed by the Wrangell/St Elias Mountains — one of the world's highest mountain ranges which continues to grow at a geologically-hyper speed of 4 cm (1.6 inches) per year — that effectively block most storms from entering eastern Alaska and the Yukon Territory. The Gulf of Alaska is the most common entry point for the northeastern Pacific storm track that sends stormy weather to the North American coast.
Storms move out of the Gulf of Alaska into the Pacific Northwest region of the continent with great regularity, as many as three or four per week during the height of the winter storm season. Quite often, these storms are packed so closely that the Pacific Northwest does not experience the clearing weather break so common over the rest of the continent. I have compared this train of tempests to the roll of a nearly never-ending freight train of nearly uniform boxcars. As each storm rolls by, the clearing break is often no more than a tease, like the daylight seen between the roll of a chain of boxcars. Only rarely in some areas of the coast does a "flat car" appear and the "caboose" may not arrive until spring. Winter Gulf of Alaska storms typically sport winds in excess of 80 km/h (50 mph) with corresponding high waves. Some storms rival the strength of the great hurricanes/typhoons and would be considered as such if their origins were tropical rather than polar. (In fact, the Hurricane Hunter air squadron often deploys aircraft into these storms to study their structure.) Winds as high as 160 km/h (100 mph) have been recorded with wave heights pushing 20 m (65 ft) or more. Over the years, these storms have taken their toll of fishing and merchant vessels caught in open waters. When these storms hit the North American coast, they encounter a series of high mountain ranges parallelling the coast from central Alaska southward into California. The mountains force the storm air to great altitudes causing then to dump much of their prodigious moisture content on the coastal mountains as rain and snow. The result is the incredibly dense temperate rainforests that cover the coast from Alaska's Panhandle through British Columbia and into northern California.
In these regions, rain and snow are measured in metres (yards) annually. During the winter, nearly all days report rain or snow somewhere in the region. The wetness sits in the region can be exemplified by Juneau, Alaska — 222 wet days annually; Prince Rupert, British Columbia — 240; Clearwater, Washington — 192; and Astoria, Oregon — 190. The world's record for snowfall in one snow year (which runs from July 1-June 30) was established on Mt Baker in Washington in 1998-99: 2986 cm (1140.0 inches). And North America's wettest year drenched Montague Island's MacLeod Harbor, about 112 km (70 miles) east of Seward, Alaska with 8440 mm (332.29 inches) in 1976.

For Strong Winds:Gulf of Alaska Storms ©2003, 2005, Keith C. Heidorn, PhD. All Rights Reserved.

As summer wanes and the sun's influence on high Northern Hemisphere latitudes diminishes, the prime global breeding grounds for northern winter storms renew their vigour. One can be found in the North Atlantic Ocean between the coasts of Greenland and Iceland, the appropriately named Icelandic Low. The second lies in the North Pacific off the coast of Alaska between the Aleutian Islands archipelago and the southern Alaska coast. It goes by the names the Aleutian Low and the Gulf of Alaska Low. These low pressure zones are semipermanent features of the global weather map and general circulation patterns that diminish in extent and depth during the warm season and intensify during the cold months.
The Aleutian Low and the eastern North Pacific High found to the south have a cyclic relationship during the course of the year which impacts the weather along the west coasts of Canada and the United States and into the northern portions of the western Cordilleran. Since this is also a prime source region for Pacific maritime air masses, the weather patterns across the continent are also affected. Within the subpolar zone, warm air moving north from the tropics and cold air moving south from the Arctic clash, a conflict that is strongest during the cold half of the year and weakest during the warm season months. After an active winter, the Aleutian Low diminishes slightly in March and by April is sending fewer storms outward. The feature virtually disappears in July, appearing as a trough of low pressure rather than a tight low-pressure cell. As solar energy falling on the arctic regions diminishes, the Aleutian Low again strengthens in September, ready to produce a litter of winter storms. The clash between cold and mild air generates spinning, low-pressure cells that grow to energetic youth over the Gulf of Alaska. As a result, meteorologists call the region a "center of action" for North Pacific maritime and coastal storms. The Aleutian Low region is characterized by barometric pressure readings of 101.3 kPa or less, high humidity, and generally complete cloud covers. When a newly born storm spins up, the region experiences strong winds and heavy precipitation, most falling as rain, despite the high latitude. By November, the Aleutian Low average surface pressure has dropped to 100.2 kPa, a level it maintains for much of the winter. The Gulf of Alaska lies in the arched bite of the State, south of Anchorage between the Kenai Peninsula and Kodiak Island and the eastern panhandle. The northern coast of the gulf is fortressed by the Wrangell/St Elias Mountains — one of the world's highest mountain ranges which continues to grow at a geologically-hyper speed of 4 cm (1.6 inches) per year — that effectively block most storms from entering eastern Alaska and the Yukon Territory. The Gulf of Alaska is the most common entry point for the northeastern Pacific storm track that sends stormy weather to the North American coast.
Storms move out of the Gulf of Alaska into the Pacific Northwest region of the continent with great regularity, as many as three or four per week during the height of the winter storm season. Quite often, these storms are packed so closely that the Pacific Northwest does not experience the clearing weather break so common over the rest of the continent. I have compared this train of tempests to the roll of a nearly never-ending freight train of nearly uniform boxcars. As each storm rolls by, the clearing break is often no more than a tease, like the daylight seen between the roll of a chain of boxcars. Only rarely in some areas of the coast does a "flat car" appear and the "caboose" may not arrive until spring. Winter Gulf of Alaska storms typically sport winds in excess of 80 km/h (50 mph) with corresponding high waves. Some storms rival the strength of the great hurricanes/typhoons and would be considered as such if their origins were tropical rather than polar. (In fact, the Hurricane Hunter air squadron often deploys aircraft into these storms to study their structure.) Winds as high as 160 km/h (100 mph) have been recorded with wave heights pushing 20 m (65 ft) or more. Over the years, these storms have taken their toll of fishing and merchant vessels caught in open waters. When these storms hit the North American coast, they encounter a series of high mountain ranges parallelling the coast from central Alaska southward into California. The mountains force the storm air to great altitudes causing then to dump much of their prodigious moisture content on the coastal mountains as rain and snow. The result is the incredibly dense temperate rainforests that cover the coast from Alaska's Panhandle through British Columbia and into northern California.
In these regions, rain and snow are measured in metres (yards) annually. During the winter, nearly all days report rain or snow somewhere in the region. The wetness sits in the region can be exemplified by Juneau, Alaska — 222 wet days annually; Prince Rupert, British Columbia — 240; Clearwater, Washington — 192; and Astoria, Oregon — 190. The world's record for snowfall in one snow year (which runs from July 1-June 30) was established on Mt Baker in Washington in 1998-99: 2986 cm (1140.0 inches). And North America's wettest year drenched Montague Island's MacLeod Harbor, about 112 km (70 miles) east of Seward, Alaska with 8440 mm (332.29 inches) in 1976.

The article below was sent to me by a friend.  It goes into more detail than my recent post about the weather created by the Gulf of Alaska.  Please forgive the weird spacing. One reader asked about the size of the net I use to catch mosquitoes.  I use that size because the ones it catches fry up the best.  The bigger ones are too tough.

There have been a few more bears around the last week or so.  Traveling over to the boat I see on every other day or so.  Two days ago Louis and I came across two out back of the cabin.  He ran them off into the bushes.  Last evening there were these two out front.  The one on the left continued on into the brush while the one on the right just settled down into the sand to rest.  He didn’t get to rest long because between Louis, the two neighbor dogs and me he had to go. Later the one on the left in the first picture came back out and was enjoying a salad of Cow Parsnip in the front yard.   It has been raining on and off since Saturday.  Today there is a wind from the south and it is 49 degrees at 1:00 in the afternoon as I type this. I think I will just curl up on the bed with Louis and wait for better weather before I do anything outside.

Later the one on the left in the first picture came back out and was enjoying a salad of Cow Parsnip in the front yard.   It has been raining on and off since Saturday.  Today there is a wind from the south and it is 49 degrees at 1:00 in the afternoon as I type this. I think I will just curl up on the bed with Louis and wait for better weather before I do anything outside.

Today I needed some ice for the cooler.  Frequently icebergs will float all the way down the Alsek River from the glaciers and wash ashore at the river’s mouth.  The trip around the mouth of the Alsek on the Honda didn’t produce any ice today so that meant a trip out onto the river to try and find some. On the way to the boat I saw a beautiful wolf.  A big one with a mottled coat, shades of brown, gray and black.  It has taken you longer to read this sentence than the wolf was within sight before it disappeared into the Alders.  When I’m on the Honda I need to start looking farther down the trail to see these elusive animals sooner. The river is about a mile wide near where we anchor the boats.  The ice coming downstream doesn’t get pushed by the current into the sheltered anchorage so I figured if there was any ice to be found it would be out where the current is strongest.  Sure enough there were some icebergs out there.  So were some trees and snags that had been washed off the banks of the river upstream.  When you find ice floating down the river you run the boat up to it then with a gaff in one hand try to keep the boat within reach of the ice and with a gaff in the other hand chop off pieces of ice small enough to lift into the boat.  While doing this the boat and ice are floating down the river together.  Remember those trees and snags?  If one doesn't keep an eye out one ends up being swept into the branches of a snag then the fun begins.  The current is so swift the boat was well below where I started out when I figured I had enough ice. The trip produced enough ice to share with a couple of neighbors. The hummingbirds are still around.  That feeder has 8 little holes in it where they can get to the sugar water.  In this picture there are over a dozen of the little guys sharing those eight holes.

This morning it looked like we might have a day without showers or rain.  Some of the old timers up here think it is foolish to go far from the cabin without rain gear stashed on the Honda.  Not being an old timer I sometimes get wet.  Not today.  It was beautiful. The beautiful day was mostly spent inside hanging new fishing nets.  Having never done this before I asked Wildflower if he would show me how it was done.  Being the kind old gentleman he is (nine days older than me) he said sure.  I thought if I put off the lesson long enough he would just go ahead and hang the new nets himself but he, being older, was onto my scheme. In the picture the webbing of the new net is hanging from a beam that runs across his cabin.  The float line gas already been attached. In this second picture is the bench set up to allow you to correctly space the knots that hold the net on the float line and lead line.  If you look closely there are pins sticking up out of the  board that protrudes out the front of the bench.  Those pins are the correct distance apart for the knots.  Between each knot there are three meshes of met.  This net is 20 fathoms long.  Each knot is made up of three half hitches.  If you do the math there are about 500 knots to be tied.  After one has hung a few dozen nets one can hang a net in about four hours.  It took me over six hours but I'm beginning  to get the hang of it.

When the commercial fishing begins almost everything else around here gets put on a back burner.  As mentioned here before the fishing starts at exactly 12:00 noon on Sunday.  All the fishermen are poised, watching their watches for the time when the nets can be pulled into the water.  In the picture below you can see this guy was ready to go way ahead of time.  Even had his lawn chair out.  Might as well be comfortable waiting for time to pass. The flowers are probably at their peak now.  The lupines are starting to fade but meadows, trail sides and old logs are in full bloom.   Lots of wildlife sightings since anything got posted here.  The black wolf was out front Saturday night.  I’ve seen seven or eight bears in the last two days and this afternoon this moose was across the slough from Wildflower’s cabin. Last week considerable time was spent hanging the new nets.  This fish was the first one to try them out.

Last week considerable time was spent hanging the new nets.  This fish was the first one to try them out.

The latest commercial fishing opener is history.  My nets continued to produce fair results but Wildflower’s nets caught a lot of fish.  Together we took over well over 3,000 pounds of fish to the buyer.

The river has been low so far this year.  This week it began to come up to the normal spring runoff levels.  That deeper water and faster current changes how the fish move and in turn where you set your nets.  What might have been a highly productive spot last week was not this week.  Of the three nets I have been fishing two were catching fish.  I moved the third net five times in the three day opener.  Last night it finally caught a couple of fish.  Two big King Salmon to be specific.  One of them weighed 25 pounds the other 30 plus a few sockeye.

It is a mystery to me how the fish move in the water of the Alsek.  It is so cloudy with glacial powder you can’t see more than a couple of inches into it.  Yet millions of fish swim up this river to spawn, following the scent of the stream where they were born.   Sometimes we will catch a single fish.  This week many of the fish caught in the net seemed to be in pairs.  In one instance I was surprised by what seemed to be an explosion in the net.  In about 15 seconds more than a dozen fish hit.  Then the rest of the afternoon nothing else came by.

Traveling back and forth from the cabin to the boat I saw several bears.  There was one sow with twin cubs along the trail from the fish plant.  The Park Ranger saw here too.  The Ranger said that bear was the biggest sow she had ever seen.  In typical mother bear fashion she ran into the bush leading her cubs.  When they are safe she will turn around and see if you are a threat.  I would like to get a picture of all this but there is something about a mother bear’s attitude that causes me to keep right on going down the trail.  One of my old Uncles told me a long time ago, “You can’t win if you try to get between mama bear and her babies”.

I kept several small Kings this week.  Tomorrow I will vacuum pack and freeze them.  I need to see if all the parts I need for the smoker are working.  The next batch of fish I keep just might get smoked if everything is in order.  Someday I would like to try canning some salmon.  No refrigeration required then.

This afternoon I tried to wash all the stinky clothes accumulated from the fishing.  The washer went through the first cycle just fine.  It refilled with water and quit.  Now most of my clothes are floating around in the tub of the washer.  If I can’t get it going in the morning I’ll dip the water out and maybe go looking for a new washing machine on-line.  Oh yeah, the older generator conked out this week too.  I may need to charter a plane to Juneau to find replacement for these things.  Louis is almost out of dog food   I could go up to Yakutat, take a commercial plane to Juneau.  Then return the same way.  I need to check on all the options. Charter directly to Juneau or go commercial.  If it is nice tomorrow and I can get my clothes dried out I will probably just put all this off except for the dog food.
