Happy Independence Day from Dry Bay, Alaska.  For several days there has been a lot of activity over around the fish plant.  Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday there were fish to process and planes to load.  In addition from now through September there will be two or three groups of rafters coming down the Alsek River each week.  Most of them come off the river at a site near the plant.  Then planes come in from Yakutat or Haines and fly the rafters back out to civilization.

On top of all that today the community Fourth of July celebration was held at the plant.  That location was a good choice for today.  It has rained steadily.  At the plant we could all be inside out of the weather.  Most of the seasonal residents showed up for a pot lunch meal.  One of the special treats beyond the normal pot luck fare were fresh oysters either on the half shell or cooked.  Another was fresh wild strawberry/rhubarb pie.  Finally someone brought a tossed green salad.  I haven’t had fresh green anything since the end of April.

I didn’t get any of the pie because the chef said I had to wait for the homemade ice cream to go with it.  I didn’t want to hang around the gathering long enough for that.  I took plastic cups, knives, forks and spoons.  Most everyone seemed to enjoy my contribution.  Next year I might take napkins.  I don’t cook much!

Lots of bear sightings lately.  Two were in front of the cabin today.  The wolf is still leaving paw prints in the sand out front most nights.  I saw an otter just across the creek yesterday on my way over to the river to get some more ice.  I will go back to the boat again tomorrow.

Next Monday wildflower has several guests coming in for a visit.  Because of that he and I will fish separately the rest of the year.  He taught me a lot in the few weeks we fished together.  I appreciate his patience.  I had been fishing with one of his nets so I need to take one of my own over to fish with from now on this season.

There was an announcement yesterday that the East Alsek River will be open for commercial fishing Sunday at noon till Monday at noon.  The East River is the one just outside my cabin door.  I may start fishing there a little later on but this week I’ll stay on the bigger river.  If there are a lot of fish in the East River I may move over here the next week.  Fish and Game laws won’t let me fish in the two different rivers at the same time with the one permit I have.

Happy Independence Day from Dry Bay, Alaska.  For several days there has been a lot of activity over around the fish plant.  Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday there were fish to process and planes to load.  In addition from now through September there will be two or three groups of rafters coming down the Alsek River each week.  Most of them come off the river at a site near the plant.  Then planes come in from Yakutat or Haines and fly the rafters back out to civilization.

On top of all that today the community Fourth of July celebration was held at the plant.  That location was a good choice for today.  It has rained steadily.  At the plant we could all be inside out of the weather.  Most of the seasonal residents showed up for a pot lunch meal.  One of the special treats beyond the normal pot luck fare were fresh oysters either on the half shell or cooked.  Another was fresh wild strawberry/rhubarb pie.  Finally someone brought a tossed green salad.  I haven’t had fresh green anything since the end of April.

I didn’t get any of the pie because the chef said I had to wait for the homemade ice cream to go with it.  I didn’t want to hang around the gathering long enough for that.  I took plastic cups, knives, forks and spoons.  Most everyone seemed to enjoy my contribution.  Next year I might take napkins.  I don’t cook much!

Ever have one of those days when even the simplest thing can turn into a real mess. Sure, we all have. Today a couple of really simple things went way south while I was on the river.

The first one involves resetting the little ten fathom net. The fishing was slow and I had moved one other net to a more promising spot. When you find a spot where there is an eddy in the water and the water is deep enough and there are no trees or snags on the bottom to tangle your net in a person should try setting a net there. There was just such a spot along the bank of the river just barely off the main channel. The glacier upstream was calving off very large icebergs this morning. These bergs were floating by at about 6 miles an hour just beyond where I wanted to set up in that little eddy. You probably know what you see of an iceberg is only about ten percent of the size of the beast. Some of them this morning were more than 20 feel long and were sticking out of the water three or four feet. Even a beach ball size chunk of ice can play hell with a net if it has a current pushing it along. Back to the simple thing of setting the net. First you climb up the bank of the river and set an anchor to hold the shore end of the net so the webbing is in the water. Depending on the way the net is rigged that anchor might be 20 feet from the edge of the water. Then you back the boat out into the river letting the net spill over the into the water until you get to the other anchor at the far end of the net. You hold onto the anchor pulling the net tight then throw the anchor overboard, hoping it will catch the bottom and hold the net straight. Simple. Usually. The current was so strong on the outside of the eddy the boat swung around and the propeller caught the anchor rope. It only wound around the prop two or three times before the engine quit. There I am anchored to the bottom with no engine, the stern of the boat pointed upstream toward those United Van Lines size icebergs coming down the river. I raised the outboard so the prop was out of the water but couldn't reach the wound up rope. To cut this rambling off the solution was to cut the rope, recover the anchor since it was still attached to the net and reconnect everything. Oh yeah, there were snags under the water at this eddy so I ended up pulling the net out before I got into any more trouble.

The other river episode involved the boat anchor. At night we anchor the boats out a ways from the shore for a couple of reasons. Depending on the tide you might find the boat sitting on the shore if you anchored it at high tide and went back for it at low tide. The bears are also attracted to the sent of fish assuming you caught some recently. The way around these problems it to use two anchors. The regular anchor attached to the boat is connected to another anchor, with a long rope, which is on shore out of the water. You attach this shore anchor so you can pull the boat anchor backwards so it won't catch the bottom. You put the boat anchor up on the bow and shove the boat out away from the shore. When the rope connected to the on shore anchor is all the way out it caused the anchor on the boat to fall into the water. To get the boat back in to shore just pull on the rope. and in she comes. I had to go through this three times before I got the boat anchored tonight. Either the anchor on the bow of the boat fell back into the boat or the rope on the shore anchor was tangled or I stepped on the long rope and pulled the anchor off the boat before it was ten feet out. Damn! 

The pictures I take remind me of things to write about. Most of the time the pictures speak for themselves.  I just tried to load ten pictures into this post.  I'm doing something wrong.  They all had some sort of error.  A couple of them were of Bog Orchids.  These fragrant flowers are so delicate I have to find a way to show them off.  I remember orchids from Easter and High School Proms.  Used to be the boy asked the girl and brought the orchid.  Now I guess anything goes.  I think that's a good thing.

The other pictures included a Bald Eagle watching me fish and two bears playing out in front of the cabin.  I'll try and get them to show up another day.  I can't believe its ten thirty already.  I expect having to try four times to get the boat anchored caused me to run late today.

Location, location, location.  In a past life those words had to do with real estate.  Lately they have to do with net placement on the Alsek River.  One of the places where I have been setting a net the past few weeks always produced fish.  Dozens of salmon each commercial fishing opener.  This week there were so few fish being caught we were allowed to fish just one day.  I had the same net set in the same place as in the past.  This week it caught only one fish.

That net is 20 fathoms long.  It caught only one fish.  I also have a 10 fathom net.  The one I was having trouble with yesterday.  I set it in a new place farther up the river.  That little net caught more fish than the other two 20 fathom nets combined.  Bottom line; The fishing was slow for most of us this week.  I managed to catch about 50 and one big King.   Location, location, location.

I didn't sell the King ($1.85 a pound) and kept a few of the sockeye too ($1.25 a pound).  I gave these fish to some of the people here who don't fish commercially.  We cleaned them in the creek out in front of the cabin.  Now there is a bear down there wading around in the water enjoying the morsels he can find.

It has rained most of the day and the Vet said the 5 day forecast calls for more of the same.  

Just now I had the same problem trying to load a picture into this post as last night.  I wanted to show a picture of the bear in the water looking for fish morsels.  There is a pretty high tide tonight and with all the rain the bear looks like it is out in the middle of a big lake.

With just one day of commercial fishing this week there should be plenty of time to get chores done around the cabin.  On top of that there are very few Sockeye in the East River to make sport fishing any fun.  So I am getting serious about building the wood storage shed.  Today I drew a picture of it.  Tomorrow I might add dimensions.  Later this month I am going down to Juneau to buy more stuff than I really need.  Need and want being the subtle difference between chartering a plane that will haul washers and building material vs a plane that can only carry groceries.  My accountant says I need to show a profit with this fishing stuff sometime in the first five years.  So after this year, having fulfilled all my wants, maybe I will just buy what I need the next three years.  And hope the fishing is good.

Wildflower found a glass ball on the beach a couple of days ago.  That is the first one found on the local beach this year as far as I know.  When he told me of his find I went all the way down the beach looking too.  No luck finding old glass fishing floats but the chain saw engine I saw washed ashore last week is still out there.

More and more bears are showing up down near the beaches.  The wild strawberries are beginning to ripen.  It is a lot easier to pick the berries in the open on the sand dunes rather than having to fight your way through the Alders and brush looking them.  The wolf continues to pass through at night. And this afternoon there was a coyote out front.

Today the computer downloaded a bunch of updates.  Tomorrow I will try and load pictures into the post again.  Maybe the updates will have taken care of the problem.

Things have been pretty slow here this week.  Today it has rained all day long.  The weather service calls it “Heavy at times”.  Most of us would say it was pouring.  The weather station showed one period at six tenths an inch per hour.

I did manage to pick up a net I had left over at Wildflowers earlier in the season.  Much of the conversation between fishermen is about how high the water is getting in the Alsek river and whether one is going to move their nets from that river to the East Alsek river.  I’m going to move all my nets up to a place on the river called the elbow.  It is a little farther up the river from the harbor but with the higher water level I hope the fish are there.

This afternoon there was a meeting at the ranger station between the Dry Bay fishermen and some of the park officials.  The Chief Ranger, the District Ranger and the Dry Bay rangers were there.  The Park Superintendent was supposed to be but the bad weather kept him from flying in for the meeting.

It was just my second of these annual meetings.  Some of those present have been coming out here to Dry Bay for almost 40 years.  Those old timers can shed a lot of light on why things are the way they are.  For example:  Trail maintenance is always an issue.  Today you might question why there is a turn in the trail when going straight would make more sense.     Years ago when people first started driving jeeps and trucks out here there might have been a log that had washed in that had to be driven around.  The log is now long gone, the Willows and Alder have grown up all around where that old log was therefore the unexplained curve in the trail.

Another example of how this land is changing.  There used to be a trail that parallels the ocean.  That trail skirted the edge of the brush that grew on the land above the tide line.  The surface of the land here is rising because of tectonic activity and glacial retreating.  The higher land allows the brush to advance over the older trails.  So, as a result, we now drive on the third trail that parallels the ocean.  The first two have been swallowed up by the brush.

Since I’m shifting my nets to all new places and the river is continuing to come up I will wait till Sunday to get them ready to pull into the water.  I’m anxious to get back to the fishing.  The anticipation is addictive.  If you catch fish the feeling is satisfying.  If you don’t the anticipation doubles.  ….

I’m loving it!

The new weather station has provided a lot of information today.  It has rained over 2 inches so fay.  The highest rain rate was 1.09 inches per hour.  That happened shortly after midnight. The maximum temperature today was 57 the minimum was 54.  The wind has averages slightly less than 2 MPH all day.  The beach out front looks like a big lake.  It is completely covered with water...about one inch deep.  The sand is so saturated the water has no place to go till the river goes down.

The tides are adding a lot of water to the beaches and rivers too.  Tonight there will be an 11.8 foot high tide then the next low tide in the morning will be -2.9 feet.  In other words there will be a 14.7 foot change in the sea level in the next half day.  I wonder what that will do to the fishing.

We had a visitor last night.  Louis had been whining quite a bit early in the evening.  I didn’t see anything outside but this morning there was proof we had had company.  A bear dug up some roots out in the yard.  It must have been here a while because it or they left three piles of poop around where the digging had happened.

A brother-in-law is coming for a visit next week.  I got his room ready today.  Bill is fairly bald.  So am I.  I thought it was interesting in that he wrote in an email he had changed his hair style.  Now he parts it on the left.  I wrote back I had not changed mine.  I still have that wide part right down the middle.

One of the old timers said these high tides have unpredictable results on the salmon movement.  Sometimes the fish hold off in the ocean because of the rough surf.  Other times the high water just pushes them far upstream past where we are fishing.  This time tomorrow night I will know the answer for this tide anyway.

Another commercial fishing opener has closed.  Like last week the fishing was slow.  Yesterday I caught 29 fish and today added 27 more to the food chain.  I kept seven.  The others weighed 255 pounds.  A month ago the average weight of each fish was about 6.5 pounds.  This week the average is a little over 5 pounds.

I commented to the Fish and Game fisheries biologist about the smaller size.  She said when the volume of fish in the river drops off like it has the last two weeks and when the size goes down that means the salmon run on the Alsek River is half over.

All the rain and the very high tides have made many of the trails difficult to travel over.  To avoid these roads covered with water I go down the beach as far as I can then cut across to connect with a regular route to the boat harbor.

To get the fish to the buyer I pull a trailer with a tote on it back and forth between the harbor, the fish buyer and the cabin.  It is important to strap the tote down on the trailer for a couple of reasons.  When crossing a stream the tote would float off if it weren’t held down.  The surface of the roads is not exactly smooth.  The tote bounces around on the trailer making a lot of noise and the strap keeps it secured and much quieter.

The Fish and Game biologist announces over the VHF radio at 9:00 on Monday morning whether the fishing opener has been extended another day or two, or if it closes at noon.  Because of the high water and a dense fog this morning I waited for the announcement before I left the cabin.

The announcement meant I had to get a move on to get to the nets, clean them of the 22,000 sticks and hopefully some fish, then load the nets into the boat by noon.

As I zoomed down the beach I could hear the tote rattling around on the trailer behind me.  When I made the turn to head toward the regular route I could still hear it back there.  For some reason about half way to the harbor I looked back to check on the trailer and tote.  There was no tote on the trailer!  The strap had worked loose.  Nothing to do but turn around and backtrack.  I got to a hill where I thought it might have fallen off.  Nope!  The beach route crosses a couple of shallow sloughs that have a dip in them.  No tote there either.  The next probable place was the creek in front of the cabin.  That would be a big problem.  A: My neighbors would have seen this happen and there would be no end to the ribbing I would get.  B: The creek was flooding and the tote floats.  I kept checking the river to be sure it wasn’t floating by, on its way to the ocean.

Alas I found the escaped tote in a spot where no neighbors saw the thing jump trailer and it was far enough from the creek to not attempt an escape by water.

At the harbor the fog was so thick one could barely see one hundred feet.  Earlier in the season the route to one of the nets was stored on the GPS.  With the GPS on I proceeded to slowly leave the comfort of a visible shoreline and almost immediately ran aground on the other side of the harbor.  The fog is so disorienting and the gray color of the Alsek glacier water makes hard for this newbie.

I finally got on track with the GPS and proceeded into the fog bank at about one quarter speed.  All the while thinking of those huge icebergs and trees coming down the river toward me out of the fog.  I would not have been able to see them till they were a hundred feet away and closing fast.  All I could hear was the engine running and the water passing under the boat.  Then there was another noise.  One of the old timers, who knows the river like the back of his hand, roared past me in his boat.  He went by at full throttle.  He threw up his hand and waved as he passed.  I waved back and increased my speed about one mile per hour as long as I could see him in front of me.  It seemed to take forever to make the two mile run across the river to the other shore.  When it came into view I was very relieved.

The strength of the water was demonstrated as I eased up that far shore.  There is a vertical earthen bank that the river’s current presses against.  A large spruce tree gave way and crashed into the water as I went by.  This tree was probably 40 feet tall.  As soon as it hit the water the current tore it from the bank and carried it away.

I lost my life jacket one day a few weeks ago.  I found it floating by one of my nets the next day.  I ALWAYS wear it when out on that big water.  Seeing that 40 foot tree swept away …….

Another commercial fishing opener has closed.  Like last week the fishing was slow.  Yesterday I caught 29 fish and today added 27 more to the food chain.  I kept seven.  The others weighed 255 pounds.  A month ago the average weight of each fish was about 6.5 pounds.  This week the average is a little over 5 pounds.

I commented to the Fish and Game fisheries biologist about the smaller size.  She said when the volume of fish in the river drops off like it has the last two weeks and when the size goes down that means the salmon run on the Alsek River is half over.

All the rain and the very high tides have made many of the trails difficult to travel over.  To avoid these roads covered with water I go down the beach as far as I can then cut across to connect with a regular route to the boat harbor.

To get the fish to the buyer I pull a trailer with a tote on it back and forth between the harbor, the fish buyer and the cabin.  It is important to strap the tote down on the trailer for a couple of reasons.  When crossing a stream the tote would float off if it weren’t held down.  The surface of the roads is not exactly smooth.  The tote bounces around on the trailer making a lot of noise and the strap keeps it secured and much quieter.

There is a delicious reason I didn’t post anything here yesterday.  

The park has a ranger who specializes in Bears and Birds.  She passes through Dry Bay most summers for a few days then moves on.  She sent me a note asking if we could work out some deal that involved me giving her some Alsek Sockeye in return she would try to provide something I wanted.  Now this woman is younger than two of my children.  So that tended to eliminate several things I might ask for right away.

I got the five fish she wanted cleaned iced down in the cooler.  She brought me the batteries I needed and some other home grown vegies from her garden.  She and her associate visited for a while than we decided to cook one of her five fish.  It was delicious.  For desert we had chocolate chips.  The bourbon we three shared added a nice bit of warmth to the evening.

Yesterday I pulled the boat out of the water since I will be gone for a few days.  If it is up on the shore there is little chance it will float away should some rope break or it sinks from too much rain water collecting in it.  The subject in that last sentence caused me go back over to the boat today.  On shore unless I prop the front of the boat up on something it tilts bow downward.  With three fishing nets in the boat and a few gallons of rain water there would be no way I could reconnect it to the Honda to put it back in the river next week.  So today I took a jack and a section of log over to the boat. Now it tilts toward the stern and any rain water can drain out.

On the way over to the harbor I saw a huge wolf.  My pal Louis is a 70 pound dog.  I believe Louis could stand under this wolf.  It was a brindle brown color.  It saw me but did not seem alarmed.  I watched this magnificent animal for ten of fifteen seconds before it trotted into some taller grass out of sight.

That trip over to the boat was squeezed into a day of smoking fish.  I hope I did it right this time.  The fish were Sockeye from the Alsek River.  The neighbors say fish from the East River smoke better because they don’t contain as much fat.  But, since there are not many fish being caught out of the East River and I had these two nice Alsek fish in the cooler I made do.  I will let you know how they came out.

A big day tomorrow.  Heading down to Juneau to stock up on things that have broken or have been consumed.  Instead of renting a car I’m renting a U-Haul truck.  That way all that bulky stuff will be secure, out of the weather and deliverable in one load to the bush plane on Sunday when I return.

A big day tomorrow.  Heading down to Juneau to stock up on things that have broken or have been consumed.  Instead of renting a car I’m renting a U-Haul truck.  That way all that bulky stuff will be secure, out of the weather and deliverable in one load to the bush plane on Sunday when I return.

It is Sunday morning here in Juneau.  Brother-in-law, Bill, arrives in less than two hours.  We are supposed to meet the bush plane to fly us and all the gear I bought back to Dry Bay at noon.

Yesterday I got a call ( first time I have used a phone since late April) from the bush pilot that they might not be able to fly today because of weather.  Dang!  Now there all sorts of things to tend to.  Hotel rooms, rental truck return, etc.  However this morning it looks like the storm did not develop and maybe we can get out of here after all.  I still won't know till hear from the bush pilot but things are looking up.  When I do get the final word I need to finish unloading the truck at the airport.  Uhaul won't pick the truck up at the airport on Sunday so we need to get it back to the Uhaul barn. Then call a cab to get back out to the airport

I'm finding it interesting that being in the city is more stressful than living out there with wolves and bears and other independent old fishermen.

Waiting is another adjustment that is confusing.  One can sit and wait for the fish to swim into the net or maybe they won't.  That is no problem.  Waiting for someone in a line in to finish telling their latest joke to the cashier at the grocery store is a problem.  Waiting for your food at a restaurant is different than waiting for the water to boil for the ramen noodle concoction in the cabin.  Progress?  I guess so.

I got an email from one of the Dry Bay neighbors.  Louis is getting a lot of attention.  Two or three different people have stopped in to take him for walks or to just rub his head.  I appreciate their help.  On the big plane being chartered there is room for three cases of their favorite brew.  If I keep this up some of them will want to take care of Louis more often.



The plane will be loaded with 14 foot long pieces of metal roofing, several sheets of 4x8 sheets of plywood, about 50 2x4 boards, a big washing machine, a small freezer, a smaller fridge about three months of food, a weed eater and two fishermen plus the pilot.

A lot has happened since I wrote something here last Saturday.  Our flight from Juneau to the cabin was still in doubt for Sunday.  The weather up at Dry Bay was awful.  It was raining buckets according to one of the neighbors.  The bush plane that we had chartered had two flights scheduled ahead of ours.  I had unloaded the uHaul truck by ten in the morning but didn’t know if I should turn it back in yet.  Same thing concerning the hotel room.  Finally around eleven I got a call that the plane would pick us up about twelve thirty.  The rest of the return trip went smoothly.

We got back in time to go over to the river and set three nets.  The fishing was VERY good for the fishermen who were fishing down nearer the mouth of the river.  So good that the Fish and Game department extended the opener for two days.  The fishing will at noon tomorrow, Wednesday.  Not so good for us higher up stream.  I kept thinking the fish were bound to migrate farther up but as of tonight most of them have not.  We caught about 75 so far.  Bill has kept a few of them to take back home when he leaves on Saturday.  We clean the fish down at the creek in front of the cabin.  The eagles and gulls have figured out when we go down there and stop there might soon be some tasty fish parts floating down in the current.  It is quite amusing to watch the literal pecking order of the young gulls who are at the bottom of the order.  Then the adult gulls have to defer to the young eagles then in turn the mature eagles.  Those mature eagles can choose to go after the fish or one of the gulls.  Just like on TV.

Tonight I moved one of the nets down to where the fish have been holding.  I hope my doing that doesn’t scare the fish away from all the other nets.  A couple of the old timers who have the prime spots have caught upwards of six hundred fish since Sunday at noon.

Bill wanted me to mention here how humble and good he is.  So the next sentence is dedicated to him.  Bill is _______________________.

The storage side of the cabin is cramped right now.  There are several totes of food purchased in Juneau that I have not had time to unpack and store because of the fishing.  Maybe tomorrow afternoon I can get that done.  

There are a couple of places I want show Bill before he leaves.  One is where some of the sockeye spawn.  It is a beautiful spot and we are likely to see some bears up there too.

The storage side of the cabin is cramped right now.  There are several totes of food purchased in Juneau that I have not had time to unpack and store because of the fishing.  Maybe tomorrow afternoon I can get that done.  

There are a couple of places I want show Bill before he leaves.  One is where some of the sockeye spawn.  It is a beautiful spot and we are likely to see some bears up there too.

A full day of Alaska life unfolded for us today.  We got out on the river around nine this morning.  The 10 fathom net was checked first.  It had 6 big sockeye in it.  The second net was a disappointment.  There had been several salmon in the net but the seals got everyone.  All they left were a few fins and unrecognizable parts.  The third net, old faithful, had over 20 fish in it.  The seals had been there too but only a couple of the fish were damaged.

Bill wanted to keep a few more fish.  He filleted a some  more to freeze and prepared the rest for smoking.  We will probably do that tomorrow.

This afternoon we went up near the headwaters of the East Alsek River to see if the sockeye had started spawning.  The water up there is so clear you can’t perceive how deep it is.  There was a slight breeze and the water sparkled like crystal.  These fish turn a crimson red when they are ready to spawn.  There weren’t many but those we saw swimming in this shimmering water looked like rubies in a stream of diamonds.  Most people will never have the chance to see this much natural beauty much less stand in it as we were.

There is a spot downstream where the fish tend to congregate before heading up to spawn.  Steve’s island is about two city blocks in size.  To get to the fish you have to walk half way around Steve’s island.  Today as we approached the island there was a bear watching us.  It disappeared into the brush on the island.  Later we saw two more bears from the spot where we were fishing.  None of them caused us any problems.

Bill hooked a frisky sockeye but it soon shook the hook and got away.  This week is Bill’s first visit to Dry Bay.  Since Sunday most of our time was spent on commercial fishing or preparing fish for him to take home.  This afternoon we finally got to change our pace.  The things we did and the things we saw are what most outdoors people only get to read about or watch on TV. .I think he got a glimpse of how special this place is today.

Mother Nature has sent along the normal Southeast Alaska weather today.  The forecast called for 100% chance of rain.  The forecaster was right.  It has sprinkled all day.  As of three this afternoon we have received eight tenths of an inch.

Bill is scheduled to leave for Yakutat in about an hour.  I believe he has enjoyed his trip.  Yesterday afternoon we went up the river and he caught his first Sockeye with his fly rod.  It was a large male.  It probably weighed a little over seven pounds.

We had been up there the previous two afternoons.  The first day we saw three grizzlies.  The next day we saw four.  I recognized two of the bears.  They were the ones out in front of the cabin about ten days ago.  I hope to post pictures again soon.  I have the technical support team for Notes From Alaska working on the problem.

The old timers predict this next commercial opener will be a good one then we can expect the number of fish in the river to fall off dramatically.  When that happens they will either move their boats and gear over here to the East River or move on to another fishery.

Last night we had dinner at a neighbor’s house.  Lamb, boiled potatoes and gravy, homemade bread. Sweet corn on the cob and a special concoction of Brussel sprouts, bacon bits, brown sugar and raisins.  I took brownies.  By following the directions on the box I managed to cook them too long.  I suggested we use the table saw to cut the brownies into serving sizes but we found a cleaver and used it instead.

It must have been Thursday morning when we had another earthquake wake us up.  This 5.9 one was preceded by a rumbling that sounded like distant thunder.  Then there was a noticeable jolt that was followed by several seconds of swaying.  Things hanging inside the cabin were swinging back and forth several inches.  These earthquakes cause my adrenalin pump to awaken.  There is nothing to do but wait and see if the movement gets worse.  If the earth did start to shake more I would open the valve that the adrenalin flows through and get moving.  But this quake was like the last one.  Just some plates moving six miles below the surface.

This is a test.   Another test.   Test again
This is a test.
This is a test.   Another test.
This is a test.   Another test.   Test again

Another commercial fishing opener started at noon today.  Setting the first two nets was not a problem in that I had already decided where they should be.  The third net was a problem.  I couldn’t find the eddy Wildflower suggested.  One place over at Seagull Island looked promising.  I set the third net there.  This set is right at the edge of the main river’s current.  To pull the net tight the boat ended up in that current and was swept downstream.  I couldn’t get the net perpendicular to the shore because of the current.  So I just left it at an angle.

Checking the first net there were five or six salmon in it.  The second net had three and the third net had a tree in it.  A tree the size of those tall ones Home Depot sells in the fall.  There were no fish accompanying the tree so I pulled the net and started looking for another spot.

Net number one was about three miles up the river from net number two.  I found a spot in between for the third net.

To wind this up, I ended up with 29 fish this afternoon.  They weighed a little over 150 pounds.  The location of the third net looks promising.  In a little over an hour it had five big fish in it and it is the short, 10 fathom, net.

Rather than drive all the way home then back to the river I just anchor the boat near one of the nets and wait.  This afternoon an otter came loping down the beach and stopped at the end of the net I was watching.  I did my best anti-otter scream and rattled some stuff in the bottom of the boat.  The otter hurried away but I bet I have a few fish in that net in the morning with pieces missing.

On the way home there was a grizzly in the road but it ran into the bushes as I approached.  Other than a few hundred seagulls and a dozen or so Bald Eagles that is all the wildlife I saw today.

I’m anxious for morning to see how the nets do overnight.  I’ll report back soon.

To wind this up, I ended up with 29 fish this afternoon.  They weighed a little over 150 pounds.  The location of the third net looks promising.  In a little over an hour it had five big fish in it and it is the short, 10 fathom, net.

Rather than drive all the way home then back to the river I just anchor the boat near one of the nets and wait.  This afternoon an otter came loping down the beach and stopped at the end of the net I was watching.  I did my best anti-otter scream and rattled some stuff in the bottom of the boat.  The otter hurried away but I bet I have a few fish in that net in the morning with pieces missing.

On the way home there was a grizzly in the road but it ran into the bushes as I approached.  Other than a few hundred seagulls and a dozen or so Bald Eagles that is all the wildlife I saw today.

I’m anxious for morning to see how the nets do overnight.  I’ll report back soon.

The opener must have been pretty good for some of the fishermen.  Alaska Fish and Game announced a two day extension.  That means we can fish until noon tomorrow.  I caught 60 fish in the first 24 hours.  This week seems to be running about 20% ahead of last week.

Some of the fisherman are having major problems with bears and seals stealing their fish.  I heard third hand that one team figured they were losing 50% of their catch to seals.  That might mean that half the fish are damaged by the critters not completely taken from the net.  The damaged fish, also called seconds, sell for just $0.86 a pound.  An undamaged sockeye is selling this week for $1.25 a pound.

My nets have seen some thief activity too.  Upstream the seals and otters are making off with about 10% of my fish.  The net set down near the harbor has its own bear to deal with.  Yesterday morning Wildflower saw it eating a fish out of the shore end of the net.  Later yesterday he saw the same bear swim across the lagoon to the outside end of the net.  The water is shallow there.  The bear stood up on his hind legs and proceeded to walk toward the other end of the net looking for fish.  I had picked the fish out of that net a short while earlier so the bear did no damage.  Last night about 9:30 another fisherman watched the same bear watch my net.  A fish got tangled in the net and was splashing.  The bear didn’t swim to the net this time.  It ran about three hundred yards around the end of the lagoon to the net.  The fish had stopped splashing.  Mark said it then started playing with the orange buoy that marks the shore end.  This morning that net which usually had 8 to 10 fish in it had the front half of one fish!  That net is now several miles away in another spot.

I had visits from both park rangers yesterday.  Jim came by just as I was getting ready to go back to the river.  Kae stopped in after I got back.  While she was here a sow grizzly with twin cubs walked past the front of the cabin.

Some of the fishermen are talking about moving their operations over here to the East Alsek River.  I think they are getting frustrated with all the losses to seals and bears.  If Wildflower does that I might put a net in his hot spot and just sit on it to keep the bear away.  I’ll see how he does there this week and if he moves to the East or not.

Rather than sell the seconds for eighty six cents I am bring them home, fillet them and vacuum packing them to eat later.  Some of them might even make it back to Colorado.  My new five cubic foot freezer has about two and one half cubic feet of King and Sockeye salmon in it already.  I might have to back off on the Grape Nuts and start eating some salmon soon.

August 2nd

It has been a couple of days since anything exceptional happened here except:

Wildflower didn’t fish on Wednesday so I put a single net where he always catches fish.  That spot produced 41 fish in about four and a half hours.  I had pulled the nets from the spots I had been fishing and only had the one net in the water.  The bears and seals had been robbing all the nets set near the harbor.  With only the one net out I either sat in the shore watching it or sat in the boat doing the same thing.  The seals are so sneaky.  While I was pulling fish out of one end of the net a seal swam, unseen, from far away and grabbed a salmon out of the other end of the net.

A mother Merganser swam by followed by her clutch of seven little fuzz balls following.  Every few yards one of the little ones would break rank and swim ahead of the others to grab a bug off the surface of the river then fall back in line behind mom.

Thursday morning I went back over to the harbor to clean the boat.  Part of that trail goes through a grassy area where the Willows and Alder have not started to grow.  The black wolf that has been mentioned here before was sitting out there looking at me.  I tried to get the Honda stopped without making too much noise.  I fumbled around trying to get my pocket camera out before it disappeared.  To my surprise it got up and trotted right toward me.  I got several great pictures.  It closed to within about 50 feet then started to circle around behind me.  I stepped off the Honda and clapped my hands to scare it away.  By now it was going away from me but in no hurry.  Running toward it did speed it up a little but I bet that wolf was thinking “what a joke that thing on two legs could never catch me.”  It was right of course but it better learn to be more wary of two legged things.  

Back in April, when we were in Haines, Wildflower went by the lumber yard and got an estimate for the materials required to put a metal roof on his cabin.  The materials finally arrived so Thursday afternoon we began getting the roof ready to receive the new metal.  Friday morning the serious crew showed up (read younger more nimble men) and the new metal roof went up.  No problems as far as I know.  I bailed out after lunch since he had plenty of help.  Funny how some more help showed up at lunch time.

Thursday and again yesterday there were some Sandhill Cranes out front.  Those birds are probably the first of thousands that will begin moving through in the next weeks.  The last of the Hummingbirds headed south this week.  The feeder that had been the busiest place around here a few weeks ago is now a lonely fixture hanging outside the window.  I need to bring it in but that would be my first physical acknowledgment that the summer is fading into fall.  Just like last year I feel myself saying “say it isn’t so”.

The park ranger, Kae, and I have joined forces to process some of the sockeye that found their way into the nets.  We smoked several using different techniques.  I cover the fillets with salt and let them sit for about half an hour then smoke them.  Her recipe has them in a salt brine for 24 to 36 hours before they are smoked.  We have also tried canning some of the salmon.  The first batch of those fish we smoked for an hour.  As this is being typed the second batch are being smoked for a little over two hours.  The canned fish are delicious.  We added different spices to some of the pint jars of fish to see how they would taste.  I’m betting the Mesquite will be the best.  Kae, I think, is undecided because the Lemon Pepper or Wasabi might be good too.  I don’t know what Wasabi is so I just ruled it out.

Kae regularly patrols all the trails here in the preserve.  She had mentioned she was going up a new trail up toward Alsek Lake today.  The Alsek River flows into and out of the lake but the lake is the terminal end of a couple of huge glaciers.  This year the outlet of the lake is clogged with icebergs.  Rafters have to find their way through some side channels to avoid having to carry their gear around the ice jam.  I asked if I could tag along.  I had never been up river that far.  Never have I seen anything like the number of cabin size bergs being swept out of the lake.  There are several rapids a mile or so downstream.  Those huge icebergs would run aground in the shallow water of the rapids.  They sounded like someone moving boxes in the third floor attic of an old house while you sat listening downstairs on the first floor.  The sound seemed to come from some deep and enormous source, not a specific spot.  The water was muffling the sound of tens of thousands of pounds of ice crashing into a submerged rock.  Those huge chunks of ice would falter on their way down the river.  They would rise partially out of the water as that relentless force pushed them over the rock.  Once clear they would settle back into their high speed transition from old glacier ice to just plain water on their way to the sea.

If Kae reads this, I hope those words above give her some idea of how amazing this afternoon was for me.

That’s why they call it fishing not catching.  That line is so old that I didn’t even hear someone utter it today.  Last week Wildflower took the last half day of the opener off.  He said it would be OK if I put a net in the spot where he always catches fish right there at the edge of the harbor.  I took him up on it and in four hours caught 41 sockeye not counting all those the seals stole.

Yesterday afternoon in that same spot I caught six fish in five hours.  I pulled the net last night because the bears have been raiding nets that are left out overnight.  By eight this morning the net was back in the water.  Fishing opener closed at noon.  At ten this morning there were five more fish in the tote.  For some reason at eleven things started to improve.  I finished the one day opener with nineteen fish.  Not too bad considering others didn’t do as well and their nets were well up river.

The East Alsek River which is just outside the cabin door has a three day opener this week.  Fishing has been a little better over here so I moved the boat and all my gear back to this side of Dry Bay.  In the morning I will set a net about a half mile from my front door.  Fishing this much smaller and shallower river is a lot different than the Alsek.  The water can be crystal clear.  There is moss growing on the bottom.  That moss breaks loose and winds up in the webbing of the nets.  It can get so bad that the only way to get the moss out of the net is to pull it to shore (it will be too heavy to lift into the boat), and clean it out standing on dry ground.  Most nets don’t catch many fish when they are out of the water.  The solution is to almost constantly move back and forth across the net shaking the moss out before it completely clogs.

The results are in on the seasoned canned salmon.  We put three different spices on top of the salmon we canned a few nights ago.  I thought the Mesquite would taste the best.  Kae, I think, would have preferred one of the others.  It turns out they all tasted the same.  What we decided they should have as a spice is salt.  The time to add flavoring is after you open the canned fish and plan to serve it.  Maybe some of the more experienced canners out there will have a suggestion.

The nineteen fish did not get sold.  I brought them all home and will either smoke them or freeze the fillets to bring back to Colorado in the fall.  I have been reminded recently that some of the Bourbon deliveries made earlier came with a catch!  No pun intended. The recent conversation here about preserving all these Salmon must have reminded my suppliers how good these fish taste when all you have to do is buy a guy a drink!

Yesterday morning is a mystery to me.  Can't seem to remember just what happened.  On yeah, I do remember a little of it now.  Two days ago, Monday, I fished on the Alsek.  I kept the 19 fish and either canned or froze most of them.  Pulled the boat and moved all the gear, nets etc. over to my cabin on the East River.  Yesterday morning Louis and I walked to the river to see how things looked.  Some of the other fishermen were also there just checking things out.  Nobody had caught anything.  

I decided to try my luck yesterday afternoon anyway.  The east river is so shallow it is difficult to use the outboard on the boat.  I ended up pulling the net across the river by hand.  The shoreline tapers back from this river at a very shallow angle.  At low tide the river might be only a couple of hundred feet wide.  When the tide comes in the water advances across the shallow slope of the shore at about the speed of a slow walk.  So, when I set the net it was at the edge of the water.  As the tide came in it appeared to be near the middle of the river.  That turned out to be a good thing.  The incoming salmon were swimming in the middle of the river.  I caught over four hundred pounds yesterday afternoon.  Most of the fish were sockeye.  There were a couple of Pink salmon as well as Coho and Chum salmon.  There is a market for the Coho and Chum but not for the Pinks.  The two I caught I threw back into the river.  One of them was in poor shape.  As it floated near the surface a Bald Eagle swooped down and grabbed it.

The fish must have weighed near the payload limit of that eagle.  It's wings were slapping the water as it carried the fish toward shore.  The bird headed for a slight knoll back about three hundred yards from the river.  It managed to gain about three feet in altitude in that distance.  At the knoll it dropped down and proceeded to eat the fish.  After a while it took off.  I guess it is easier to fly with the fish in your stomach than between your feet.

Got home a little after ten last night after selling the fish.  

Today I'm smoking the remainder of Monday's fish.  Doing something a little different this time.  Brown sugar is mentioned in several of the recipes I have heard about.  So in addition to the salt this batch has brown sugar on it to.  It will be interesting to see how that tastes.

No rain today.  Early yesterday morning the rain awakened me.  The fancy weather station told me a couple of things.  The little display said “it’s raining cats and dogs”.  I wonder how many corporate meetings it took to allow that bit of humor to leave the factory.  The other thing the weather station told me was for a brief period that morning it was raining 3.86 inches an hour.  That’s what woke me up. It sounded like a fire hose was directed at the roof.

There will be big tides the next two nights.  A 10 footer tonight and an 11.4 foot high tide tomorrow night.  I might have to do a little beachcombing these next two mornings to see if anything interesting washes in.

Today Louis helped me start on the wood shed I want to build.  It will be 8 feet deep and 15 feet long.  Logs from the beach will rest on pressure treated blocks for the foundation.  Lumber from Juneau will be the frame and other Home Depot material will be used for the roof.

Louis proved his nose still works well this evening.  He started barking here inside the cabin.  Looked out and there was a bear about three hundred yards away.  The bear started to run into the river when Louis went outside.  The old pal of mine didn’t run after the bear.  He just sat in the yard and barked at it.

When the chores and fishing can be pushed to aside for a while this place with all the natural beauty can be almost overwhelming.  The subtle signals nature is beginning to give are reminding me that fall is not far off.  I’m beginning to see family groups of birds that were not here a week ago.  The color in the meadows is changing from the vibrant shades of blooming flowers to the muted hues of seed pods and dried stems.  Some of the fishermen have already left.  Others have plans to move on to more productive waters or to jobs the changing season provides.  A few visitors are still showing up.  These “outsiders” disrupt the routine this small community tends to fall into.  Or maybe it is just me.  Leaving this simple life is still weeks away but I am homesick for this place now.

Louis just woofed.  I looked out front and the grizzly is back down there at the creek.  Until this week when I would get up during the night it never was really dark.  Now at two or three in the morning it is dark outside.  Our Mother is still at it.   Tilting our part of this globe away from the sun a little more each day.  By the end of this week it will be the seventieth time I have seen that happen.  You’d think one would be used to all this life throws at him by now.  I’m not used to it.  I’m loving it!

A big day here for me.  A new chapter in my life.  Chapter number seventy.  

Louis and I spent the morning taking a walk, doing laundry and skipping breakfast.  I made up for it by drinking lots of coffee.  This afternoon wildflower came by for a short visit.  Then I went over to a neighbor’s place to can some salmon have a bite to eat and watch part of a movie.  I had a nice visit there.

When I got back to my place there was a package inside the door and an envelope on top.  The package contained some appreciated libations and a couple of pounds of mixed nuts.  The envelope contained a note of condolences.  I wondered what I had missed.  I don’t get a newspaper here but I do follow the news on the internet, biased as it can be.  Who would bother to send me a note of condolences when I have been going on about how lucky I am to be in such a beautiful place with some beautiful people and a faithful old pal like Louis?

Then I kept reading.  The note said “CONDOLENCES ON THE PASSING (are you ready for this?) ON THE PASSING OF YOUR YOUTHFULNESS.

My younger sister sent that to me.  Here I am turning another page, opening a major decade of my life.  The decade when one might notice the days are in fact going by much faster than they used to.  Fall days.  Days that signal the approach of one’s cold winter.  Days when a little comfort and love would be appreciated.

The card also had a gravestone on the front that had been stuck in a cake.  The stone had RIP on it.  She probably thinks that means “Remember I’m Prettiest”.

Thank all of you for letting me use this semi-public forum to recognize her sense of humor.  She is a wonderful person who ….well the rest would be bullshit so I’ll move on to fishing.

Tomorrow the commercial opener will find me within sight of the cabin door fishing the East Alsek River.  The fish there are pretty predictable in that they ride the incoming tide and other times there usually isn’t much movement.  The high tide tomorrow is at 1:48 pm.  Getting the net in the water at noon should be early enough to intercept the fish.  We will see.

A big day here for me.  A new chapter in my life.  Chapter number seventy.  

Louis and I spent the morning taking a walk, doing laundry and skipping breakfast.  I made up for it by drinking lots of coffee.  This afternoon wildflower came by for a short visit.  Then I went over to a neighbor’s place to can some salmon have a bite to eat and watch part of a movie.  I had a nice visit there.

When I got back to my place there was a package inside the door and an envelope on top.  The package contained some appreciated libations and a couple of pounds of mixed nuts.  The envelope contained a note of condolences.  I wondered what I had missed.  I don’t get a newspaper here but I do follow the news on the internet, biased as it can be.  Who would bother to send me a note of condolences when I have been going on about how lucky I am to be in such a beautiful place with some beautiful people and a faithful old pal like Louis?

Then I kept reading.  The note said “CONDOLENCES ON THE PASSING (are you ready for this?) ON THE PASSING OF YOUR YOUTHFULNESS.

My younger sister sent that to me.  Here I am turning another page, opening a major decade of my life.  The decade when one might notice the days are in fact going by much faster than they used to.  Fall days.  Days that signal the approach of one’s cold winter.  Days when a little comfort and love would be appreciated.

The card also had a gravestone on the front that had been stuck in a cake.  The stone had RIP on it.  She probably thinks that means “Remember I’m Prettiest”.

Thank all of you for letting me use this semi-public forum to recognize her sense of humor.  She is a wonderful person who ….well the rest would be bullshit so I’ll move on to fishing.

Tomorrow the commercial opener will find me within sight of the cabin door fishing the East Alsek River.  The fish there are pretty predictable in that they ride the incoming tide and other times there usually isn’t much movement.  The high tide tomorrow is at 1:48 pm.  Getting the net in the water at noon should be early enough to intercept the fish.  We will see.

Another commercial fishing opener is in full swing. In fact it just struck out. There has been so much rain the river is full. The tides this week are very high. Monday through till Saturday all the high tides are around eleven feet. With that much water the fish don't have any problem avoiding the nets.  I caught six in the new location and those fishermen who always catch their fair share didn't do much better.  Today I brought the net home.  I left the boat on the water just on case but commercial fishing might be over for me this year. A neighbor gave me a couple pounds of bacon this morning. He thought Louis would enjoy it. When he left, Louis and I had a talk. If I would fry it I could have some. Because there was so much of it I cut a lot of the fat off. I put that fat on the stove where it proceeded to fill the area around the cabin with that delicious aroma of cooked bacon. Now I wonder how many bears are headed this way. I have discovered a possible way to get some pictures into these posts again.  If I use the iPad it will sort of work.  I just have to add them at the end.  So the next couple of sentences describe what is below. A while back the wildflowers were everywhere.  The first picture has at least five kinds of blooming plants in it.  The next two pictures are of the black wolf that approached.  I haven't seen this wolf since that day.  The first shot is as he came off the knoll toward me and the second is when he was alongside the honda about 50 feet away. The last picture was taken the day Ranger Kae let me tag along on the trail up toward the glacier fed Alsek Lake. Those are icebergs blocking the channel out of the lake in the distance.  The river here is about a half mile wide and very VERY swift. I will continue to work with tech support to try and get back to the point where I could put the pictures where I wanted them.

The biggest thing that happened around here today was/is the tide. There have been eleven foot tides before but in my time here I don’t recall one that had a strong wind blowing out of the south at the same time.

To back up in time a little this might make more sense. Today four more people left Dry Bay. This exodus is not unexpected. It does cause those of us remaining to think a little harder about what we might need since there are fewer neighbors to borrow from. I had about sixty gallons of fuel in the barrels outside. The burn rate this summer has been about one barrel a month. Since I plan on staying till the end of September I thought it might be a good idea to have a little more on hand. That doesn’t even count the fuel I will need next spring when I open up here again.

This morning I talked to the guy at the fish plant and asked if he could bring a barrel of gas down on the plane for me to pick up. With those arrangements made I put an empty barrel on a trailer and headed to the plant. I beat the plane to the plant so I waited.

The plane shows up just in time for me to head back home when the tide was at its peak. About a third of the way back I ran into a neighbor on the trail. He just shook his head and said there was no way I could get to the cabin. He said the wind was blowing about 45 off the ocean and pushing lots of water up the river and creeks. Joe had made it to within about a half mile of his cabin and had to turn around and go all the way back toward the plant to take a back way home. I decided to take a different route toward home.

That turned out to be a good decision till I got to Dog Salmon creek. The one just out in front of the cabin. It was about a quarter mile wide. It is usually about twenty feet wide and shallow enough to wade across in the 16 inch boots I had on. I parked the Honda on some higher ground then waded into where the water is usually less than a foot deep. By the time I got across I was in water nearly up to my arm pits. The wind had not let up. It is not often that one can see white caps in their driveway.

The low tide is at 10:00 tonight. I think I will put on waders this time and go back across the creek and finish bringing that load of gas home.

It has been a couple of days since I posted anything.  The main reason is I felt most of you know about rain.  The handy little weather center has this to say about rain here at the cabin.  Total accumulation since June 6th is 26.87 inches.  This month it has rained 13.72 inches. At one point this month it was raining at a rate of 5.7 inches an hour.  When it rains that hard it is like being in one of those automatic car washes.  The water seems driven not just falling out of the sky.

Park Ranger Kae told me there are impassable places on the trails that have never been impassable before.  I believe that because twice in the past few days I have had to leave the honda on the other side of Dog Salmon creek and wade back to the cabin.

Progress is being made on the wood storage shed.  All the wooden logs or poles I need are all off the beach.  The long ones I need are all over 21 feet long.  When I tie one or two of them on the back of the honda the weight cause the front wheels to barely touch the ground.  It is hard to steer that way.  So when I get to the flooded creek I just leave the machine with its load parked above the flood line and wade home.  At the next low tide I bring go back and bring everything across.

Haven't seen much wildlife except for gathering geese and ravens.  It seems the geese must be getting into shape for their long migrations.  The skeins are getting larger as various family groups join.  The ravens are another sign that fall is creeping in.  I don't know what brings them down here to the coast this time of year.  Maybe it is the salmon that have died after spawning.  I didn't see them but the tracks prove two moose walked up the drive to the cabin sometime during the night.  Some day, zooming along on the wheeler, I expect to come around a corner and be met by one of these big critters.  They like to walk on the trails.  I hear a moose can be rather stubborn and reluctant to enter the dense brush.  Could be interesting when that happens.

The flooding and high tides have eroded the sand dunes along the coast.  Those glass fishing floats buried in the sand are beginning to wash up on the beaches again.  I was disappointed this morning when, after driving down to where I found them last year, someone had been there before me.  I know of at least ten that have been picked up this week.  One of them was a rare "rolling pin" shaped one.  Last year I found forty glass floats.  This year so far zero.

The fish buyer has decided there are not enough fishermen and not enough fish being caught to go to the expense of sending people and planes down here this week.  That probably means the commercial fishing is over at Dry Bay this year.  If there is a big Silver Salmon run that could change but I will probably pack all that gear away this next week.=

It has been eleven days since we had a day with no rain.  During that time it rained over 15 inches here at the cabin.  Even though the last few tides have been average or below the rivers and creeks are still swollen with the runoff.  In the last post here I mentioned how the trails had more water in and on them than ever before.  Well I should have gone on to say that was the case since I have been here.  Now that that is cleared up here is what happened this sunny day.

Being rather despondent over not being able to find any glass fishing floats this year I thought I should try a different tactic.  The place where most are found is being frequently patrolled by the people who live closer to the spot than me.  Since I don’t want to get up before dawn to ride several miles down the beach I decided to search on the other side of the East River.  To get to the other side requires crossing it.  Remember the remark about swollen streams?

Earlier this year I found a spot to cross the river where the water was fairly shallow.  One had to float the Honda for only a few yards to cross there.  Because of the high water I waded across without the machine just to check the depth.  At one point I had to stand on my tip toes to keep the water from filling my chest waders.  I made it across thought and thought if I waited an hour or so the water would recede enough for me to cross.

So an hour later I drive the machine off into the water.  I have been mentioning floating these four wheelers across deep places for a couple of years now.  Well, if the water is deep enough they will float but barely.  I got the beast across OK but the water managed to fill every orifice on the thing.  After pushing it up the river bank and draining the water out of the engine it started right back up.

The search down the beach produced a couple of glass floats, some buoys I can use on my nets and a desire to go back down the beach again and search a little harder this time.  Because of the high water I just left the Honda on the other side of the river.  Tomorrow or the next day, if the water goes down enough, I will wade back across and bring it home.  Bring it home after I look for glass floats again.

As I motor down the beach I have noticed how the birds glide along beside me effortlessly.  They set their wings and slip through the air like kites, with no strings attached.  They are a few feet above the sand dunes that parallel the surf.  Sometimes I feel they look over at me discussed with all the noise I am making.  If they had thumbs they would probably thumb their noses at me.  Eagles, Ravens and Gulls all do this.  I think the breeze off the ocean rushing up the face of the dunes provide the lift they need to act like kites.

Fall is in the air here at Dry Bay.  Mount Fairweather (15,330 ft.) dominates the southeastern horizon.  The snow line is down around 8,000 feet now.  A few weeks ago it never got really dark at night.  This week the stars are making the light outside in the wee hours of the morning.  A couple of days ago a single swan was flying overhead.  It won't be long before flocks of those majestic birds will gather together here then head south.  There are a couple of sloughs where they congregate this time of year.  They are wary birds but maybe I can get a few pictures before they leave.

The Coho or Silver salmon are beginning to appear in the river.  The greatest numbers will be next month.  I caught one small Silver this evening after dinner.  Tomorrow the decision will be made about setting nets one more time.  I get the feeling there won’t be any more commercial fishing this year unless tonight’s tide fills the river with fish.

The wood shed is coming along.  I got the posts all plumbed today and about two thirds of the floor down.  I use the same arm to pound the nails as I use to cast the fly rod.  That arm is pretty worn out tonight.

The wood shed is coming along.  I got the posts all plumbed today and about two thirds of the floor down.  I use the same arm to pound the nails as I use to cast the fly rod.  That arm is pretty worn out tonight.

It’s Sunday.  That means another commercial fishing opener started at noon.  It is different now though because the fish buyer isn’t down here at Dry Bay any more this season.  There just haven’t been enough fish being caught to make it worthwhile to have people and aircraft flying back and forth to Yakutat.

Four of the fishermen thought there might be a way to make a little more money this year and made their own arrangements to have what they caught flown out today.  The Silver Salmon should begin to be in the river in good numbers by now.  The timing of today’s tide was right to catch any new fish coming up the river.  The bush pilot brought some sport fishermen down for the day.  When he returned to pick those fishermen up he was going to haul the commercial fishermen’s catch back to Yakutat too.

That all went according to plan except for the fish.  There were very few fish to be caught.  When the plane left with the sport fishermen, the commercial fishermen only had to load 42 fish.

My cabin is located closest to where they were fishing.  This afternoon, while waiting for the plane, the four fishermen and both Park Rangers showed up.  The regular population of Dry Bay right now is ten people.  For a while today seven of them were in my cabin.  I ran out of chairs.  There were some left over pancakes and enough of this morning’s coffee to satisfy my hosting obligations.  It had rained steadily most of the day.  Sometimes there are tensions between the fishermen and the Rangers who have to enforce the park rules.  Today none of that was apparent as we shared this warm, dry cabin.

One of the Rangers had a bear encounter today.  There is a grizzly up at Steve’s island that has learned fishermen sometimes have fish that can be stolen.  That bear didn’t steal anything today but was aggressive enough to cause the bear spray to come unholstered.

My neighbor, the Vet., is an avid fisherman.  He has a dog named Benni.  Benni is a pointer.  Benni can be seen running for all he is worth across the beaches in search of something to point at.  You might see him “on point” at a sea gull.  His instincts are such that any bird might be worth pointing at.  Benni is all bird dog.  He is not a bear dog.  On two occasions this year he has challenged a bear.  Both times when the bear didn’t run away Benni did run. Right back to the Vet.  Now something running away from a grizzly bear is an invitation to the bear to chase it.  A fly rod is not very comforting protection when an angry bear is interested in the dog standing between your legs.

This morning the Vet. let Benni outside, left the door open and laid back down.  A little while later The Vet. Thought he heard Benni come back inside.  He opened one eye and it was not Benni.  An otter had walked into the bedroom.  After shooing the otter away the Vet. noticed Benni hiding in his bed.  The Vet’s bed.

I just looked outside.  It is foggy and still raining.  The Vet. is out front in the river fishing.  Benni is sitting on the shore watching for birds.  All is well here at Dry Bay.

It has been a busy last few days here.  So you don’t have to read the whole post here is what transpired since the last posting.  In a past life I would call this an “Executive Summary”.

Found another glass float. Louis chased a bear.  The wood shed is almost done.  Floated about four miles on an Alsek River slough in a kayak.  Changed the oil in the drowned Honda.  Didn’t catch any fish with my fly rod.  Said good bye to Wildflower and Mark for the season.

With the roof now on the wood shed I have begun to scout the beach for logs to cut and split to for fire wood.  One of the places where a lot of the logs float in is also a good place to beach comb.  That is where I found the glass float.  This one is dark green and has mold marks on it that match another float that I found last year.  On the way home a grizzly was coming down the beach.  I shut the Honda down as just watched as it approached.  It must have caught my scent because it turned away.

One of the remaining commercial fishermen had his net in the water for two tide cycles this week.  The two sets didn’t catch 30 fish total.  The scuttlebutt is that the silver salmon will show up in the river any day now.  There are several of us watching the water closely for any sign of the expected return of the salmon but as of yesterday that hadn’t happened.  Maybe this next tide will bring them in.  In the movie “Dances with Wolves” the Indians are waiting for the buffalo (Katonka) to return.  You could see the concern on the tribe’s faces because they depend on the annual appearance of the buffalo for their winter food supply.  Kevin Costner discovers the buffalo and is suddenly a hero to the Indians.  So the few of us left here at Dry Bay will keep our lonely vigil.  We will keep each other informed as to where so and so caught one two nights ago.  All the while not looking at each other but watching the water for any sign of a fish.

It has been two nights ago on our walk that Louis saw the bear I had seen earlier in the day.  He made me proud as he went after the bear.  The bear played its part perfectly and rushed off into the brush.  Louis looks so happy when he comes back to me after he has shown these bigger critters who is boss around our cabin.

One of the neighbors has an inflatable kayak.  This boat was built for serious river water.  There are multiple air chambers.  The material is very tough.  It is self-bailing.  The neighbor bought the kayak at the water’s edge from a person who had just floated the Alsek River all the way down from Canada.  We launched the boat from a take-out point the river rafters sometimes use and had planned to float the four miles downstream to where we had left a Honda earlier.

Well…. The reason most rafters don’t use the take-out where we put in is because the water is about ankle deep.  We alternated floating and pulling the kayak for the first mile.  When the slough opened up enough for us to not drag bottom the tide had started coming in so we paddled against the current the rest of the way.  This morning my shoulders are reminding me that something out of the ordinary happened yesterday.

Two of the old timer fishermen left for the season yesterday afternoon.  Wildflower and Mark flew out.  Wildflower will be helping guide sport fishermen at a lodge about thirty miles up the coast.  Mark will be returning to his home in Main after a few days of visiting friends here in Alaska.  I gave Wildflower a book my son had given me.  “Down in Bristol Bay” is a book about an English professor at Syracuse who decided to change careers and become a commercial fisherman.  Some of the professor’s escapades were just like the rookie mistakes I have made.  I put a note on the front page of the book thanking Wildflower for all his help this year.  He seemed to appreciate the words left there.

It has been a busy last few days here.  So you don’t have to read the whole post here is what transpired since the last posting.  In a past life I would call this an “Executive Summary”.

Found another glass float. Louis chased a bear.  The wood shed is almost done.  Floated about four miles on an Alsek River slough in a kayak.  Changed the oil in the drowned Honda.  Didn’t catch any fish with my fly rod.  Said good bye to Wildflower and Mark for the season.

With the roof now on the wood shed I have begun to scout the beach for logs to cut and split to for fire wood.  One of the places where a lot of the logs float in is also a good place to beach comb.  That is where I found the glass float.  This one is dark green and has mold marks on it that match another float that I found last year.  On the way home a grizzly was coming down the beach.  I shut the Honda down as just watched as it approached.  It must have caught my scent because it turned away.

The scuttlebutt is that the silver salmon will show up in the river any day now. Kevin Costner discovers the buffalo and is suddenly a hero to the Indians.  So the few of us left here at Dry Bay will keep our lonely vigil. Well…. The reason most rafters don’t use the take-out where we put in is because the water is about ankle deep.  We alternated floating and pulling the kayak for the first mile. It stopped raining for a couple of days. It started up again just now and the forecast calls for rain most of tonight but thankfully there are no big storms in the forecast through the weekend. The light from the super moon demanded attention a couple of nights this week. Walking around at night in the moonlight and seeing your shadow following along might give you some idea how clear it was. It was nice to share something that special. Even if it was just shared with one’s shadow. I had read this was to be the last of three super moon rises this year. I had gone down to the river checking to see if there were any fish rising. The first picture below was what greeted me. I did catch salmon from nearly the same spot. The second picture is of another mountain to the left of Fairweather as I see them. The Vet had a couple of friends come in this week. They will all leave in a few more days. The three of them frequently fish just across Dog Salmon creek from my cabin. To know if the fish are biting all I have to do is sit at my table and watch them. I can enjoy a warm cup of coffee and be entertained by these three excellent fishermen. These salmon usually put up a pretty good fight when you hook one. The fish splashing in the water is easily seen from my easy chair. If I see these men catch a couple of fish I put my refreshment down, (it is not always coffee) put on my waders and join the fun. Park Rangers get to have a little fun from time to time as you can see.  That's the Vet on the wheeler in the background. The goddess of glass balls has smiled on me once again. I found another one today. As is the case with “mature” men my age I usually have to get up a time or two during the night. Two nights ago at about twelve thirty I was up and looked out front. It was one of those clear nights lit by the full moon. Like the shadow that had been following me around the night before a grizzly bear walked cautiously into the yard from the left toward the right about 75 feet from where I stood. It stopped a couple of times to look toward the cabin. This was a very big bear. It walked over to the barrel I burn trash in. The bear’s back was higher than the top of that 55 gallon drum standing on end. It sniffed around, scratched the ground in a couple of places then as if it was an unattached shadow moved off. Out of curiosity I just went out and measured the height of that barrel. It is 35 inches tall. The bear’s back was higher than that while it on all four feet. I’m no expert at comparing bears to barrels but it looked like it was a pretty big bear to me.
