The weather today has evolved from overcast to heavy rain.  Almost two inches so far and the forecast said the rain would increase this evening.

Two nights ago I watched a bear cross in front of the cabin heading up Dog Salmon creek.  It had its head up and appeared to be following some scent.  A few minutes later another bear appeared on the other side of the creek.  That one was also following its nose up stream.  There must have been something up there that they couldn’t resist investigating.

One of those bear was wearing a collar.  There are several different groups studying these bears.  Depending on the color of the collar you can tell which group is tracking that bear.  In this case the department of Fish and Game.  Sometimes fishermen leave parts of fish they have caught along the shore.  The bears quickly learn to associate fishermen with fish parts.  This is a sure way to create a problem bear.  A problem bear ends up being a dead bear.

My job list included a note to cut some more firewood.  Yesterday I found log on the beach nearly 30 feet long.  A big log.  The butt end of the log was about 18 inched in diameter.  The other end about 12 inches.  I sawed that log up into 20 some pieces.  Each piece will need to be split into several smaller pieces that will fit into the stove.  I loaded eleven pieces of the log onto the trailer and started the three mile trip back down the beach.  There are two sloughs one must cross before crossing Dog Salmon creek.  There was an 11.6 foot tide yesterday.  Those two sloughs fill with water during a tide that big.  No problem crossing the first slough.  The second slough caught me.

I could tell the Honda was laboring to pull the heavily loaded trailer.  When I began to cross the second slough the sandy bottom had become like quicksand.  The trailer sunk down to the frame.  The Honda couldn’t pull that so it being a four wheel drive machine proceeded it proceeded to dig four holes in the soupy sand bottom.  No problem I thought.  I would just unhook the trailer and drive the Honda away.  Because both machines were firmly planted in the sand even if I got the trailer unhooked I couldn’t move the wheeler away from it. .

I left the trailer loaded with wood and the attached Honda and walked to the Vet’s cabin.  He dropprd what he was doing and we took his wheeler and two ropes back to the slough.  If you were thinking that is a good way to get two Hondas stuck in the sand you would be right.  We figured that out before we stuck his machine and decided to just leave my Honda and the load of wood until the tide went back down.

Remember I mentioned the 11.6 foot tide yesterday.  The Vet went back to check on my equipment right at the peak of the tide.  Only the handle bars of the Honda were above the water.  The trailer with the tote full of wood was listing enough for the rising water to fill the tote the wood was stacked in.  We used a rope about sixty feet long to connect the Vet’s machine to mine.  The rope let him stay on firm ground and he had no problem pulling me out.

Today the submerged Honda got new oil in the engine and transmission.  Both the front and rear differentials got drained and refilled with lubricant.  By removing the spark plug and cranking the engine a few times most of the water gets blown out.  Now for the real test.  With the spark plug reinstalled would it start after spending several hours under water?

I turned the key and pressed the starter button……vroom….. I have a two honda camp again.

I turned the key and pressed the starter button……vroom….. I have a two honda camp again.

Just a couple of weeks left for me to enjoy this amazingly beautiful and raw wilderness.  Mother Nature with millions of years of experience is beginning pull the blanket of winter over the land.  The snow is creeping down from the mountain tops.  The flocks of birds heading south are more numerous.  The wildlife are moving in predictable patterns and the Silver salmon are in the river. A good neighbor from the other side of Dry Bay and I have been canning salmon to take back to our homes.  You might recall in earlier posts we tried adding spices to the unsmoked fish just as we were preparing them to can.  A better tasting produce seems to result if I smoke the salmon after they have been in a mesquite brine. This morning I went down to the river to play.  After several casts I thought they just are not here this morning.  The tide was flowing the wrong way.  There were several other excuses floating through my mind.  I turned to walk back to the Honda and a fish broke the surface just a little way upstream from where I had been fishing. I went up there and caught a fish on the first cast.  I caught another one on the second cast.  One got away on my third cast.  After about twenty casts I had my daily limit of four Silver Salmon.  They are in the cooler as I type this.  I’m going to go back over there and fish with a fly that has no barb on the hook.  That way it is easy to release a fish without harming it.  I might catch few that way but with no barb on the hook many of them get off right after they strike.   It is just a little after noon now.  I’ll finish this up later today……to be continued: Eight hours later:  They were still there.  The salmon were all up and down the river.  This morning two groups of fishermen were flown in from Yakutat.  We call them day fishermen.  They pool together, charter a plane and fly out to one of the rivers to fish for the day.  The two groups totaled about 20 people.  I was afraid they would see me catching fish and come down and crash my party.  Apparently everyone was catching fish.  No one else came down to “my” spot.  I ended up catching about a dozen. A couple of days ago I snapped this picture of the sign near where many of the day fishermen approach the stream.  The note documents bear encounters that have been reported to the rangers. I haven’t heard of any more bear problems this week but it is only Sunday.  Maybe the bears found the fish spawning in the shallow waters upstream easer to catch than day fishermen.

Lots of pictures to share today. I have been doing some beach combing.  To get across the East River without drowning the Honda yet again, I built this prototype amphibious adapter.  If the water is too deep I just hop off, pull it on across the river into shallower water, hop back on and keep on going. I went about ten miles down the outer coast today.  It was foggy down there.  This bear waited for me to take its picture.  I was too slow and it decided to move on off. While out on the beach I did manage to find a couple of glass floats.  The little rubber duck looked out of place on that rugged beach so I brought it home too. The bears are digging roots out of the sand.  This is part of about an acre of excavation some bear completed near the Alsek River. Have been smoking a lot of fish.  I’ll be heading home soon and there is a little room left in the freezer so I might as well fill it up.  The inside the little building there is a propane burner.  On top of the burner is a heavy pan.  I put Alder twigs in the pan, they heat up and make the smoke. Two days ago Ranger Kae and I walked up coast about five miles then floated back down the river to the cabin.  These Pack Rafts are really neat.  They weigh about six pounds. They fold up and easily fit into a back pack.  To blow the thing up you use a bag with a connector on one end.  The connector screws into the raft and then you just catch some air in the bag, close the open end and squeeze the air into the raft. Coming back down the river turned out to not be a matter of drifting along with the current.  The tide was pushing water upstream.  We had to paddle against the current and wind all the way back.

A couple of days ago I mentioned a collared bear that was acting a little aggressive.  The Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve bear biologist reads the stuff I type here and she contacted me about said bear.  She is really interesting to talk with about these creatures that are my natural neighbors here.  Anyway she had spoken with some of the people in the Fish and Game department.  They wondered if I gotten the number printed on the bear’s collar. Now I will do anything I can to respond to a request from this biologist.  The next time I see this bear I will try and sneak up on it, pull the hair back out of the way, get my pencil and pad out and jot down the number on the collar.  I may be stretching this a bit.  But I did respond to her written request today by writing back that I had asked the bear for his number but the bear didn’t respond.  Maybe he did respond but I didn’t have my hearing aids in that day so I didn’t catch what he said.  I know Tania will read this.  I hope my ramblings don’t put her off or cause one of her bear friends to get pissed at me. Below are a couple of bear related pictures.  The bears are more persistent beachcombers than I am.  Every time I go out on the beach, it is easy to find bear tracks.  These animals patrol the tide lines for any morsel that might have washed in.  They investigate almost everything.  In the second picture the bear had walked over to this glass fishing float, probably gave it a sniff, and then moved on.     Going across the East Alsek River to the outer coast one day I snapped this picture.  Right now I am sitting in that cabin typing this.  It is hard for me to believe how lucky I am to be here in this beautiful place.  Sitting here writing about associating with experts on one of the most magnificent animals on the planet.  Sitting here thinking about that same collard bear, mentioned above, who was out front of the cabin tonight chasing salmon in the that river in the picture.  It is easy for me to get emotional typing this stuff. I’m loving it!

It was a hell of a game!  The game between the Coho and Midnight Rambler (MR) started out slowly.  The location was Bear Point.  A neutral spot not far from MR’s cabin.  I say it started out there but the Coho didn’t show up.  MR, anxious for action, went prowling into old but familiar territory looking for the feisty Coho.  Sometime they go by the name Silver Salmon but I think that is just a gang related thing.  They are very silvery though.

The contest began down near the former hangout of the master himself “The Vet”.  Specifically a place here to fore known as Mossy Point.  That moniker makes sense because the clear shallow water produces enough algae to interfere with the equipment used during the game.  The Coho were ready to rumble.  This bunch were well prepared for anything MR would throw at them.  In the first quarter of the game the Coho intercepted three different lures MR presented and swam off with them.  These fish were really hot tonight.  Those three interceptions were on three consecutive passes.  MR and his equipment manager called time out and huddled back at the cabin.

With the game at three to nothing Coho, something had to change.  The line between the MR team and his opposition needed reworking.  The light and agile 8 pound test was no match for this rowdy bunch of Coho.  MR found some 20 pound test line on some old equipment in the locker room.  With nothing to lose but more lures, MR took a chance on this old but experienced line.

The battle resumed.  There were at least five near interceptions when a Coho would chase the lure from deep in its territory into water so shallow the attacker’s back was out of the water.  Folks you got to understand with this old line doing the work a lot of precise coaching was in order.  The primary terminal equipment was a single hook lure with no barb.  Neither team wanted unnecessary injuries.

So, using this non-lethal terminal equipment the Coho were able to make several tips and close calls.  These near misses were causing a lot of stress on MR, but the old line and the specialized terminal tackle finally began to turn the game around.

The contest continued until it was necessary to call a halt because of darkness.  The Coho seemed to have brought in some reinforcements because Mossy Point was nearly boiling with their antics along the sideline.  Eight of the Coho gang had felt the agony of defeat but they all were back in the game with their team mates when the game was postponed.  The Midnight Rambler, his trusty companion Louis and the old line are now sitting by the wood stove wondering where and when the battle will resume.

The three days before today were perfect.  Today it rained all day.  In Kentucky we would call that kind of good weather in the fall “Indian Summer”.  Up here I haven’t heard anyone use that term.  What I have heard is several say “I think I will just go do something outside”. For some reason I was out early one morning.  It was so clear Mount St. Elias looked like it was just a few miles away.  Checking on the computer it is actually 121 miles from here.  That same morning the Sandhill Cranes Began to show up in large numbers.  Wave after wave passed over.  That continued for most of the morning.  Thousands of them were winging their way South. The season is obvious in other ways too.  The Alders and Willows have lost about half their leaves.  No beautiful fall colors there.  They go from green to shriveled up brown and fall.  They do leave in the air the fragrance of fall and the smell of the leaves I remember from childhood. A few days ago there was a photograph here of the holes a bear had left in the sand from digging up roots.  Out along the trail they are also busy digging up some sort of morsel.  One can go along for a couple of miles and not see any sign of bear activity then come across a spot that looks like they ran a rototiller across the moss. Below are the results of a couple of cabin type projects.  The big hawser we pulled across the river is now a welcome mat.  That mat is made up of almost 500 feet of that big rope.   The second version of the “flotation attachment” on the Honda worked fairly well.  The machine floated a little higher with this version but some more refinement should be made before I send the design in to the patent office. While I had the contraption across the river Kae took the next two pictures.  The first one is of the cabin from a different angle.  The second picture might be one that I keep going back to.  To remind myself of this place.   The Grizzly Bear on the beach with Mount Fairweather in the background, miles from any human disturbance.  The bear never saw us.  Rather than go on down the beach and disturb him, I just turned around and came back to the cabin. Damn it.  This time next week I will probably be on the road heading south.  I doubt I will catch up with the Sandhill Cranes.  I’m sure I won’t be back on that beach to see that bear again this year.  This has been a wonderful summer.  Tomorrow, regardless of the weather, I think I will just go do something outside.

Another fisherman left today.  Kae leaves tomorrow and the last fisherman other than me may leave tomorrow too.  My current plan is to leave on Wednesday.  Paul the bush plane pilot and I have been corresponding about the flight.  The best weather both here and over the mountains in Haines is then.

When we last spoke I gave him a six day window as to when I would like to leave.  That is the way it has to be this time of year.  The weather can change so quickly from mild to severe in just a few hours.  The fancy weather station the kids gave me last June had this to say about the last few months:

In June the highest wind was 21 mph, highest rain rate per hour 2.21” and the total rain fall 2.87”.  For July the same numbers were: 22mph, 1.92” per hour and 10.28 inched for the month.  August: 31 mph, 5.7" per hour and 21.7" for the month.  September so far:  wind 62 mph, 2.68” per hour and 26.22 inches of rain for the month.  To save you the trouble that is 61.07 inches of rain since the second week of June…over 5 feet.  The lowest temperature since I have been here was 32 degrees and the highest was 69 according to the weather station.   Most days the temp wouldn’t vary more than 15 degrees.

The high tide this afternoon sent the water right up into the grass at the end of the drive way.  There were small fish splashing right in the drive.  Louis was on guard down by the water’s edge and Park Ranger Kae was practicing one of her hobbies, photography, out there too.

 

There is a lot to do around here before Wednesday.  I hope the weather remains good.  I have many goodbye's to say to this place before Louis and I hitch that ride back to the truck.  I'll try to keep you posted.

Last day of September.  If the weather holds it is also the last day of this sabbatical I have enjoyed for the last five months.  I would like to look sabbatical up in the dictionary to be sure I am using the word correctly.  However, the dictionary like almost everything else in the cabin is packed away for a long winter sleep. Last night a list was created that had 28 chores on it that I need to get finished before I fly out tomorrow.  Good progress was made on the list today.  One of the chores was to go back over to the ranger station and retrieve Kae’s bottle collection.  .  Kae left Dry Bay yesterday.  She didn’t have room to pack away her collection so she asked me if I would adopt these bottles until such time she can retrieve them. On the way over there I noticed new snow on the mountains.  It rained at the cabin most of the morning.  Obviously at about two thousand feet the rain fell as snow.   The weather started changing this afternoon.  The wind shifted around to the North and a breeze picked up.  The temperature will probably drop below freezing tonight.  The humidity is usually in the 90+ percent range.  Right now it is at 46% the lowest I have seen it in the five months I have been here.  The air is crystal clear and Mt Saint Elias even being 121 miles away stands out as clearly as those much closer. I spent a lot of time walking around outside today ignoring the chore list.  As the weather changed the sky did too.  This picture with the descending clouds reminded me of stallions carrying in the winter weather.  Don’t know why it just did. It has been noted here before how the mountains surround this part of the coast.  I have read some of these peaks haven’t even been named.  I wonder if what I was looking at this afternoon has ever felt the pressure of a human’s foot on its surface. Back at the cabin I took this picture of the trail that runs along the side of the cabin.  Louis and I walk out that way most mornings.  He is usually in front on bear patrol and I am following whistling a tune form the movie “Oh Brother Where Art Thou”.  I bet the bears think it’s pretty ridiculous those two old creatures passing through their territory.  Sometimes it is hard to pinpoint where the sound of a honda is coming from.  I probably looked up that little trail 200 times this summer wondering if someone was coming by from that direction. Louis was Nancy’s dog.  Louis has always liked women more than men.  I think it has to do with the sound of a woman’s voice and the gentler touch they have when they scratch his back.  This evening in the clouds I saw Louis looking at a lady who was looking into the setting sun.  I don’t know if you can see them but to me they are as clear as the sky behind them. I’m having a hard time leaving this place.  Tonight there were Lesser Canada geese out front ...just passing through …heading South.  Earlier Sandhill Cranes were circling above the cabin, catching thermals, gaining altitude to sail on down the coast.  While watching them, I saw two raptors, way up high, gliding in the same direction.  I will be following them all very soon. Good night from Dry Bay

Two days ago Louis and I were closing up the cabin.  I got most of the chores on the list accomplished. Paul arrived exactly on time.  He brought along his wife Amy and a friend of her's.  They wanted to film some takeoffs and landings in a remote spot so they choose to do that right outside the cabin.

No problem getting everything loaded.  We flew the 100 miles back to Haines via a scenic route through the mountains.  He wanted to show the ladies some of the sights.  It was a perfect day to do that.

At Haines the plan was to load the fish into a freezer just like the one at the cabin. My truck has a 110 volt outlet in the bed.  I thought I would just plug the loaded freezer in and drive home with the fish still frozen.  Two things happened.  The first was the freezer wouldn't go into the truck unless I took the top off.  Second the 110 volt circuit couldn't handle the power requirements of the freezer.

We hit the road anyway about 3:30.  That night we made it through Canadian customs with no problem and stayed in Haines Junction., YT Yesterday we got about 550 miles closer to home and stayed in a neat cabin at Toad River, BC.  Along the way yesterday we saw Moose, Elk, Bison and a black bear grazing on the wide shoulders of the Alaska Highway.  In Whitehorse added some dry ice to the freezer.  That should keep the fish frozen for a few more days.

It is about 6:30 in the morning now.  Waiting for the resturant to open.  Louis has eaten.  I'll feed the truck, get something for myself then head South.  One time son Joe and I stopped at a state park and rented a couple of horses to ride back into a canyon.  Those old nags needed a lot of prompting to get them started.  Needed prompting until we turned around.  Those horses showed us what poor riders we were as they nearly ran back to the comfort of their corral.  I'm getting into that mode now.  I'm ready to head back to the barn in Boulder.

Back in the good Ole USA tonight.  Barely.   Great Falls, Montana seems like a nice place.  I was very impressed with how clean and uncluttered Alberta is.  I drove half way around Calgary on the freeway.  There was not one big advertising sign to be seen.  The freeway was like a man made river for cars snaking around town with no junk along the banks of that stream. It is clear and breezy her tonight.  The moon is out.  Last time I saw it I was standing in front of the cabin some 2,000 miles from here.  I know it is the same moon but it just doesn't seem the same. In some correspondence lately I mentioned following Louis down a trail behind the cabin.  He is my scout on bear patrol and I follow up whistling a tune from a movie.  I have the soundtrack of that movie in the truck.  I must have played :"DOWN TO THE RIVER TO PRAY" ten times today along with several others.  Sometimes this summer I would change the words to "DOWN TO THE RIVER TO PLAY". Speaking of that, Bob Miller,  up in Yakutat,  posted a picture of some Silver Salmon swimming up the river near his cabin.  The ripples in the water are sometimes called "nervous" water.  That ripple could be mistaken for just that, a ripple caused by something under the surface.  In this case the "ripple" moves upstream.  As a sport fisherman, when you see that, you can be pretty sure of your heart rate going up.  If you cast a lure in front of that ripple you just might be lucky enough to catch one. I'm honored to be able to report 2,360 times people have bothered to read what shows up here.  Well maybe they didn't read this stuff but they opened the web site anyway.  Those visits came from 35 different states. This might be it for "Notes From Alaska" this season.  I'm having a hard time shutting this down.  This summer was filled with heart felt appreciation for the good fortune that has come my way.  I have grown to know some of the people very well and feel I can call them more than friends...dear friends.  Others have accepted me and my awkward and sometimes crude ways.  They have all enriched my life.  Thank you from the bottom of my heart. John B. Guthrie

Back in the good Ole USA tonight.  Barely.   Great Falls, Montana seems like a nice place.  I was very impressed with how clean and uncluttered Alberta is.  I drove half way around Calgary on the freeway.  There was not one big advertising sign to be seen.  The freeway was like a man made river for cars snaking around town with no junk along the banks of that stream. It is clear and breezy her tonight.  The moon is out.  Last time I saw it I was standing in front of the cabin some 2,000 miles from here.  I know it is the same moon but it just doesn't seem the same. In some correspondence lately I mentioned following Louis down a trail behind the cabin.  He is my scout on bear patrol and I follow up whistling a tune from a movie.  I have the soundtrack of that movie in the truck.  I must have played :"DOWN TO THE RIVER TO PRAY" ten times today along with several others.  Sometimes this summer I would change the words to "DOWN TO THE RIVER TO PLAY". Speaking of that, Bob Miller,  up in Yakutat,  posted a picture of some Silver Salmon swimming up the river near his cabin.  The ripples in the water are sometimes called "nervous" water.  That ripple could be mistaken for just that, a ripple caused by something under the surface.  In this case the "ripple" moves upstream.  As a sport fisherman, when you see that, you can be pretty sure of your heart rate going up.  If you cast a lure in front of that ripple you just might be lucky enough to catch one. This might be it for "Notes From Alaska" this season.  I'm having a hard time shutting this down.  This summer was filled with heart felt appreciation for the good fortune that has come my way.  I have grown to know some of the people very well and feel I can call them more than friends...dear friends.  Others have accepted me and my awkward and sometimes crude ways.  They have all enriched my life.  Thank you from the bottom of my heart. John B. Guthrie

Yesterday Louis and I left the house in Boulder at 10:33 heading for Haines, Alaska.  At 10:36 we were back at the house looking for my passport.  This year we are traveling in a pickup with a camper on the back.

The weather yesterday was a preview of what we might expect up at the cabin in Dry Bay.  Low clouds, misting rain.  It was like that all day.  We ended up driving 642 miles and spent the night among a cluster of 18 wheelers in the parking lot of a casino in Northern Montana.  There was very little traffic. Eighty is the speed limit through Wyoming.  No construction zones all day.  This morning I hit fog and construction just a couple of miles outside the casino.

I'm typing this at a McDonalds in Great Falls.  Today I hope to get up into British Cloumbia before dark.  I may opt for a motel tonight in that the camper doesn't have a shower or a bathroom.  That isn't a big problem for me but Louis seems reluctant to get back in the cramped space of the truck can with me.  He is old, can't hear, his eyesight isn't what it used to be.  We share those traits.  His nose is still good.  That might explain why he is tending to keep a little distance between us.  He has been a little off his food the last couple of days.  I bought him an eggMcMuffin.

Here we are at another McDonalds.  My breakfast is being digested and good ole Louis is waiting for his share in the truck outside. Perfect driving weather yesterday (750 miles).  One scare though.  I was just behind the rush hour traffic in Edmonton so I went through that city without stopping.  My plan was to get to Whitehouse  then start looking for a place to stop.  As we rolled along, consuming huge amounts of fuel, I heard a "ding". The tiny gas pump on the dash was glowing and the fuel gauge needle was in the red.  It was sixty miles to Whitehouse and the truck said I had 29 miles of fuel left.  I slowed down.  I fussed at myself for leaving the rosary at home.  I started looking for friendly farmsteads where I could maybe beg for a few gallons of unleaded. Everyplace I passed looked like they only had diesel.  Cars and trucks I had zoomed past were passing me now.  Finally I saw a tiny place across the divided highway that had fuel pumps outside.  I told the lady behind the counter how happy I was to see her.   I have not calculated the cost per gallon of fuel up here but it must be expensive.  It took $98.00 to fill the truck up.  The beast has a 31 gallon tank but with the big engine and carrying the camper at eighty miles an hour I am only getting about 11 miles per gallon.  I hope my accountant lets me write off part of the expense for hauling "freight" to Alaska.

The end of April finds Louis and me at the Haines, Alaska public library where internet access available.  We got in here about eight local time last night.  The last couple of hundred miles were the most beautiful of the trip. Since Sunday morning at ten we drove 2,780 miles averaging 62 miles an hour and gulping a gallon of fuel for every 9.5 miles traveled.  As you enter Hains you drive right by the airport.  We spent the night parked by the Mountain Flying hanger.  I will leave the truck and camper there till October. Yesterday we drove by dozens of Bison who were grazing along the shoulder of the road.  A moose raced us along the highway for a short distance.  We saw two different black bears and a few more caribou.  The prettiest sight were the flocks of ptarmigan along the roadside. These birds are pure white in the winter for camouflage turn mottled brown for the same reason in the summer.  Some of the ones we saw were beginning to turn on their summer plumage.  As we passed them the sun was getting low.  These birds looked like snow balls lighted from within as the sun reflected off them.  There is still a lot of  snow in the mountains but as I decended back to sea level spring has returned. Louis and I discussed how we had driven away from spring on this trip.  Back home the trees are about half way budded out.  As we came North all the deleciate, tender green of the budding trees had disappeared.  In about the last thirty miles of the trip spring came back. The plan is to fly on over to the cabin this afternoon.  Because this is the first flight over there from Haines this year, Paul, the pilot, wanted to be sure not to arrive at the high tide.  One never knows what the winter might have done to the normal landing spots. Last October when I took the Hughesnet antenna down I may have disturbed one of the adjustments that aligns the antenna with the sattilite.  If that is the case I may not be able to post anything else here until mid-May when some of the neighbors with undisturbed antennas show up. If my good luck holds that won't be an issue.  Another piece of luck will be if I can get a few of the pictures I took recently to show up here:  it is about 15 minutes after I typed the colon above.  Working with the iPad and getting the pictures to show up where I want them to is proving to be difficult.  In the picture below note the road in the background.  It is so beautiful here I'm glad you don't have to depend on my words to describe the scenes.

Got some final shopping done before the flight out to the cabin. Some of the stuff was real important. I.E. Killer fishing lures. I know these will out fish all the other guys on the river. A new spinning rod and reel. These used to come with the reel full of line. Now you have to buy the line separately. I bought two new cans of bear spray.

Paul, the pilot, brought a friend of his along on the flight. Louis and I rode in the seat behind them. There wasn't much room for Louis. About fifteen minutes into the flight he noticed his dog bed up on top of all the other gear we had crammed into the plane. Showing great athleticism he scrambled up on top of all that stuff and promptly went to sleep. The flight over the mountains was very smooth. Not a single bump.

Paul and his wife Amy provide charter services like they provided for me today but they also fly many "flight seeing excursions" for tourists. The cruse ships that stop at Skagway provide a steady supply of new customers who might want an aerial view of this country in addition to seeing it from sea level on the ship. This time of year the plane is equipped with skis mounted in such a way he can land on the glaciers as well as on harder surfaces as the wheels are still attached too.

We flew over mountain goats in the high country and several grizzly bears as we neared the cabin. No problem at the cabin except the valve in the shower must have frozen. Water comes out at the handle and not the shower head. No weasels, no otters either. Both wheelers started right up even though they have sat unused for seven months but both started with no problem.

I went up the beach to see if I could find any treasures but no joy there today. On the way home there was a good sized grizzly in front of the cabin. We nodded to each other and both kept on minding our own business.

Tomorrow will involve a lot of unpacking and probably a trip across the East River to look for treasures there.

Lots of bears around the cabin.  On our walk yesterday morning there were a pair just up the river.  One of them had a blond body and brown head.  The other was a regular old brown grizzly bear.  Later in the day another one strolled by the front yard.

I got the Internet antenna reinstalled yesterday but can't get a connection.  So I "break into" a nearby cabin and am using their system for this.  Trying to work with someone in Mexico about the connection difficulty with no phone and being a couple hundred yards from the problem is proving to be challenging.

The frozen shower valve has not been a simple to repair as I thought.  when some of the other neighbors begin to show up they might have the parts I need to get her going again.  In the mean time bathing in water heated up on the wood stove beats not bathing at all.  That last sentence was a quote from Louis.

Speaking of my old friend.  He is loving it here.  He watches me like a hawk to see if I might be in "go for a walk?" mode.  He beats me out the door if the answer is "let's go".

This morning the timing was right to go across the river to the outer coast and beachcomb the 16 miles or so of undisturbed beach.  I found a couple of treasured things that I will share here when I can upload pictures again.  Saw another bear and some very large wolf tracks.

Last night I put out the hummingbird feeder.  Today the first of those jeweled beauties showed up.  There is nothing blooming here yet that I can see.  There must be something natural for them to feed on or they wouldn't be here yet.

It's a good thing the batteries on my watch have not worn out. I just now had to look to see what day it is.  In spite of the normal getting settled problems to solve here at the cabin I managed to create a few more for myself.

One of the jobs on my list was to clear the front yard of all the logs that had been washed in during storm surges over the last few decades.  I thought I would just pry the end of a log up out of the grass, attach a rope and pull it away with the ATV.  I did get the rope attached but when I tried to pull the log out I simply dug four new holes in the yard, one hole under each wheel.

So the log is too heavy right!  Got the chain saw out and cut this log in half.  Back on the wheeler.  The four holes are now deeper.  Solution; cut the log into four pieces.  Nope, the starter cord on the chain saw broke.  An hour later I got the saw running again and managed to move the log.  Whew!

My cabin is located in the Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve.  To have a cabin here in the preserve you have to have a limited entry commercial fishing permit.  Commercial fishing here can, in theory, happen between the months of May and October.  The fish have a lot to say about that but those months are the only time I am allowed to be here without special exception.  Because the only reason I can be here is to fish any guests/helpers that might join me have to contribute in some way to the fishing.  One could be an assistant fisher (crew member) or a person skilled in a trade that would support the fishing (electrician, carpenter etc.) or a family member.

That last paragraph leads up to why move the logs that had been in place for decades.  I saved some of them to be cut up into firewood.  Anyone considering a visit might expect to help support my fishing habit by splitting firewood to heat the cabin to keep the resident fisherman warm.  Pretty clever way to get the wood split I think.

As soon as I can get my own internet working I will post some interesting pictures here.  On the beach the other day I could see from the tracks in the sand a grizzly had played with a round bouy that had washed up onto the beach.  The bear had batted the basketball size bouy about 150 feet down the beach toward the surf.  The bear's tracks zig zagged along behind the smooth impression the bouy had left as it rolled along.  You could also see where the bear had laid down on the sand contemplating his toy.  One might think this was a young bear.  I took a picture of its rear foot along side my boot print.  That bear's hind foot is longer than my size 13 boot.   It would have been a real treat to see this big bear play like that.  I am happy though to have come across this.  The next tide washed all that story away.  What a gift that was for me.

If Marie Keene was still around, today would have been her birthday. Reflecting on that, today is still her birthday but she's not here to celebrate with us. She she was the product of a conservative rural farm family. She married a widower who had a child. She bore two more children with him before he died at age thirty. She never let another man into her life though I recall a couple tried.  She raised those two daughters and one son by herself. Self sufficient throughout her life. Someone, probably one of her parents, told her to always save something. If I remember correctly she told me one time, "some months I saved a nickel". Self sufficient. She had amazing people skills when she wanted to use them. She was the first woman elected to a public office in the county where she lived. She held that job for 22 years till she retired. Self sufficient. Those people skills didn't always show up however. She also told me to " keep your cards close to your chest". I think she sometimes held her cards too close. Anyway, HAPPY BIRTHDAY MARIE. You were the. Best Mother I ever had.

My trips down the beach are resulting in a lot of burnt fuel and few if any treasures to show for it. I have decided to take the chainsaw along so I can at least bring home a log to turn into firewood. The last couple of evenings I took a drive out onto some of the other trails that I wouldn't normally travel. Tonight I surprised a pair of Grizzlies in a meadow and then at a slough off the East Alsek River there were four Tundra Swans watching me.

The sky is full of birds these days. It's hard to estimate but I wouldn't be surprised if I don't see ten thousand birds in a day. The bigger birds, geese and ducks, are up higher, above the horizon. The little flocks of shore birds, from a distance look like wisps of fog or vapor, as they skim along the surface of the beach. If there are ten thousand birds in my view in a day, nine thousand seven hundred and fifty are all headed in the same Northwesterly direction. The other two hundred and fifty are locals, gulls, ravens, robins, eagles a pair of Northern Harriers and still only two hummingbirds.

As I'm typing this there are a couple hundred geese out front. Whenever a raptor comes soaring over the entire flock of geese lift off in unison. They make a circle and land again right where they had been feeding a few seconds before. That must be a safety in moving numbers tactic to keep the predator bird from choosing a specific target.

If Marie Keene was still around, today would have been her birthday. Reflecting on that, today is still her birthday but she's not here to celebrate with us. She she was the product of a conservative rural farm family. She married a widower who had a child. She bore two more children with him before he died at age thirty. She never let another man into her life though I recall a couple tried.  She raised those two daughters and one son by herself. Self sufficient throughout her life. Someone, probably one of her parents, told her to always save something. If I remember correctly she told me one time, "some months I saved a nickel". Self sufficient. She had amazing people skills when she wanted to use them. She was the first woman elected to a public office in the county where she lived. She held that job for 22 years till she retired. Self sufficient. Those people skills didn't always show up however. She also told me to " keep your cards close to your chest". I think she sometimes held her cards too close. Anyway, HAPPY BIRTHDAY MARIE. You were the. Best Mother I ever had.

The little flocks of shore birds, from a distance look like wisps of fog or vapor, as they skim along the surface of the beach. If there are ten thousand birds in my view in a day, nine thousand seven hundred and fifty are all headed in the same Northwesterly direction. The other two hundred and fifty are locals, gulls, ravens, robins, eagles a pair of Northern Harriers and still only two hummingbirds.

As I'm typing this there are a couple hundred geese out front. Whenever a raptor comes soaring over the entire flock of geese lift off in unison. They make a circle and land again right where they had been feeding a few seconds before. That must be a safety in moving numbers tactic to keep the predator bird from choosing a specific target.

May 6

For the second time this week I shook my head with amusement at what it takes for the locals to get around up here.

As the season progresses there will be more small plane traffic, flying low,under 500 feet, up and down the coast. In many cases you recognize the plane and make a pretty good guess as to who is in it and where they are headed. Not unlike the cars in your neighborhood. The two times I referred to were when I could hear a small plane, flying low, approaching. I knew it was my neighbor PR because they have a red and white plane with a nose wheel like a tricycle rather than a tail wheel. He lands on the gravel runway to the left of my place then taxes up to their cabin. Parks the plane less than 100 feet from their cabin door and proceeds to unload several totes of supplies. He can't stay for coffee. There is too much to do. Hops back in the plane and is gone in less than ten minutes. During his second trip he mentioned a couple more people with cabins near mine would be showing up on the next few days.

Sure enough two more did show up late in the day. They left Yakutat at nine on the morning and arrived here around six in the evening. BS and LR had driven BS's new Honda down the beach some 50 miles, crossing at least three rivers along the way. I'd like to make that trip someday.

Tomorrow a storm is supposed to come in. The forecast is it will last through Saturday. There will be a few inside chores to do but my time may mostly be spent reading "THE GOLDFINCH" by Donna Tartt. The book caught my eye initially because of the nature sounding title and picture on the cover. Later I saw where it won the Pulitzer Prize. The first few pages didn't grab me but now I can't get it off my mind.

I learned a new dance yesterday. I'll call it the "shakey foot" It has been so dry I was just wearing sneakers while working outside. Deciding to burn a pile of brush accumulated from the 2014 ice storm. The fire was going nicely. Flames maybe ten feet high at times. I kept pushing the ends of the burning limbs deeper into the center of the fire. Those low cut sneakers/running shoes have the screen type upper material. Sometimes a spruce needle will work its way through that screen and irritate ones foot. Something was irritating my left foot and just thought I could shift my weight to my right leg and shake the needle out of my left shoe. That didn't work. I shook harder. I even grabbed onto a tree to keep my balance and continued to shake the heck out of my left foot. The irritation was getting much worse. I looked down and the screen material on my shoe had a quarter size hole surrounded by little red glowing embers. The Cabela's wool sock under the screen had a hole in it too. The pink and white toe under the sock, under the screen didn't have a hole in it but it wanted out from under the hole. Now normally one would just stomp out a small ember like that. Since my right leg was busy holding me up stomping out the inferno with that appendage wouldn't work. Solution; fall flat on my butt and jerk the shoe and sock off.

I'm glad I wasn't wearing high tops.

Yesterday about all that happened is it rained a quarter of an inch. I did go up the beach and again found no treasures. Maybe I already mentioned rather than come home empty handed I have decided if I don't have any luck beach combing I will bring home a log to be turned into fire wood. Which I did. I'm typing this as good old Louis has taken my place on the left side of the bed. Today it has rained almost a half inch. These rainy days when there is no real pressing work to do it is easy to sit around and read, doze off for a while, read some more, lie down on the bed, feel guilty for not doing anything, get up and read some more. Then repeat. But that is not what makes today special. Today Louis and I had a real bear encounter. As we usually do right after we got up we went outside to relieve ourselves, scratch a little, stretch then open our eyes. Louis went off to the left and I angled off toward the right. A movement at the base of a spruce tree at the edge of the yard caught my eye. Peering out was a grizzly. First thought was; what a great picture that would be. This big bear right in the yard. Second thought was; I don't have the camera and I don't dare take my eye off this guy to go get one because he was so close. (I later stepped off the distance. He was less than 60 feet away. That's about three car lengths). The next thought was; what was that black streak rushing past me barking at the bear. The bear started away as I cheered Louis on. But then the situation changed. The bear stopped and turned toward Louis. Louis also stopped since the bear wasn't doing what he thought the bear should be doing. The bear, focused on Louis started back toward him. Hoping the bear wouldn't break into a charge for Louis I went toward him yelling for all I was worth. The bear turned away again. So did Louis and I. When I turned back around the bear was coming toward us again. It seemed he had a hot dog on his mind. By now I was pissed at the bear for seeming to threaten my pal so I ran back into the cabin and grabbed the shotgun. I had some rubber bullets in the magazine. As I ran toward him the bear turned away. I got close enough that I shot him in the butt with one of the rubber bullets. I think the noise startled him but the rubber bullet seemed to have no affect. I should note, I believe this same bear came out of the woods while my neighbor was here unloading some supplies. The neighbor had his dog Charlie with him. Charlie is a real German bear dog. When Charlie went after the bear it ran a short way then stopped and turned back on the dog. After a few seconds stand off the bear proceeded to stroll away. Not in rush just seeming to say "this ain't worth it". That makes me think this bear could be a problem at some point in the future. So, being upset with this bear, and the rubber bullet not bothering him too much (I should have been closer when I shot) I hopped on the Honda and went after him. After running the bear down the beach a ways I discovered I could kind of steer the bear in the direction I wanted him to go by pilling up along side it as he ran. Later I went back and guesstimated that guy was covering almost 20 feet each running stride he made with me in third gear on the Honda beside him. To test this theory I directed him into the East River. Those animals are so powerful hitting the water hardly seemed to slow him down at all. Back at the cabin I thanked Louis for being such a brave dog. I also thanked my lucky stars for being able to experience things like this, with him.

MOTHERS DAY, 2015

During the night I woke up thinking today is Mothers Day. Mothers Day seems a lot more important than most days of the year. More important to me than Easter or Christmas or Fathers Day or certainly my birthday. There have been way to many of those or, on second thought, maybe not near enough.

Maybe the reason I have been busy in the kitchen this morning is some subliminal memory of the pleasant experiences that have come out of other kitchens. Kitchens I have had the pleasure of enjoying while mothers I have known went about the magic they weave in those rooms.

Up here in the remoteness right now there is only one mother I can wish a happy day too. LR is a couple of cabins away. Her husband flew in late yesterday to spend today with her. Yesterday I invited her and the other neighbor who happens to be here right now to a pasta dinner. They begged off but took a rain check for tonight.

So the reason I have been busy in the kitchen is to bake brownies with pecans inside and Carmel drizzled over the top. They have about fifteen minutes to go in the oven and the place smells great right now. The thought of sitting on the radiator in my Mother's kitchen waiting for something delicious (cinnamon toast) to come out of the oven is making me smile.

Anyway it is a beautiful Mothers Day here. I hope wherever the Mothers who read this are having a wonderful day too. Doesn't matter if they are in Kentucky, Texas, Utah, Colorado, Alaska. I hope as you read this you know this message is for you.

HAPPY MOTHERS DAY.
I love you,
John

Woke up early to low clouds this morning. Much of the day there was a very fine mist in the air. A mist made of droplets slightly bigger than those vaporizers that puff out clouds in the hardware stores.

Productivity today consisted of pulling the well pipe for the old fashioned hand pump out of the ground. The screen at the bottom of the pipe is stopped up so I can't use the hand pump to fill the sink. I thought the pipe was going to be fifteen feet or so into the ground. After rigging a chain around the pipe and using a high lift jack to pull on the chain in just a few minutes I had the pipe out. It was only into the ground about eight feet. I may be able to clean the screen part of the pipe and reuse it.

Yesterday I went down to the mouth of the river to see if any salmon were coming in with the push of the tide as it started in. I thought I saw a couple of fish. It seems a little early but what the heck. Who am I to tell the salmon when to arrive.

This afternoon rod in hand, tide coming in, no salmon. There were quite a few Dolly Varden trout to be caught. Released all of them. The droplets in the air became BB size and were being driven by a ten mph wind so I came home and finished the novel I have been reading.

The Goldfinch, by Donna Tartt, #1 best seller, winner of Pulitzer Prize for fiction, Andrew Carnegie medal, on and on. A really good book. Hated to see it end.

Yesterday and today have been ho hum with with sugar free, no fat green plum frosting. Kind of like a small, skim milk, no foam, decaf latte. At some coffee shops they call that a "why bother".

Didn't catch any Dollies today. Did see some bear tracks near by. As I banged around the cabin Louis couldn't stand it so he went up to the neighbors for some peace and quiet. The young couple who's cabin is next door arrived yesterday. They have a one year old daughter named Fathom. She is precious but a little shy of me. I'll work on that.

This afternoon the temperature and humidity reached that critical point where fog developed. At one point I could barely see beyond the tree on the front yard.

Fathom's grand parents have a sport fishing camp about 25 miles up the coast. The river near their camp has eroded the away the bank to the point they need to move their buildings back away to higher ground. I will be going up to help with that project tomorrow if the fog lifts and we can get out of here. Louis will be looked after by some of the neighbors staying nearby.

Typing this much earlier than usual. I thought I would be traveling up the coast to help move the neighbor's fishing camp by now. Yesterday's fog lifted overnight but settled back in by dawn. The weather broadcast on the VHF radio said it should clear this afternoon. If that happens we would fly to the camp.

Having just checked with the neighbor the plan B is to drive the wheelers the up the beach to the sport camp. That will require fording two rivers. I'm all for that. The 25 mile ride would take us by just one cabin. All that distance without any serious beachcomber competition. The problem is we would probably be covering that 25 miles in about an hour. That is way, Way to fast to find treasures.

If we use plan B we wouldn't leave till about three this afternoon. The tide would be near its lowest by the time we needed to cross the second river around four. We would load the wheelers in a boat to cross the first river. At the second river, much smaller, we could wade across at low tide.

While at the sport camp there will be no internet. So there might be a spell where no posts show up here.

This is the fourth time I have tried to publish this May 19th edition. Hopefully I can get some pictures to come over here too.

This is the fifth time the May 19th post has been attempted.  Lets try again.  Damn, it seems to be working finally. That picture is of Fathom Iris Grabber.  She lives next door.  Fathom is about 14 months old.  She and her folks came over for a visit yesterday.  She took to Louis right away and he to her. To get over to the sport camp I have been writing about we have to cross two rivers.  To transport a boat between rivers or just to get a boat out of the water without having a trailer, a modification is made so wheels can be added and removed from the boat as needed.  Here we are putting the boat into the Alsek River. Once the wheels are pulled off the boat you pull it up parallel to the shore and load the wheeler.  We needed the wheeler to make the 25 mile run down the coast to the next river.  That's Fathom's Dad doing the hard part. That's me being glad Fathom's Dad loaded the Honda.  On the other side of the Alsek we pull this boat out of the water, re-install the wheels and leave it up above the tide line.  No need to take this big boat the 25 miles up the coast.  There is another smaller boat for the smaller river we have to cross next. We crossed the next river with this boat.  On the way home three of us plus Charlie the bear dog and the wheeler were all in this vessel at the same time The water was about the level of the top of the wheels. As we crossed nobody  made any sudden moves. No rocking the boat when the water is just inches from coming over the sides.  I should note however, this second river isn't very deep or swift.  If one fell out of the boat all you would have to do is stand up and walk on out. This picture and the next are of some of the activity involved in relocating the buildings at the sport fishing camp.We broke this building down into eleven pieces, moved those pieces about a half mile, and reassembled it in the new spot. The reason the camp had to be moved is the river is eroding the beach so quickly a major storm would probably wash away the dunes that protect the previous location.  In the two years since I was there last, the river has moved nearly a half mile closer to the camp.

Today the population on this side of Dry Bay went from 5 people to seven.  Actually four more people arrived but two of them live on the other side of Dry Bay.  Hans, the owner/pilot of Yakutat Coastal Airlines, brought these guys in in his Otter.  He had the plane painted this last winter.  I made the mistake of being the first one to scratch it while loading a fuel drum.  He cautioned me to be more careful next time with his new $35,000 paint job. Some other fliers have been around for the last couple of weeks.  These geese come and go several times during the day.  They feed on the new grass coming up on the sandbars out front.  There is one snow goose hanging out with the several hundred white fronted geese.    That picture is of some of the treasures I drug home from the beach.  The chain was through a hole in a log.  I think it was used to hold a raft of logs together somewhere down the coast.  It was pretty windy here today so I hung it there to serve as a wind chime.  The orange buoy attracted attention because of the macramé netting around it.  No telling how far that drifted across the pacific before washing in here.  The metal buoy has a collar around it.  It is the only one like that I have seen.  My theory is the collar makes a splashing or popping sound when the buoy is attached to the end of a net or is anchored in some way.  The noise it makes might scare the fish into a net. ???  Just a guess! Sorry about the mixed orientation of the pictures in yesterday's post.  They looked OK when I hit the send button.  Or maybe the Jim Beam I had helping me had something to do with it.

Today the population on this side of Dry Bay went from 5 people to seven.  Actually four more people arrived but two of them live on the other side of Dry Bay.  Hans, the owner/pilot of Yakutat Coastal Airlines, brought these guys in in his Otter.  He had the plane painted this last winter.  I made the mistake of being the first one to scratch it while loading a fuel drum.  He cautioned me to be more careful next time with his new $35,000 paint job. Some other fliers have been around for the last couple of weeks.  These geese come and go several times during the day.  They feed on the new grass coming up on the sandbars out front.  There is one snow goose hanging out with the several hundred white fronted geese.    That picture is of some of the treasures I drug home from the beach.  The chain was through a hole in a log.  I think it was used to hold a raft of logs together somewhere down the coast.  It was pretty windy here today so I hung it there to serve as a wind chime.  The orange buoy attracted attention because of the macramé netting around it.  No telling how far that drifted across the pacific before washing in here.  The metal buoy has a collar around it.  It is the only one like that I have seen.  My theory is the collar makes a splashing or popping sound when the buoy is attached to the end of a net or is anchored in some way.  The noise it makes might scare the fish into a net. ???  Just a guess! Sorry about the mixed orientation of the pictures in yesterday's post.  They looked OK when I hit the send button.  Or maybe the Jim Beam I had helping me had something to do with it.

Some of the neighbors jointly own a portable saw mill.  The mill can be broken down and moved by one person from place to place.  In many cases it is easier to take the saw mill to a group of logs on the beach than to move the logs to the mill.  Today we moved parts of one log.  That one log was probably 60 feet long.  We moved 3 twelve foot sections of it to the mill. By coupling the small trailers that usually haul fish totes, using a high lift jack and some straps those very heavy 12 foot sections become portable. At the saw mill the log remains stationary while the engine and blade move along rails.  The rails are adjustable so the operator can change the width and thickness of the boards cut from the log.  The blade can be oriented parallel to the ground (width of the board) or vertically (thickness of the board) by moving a handle. This stack of 12 foot long boards came from one (1) of the three logs we brought back from the tree found on the beach. Remember “This little piggy went to market.  This little piggy stayed home.  This little piggy ate roast beef.  This little piggy had none.  This little piggy went wee, wee, wee all the way home.” that little ditty came to mind while I was learning the new dance I mentioned here a few days ago.  Now that I can add pictures you can see the proof that wearing screen top sneakers is not the best choice of foot ware while burning brush.  That little piggy went ouch when the ember burnt through the shoe and sock…that is how I learned the footwork in the new dance called “shakey foot”. On a quieter note there were two beautiful females out front late last night.  Luna, goddess of the moon, and Venus, goddess of love and beauty.  They were very bright in the western sky.  They were beautiful together.  They made me feel lucky to be in their company.  Those two goddesses.

Dense fog advisory.  That keeps popping up whenever I log on to the Internet.  I wonder how they know I am foggy on these dark overcast days.

Yesterday there were a bunch of terns flying around up above the shallow part of the creek in front of the cabin.  Investigating I managed to scare the terns away so no good pictures.  They had been hovering over a shallow pool of water where some tiny fish (probably salmon fry) were stranded.  They were out there again this morning.

Last night we had a stealthy visitor.  The trash barrel got turned over.  Couldn't find any tracks.  It was probably a bear.  Louis was very interested in the smells left behind.  He left his mark at the scene.  Then he proceeded to pull something out of the barrel for himself.

Today took the boat off its winter blocks.   Several maintenance things need attending to before I put her back in the water.  Oil change, service the lower unit etc.  I bought a small sonar device I need to get it installed.  With it I will be able to tell how deep the water is I'm fishing in.  In the past I just pushed the paddle down along side the boat.  If I didn't touch bottom I knew the water was more than paddle deep.  This year I can be a little more scientific.

Yesterday was not a good day for the newest Honda.  When I ordered it I specified the manual pull start mechanism be added.  Figured if the battery failed while out in the bush someplace that might be handy.  Several others here have done the same.  The machine had been starting slowly so I thought I should test the manual starter.  It turns out the manual mechanism is not waterproof.  When I tested it the cord came out, the engine started but the cord would not retract….water had damaged the retracting spring.  I “fixed” (note the quotes) it and went out to gather some more logs for firewood.  Back at the cabin I shut the Honda down to unload the wood.  Went to start it…no go…grabbed the manual start cord and gave it a pull…it came out and stayed out again but the engine didn’t start.  Now it won’t start at all.  A new starter is $156.38 in Anchorage.  A new manual start mechanism is about $60.00.  One of the other fishermen told me today the going price for the few early king salmon being caught is around $9.00 a pound.  Sooo if I catch a couple of twenty pound kings early this year maybe I can get the Honda going again. Sunday, two weeks from today the first commercial fishing begins for those of us here at Dry Bay.  Some, not already occupied sawing wood, finishing cabins, moving sport camps are getting the fishing gear ready.   I pulled a couple of nets out of storage today.  If I can get to the right web sites I hope to see how to mend the torn places.   There have been many eagles hanging around the beach and rivers.  They seem to know something is about to happen.  What that is I haven’t a clue but I’d bet it has to do with food.  The one above was perched on the gateway to the Vet’s cabin.  The Vet is a retired veterinarian and is a wonderful man even if his political views don’t align with mine.  Last year he noticed Louis eating a scrap of paper.  The Vet exclaimed “My God man do you realize how much money you could save by feeding him paper instead of dog food”.  He is coming back to his cabin here this week.  The Vet sent me an email asking if I needed anything.   I responded:  “Louis could use some paper to eat.  The New York Times would be OK.  Something liberal you know.”  The Vet responded:  “John:  It is reassuring to know that Lewis has the good sense to turn the Times into it;s most useful form.”…I think he probably meant dog poop. This afternoon was spent down at the mouth of the East River.  A few sockeye salmon are beginning to come in.  Didn’t catch a salmon but did snag a few Dolly Varden trout.

Today is oldest son's birthday.  How time flies.  I remember like yesterday going down to the gift shop at Saint Joseph Hospital on Eastern Parkway in Louisville an buying those cigars that said "Its a Boy" on the cellophane wrapper.  I hope he had a good day.

It finally rained here again.  Just barely enough to get good and chilled while fishing.  I think this is the forth or fifth day it has rained this month.  The total for the month is less than an inch and a half.  To be in a temperate rain forest it is very dry.

Still no Kings in the river.  I did catch about a dozen Dollies but threw them all back.  While out there a couple of eagles took turns scooping something up out of the surf.  One would snag what looked like a small flounder then drop it back into the water.  The second eagle would then swoop in and do the same thing.  They did this dance for me a couple of times before sailing off up the coast on set wings.

Spotted an otter on the other side of the river on the way back home.  I waited for it to swim over to my side.  And waited and waited.  Finally it came up on my side a couple of hundred yards down stream.  Amazing how far those animals can swim without appearing to come up for air.

This time of month two years ago there were as many as a dozen hummingbirds at the feeder at once.  I have not seen more than two out there this year.  Makes one wonder what happened.  Were they early?  Are they late?  Makes me wonder anyway.

Today was not cold temperature wise (49 at 6 am 50 at 8 pm) but it felt chilly because of a steady wind from the West.  That wind blew in my neighbor the Vet and three of his buddies.  It took two planes to get all their stuff here.  A couple of us had fun helping move all that gear from the beach to his cabin.  He kept saying “Don’t worry about that stuff.  I’ll move it later.”  I told him we were just being nosey. Today was also the day several of the fishermen moved their boats over to the river and into the water.  I’ll probably do that tomorrow.  Today I pulled all my nets out of the tote where they rested all winter. One of them was in bad shape because it got caught in the propeller of the outboard last fall.  I cut the damaged webbing off the float and lead lines and am in the process of replacing it.  That’s the float line by the boat. I made this crude bench to help me rehang the net with the proper spacing.  The two posts are set the proper distance apart for the size opening in the new netting.  Several hundred knots will hold the net on the float line and lead lines. In this picture you can see the needle that gets filled with twine to sew the net onto the lines.  It will probably take most of tomorrow to finish that net.  An experienced person can rehang a net in about four hours.

Yesterday the boat went to the harbor across Dry Bay.  Dry Bay shows up on some maps to the South East of the Alsek River’s mouth.  From some of the reading I have done the area got its name because years ago there may have been some deceiving water over the area.  If there was it was very shallow.  Now days in periods of heavy rain the part that at one time may have looked like a bay still does but most of the time it looks like the picture below.   There is a trail across the “Dry Bay” we call the super highway.  There are only a couple of curves in the four miles or so across the desert like area.   One can run his Honda wide open across there if one chooses.  Not pulling a boat though. It has been very foggy the last few days.  I knew fog is the result of the air not being able to hold any more moisture.  Terms like relative humidity and dew point have something to do with that but I wasn’t sure how they related.  They were a mystery to me.  Google had plenty of explanations to offer.  Some of the explanations left me clueless but here are a couple that made some sense. “Humidity is a term that describes the amount of water vapor in the air whereas dew point is the temperature at which moisture in the air - humidity – begins to condense” “Humidity is the amount of moisture in the air but not necessarily “condensed” moisture.  Dew Point is the temperature at which the moisture in the air will start to condense and become liquid.  When dew point and temperature are within 4 degrees F you will get fog” Mystery solved.  Right now my weather center says the dew point is 49 and the temperature is 50.  It is also very foggy outside. That’s an eagle perched on a stump waiting for the fog to clear. We have another mystery out back.  None of us have caught a salmon yet.  I haven’t seen any birds with one either.  However something left part of a salmon in the middle of the trail behind the cabin.  Bear?  Otter?  Mysteries…make life interesting.

Nancy died 4 years ago today.  Her love of pets prompted us to sponsor a "Get Acquainted Area" at the Humane Society in Boulder. It is touching to watch people get to know the pets they adopt in a space dedicated to Nancy.  She would have liked that.

Nancy died 4 years ago today.  Her love of pets prompted us to sponsor a "Get Acquainted Area" at the Humane Society in Boulder. It is touching to watch people get to know the pets they adopt in a space dedicated to Nancy.  She would have liked that.

A quiet day here.  I did see a plane flying up and down the East River.  I bet it was the wildlife biologists getting a count on the number of salmon in the river.   Yesterday evening I spent several hours down at he mouth.  You could see, every couple of minutes, two or three fish push in, against the current, from the ocean.

I went through my nets some more today picking out the three I will use next week.  There are some holes in a couple of them.  The holes are usually caused by an otter or seal tearing a fish out of the net.  Occasionally I'll tear the net if a fish is so tangled I can't get it out any other way.  Looking on line for a way to mend nets I found a publication from the University of Oregon explaining it.  There were over 25 illustrations and photographs.  I took the iPad out in the yard and put it down beside one of the holes. I even rubbed the iPad over the hole and it still isn't fixed.  Maybe I can get one of the other old guys to show me how to tie the six or eight different knots I need to learn.

One measure of how long I have been here.  From May 1 to June 1 one bottle of Jim Beam lasts that long.  At that rate the pantry has enough bourbon to last until July 12th

Tried to make some progress toward Sunday’s fishing today.   I hauled the boat over to the Alsek River a few days ago.  Today I took the buoys, anchors and ropes over there.  The next trip will be a trailer with the nets.  I tied all the gear delivered today to one of the wheels that go under the boat. Quite a few bears hang around the beach we call the boat harbor.  I didn’t want to go back over there and find the critters had decided the buoys looked like toys to roll into the river.  Once another fisherman found the bears had pushed his unattended Honda into the river.  It was found floating wheels up in some quiet water downstream. Other preparations today included patching nets.  I still haven’t gotten the hang of how to tie the meshes together properly.  I did patch one big hole with another piece of net.  Sunday I’ll find out how the work I did affects how the net hangs in the water. The wild flowers are about to explode across the area.  There are already acres of shooting stars.  I thought of my good neighbor Dave L. when I took the picture below.  These beauties are one of his favorite flowers The yellow indian paint brush are just coming on.  The huge lupines are about 10 percent out and the elusive chocolate lily is shyly showing herself in a few places. The lupines will cover some of the meadows.  Meadows of  fifty or more acres.  I’ll try and get a picture of that this year. The weather forecast is for 90% chance of rain tomorrow.  One hundred percent on Thursday then gradual clearing.  Just a chance of getting wet fishing on Sunday.  The VHF radio weather is calling this a pretty good storm.  The seas out in the Gulf of Alaska may have 40 foot waves.  Those waves will break before they hit our beaches.  A storm like this one might make the beach combing more interesting.

Tried to make some progress toward Sunday’s fishing today.   I hauled the boat over to the Alsek River a few days ago.  Today I took the buoys, anchors and ropes over there.  The next trip will be a trailer with the nets.  I tied all the gear delivered today to one of the wheels that go under the boat. Quite a few bears hang around the beach we call the boat harbor.  I didn’t want to go back over there and find the critters had decided the buoys looked like toys to roll into the river.  Once another fisherman found the bears had pushed his unattended Honda into the river.  It was found floating wheels up in some quiet water downstream. Other preparations today included patching nets.  I still haven’t gotten the hang of how to tie the meshes together properly.  I did patch one big hole with another piece of net.  Sunday I’ll find out how the work I did affects how the net hangs in the water. The weather forecaster was right.  It started raining around midnight and rained steadily till about eleven then turned into a beautiful day.  The forecast for the next two days is one hundred percent chance of rain.  If it rained at night and was beautiful during the day that would be a win win for us and the forecaster. On the way home from beach combing there were a bunch of people on the other side of the East River.  Ten hikers had come some 60 miles up the coast and were going to be picked up here at Dry Bay.  It was still cold and windy when I came across them so I offered to haul their gear back here to the cabin.  They enjoyed the warm stove and some hot tea.  Six of them were from Juneau and the others from down south.  One man and his wife upon introducing themselves self said they from Colorado.  Small world in that they live on the south side of Boulder. The Humming birds are back!  After heating up the cabin for the hikers I left the doors open to cool things back down to normal.  Two of the tiny fliers came in to keep Louis company.  We sent them along their way unharmed.

The win/win mentioned in yesterday’s post didn’t happen.  The weather forecaster got his part right.  It rained all day.  The heavy rain at times in the forecast didn’t happen but an inch and a quarter has fallen so far.  The wind was present as predicted.  Steady most of the day around ten mph with gusts up to 35.  The sandy area in front of the cabin where I tried to patch the nets the other day is covered with water. My tiny feathered friends have been enjoying the feeder today.  The little guys seem to be shivering as they dip into the sugar water.  I’m glad to provide the fuel to help them keep their motors running. Speaking of fuel, on May 18th I sent an empty barrel to Yakutat to be filled with gasoline.  After several email exchanges, some of which were tense, I finally got my fuel today.  Other frustrating communication events this season have caused me to cave in and invest in a little more technology. Iridium is one of the suppliers of satellite telephones.  They have come up with a device that lets one connect an Apple iPhone to their network.  The little box is self-contained, waterproof and its own Wi-Fi hotspot.  The literature says I will be able to use the iPhone anywhere on the planet as long as the device has a clear view of the sky.  When I get all the registrations completed I “hopefully” can sit inside the cabin wirelessly connected to the GO device outside and make phone calls to suppliers rather than trying to do it with emails.  The calls are expensive though.  A little less than $3.00 a minute. One exception to the email ordering problem was a recent transaction with Plumbers Supply in Anchorage.  On Monday they received an email from me explaining what I needed to get the manual water pump working.  Yesterday, two days later, I had the parts.  I installed them today.  Problem is though the pump still doesn’t work. This morning Louis and I went for a short walk.  The trail was littered with leaves blown off the Alder trees.  The grizzly must have seen us just before we saw it.  All we saw was a glimpse of its backside diving into the bushes.  The wind is still almost howling outside.  When I look out the grasses, the wildflowers and the trees are all leaning away from the ocean....their backsides taking the brunt of the storm.

Today was a good day.  Good thing number one was the morning came with no wind.  Still a little mist in the air but that didn’t keep me from heading down the beach looking for the first glass ball of the season.  One would think with the high tides, and the wind/rain storm we had there would be something to find on the beach. Some of these old Japanese fishing floats have marks on them.  The marks might signify the fishing company or the boat being fished from or the village where the ball was made.  There are a couple of books that describe the various markings and in some cases describe what the mark represents. One of the books described the mark on this float as being “exceedingly rare.”  The other book had this to say; “It has been found only on blue-green 3- inch diameter glass balls.  Beachcombed around the Pacific and still found in Japanese gear piles in fishing villages on the Eastern coast of Hokkaido and in the extreme Northern tip, just south of Russia.  Uncommon.” Good thing number two was the email came through on how to register the satellite phone.  That turned out to be a piece of cake.  So, anxious to test the thing, I took the little base station out and set it on a stump in the front yard.  Back inside the cabin, I made calls to the kids in Kentucky….no problem. Good thing number three was I got the locations pinned down where I will set the three nets when the commercial fishing starts Sunday at noon.  On the way back from the river another nice thing happened.  Motoring along off the regular trail I spotted a cluster of Lupines unlike the millions of others.  These were a very dark purple with almost no white petals.  For comparison the second picture is the standard model. Another unusual trait with this group was they were growing in a circle about 10 feet across.  On the farm one could sometimes see circles of darker green grass in the pastures.  I think we called them fairy rings.
