The first day of the 2015 commercial fishing season is over here at Dry Bay.  The next fishing day is next Sunday.  As far as I can tell it was pretty slow fishing for most of us.  I ended up with a few Sockeye and even fewer Kings but did probably manage to pay for the gas I burnt in the outboard and Honda. This is the first fish of the year.  This King Salmon weighed about 18 pounds.  I kept one of the Kings to smoke.  I'll check the weather.  Smoking the fish requires one to be around the smoker most of a day.  The weather is what usually determines if I stay near the cabin or not.  So if the weather is not so great I'll smoke the fish. A few days this group of hikers were here for a short visit.  Their schedule to be picked up by the bush plane had to be flexible.  So between the time they arrived and when the plane showed up I had the pleasure of their company.  Great folks!   The last few days of rain and wind seemed to cause the lupines to pop.  They are still not quite at their peak but close. I took this picture this morning while waiting for fish that didn't come.  There was a light rain falling.  The aluminum seat in the boat was cold.  The heavy industrial rain gear  I was wearing is not real comfortable but.... This country is so vast,  so majestic, so powerful, so inspiring, so spectacular I was thrilled to be there.

It has been a slow couple of days.  Rain off and on.  Thirty five knot winds off shore. However there is that King salmon that needed smoking so that’s what we are doing today. The plywood smoker needed a little attention.  It has been sitting on the ground for who knows how long.  The bottom edge was rotten in places.  The door was hanging on by one hinge.  The slats inside that hold up the metal grates were in bad shape.  All that is better now.  Now there is even a hole in the top for the thermometer. The humming birds are going through more than two quarts of sugar water each day.  I have already used six pounds of sugar for them this month.  The feeder has eight little holes for the birds to drink out of.  In one of the pictures below I count eighteen birds.  They are quite entertaining.     More rain due the next couple of days.  Sunday is forecast to be sunny.  That is when the next commercial fishing begins.  There is some net work needed.  I got one of the nets hung up on a submerged tree.  To get it loose required pulling it off with the boat which broke several of the strings holding the net to the lead line.

Yesterday and today were spent finishing up fishing, going fishing and getting ready to go fishing. The finishing up amounted to vacuum packing most of the King salmon that got smoked.  It seems a little salty to me but everyone else who has tried it think it is delicious. The fishing was with my neighbor the Vet.  We went up river to a place called Steve’s Island.  The Vet is a terrific fisherman.  We didn’t see a single fish.  Today in front of his cabin there were several Sockeye rising but none of them were interested in anything the Vet or I offered them. One of the getting ready chores took me back over to the boat harbor.  A couple of the nets needed attention.  The one that got stuck on the bottom last week needed mending.  The second net turned out to be illegal this year.  The Dept. of Fish and Game placed a 6” limit on the size mesh one can use in the Alsek River.  The short net I was using was bigger than that.  So one of the chores today was to find another short net that was legal. Wildlife activity amounted to seeing a bear or two on almost every trip over to the harbor.  I haven’t seen a bear from here in the cabin for two or three weeks.  There was a wolf out front this morning.  A beautiful healthy looking animal.  Louis and I had already had an early walk.  The wolf approached where we had been very cautiously.  I guess he could smell where we had been walking.  Rather than get too close to where we had been it crossed the river and proceeded up the other side.  I tried using the camera with the long lens to get a picture but it was just too far away.  This young Bald Eagle was less than twenty feet away while I unloaded the nets from the boat. Tomorrow the plan is to lay the nets out on the shore so all I have to do on Sunday is pull them into the water.  There is one set, depending on the water level where that may not work.  Whatever…it is what it is...or will be what it will be...whatever

Sunday.  Another day of fishing.  Yesterday I took the repaired and legal nets back over to the river.  The idea was to lay them out on the river bank so all I have to do today is pull them out into the water.  The Alsek River was very low.  Last weekend the water where I fish was gray with glacial silt.  Some of that water had come down from Canada.  A lot of that water had been locked up in glaciers as ice until recently.  Yesterday the water in a side channel where I set two of the nets was crystal clear.  That’s not a good sign for fishing.  The salmon in the river are seeking their way back up the Alsek.  When they hit the clear water they will know they are in the wrong stream.  One thing that may change the situation is the warm weather.  Yesterday it got up into the mid-seventies.  That will cause an increase in snow and glacier melting.  That in turn may raise the river back up.  We will see... The last message here commented on the lack of bear sightings.  After I sent that post on its way I looked out the window and this guy was right out front.  This is an adolescent grizzly.  In the second picture check out the claws.   On the way home from the river there was a sow and twin cubs. The routine Louis and I have includes a morning walk.  Part of that walk usually takes a detour by the outhouse.  My faithful companion will park himself just outside.  We are both beginning to need a hair cuts.  I bet he gets his first. My faithful sister in Texas sent me a care package which I appreciate very much.  For a rainy day she included a 300 piece Lego toy to assemble.   There were a couple of bottles of Kentucky’s finest included too.  Thanks Sis.

The routine Louis and I have includes a morning walk.  Part of that walk usually takes a detour by the outhouse.  My faithful companion will park himself just outside.  We are both beginning to need a hair cuts.  I bet he gets his first. My faithful sister in Texas sent me a care package which I appreciate very much.  For a rainy day she included a 300 piece Lego toy to assemble.   There were a couple of bottles of Kentucky’s finest included too.  Thanks Sis.
The warm weather has persisted.

The warm weather has persisted.  This afternoon the temperature got into the middle eighties.  The seventies and the eighties today should have caused the river to come way up.  It didn’t happen.  Perhaps the warm weather is isolated over here near the coast and the interior didn’t get as hot. On the way over to the river I thought there was a fire.  A great plume of what I thought was smoke was rising into the air.  It turned out to be sand blowing odd the sand bars out on the river.  It is so dry and the wind today was coming right down the throat of the river. The wind’s direction made it VERY difficult to tend the nets.  When I check a net for fish the usual way is to ease the boat up to the net, being careful to stay down wind or down current so the boat doesn’t cross over the net.  Today the wind was so strong you couldn’t “ease” up to the net.  You had to run up to it under power.  Fishing by myself that meant when I reached the net I had to run to the front of the boat, lean over the bow and try to grab the net.  The wind today would blow the boat back before I could get to the net.  By driving over the net I could grab it as I was blown back but sometime the boat’s motor would get caught in the net.  What a mess it was for 2 Kings and six sockeye. Yesterday was better.  I caught ten kings and sixteen sockeye.  Five of the kings were small so I kept them.  They are now in the freezer.  I kept these smaller fish rather than sell King Salmon for the pittance being offered.  $0.58 per pound.  Larger fish are going for $2.08 a pound.  Last year I was getting over $4.00. I cleaned those fish in the creek in front of the cabin.  The eagles and gulls always gather for the scraps.  The biggest scraps are the head and skeleton of the fish.  That weighs enough that the eagles can’t gain much altitude after they grab the treat out of the water. The adolescent bear that was out front a couple of nights ago is still hanging around.  I saw it down at the river this afternoon and on the trail on the way home from the fish plant last night.

Early every morning Louis and I take a walk down the trail toward the river.  The last two days the camera went along with us.  These pictures are all just suggestions of the beauty we see.  The pictures are just a fraction of the resolution the camera takes. The full resolution shots would take forever to send over the internet.  These Arctic Lupines are with Indian Paintbrush.  I think the purple flowers in the foreground are Beach Pea. Arctic Lupines are out in full force right now.  Compared to Lupines like the Texas Blue Bonnets they are huge. The bears love the Cow Parsnip.  They eat the stalks and will dig up the roots as well.  The little wild flower booklet I have says they can be up to nine feet tall.  This one is only about four feet tall standing in front of Wild Iris. This Wild Iris was showing off for me along side the trail.  I had to take its picture. Back at the cabin this Western Columbine is about three feet tall.

Yesterday there was some traffic in the neighborhood.  Yours truly caused some of… well maybe all of it. The human traffic was caused by my telling one of the neighbors I had seen a King Salmon down at the mouth of the East River.  As far as I know nobody has caught a King sport fishing this year.  Last year there were plenty of fish to catch with a rod and reel if you wanted to put in the time.  This year the fish are very scarce.  Those few that do show up have lock jaw and won’t bite. The other traffic was out by the outhouse.  It would be interesting if the bears could communicate with us in written or verbal ways.  I expect there would be signs all over the place that said things like; “Keep out of my patch of woods”.  “This territory between the big rock and the spruce tree is mine”.“All the stuff on this stretch of beach belongs to me”.  Things like that that would let us humans know what they are trying to tell us and other animals. There was a bear trying to do that night before last out back.  On my way to the outhouse yesterday  morning I noticed a bear  had left a deposit in the trail.  That’s not unusual.  They poop a lot.  Approaching the building there was  this serpentine mark on the path.  This bear was really trying to get my attention by urinating along the  path I take. Finally the bruin backed up to a tree just outside the outhouse door and left some more sign.  These bears seem to have a few favorite trees where they mark their territories and scratch their backs.  Note the  bear hair clinging to the tree. I didn’t find any hair over six feet up the tree.  Small bear???  Or just a warning sign that that tree belongs to him.  The bear was quiet enough to do this while Louis and I were sleeping about 50 feet away with the window open.

Happy Fathers Day to all you Dads who might read this.  This year our day happens to be the longest day of the year.  Here at Dry Bay the official sun rise this morning was at 3:58 and it officially sets at 10:39 tonight.  Eighteen and a half of official sun.  This time of year the sun doesn’t really set, it kind of slides behind the north western horizon.  It doesn’t really get dark dark. As often as the cabin is mentioned I finally remembered to take it’s picture. Yesterday in preparation for today’s fishing I set a couple of the nets out on the bank.  All I have to do today is grab that white float in the foreground and back the boat out into the river.  If all goes well the net will follow without getting tangled up. The Vet found the fish yesterday.  We had been having no luck sport fishing.  The fish were in the river but wouldn’t “hole up”.  They just kept heading upstream.  The Vet found where they were congregating. There were so many fish in this spot that you might get three strikes while retrieving a cast.  Sockeye are hard to hook.  The fly I was using seemed to be what they wanted.  The first picture features the new fly rod and reel I got from a family friend in Texas.  The second picture features that new rod “broken, snapped into.  Those fish are very strong and put up a terrific fight.  Somewhere along the way I must have nicked the rod creating a weak spot.  There was a second outfit available.  With it several more fish were landed.   A couple of weeks ago a group of hikers stayed with me a few minutes while they waited for their plane to pick them up.  Yesterday I received a very pleasant surprise.  It was like Christmas in July.  While they were here in the cabin my jabbering must have impressed them with typical meal menus.  Louis was remembered too.  He and I both appreciate their thoughtfulness.

Morale at the Dry Bay Cabin is high this evening.

The fishing was good enough that the Department of Fish and Wildlife extended the opener for a second day. So we got to fish from noon on Sunday till noon Tuesday.

The spots I fished last year and this year until today were just not producing very many fish. I tried a couple of new spots and the results improved. My numbers are nothing like some of the old timers. I might bring in 10% of the fish they do some days. But I’m excited about next week’s opening. I kept 5 of the sockeye. They are resting in the freezer now. Soon I have to figure out how to ship some home. The freezer there is empty.

When I came home this afternoon there was an Amazon package at the door. Grape Jelly, Sweet Baby Ray’s Barbecue sauce and some AA batteries. Now I feel complete. I already had plenty of peanut butter.

Another morale booster was the new satellite phone worked perfectly and allowed me to speak with a guy in Bellingham, WA about some fishing gear I need. The stuff is on its way.

My sister introduced to one of those web sites that send out a daily inspirational message. I read then delete most of them. I just don’t get the message in some of them. I did get this one though.

Remember the sky you were born under,
know each of the star’s stories.
Remember the moon, know who she is.
Remember the sun’s birth at dawn, that is the
strongest point of time. Remember sundown
and the giving away to night.
Remember your birth, how your mother struggled
to give you form and breath. You are evidence of
her life, and her mother’s, and hers.
Remember your father. He is your life, also.
Remember the earth whose skin you are:
red earth, black earth, yellow earth, white earth
brown earth, we are earth.

(Joy Harjo, 1951 - )

The satellite internet system has been on the blink the last couple of days. My good neighbor the Vet has an older system that seems to be working fine. When I called the representative in Yakutat he said most installations are having problems. The Vet is kind enough to let me use his system to upload these posts and check my mail. I appreciate that very much.

The Park Service hosted the annual fisherman's meeting today. We got to meet the new superintendent. He seems like a nice enough guy.

There were chores that needed doing here at the cabin. Don't know what if anything I might have missed by being one of the first to leave. One of the chores was to go back through all my nets. The ten fathom net needed to be replaced. By sorting through the longer nets I found one with several holes in it. By using the best part of that net I now have a new ten fathom net.

One of tomorrow's chores will be to finish up that modification. The forecast is for rain the next few days. So late this afternoon the fly rod and I went fishing again. Two big Sockeye succumbed to my offerings and two more thought they liked what was offered but spit out the hook before I could land them.

The waders have a small leak high up the left leg. The forecasted rain started while i was fishing. My light weight shirt was soon soaked and half my legs were wet. Don't remember the last time I was shivering but this afternoon reminded me of what that felt like.

Good news when I got back to the cabin. An Amazon delivery was dropped off by a neighbor. More Grape Nuts on the shelf now.

Watched a bear cross the river just down from the house today. It has been so warm and dry the feeling is most of them are back in the mountains where it is cooler. There is still snow on the higher peaks.

Scud (v) to run or move along quickly and easily 2: (n) to run before a Gail with little or no sail set 2a: wind-driven clouds, snow, mist or rain

That was the word that rose up in my mind every time I looked out the window at the sky today. For most of the day there was water on the air. Sometimes just a very fine and scarce mist. Other times the water fell from the sky like one of those fan shaped attachments that go on the end of a hose. Not a driving rain of big drops but a heavy gentle rain made up of little drops.

It escapes me the number of words some of the people who live north of here have for snow. A dozen maybe? I bet there are at least that many words that can be used to describe the types of rain that fall here. Referring to the direction it falls from. The shape, velocity and size of the rain drops. Never paid much attention to those things till being exposed to them here.

Got the ten fathom net ready to go. Tomorrow I'll take it over to the river and lay it out on the bank along with the other two longer nets in the spots where I will fish on Sunday.

June 30, 2015
Here we are the last day of June. This week's commercial fishing opener was disappointing in that it lasted only 24 hours. The spot my nets were set produced better for me than any thing else so far this season. I caught fifty fish that weighted right at three hundred pounds. Kept half of them. There must be a huge number of fish coming in someplace else to keep the price so low. I am getting just $0.93 a pound for what most consider the finest sockeye salmon in the world.

The Internet is still down at my cabin. I will post some pictures when my system is back up.

The wolf was back yesterday morning. There was a moose out back.  No bear sightings recently. The seals only stole a couple of fish from me. After being socked in by fog for four hours on the river yesterday and nearly being stranded on a sand bar as the tide went out, today I will stay close to home, pack and freeze the fish.

Sometimes one wonders what in the world is going on.  The internet system here at the cabin has been installed for over two years.  It is a Hughesnet satellite system.  The first two years…no problems.  This year the modem had to be shipped away to be repaired.  Last week the system went down again.  A phone call to tech support informed me there was a system problem and everybody was having trouble.  Just be patient.  A couple of days later the neighbors were all back on line.  Not me.  This morning I called tech support three times.  Each time after plowing through the menus I was put on hold for eight to ten minutes then the call would drop.  Three dollars a minute.  I was steaming.  All I got to talk to was a machine. A couple of the tech savvy neighbors could see the steam rising off the roof of the cabin.  With a special meter the antenna got readjusted by about one degree and now things seem to be working fine.  Back to wondering what is going on.  How come the antenna was pointed correctly for over two years and it suddenly needed readjusting.  One of the neighbors said it is because of the land rising here.  I think it is called glacial rebound.  As the glaciers retreat the land rises.  That subtle gradual movement caused the alignment to shift just enough to lose the signal. The Vet helped me vacuume pack the salmon.  The color of the flesh in these sockeye is amazing. This wolf came through yesterday morning.  Today there was a sow grizzly and a real dark, almost black, little cub with her.  The little guy looked like a giant black cotton ball as it tried to keep up with mom going through the grass.

Happy Independence Day.  It was a beautiful Day here.  Yesterday was a nice day too.  The annual Dry Bay 4th of July celebration was held up at the fish plant.  Most of the camps brought food.  I took plastic forks and paper cups. The picture below features the youngest resident and the oldest.  They are both nice people.  Fathom is a precious 15 or 16 months old.  The Vet, also known by his radio handle as the Old Fart, is in the background.   He is older than dirt. Today besides getting the nets ready to fish tomorrow I took a couple of visiting neighbors fishing.  Everybody caught fish except me.  Didn’t feel too bad though hanging out in a spot as beautiful as this.

There are enough fish in the Alsek River to allow the Department of Fish and Game to extend this week's commercial fishing till Wednesday. Three days. That means there will be some money made. Not much money at ninety three cents a pound but a little anyway. So far, half way through the opening I have sold a little over four hundred pounds of fish.

The company that is buying the fish I catch will sell you one of them in Yakutat for something over four dollars a pound. They have to get my fish up to Yakutat and they are selling a dressed fish but...

On a brighter side I dodged a couple of bullets today. The first on was on the river. One of my nets got caught up in a tree on the bottom. No amount of tugging could loosen the lead line from the tree's grip. I hooked the net up to the boat and backed away from the tree hoping the line would pull free. Nope. Then I got a running start with the boat thinking that would pop the line loose. Nope. All that did was cause water to pour over the transom into the boat. The solution was to cut the lead line on both sides of the invisible net eating monster and recover the balance of the net.

The second bullet had to do with the trailer I pull behind the Honda. These tough little trailers are built to carry the totes we haul the fish, firewood, groceries, packages and people in. From time to time the last couple of days it seemed the trailer wanted to pull the Honda to the side as we motored along. Checking it out this evening found one of the wheels was about to fall off. The bearing was shot. Not a problem though. That trailer has a twin in the side yard and I think I have a new hub and bearing in the workshop.

Hoping to beat the seals to any fish that were in the nets I was on the river around five this morning. The seals stole two. I may sleep in a little longer tomorrow. An extra hour's sleep is worth more than $0.93 cents a pound. Ain't it?

There are enough fish in the Alsek River to allow the Department of Fish and Game to extend this week's commercial fishing till Wednesday. Three days. That means there will be some money made. Not much money at ninety three cents a pound but a little anyway. So far, half way through the opening I have sold a little over four hundred pounds of fish.

The company that is buying the fish I catch will sell you one of them in Yakutat for something over four dollars a pound. They have to get my fish up to Yakutat and they are selling a dressed fish but...

This last commercial fishing opening was for three days.  I fished for two of them.  Caught about 100 salmon that weighed a little over 500 pounds.  There were several reasons for not fishing the entire three days.  The main reason is I was so tired on Tuesday that another day just didn’t make sense.  Reason number two was the fog.  These last several days a patchy fog has hung over the area.  It is really spooky out on the river not being able to see with the current carrying you downstream at about 8 miles an hour. Today the fish that had been packed and frozen were sent on their way to Boulder.  My life here is so simple the coordination of the shipment taxed me. Boxes needed to be found in Yakutat and delivered to the fish plant here at Dry Bay.  The frozen fish had to be transported the five miles from the cabin to the fish plant and packed in the boxes. The plant has no refrigeration so I wanted to deliver them fairly close to the time the bush plane was to fly back to Yakutat. In Yakutat somebody had to move the three boxes of fish over to the air freight office.  As this is being typed I hope the guy at the fish plant remembered to add my fish to the plane's load.

The fish that were sent south on Thursday evening were nestled in my freezer in Boulder about twenty hours later.  A salmon loving friend met them at the Denver airport.  Upon delivery to the house she discovered they would not all fit in my freezer.  What to do???   Jan and my brother-in-law Tim came up with a brilliant solution.  Jan took them home with her.  I am very happy they came up with that solution.  I could not have stocked my freezer without their help. A little sport fishing has been going on.  There are thousands of sockeye in the East River according to the Fish and Wildlife people.  Where we have been fishing you can see them in the water.  These fish turn a crimson red when they are about to spawn.  In some places the clear water has a pinkish color reflecting back there are so many fish holding in the pools.  This one had not changed color yet. Part of yesterday was spent repairing the net I tore up last week.  When I’m doing that sort of thing I am reminded of the little spider that has a web in the corner of the kitchen window.  Whenever I open that window it damages the web.  In just a couple of minutes that spider is back out there repairing the damage.  I have watched this happen a couple of times.  I wish I was one tenth as good at repairing my nets as that spider is. Commercial fishing happens again tomorrow.  I took the repaired net back over to the boat, reattached the bridals, buoys and anchors. Then I spread the net out on the river bank.  Tomorrow all I have to do is pull the net out into the water. On the way over this mom and her two cubs were across the slough.  I had seen them earlier this year.  The cubs look almost twice as big as they were a few weeks ago.

Commercial fishing is over for another week.  It is strange the fluctuations in the number of fish in the river.  One would expect a gradual increase in the number of fish migrating upstream then a gradual tapering off.  A bell curve if you plotted the catch on a piece of graph paper.   Last week everybody caught more fish than the weeks before.  We could fish three days last week.  True to the bell curve.  This week the bottom dropped out.  Fishing was closed after one day.  Yesterday I didn’t catch a single fish.  A dozen ended up in the nets overnight.  Experienced fisherman who usually catch many more fish than me did not this week.

All the time spent running back and forth to the river has given me the chance to see several bears along the trail.  There has been a moose hanging around in the Alders around the cabin.  I haven’t seen it and as far as I know Louis has not either.  There are tracks all around though.  Today on the way home from the fish plant I think a Lynx jumped off the trail just ahead of me.

Have been reading a lot lately.  While the internet was down books began to take up my spare time.  Today I finished Pearl S. Buck’s “<u>THE GOOD EARTH</u>”.  A classic story so well written.  Those of us in the late summer and fall of our lives can easily relate to it.

A quiet couple of days here at the cabin. It has rained gently off and on.  On and off.  Off and on.  Not hard enough to keep the swallows from darting about catching bugs. Not hard enough to keep the hummingbirds away from the feeder. Hard enough keep Louis and this old guy close to home. The forecast for tomorrow is: rain, heavy at times. I finished two novels this week. It might be three if the forecast is correct.

Some visitors came through yesterday. Tanya, the Glacier Bay bear biologist and her seasonal helper Christian, stopped by for a visit. It is always informative talking with them. They are both musicians and tonight if it isn't raining they will they will entertain the community.

The flying service I have used getting in and out of here landed out front yesterday afternoon. Paul offers a variety of trips in his beautiful plane. He will take you on a flight that includes landing on a glacier. He will take you through the mountains for amazing photography opportunities. He will even take you into the outback and land on a remote beach. One of those remote spots is here in front of the cabin. His clients yesterday were from Alaska and Michigan.

Got a compliment of sorts today. Wildflower, the man I fished with last year, asked me if I would be interested in fishing with him again next year. I thanked him and said I thought that would be fine. Wildflower and I were born just 9 days apart. He is the older one. We discussed how the decades have changed our energy levels. Him more so than me cause he is so much older.

The Fish and Wildlife people published an announcement today that the East Alsek river will be open for two days fishing next week. The East Alsek is the river just outside my cabin. Most of us will continue to fish the Alsek River which is about five miles away. There is one fisherman who will fish the East. The rest of us will wait to see how he does before we move the boats and gear.

Today was indeed a unique day in my adventures here in this remote part of the world.  The bear biologist called it a false attack rather than a false charge.  That was after she had made a special trip back over to my cabin to interview me just before she was to fly out. But as she said “Take me through it from the beginning” so I will for you.  Two nights ago the neighbors hosted a pizza party.  There were sixteen people there.  The hostess was amazing in that she could keep pulling pizzas out of that oven as fast as we could eat them.  The biologist mentioned above is also a gifted songwriter and musician.  She and her friend played several songs for us.  Some of them we could sing along to.  It was a very enjoyable evening.  One of the songs stuck in my head.  I will post those lyrics here another time. This morning Louis and I were on our normal walk along the trail that runs along behind the cabin.  I was whistling that song that was stuck in my head.  I noticed some of the cow parsnip plants alongside the trail were mashed down.  Might have even mentioned out loud to Louis that somebody had been through here recently. Shortly after that Louis took off up the trail at a run.  I knew there was something up there, probably a bear.  They usually crash off into the brush.  Louis then trots back to me feeling very proud.  I caught a glimpse of a small bear disappearing off to the right of the path.  The next thing I saw was a sow grizzly dropping down on all fours running right at me.  Louis was about 50 feet in front of me.  The bear ran right over him and came charging toward me.  Remembering to act big, raise my arms and make noise I did those things.  The bear stopped about eight feet from me.  She couldn’t decide what to do next. The thought running through my mind at that instant was “how bad is this going to hurt?”.  After maybe ten very long seconds she turned around and went back past Louis to check on the cub that had disappeared to the right.  Then she turned back around.  Louis was trying to regain his footing.  She bit him just in front of his left hip and came charging back down the trail to me.  Again she stopped about eight feet away.  By now about a pint of adrenaline had entered my blood stream.  I don’t know why she decided, after another hour long few seconds, to turn away but she did.  She went back past Louis to where her cub has vanished.  She made a couple more advances toward me then moved away into the brush. Louis has a gash on his flank that will require stiches to close.  The neighbor fisherman who is a retired veterinarian has been invaluable in administering first aid to Louis.  Tomorrow we will suture the wound closed.  A cousin in Florida recently sent me a care package containing some of Kentucky's finest bourbon.  I used that for my first aid and second aid too. When the biologist came this afternoon she and I walked through the scene of the encounter.  She commented that it is often the dog that prompts the bear to become defensive and go into attack mode.  There was enough distance between me and the cub that the bears would probably just moved off.  But because Louis was going after the retreating cub, mama grizzly thought she needed to go into attack/defense mode. This evening (its 7:45 now) Louis has eaten as normal and is resting.  There are still about four ounces of adrenaline circulating through my veins.  I’m worried about how a fourteen year old dog can handle this but we are doing the best we can under the circumstances. Late this afternoon a sow and twin cubs passed by.  I bet it is the bears we encountered this morning.  Louis and I have walked along that trail probably three hundred times the last two years.  We have seen a few bears.  Nothing like today though.  From now on I will carry some bear spray.  If it doesn’t deter the bear maybe the pepper in the spray will make me taste better.

If one were to describe the last few days here at the cabin one would soon wonder to one’s self where to begin.  The bear episode described earlier kicked off these recent days.  Louis’s surgery on the kitchen stove came next.  Hanging around the cabin while he began his recovery a new smoke house began to take shape.  Yesterday was spent catching lots of sockeye for the smoke house.   Today the fish are smoking.   Commercial fishing was limited to one day on the Alsek River.  The East Alsek was open for two days.  Nobody caught lots of fish but most of us caught a few.  The water level in the Alsek was higher than normal this week.  I have been fishing in a slough behind three other nets set out by Wildflower.  That usually means I catch about 20% of what he does.  This week because of the higher water we were almost even at around 60 fish each. Sport fishing was another story.  Sockeye are hard to catch with sporting equipment.  Not yesterday.  A few weeks ago I broke one section of my fly rod while landing a fish.  The new section arrived and the fish seem to love the replacement.  I caught the limit in a couple of hours.  Feeling smug I invited the other guys fishing to come by the cabin for dinner last night.  We had one of the fish prepared with a brown sugar and chili powder rub.  It was delicious. When we stepped outside this morning Louis went on alert.  The wolf was back.  I believe it is an adolescent.  When the wolf saw us it stopped and its body language seemed to be saying to Louis “want to play”?  I suggested to Louis that might not be a good idea.  The wolf got the hint and moved on off. A few nights ago the bear biologist and her assistant entertained our little community with their acoustic instruments and beautiful voices.  One song Tania sang for us was called “THE SWELL”.  The melody has been in my head ever since.  I asked her for the lyrics.  If you’ve been out on the ocean or from the beach watched the sea, I hope these words inspire you the way they have me. The Swell by Tania Lewis I am a poor girl from the Midwest, when I was younger I took a trip west, I saw the ocean crash to the shore, and knew from that moment that I wanted more, In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.  In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.   Then you came to me, and taught me to sail, and when to row harder and when not to bail, Now you give me courage and you give me hope, riding the waves in our little boat, In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.  In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.   Now you got the cooler and I got the poles, we’re anchored together at our fishing hole, We’ll lay our sleeping bags out on the deck, and kiss and give thanks for this sweet life we get, In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.  In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.   Now if you sail west, for an hour or two, you’ll feel the ocean begin to rock you, Don’t be worried and don’t be afraid, it’s just the love that the wind and moon made, In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.  In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell. In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.  In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.

If one were to describe the last few days here at the cabin one would soon wonder to one’s self where to begin.  The bear episode described earlier kicked off these recent days.  Louis’s surgery on the kitchen stove came next.  Hanging around the cabin while he began his recovery a new smoke house began to take shape.  Yesterday was spent catching lots of sockeye for the smoke house.   Today the fish are smoking.   Commercial fishing was limited to one day on the Alsek River.  The East Alsek was open for two days.  Nobody caught lots of fish but most of us caught a few.  The water level in the Alsek was higher than normal this week.  I have been fishing in a slough behind three other nets set out by Wildflower.  That usually means I catch about 20% of what he does.  This week because of the higher water we were almost even at around 60 fish each. Sport fishing was another story.  Sockeye are hard to catch with sporting equipment.  Not yesterday.  A few weeks ago I broke one section of my fly rod while landing a fish.  The new section arrived and the fish seem to love the replacement.  I caught the limit in a couple of hours.  Feeling smug I invited the other guys fishing to come by the cabin for dinner last night.  We had one of the fish prepared with a brown sugar and chili powder rub.  It was delicious. When we stepped outside this morning Louis went on alert.  The wolf was back.  I believe it is an adolescent.  When the wolf saw us it stopped and its body language seemed to be saying to Louis “want to play”?  I suggested to Louis that might not be a good idea.  The wolf got the hint and moved on off. A few nights ago the bear biologist and her assistant entertained our little community with their acoustic instruments and beautiful voices.  One song Tania sang for us was called “THE SWELL”.  The melody has been in my head ever since.  I asked her for the lyrics.  If you’ve been out on the ocean or from the beach watched the sea, I hope these words inspire you the way they have me. The Swell by Tania Lewis I am a poor girl from the Midwest, when I was younger I took a trip west, I saw the ocean crash to the shore, and knew from that moment that I wanted more, In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.  In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.   Then you came to me, and taught me to sail, and when to row harder and when not to bail, Now you give me courage and you give me hope, riding the waves in our little boat, In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.  In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.   Now you got the cooler and I got the poles, we’re anchored together at our fishing hole, We’ll lay our sleeping bags out on the deck, and kiss and give thanks for this sweet life we get, In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.  In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.   Now if you sail west, for an hour or two, you’ll feel the ocean begin to rock you, Don’t be worried and don’t be afraid, it’s just the love that the wind and moon made, In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.  In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell. In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.  In the swell, in the swell, in love I fell.

What a week it has been for Louis. Last Saturday the bear mauled him. On Sunday he had abdominal surgery while he was laid out on top of the kitchen stove. During the week he took it pretty easy resting and licking his wound.

That licking his wound resulted in the stitches coming out and today he had to be sedated again. Another trip to the top of the stove. This time Dr. Perry used 20 pound monofilament fishing line to sew him up.

The interior stitches had held and he is healing but the external stitches holding his skin together failed. With this heavy duty "thread" his licking the incision won't degrade the closure.  We have also fabricated a collar that hopefully will keep him from reaching the incision.

Almost all the fishermen have abandoned the Alsek River to fish over here by the cabin in the East Alsek River. I'm staying over on the Alsek for this week anyway.

There has been an ongoing stress when it comes to having propane tanks and fuel drums refilled. If the fishing doesn't improve the fish buyer will pull out of Dry Bay. The planes that haul the fish out are the ones that deliver the fuel....sometimes. As of yesterday my propane tank had made it up to Yakutat after waiting two weeks. When it comes back I should be set for the next year with propane. Next issue is gas for the Honda and outboard. I need at least another barrel for this year and it is good to have one in place here so when I show up next spring there is fuel to get things started till the fish buyer comes back in June.

Maybe this coming week will be more "normal". I sure hope so.

Yesterday there was another commercial fishing opening. Again this week it was for both the nearby rivers. Many of the fishermen moved over to the East Alsek River from the Alsek. In the past this time of the season fishing declines on the Alsek and is about prime time to fish the smaller East river. As a result I had my choice of previously "good" sets over on the Alsek.

A couple of unexpected things happened. First the weather went south in a big way. The wind was blowing hard and steady rain was falling on the East River. The water was white capped and controlling the boats while tending the nets made a hard enough job even harder. The steady rain fell where I was fishing but my sets were sheltered from the wind. More good fortune followed my not moving my gear. I caught several fish while the men that moved and had to fight the elements caught fewer fish than they had hoped. The last bit of good fortune is that the Fish and Wildlife petrol decided to leave the Alsek River open to fishing two more days. The East Alsek River was closed at noon today.

When the chips fall like they did this week it is no wonder they call it fishing and not catching.

Louis is mending nicely. This morning he acted excited to go for a walk even though it was shorter than we used to take. He is eating well. Right now he is lying on his side that was mauled by the bear. I hope that means the discomfort is reducing as the wound heals.

Evolve (v) to achieve or develop gradually. To work out. To develop by evolution. To undergo evolutionary change. To undergo any change. I must be gradually evolving into the life patterns required here at the cabin. There is still plenty to do around here but some of the chores I just don't want to do. Like replacing the insulation in the ceiling. I'd rather do something .. anything else. Maybe we, Louis and I, should evolve and take a trip. The weather has finally cleared up. This month we have had 18.72 inches of rain. 27.65 inches since the first of May. The rain caused me to not even fish the third day this week. This morning the Vet and I went over to the harbor and brought the nets and boat home. There is a slight chance I will set a net for the silver salmon when they come into the East river but there is no commercial market for them here at Dry Bay and I think the freezer at home is nearly full. Maybe I'll ask a neighbor to check and see how much room is left. There are about twenty sockeye in the freezer here. Most of them are smoked. Tried an new smoking recipe. One cup of salt, two cups of brown sugar, two cups of white sugar. Lay the fish between layers of the salt/sugar and let that sit over night, rinse well then put them in the smoker as usual. I did that. I can't really tell much difference in the taste with this method and what I have been doing with just salt. Anyway there are fifteen pounds more smoked salmon in the freezer. The Alaska State Fair is going on this week down in Haines. I thought some folks from Yakutat might be going down to see the sights. If that happened then maybe I could hitch a ride back down to Haines on the empty plane when the folks from town came home. Not to be this year. Nobody chartered a plane to go to the fair. Another way to get to Haines on the cheap would be to fly down with a group of rafters who have come off the Alsek River. The charter service informed me those flights are all full because the ten to fourteen day raft trip requires so much gear the plane is always full. The third option might work out. The good folks at Mountain Flying Service have hauled Louis and me in and out of here the last two years. After contacting them it looks like there might be a way to get down there. If that happens Louis and I are going to hop in the camper and become wanderers over in the middle of this huge state. We might go to Fairbanks with lots of stops in between. We might end up in Valdez on the Prince Williams Sound. We might go to Dawson City in the Yukon and drive the Top of the World Highway. We hope the weather holds and Paul can fly his beautiful deHavilland DHC-2 Beaver over here to get us. We would need to be back by the first of September. The silver salmon should be in the river by then and with them world class sport fishing. Sportsmen from Europe come here to fish just out my front door. Every time I run into the Vet, aka Dr. Perry, I quickly run out of words trying to express my gratitude for his saving Louis. Between the surgery and the antibiotics he gave us the old dog seems to be doing just fine. I might pick up something special for him on our trip. I am so tempted to type something very tacky here but just imagine what us two old guys might come up with for entertainment. It probably wouldn't be a DVD of Billy Graham's best sermons.

Went fishing with the Vet this morning.  There are so many Sockeye in the upper river sometimes you could see three or four jumping at the same time.  For some reason the fish really like the fly I have been using.  Every few casts I would have some sort of fishy experience.  I wouldn’t always land the fish.  Many times they would shake the hook out.  Some of the fish were ready to spawn and would not be good for eating.  Some others were fresh in the river from the ocean.  Those were the ones we kept. It was becoming routine casting and catching fish.  Then it stopped.  Using the same fly.  Standing in the same spot.  Casting the same way.  The fish were still out there.  What could have happened?  For about thirty minutes and probably a hundred casts I didn’t even feel a fish.  Something had changed.  Somehow while landing the last fish the line had become wrapped around the hook in a way that the fly came through the water differently.  I cut the fly off and retied the fly.  I caught two fish on the next two casts. A beautiful day here.  A chill in the air this morning.  It was 42 when I got up.  An 11.2 foot high tide last night and a west wind yesterday made me think it might be a good morning to go beachcombing.  There were no man made treasures out there for me but nature left some images for me to enjoy. A pair of wolves preceded me down the beach.  One big one, one not so big. On the way back to the cabin I had to stop and marvel at the beauty of this place.  It is so pristine.  An eagle watching the surf for some morsel to wash in.  The pair of wolf tracks….symbols of wildness.  A 15,000 foot peak with glaciers on her flanks.  How lucky can one be to have that all to oneself early in the morning on the last day of July 2015?

After we left WalMart last night we headed up Yukon Highway 2 toward Dawson City. There was a small sign mounted on a fence post that was part of a horse pasture. The sign read" Camping cheap rates". We made a U turn and checked the place out. The pasture held about a dozen of the most beautiful paint or pinto horses. The accommodations for people didn't compare so we kept truckin.

A little later we saw a sign for a Yukon Park campground. What a terrific find that was. There were few other campers and we had a site right on the shores of Lake Laberge. This lake is really just a very large and long wide spot of the Yukon River. It was very quiet and peaceful. Some critter did come by during the night and cleaned up Louis's dog bowl.

This morning there was a family of Loons out on the lake in front of the camper. Driving today we crossed the Yukon River five times. Twice on a ferry.

Tonight we are in Dawson City. This is the place where many of the Klondike gold rush miners were headed. Tomorrow the plan is to drive up toward Fort McPherson. If we get that done we will cross the Arctic Circle.

im using the iPad while we are on the road.  When I can get Louis to show me how to get pictures into it then maybe we can begin to add something interesting to these posts.

Boy, what a day! I don't ever remember being on a drive when I said to myself; isn't this great that I am excited about what the scenery will be like around the next curve. That actually happened more than once today.

The drive from Dalton City, Yukon to Fort McPherson, North West Territory is about four hundred miles. Three hundred sixty of them are on gravel road. Most of the road way was smooth and wide. There were a few places where that description did not apply. Especially when you were meeting a 30 wheeled tractor trailer (double trailers) on a curve with pot holes six inches deep. That only happened once. The solution of course is to slow down. On the first part of the trip it is nearly two hundred miles between services (gas).

The main goal today was to cross the Arctic Circle. Tonight we are camped about 75 miles above there. Most of the day was beautiful. The information at one of the roadside rest stops mentioned you could easily see over a hundred miles up the valley. That was the case most of the drive. Huge, HUGE, valleys stretched away on either side of the road. The tundra looks like the fairways on a golf course. Par for some of those holes would be in the thousands.

Another ferry crossing took us to within a few miles of Fort McPherson. We pulled into the one gas station at eleven after eight local time. The station closed at eight. No problem though. We just set up camp at a Native managed campground. There are just three campers here tonight.

There were three of us on the road together. Two other men in their own trucks. I had passed them both early on the road. After that it was difficult for them to pass me because of the sometimes dense dust off the road. At the only gas station in the 360 miles we all hit there within about five minutes. I asked them if I was holding them up. The reply was "a little bit". So I let the, leave before me. A little farther down the road the driver that said " a little bit" had pulled over to help a guy headed the other way. That truck had a flat. So the three of us changed the tire and we went on our ways.

That incident reminded me of running out of gas last April and the fellows that helped me. Recalling that I bought a five liter can today to keep a reserve of gas in the truck....just in case.

We thought we would get an early start from Fort McPherson back to Dalton City. We were at the ferry crossing at 7:30. I should have read the signs last night. The ferry starts running at 9:15. Time was not waster though. Still have not figured out the controls for the little GoPro camera. All I have managed to do so far is take pictures of the back of my fingers and the floor of the truck.

Back at the Dawson visitor center there were four films of about 15 minutes each. One on steam ships on the upper Yukon, one on gold mining, one on town's history and the last one on the area's colorful people. The lady at the campground where we stayed the first not highly recommended making the visitor center ones first stop. That was good advice.

It got up into the mid eighties today. Above the Arctic Circle it was in the low forties this morning.

Blasting back down the gravel road today I found a Beach Boys Greatest Hits , vol. one album on the iPod. With the windows down and accompanied by rocks hitting the bottom of the truck RHONDA helped me along with BA BA BA, BA BARBARA ANN and her GOOD VIBRATIONS. GOD ONLY KNOWS how many CALIFORNIA GIRLS in their 409's or LITTLE DUCE COUPES had FUN FUN FUN before they were SHUT DOWN. But Louis and I GET AROUND.

All the words in caps above are the names of some of the songs on the album. You might assume there wasn't much else to report today.

Today finds us in Fairbanks.  The drive over here from Eagle took longer than I expected.  The interruptions in our normal rate of travel were all good. Having never caught a Grayling the beautiful streams along side the roadway looked to me like they would hold lots of these beautiful fish.  That in fact might be true but those fish were not at all interested in what I offered them.  At one stop some men suggested a spot where the Grayling were supposed to hang out.   No luck there but in the conversation they explained the Bureau of Land Managment had hired them to clean up an old gold mine a ways down stream. Nearly a century ago gold mining was a huge industry around here.  There is still quite a bit of mining going on.  Some of the stream banks are littered with rusty equipment used in the old days to extract the ore.  Now days people are going back through the mine and stream side tailings to recover what was missed first time through.  In the community of Chicken (the founders couldn't spell ptarmigan) the store where I bought gas had a variety of gold mining equipment for sale.  Everything from pans to sluce machines.  A sign on the bulletin board out front offered bulldozers for rent. Back on the road we kept an eye out for Carabou. The Fourty Mile Carabou herd is currently estimated to me about 60,000 animals.  Sometime they cross the road we were on. The Park Ranger at Eagle told me he once had to wait a couple of hours while the animals streamed across the road in front of his car.  I think it is a little early for those kind of numbers to be crossing now.  Maybe I will pass back through there on the way back to Haines.

Back on the road we kept an eye out for Carabou. The Fourty Mile Carabou herd is currently estimated to me about 60,000 animals.  Sometime they cross the road we were on. The Park Ranger at Eagle told me he once had to wait a couple of hours while the animals streamed across the road in front of his car.  I think it is a little early for those kind of numbers to be crossing now.  Maybe I will pass back through there on the way back to Haines.

Yesterday started off in a good way. The tired old campground we were in had hot showers included in the $24.00 a night charge. Many of the private campgrounds have showers. Most of them charge extra for showers. In some cases you have to buy tokens that are deposited in a box that starts the shower. The campground in Dawson City gave you six minutes of water for each token. Back in Fairbanks we found a Fred Myers store. Theses stores are huge. Free wifi. A nice deli. A Starbucks. Hot breakfast. Right next door was one of those hair salons franchises. Lately Louis had been looking at me in kind of a puzzled way. I think not having a haircut or beard trim since April might have had something to do with it. A little farther down the road we found a Home Depot. The camper needed a little maintenance. The Depot had all the things we needed. Within sight of the Depot there was one of those do it yourself car wash places. Fifteen dollars of tokens later we pulled out of there with a truck and camper several pounds lighter. I don't think the bugs on the front of the truck weighed that much but the stones, gravel and mud in the wheel wells did. Fairbanks also hosts several McDonalds restaurants. Lunch for me was one of their new sirloin burgers with fried onions and mushrooms. Louis got two of their dollar meal cheeseburgers. Leaving Fairbanks behind heading toward Denali National Park we were in no hurry to find a place to spend the night. Mount McKinley, 20,320 feet high, is the highest peak in North America. Denali draws people from all over the world to her scenery and wildlife viewing opportunities. One campground sign along the way said "take the next left". We did and about two miles later on a narrow gravel road we pulled into a family's yard. Five beautiful small children ran out to see who the visitor was. Apparently we turned left too soon. The actual campground was a little farther along. It was cramped and full of campers so we kept going.   Farther down the road we found the perfect spot. Widely spaced camp sites among beautiful white trunks of burch trees. Louis could run free on the airstrip adjacent to where we parked. The owner was doing some work nearby and we struck up a conversation. He is building a storage building for some of his equipment. I am envious of all his "toys". He had been operating a small bulldozer. There was a backhoe parked near by. Some big tracked machine with an auger attached for drilling holes in the ground was off to the side. In another shed was a bush plane, on wheels. There were floats beside the plane he could attach if there was a need to land on a lake. The walls of the gift shop/office were lined with mounted big game animals and other Alaska critters he had taken over the years. This man and he is wife spend the winters in Central America where they have another home. For an outdoors man he seemed to have it all EXCEPT a good place to fly fish for salmon. ( imagine a big smile on my face here ). We hit it off really well. He and his wife came over to the camper and we shared a drink, some snacks and great conversation. Who knows, maybe they will come to Fry Bay for a visit. What a nice way to wind down my birthday.

Yesterday we couldn't get a campsite in the National Park so we drove on toward Anchorage. About an hour and a half down the road we found a gravel road off onto the bush. It was a perfect spot for us to settle in, read a book and wait for today. Seventy seven miles later we were back in Denali. One of the artists featured at the visitor center created this beautiful quilt. I photographed it for my sisters who both are skilled at making quilts too.   The rest of today's posting would come up lacking trying to describe the beauty of this place. I wish the iPad could reproduce the scale and beauty my eyes see here.   It occurred to me that the relationship I am enjoying here on this splendid unspoiled land is not unlike relationships we experience with others. We become familiar with the beauty that attracted us in the first place. I don't want to get used to this. I want to keep discovering it.

Didn't post anything yesterday since most of the roads we were on were four lane divided expressways. We had gone from camping in a deserted rock quarry where we could barely hear the traffic on the highway to Anchorage. We got all our shopping done except for the things I forgot. Before afternoon rush our we got out of town.

One plan was to drive down to Whittier, take the ferry to Valdez then head back toward Eagle. Instead we cut across to Palmer and then on to near Gllenallen. We stumbled across a private campground whose host, Curtis from Texas, asked what kind of campsite I wanted. I told him we didn't need water, sewer or electricity. He asked if I wanted to be out in the boonies? Yes. It was a perfect spot of Lewis and me.

We tried catching grayling again. No luck.

Just the other side of Gllenallen is the visitor center for the Wrangell Saint Elias National Park. It was worth the stop. I bought the movie they show describing the park. One detail mentioned in the movie is the park is larger than Switzerland and the mountains are higher.

Along the road we caught this moose in a classic Alaska pose.

We crossed the Little Toc River on the way toward Chicken, AK. Story goes that the founders wanted to name the town Ptarmigan but couldn't spell it so they named their town Chicken. The little stream was running clear. Most streams and all the rivers we have crossed are gray with glacial silt. The elusive grayling were cooperating. Caught six or seven of these beautiful fish and returned them to the water unharmed.

 

Tonight we are in another abandoned rock quarry. No water, no sewer, no electricity. The view is terrific.....Perfect spot.

Louis and I are beginning to be restless about getting back to Dry Bay.  We have driven over 2,000 miles on this break from there.  We have at least 650 more to go to get back to Haines.

However.......I have wanted to see Sitka.  We could take the ferry from Haines to Sitka and back.  That would add another ten days to our "vacation".  We might just do that.

Yesterday Louis and I rolled into Haines again. That drive from Haines Junction, BC to Haines is still my favorite as far as scenery is concerned considering the distance traveled. We have decided to hang out here a couple of days then take the Alaska Marine Highway ferries down to Sitka. On Thursday evening we board a ferry from Haines to Juneau. After a 4.5 hour ride we depart that boat then wait about eight hours and get on another ferry. Four and a half hours later we will be in Sitka. When we were in Eagle we met Park Ranger Kae again.  She had Saturday off so we went for a hike up in the high country.  This is the area where the Fourty Mile Caribou herd passes through. Fall has begun to show itself up there.  The wild blueberries were just begging to be picked.  In just a few minutes we gathered enough for. Delicious batch of muffins.   On the way out there were about fifteen  caribou in the road. I couldn't get the camera turned on fast enough to photograph them.  Most of the animals were Bulls with trophy antlers. It is hunting season up there. No wonder they didn't hang around. Apparently cow moose don't worry about hunting season. Last night a storm blew through here.  A steady wind blowing about 50 mph kept the camper rocking.  Louis slept right through the gusts.  I woke up a couple of times just to check and see if there was still a roof over our heads. There are two Alaska state parks near Haines.  One of them is adjacent to a lake and river that has salmon migrating through.  We might move the camper up there into the trees for a couple of days.

We are enjoying spending  time here in Haines.  Last night Paul and Amy, the owners of the bush plane service I use, invited me to have dinner with them at their beautiful home.  Fresh veggies and grilled halibut.  It was delicious and sure beat the canned chili that I would have had in the camper. The Chilkoot Lake state park is where I am staying again tonight.  Pink Salmon are migrating up out of the river that drains Chilkoot Lake.  There are so many fish I couldn't resist going into town and buying an inexpensive rod and reel which I promptly broke.  It was not heavy enough for the salmon.  It was designed for trout.  I took it back to the store and upgraded to a heavier outfit. It seldom took more than five casts to catch one.  Several times I would hand my rod to a person watching and let them bring the fish in.  This morning a lady from China who was on the cruse ship kept one of the fish.   After landing maybe twenty fish I called it quits and went back to the camper.  A guy named Bill came over and said he didn't know anything about catching fish in Alaska.  We talked for a few minutes.  I ended up selling him the rod and reel I had puchased.  It's pretty neat to recover all your expenses while enjoying catching all those fish. In the high winds earlier this week these ducks all gathered in one spot on the bay.  I had not seen this before.  There were a couple hundred of them.  Today with calmer winds they have all disbursed. Tomorrow we start our ferry rides down to Sitka.  Might splurge and get a pizza to go.  Maybe I could sell part of it on the boat and recover that expense too.

Whe have been in Sitka, Alaska the last two days.  Getting here has to be one of the highlights of this tour Louis and I have been taking. The Alaska Marine Highway ferries we rode from Haines to Juneau then from Juneau to Sitka took us through some magnificent scenery.  The first boat we were on was bigger and slower than the catamaran we rode on the second leg.  That second boat cruised along at over 30 knots. (33 mph) through fjords in some places barely two hundred yards wide.   The protection from the ocean by the islands on this inside passage allows all sorts of vessels to sail.  The barge this tug was pulling had stacks of containers the size of trailer trucks.  The white truck (small dot in the middle of the barge) on the middle of the barge is a concrete truck.  I couldn't begin to guess how much that loaded barge weighed. The interest in this community of about 9,000 people stems from a desire to maybe find a spot to settle up here.  Sitka is larger than Haines but the only way to get here is by plane or boat.  Real estate is also pretty expensive here.  The reason for the high prices is the steepness of the country.  The mountains come right down to the sea in many places.  There are several commercial flights into Sitka each day.  There are none into Haines.  You can drive to Haines.  Pros and Cons. Several of the streams around Sitka were full of salmon heading upstream to spawn. We spent two nights in a state run campground.  The huge cedar trees are over 100 feet tall.

This post contains a bunch of pictures and comments.  There has been so much going on around this trip to Sitka and back it might take a while to sort it all out. That stump, near our campsite, posted on an earlier day, is what's left of a huge cedar tree felled in the 1940s.  Note the notch on the right edge about half way up.  That is where boards were supported for the axmen to stand on while felling the tree. An elevated trail through an estuary was a bonus at the campground.  The shelter below overlooks a pond that is a perfect spot to birdwatch. A very quick stop at the Mendenhaul (?) glacier just outside Juneau.  More people there than I had seen in months due to four cruise ships being in town at the same time. Another raised walkway featured spawning sockeye salmon in the creek below. At still another park at the end of the road outside Juneau the chum salmon were spawning.  Here a pair are doing what comes naturally when spawning. In Sitka there is a raptor rescue/preserve.  These three have been injured in the past and can't fly. Whenever possible the birds are returned to the wild.  The tour guide mentioned the ages of some of their resident birds.  One owl had been there 28 years. Three of the four cruise ships that dump 8,000 people into Juneau on seasonal Mondays. We had to get in line to board the ferry to Haines at three this morning.  The dog sled rides on the glaciers above Juneau are over for the season so the mushers were taking their dogs north.  This rig holds about 75 dogs.  These people were moving 124 dogs in two rigs on this trip. A picture of the dogs inside the ferry...anxious to get out onto fresh air.  I didn't hear a single one of these hard working animals bark with all that commotion going on around them. Louis is lucky.  He has a whole truck to himself.     Hhh

Yesterday we made it back to the cabin at Dry Bay. Louis and I drove a little over 3,800 miles as we explored a tiny part of this last frontier. Driving a little slower the truck got 13.5 miles per gallon of fuel. At one of the weigh stations I asked the operator if I could drive the truck across the scale. The truck and camper together weigh a little over 9,600 pounds. The electronics in the truck said the average speed on the trip was 41 mph. To move that much weight and still get 13.5 miles a gallon I felt better about the truck. In Haines Tuesday night we camped out at the airport. The plan was to leave at eight Wednesday morning. There were two others on the flight to Dry Bay besides Paul the pilot. Thorsten and Clay went along for the sightseeing. Both these passengers are pilots. During the flight it was enlightening to hear them discuss flying through the mountains and how to take advantage of the terrain to avoid weather problems. Clay lives in Alaska. Thorsten lives in Switzerland. He is a 747 pilot. After they went back to Haines Thorsten flew his single engine plane back over here to Dry Bay and may stay with me a couple of days to experience life in the bush.   Back at the cabin there was a package on the table and a letter. The package has another Lego toy in it and a bunch of plastic packing material. The letter was from the Federal Government. It read: A parcel sent to you with no return address on the package was referred to our office because it broke open during shipping. The package contained 1 bottle of Old Crow Whiskey and 1 bottle of Heaven Hill Whiskey. All spirituous, vinous, malted fermented or other intoxicating liquor store of any kind are non-mailable, and should not be deposited in, or carried through the mails. Such activity is a violation of Title 18, United States Code, Section 1716(f), and may be subject to a term of imprisonment of up to one year or a fine of $1,000, or both. The prohibited matter was removed and destroyed. The legal contents were returned to the mail stream. The letter went on to say who I could call to dispute the issue. It also said if this unlawful activity continued I could be prosecuted. I guess I will have to get a bigger truck to haul my "southern comfort" up here next year.

Yesterday we made it back to the cabin at Dry Bay. Louis and I drove a little over 3,800 miles as we explored a tiny part of this last frontier. Driving a little slower the truck got 13.5 miles per gallon of fuel. At one of the weigh stations I asked the operator if I could drive the truck across the scale. The truck and camper together weigh a little over 9,600 pounds. The electronics in the truck said the average speed on the trip was 41 mph. To move that much weight and still get 13.5 miles a gallon I felt better about the truck. In Haines Tuesday night we camped out at the airport. The plan was to leave at eight Wednesday morning. There were two others on the flight to Dry Bay besides Paul the pilot. Thorsten and Clay went along for the sightseeing. Both these passengers are pilots. During the flight it was enlightening to hear them discuss flying through the mountains and how to take advantage of the terrain to avoid weather problems. Clay lives in Alaska. Thorsten lives in Switzerland. He is a 747 pilot. After they went back to Haines Thorsten flew his single engine plane back over here to Dry Bay and may stay with me a couple of days to experience life in the bush.   Back at the cabin there was a package on the table and a letter. The package has another Lego toy in it and a bunch of plastic packing material. The letter was from the Federal Government. It read: A parcel sent to you with no return address on the package was referred to our office because it broke open during shipping. The package contained 1 bottle of Old Crow Whiskey and 1 bottle of Heaven Hill Whiskey. All spirituous, vinous, malted fermented or other intoxicating liquor store of any kind are non-mailable, and should not be deposited in, or carried through the mails. Such activity is a violation of Title 18, United States Code, Section 1716(f), and may be subject to a term of imprisonment of up to one year or a fine of $1,000, or both. The prohibited matter was removed and destroyed. The legal contents were returned to the mail stream. The letter went on to say who I could call to dispute the issue. It also said if this unlawful activity continued I could be prosecuted. I guess I will have to get a bigger truck to haul my "southern comfort" up here next year.

A big day here in Dry Bay. I was able to finish another of the Lee Child murder mystery novels. Managed to not start on the next one till some other things got done. Through the early part of the summer a number of logs were collected for firewood. This week the plan has been to cut all those logs up into firewood lengths. (As I proof read this I realized it is a new week. It is easy to forget what day it is here). Then the hard part started. Those lengths had to be moved up to the wood shed and split into wood stove size pieces and stacked. Today that chore got completed for this season. There should be enough wood in the shed for all of next summer and maybe a little more. While splitting the wood a hummingbird came by. Here's wishing that little guy luck in making it back to Central America before cold weather hits. Sandhill Cranes were soaring high overhead today too. Sometimes they would circle five or six times in a column of rising air before heading off toward the southeast. A mile or so later they would catch another thermal, gain some altitude and sail off again. Those birds may pass through the same country I will drive through in about a month. The Vet is a falconer. He is trying to trap a raptor her. He is one of three people who have permission to do that this year here in Alaska. He can tell me what kind of bird of prey is flying. Y before I even see it. Went fishing after the wood project was finished. Caught the first Silver salmon of the season. While fishing one of the raptors Mike hopes to catch, a Merlin, and a sparrow put on quite show doing aerial acrobatics. The sparrow got away but for about a minute we were awed by their maneuvers. Nearly at the same time seals were chasing salmon through the shallows on the other side of the river. All this is going on with the background in the picture below behind us. Two days ago I drove over to the fish plant to pick up some mail. Drove a little over twenty miles. Did not see a single bear track. Did not see a single wolf track. There are very few Eagles in the neighborhood. Thinking the food is somewhere else right now. That night a bear hit all three burn barrels in the cabins here on the East River. Louis has been reluctant to walk on the train in a woods. The bear must still be around. There have been large tides the last few days. The recent rains have the rivers full. At the mouths of the rivers there is a lot of erosion going on. Log jams that have been buried for years are washing out. The mouth of the East River has moved northwest about 150 feet this summer. Where there used to be a beach before the sand dunes now there is a cliff of sand at the base of the dunes.

Not much going on around here the last few days.  Two days ago there was a big enough tide to let some salmon move up into the creek in front of the cabin.  I caught a couple of them but released them so they could proceed with what they had in mind. This afternoon another bigger fish took what was offered.  That fish is baking in the oven as this is being typed.  The fish are a little late coming into the river this year.  The outfitters who have clients here spend most of their time looking for fish. Next week should be better.  I know they hope so.  Some of the fishermen come all the way from Europe to catch these salmon.  There are no guarantees when fishing but to come all that way and not catch anything would be disappointing. My old pal Louis seems to be as set in his ways as me.  He likes to do things at certain times of the day. Right now he is waiting for me to take him for a walk.  Same thing in the mornings after the first cup of coffee. Mine not his.  His memory of the bear incident is still clear.  He just doesn't want to walk down the trail through the woods any more.  That is OK with me too.

The Silver Salmon have returned. Consensus is they are a little late this year but the tide Saturday afternoon brought in a good number of fish . We caught several just out from the cabin. Yesterday morning the Vet and I didn't have any luck fishing near our cabins. The fish that came in yesterday kept moving upstream. After trying several places we found them again farther up than we usually fish. Today it rained all morning but I went back to the new hot spot. I was offering the fish a yellow streamer fly. No luck at all. I tied on a purple and black fly. Second cast I had a nice fish. Yesterday every fish caught was a male. Today it was about 50/50. I try and let the females go. Each of the females carry hundreds of eggs. It just seems right let them go so there will be more salmon in the years to come.

I have ten salmon in the cooler now. Tomorrow I will crank up the smoker. The plan is to can the thicker parts of these fish. The thinner cuts will just be smoked. Tonight I need to see if the gasket for the pressure cooker is still good. If it isn't good there is always plan B.....just freeze 'em.

There is a bear in the neighborhood. It is leaving its sign around. We haven't seen it but it's out there somewhere. A cow moose and her calf were out front the other morning. They are big animals. Watching them go past they move just like a horse trotting along on these long legs. They cover a lot of ground quickly.
The Vet caught a GyrFalcon the other day. He will take it back to Washington and train it to hunt. Gyrfalcon are the largest of the Falcons. They have a four foot wing span. If you google Gyrfalcon they are truly amazing birds.
