I don't remember the name of big tropical storm that was out in the Pacific recently. I didn't pay much attention to the path it took across that huge ocean. Not even sure if the storm had a male or female sounding name. That lack of attention has come home to roost. The little weather computer Ann have me last year is blinking urgently. It is telling me "ITS RAINING CATS AND DOGS". The weather announcement on the VHF radio this afternoon is describing 12 foot seas and a 25 knot wind from the southeast. A computerized voice on the VHF is explaining there will be "RAIN, HEAVY AT TIMES". Since the first of May it has rained 48.9 inches here at the cabin. Surprisingly it has rained just an inch and a half today. Every year about this time the Vet has some friends fly in. They wind down their Alaska summer fishing and getting his cabin winterized. They will fly out in four days. The other neighbor known as Hazel Creek, will fly out with them. Louis and I will be the only ones left over here on the East River side of Dry Bay. There will be one couple still on the Alsek River side. I may see them, maybe not. What this is leading up to is the sad task of getting ready to leave here myself. Paul from Mountain Air might be bringing some sport fishers over from Haines next week. If that happens we could catch a ride back with him. That would save some money. Otherwise we would have to charter a flight. About a $500 swing. There are plenty of chores left to do before I make flight plans though. Need to change the oil in both the ATVs. One of the trailers has a flat tire I should repair so I won't be faced with that next May. I might cut and split a little more wood. The new vacuum machine will need servicing before storage. We have to eat the leftovers from packages of food opened during the summer. Half a box of Hash Brown potatoes, some pasta, two boxes of cereal. And pack. In some ways life will be simpler back in Colorado. In most ways not. In the mornings here I get up start the fire on the wood stove. Here I get the old fashioned coffee pot ready the evening before and then turn the gas stove burner on low in the mornings. By the time Louis and I get back from our walk the coffee is ready. In Boulder the coffee pot turns itself on. Here as we walk back to the cabin. Louis leading the way, we can see the smoke curling up out of the chimney. We know it will be warm and toasty inside and the coffee will be ready. In Boulder it is simpler but not as much fun.

The weather forecast calls for rain every day into next weekend. The chances of precipitation in the forecast are from 60% on up to 100% heavy at times.

The sport fishing has slowed to halt. Yesterday a couple of us spent over three hours trying to catch a fish and only one was landed. We could see salmon swim by on their way upstream but they didn't cooperate. There are some above average tides in the next few days. Maybe the bigger tides will encourage the fish to move into the river. It would be good if I could add four more fish to the freezer.

Tomorrow the remaining neighbors all fly out. Depending on the weather I might arrange to leave next week. If the weather is nice I'd rather stay a little longer but the nice weather is when flying over the mountains is easier to arrange.

A few stats:as of 1:00 pm today it has rained 1.75 inches -  6 inches the last three days - 9.43 inches in the last week - 14.45 inches this month - 59.58 inches (almost 5 feet) since May 1.  We were about to call Mountain Flying Service to get us out of here until two things happened this morning. First thing was the weather report said the sun might come out on Sunday.  If the report is correct the sun might even shin for several days next week.  If that happens the river might go down and I may be able to catch the four more fish I want to freeze. The second thing was this handsome guy was out front this morning. He is the first wild creature I have seen in a couple of weeks.  There have been bear tracks on the beach out in front but Louis and  I have not actually seen any wild creatures except for birds, mostly ducks, in quite a while. A few days ago there was some joy in the beach combing activity.These glass balls were had all washed ashore within a few yards of each other.  Since then, in spite of checking after the night time high tides, no more joy.  The theory is these glass floats have washed ashore sometime in the past and have been covered with sand.  As the beach erodes they are uncovered and left to be found or covered with sand again.  The frosted glass is from being rolled back and forth on the sand. That picture shows how much stuff is buried under these sand dunes.  Those logs are about 10 inches in diameter and the sand bank is probably ten feet high.  Since I took that picture most of these logs have been washed out and are now scattered along the beach waiting to be covered again.

MIGRATE - to change location periodically, esp. To move seasonally from one location to another.

Up here Louis and I have seen the Caribou doing it. We have see hundreds of birds all going in the same direction lately. Some Robins have shown up this week...probably heading south too. I saw three Swans flying south a couple of days ago. The Sandhills Cranes are mostly over near the mountains spiraling upward on the thermals before they set their wings and turn south. Usually we hear them before sighting their wings flashing in the light. There are three Great Blue Herons out front this morning. Probably parents showing the youngster the way. A couple of days ago there was a dusting of snow on the lower peaks. Today that snow has begun to migrate downward too.

 

 

Tomorrow morning we to will be heading south. The original plan was to stay up here through the end of the month. The flying service is bringing in a couple of fishermen from Haines. Rather than sit here in the cabin watching it rain we decided to take advantage of the empty flight back to Haines. The plan them is to take a different route home this year. There are three access routes up through Canada to the Alaska Highway. The eastern, central and western. Because we are leaving earlier than planned this trip home will be a little longer in both time on the road and miles traveled.

The sport fishing has been disappointing. The four fish I had hoped to add to the freezer just kept swimming by. There was a bear out front last night. Didn't see it but it dug up some roots to eat out of the front yard.

Going to take the Internet antenna down this afternoon. No telling where the next posting here will come from.

There are three access routes up through Canada to the Alaska Highway. The eastern, central and western.  The western rou Because we are leaving earlier than planned this trip home will be a little longer in both time on the road and miles traveled. The sport fishing has been disappointing. The four fish I had hoped to add to the freezer just kept swimming by. There was a bear out front last night. Didn't see it but it dug up some roots to eat out of the front yard. Going to take the Internet antenna down this afternoon. No telling where the next posting here will come from.

MIGRATE - to change location periodically, esp. To move seasonally from one location to another. Up here Louis and I have seen the Caribou doing it. We have see hundreds of birds all going in the same direction lately. Some Robins have shown up this week...probably heading south too. I saw three Swans flying south a couple of days ago. The Sandhills Cranes are mostly over near the mountains spiraling upward on the thermals before they set their wings and turn south. Usually we hear them before sighting their wings flashing in the light. There are three Great Blue Herons out front this morning. Probably parents showing the youngster the way. A couple of days ago there was a dusting of snow on the lower peaks. Today that snow has begun to migrate downward too. Tomorrow morning we to will be heading south. The original plan was to stay up here through the end of the month. The flying service is bringing in a couple of fishermen from Haines. Rather than sit here in the cabin watching it rain we decided to take advantage of the empty flight back to Haines. The plan then is to take a different route home this year. There are three access routes up through Canada to the Alaska Highway. The eastern, central and western.  The western route is the one we'll use this time...maybe. Because we are leaving earlier than planned this trip home will be a little longer in both time on the road and miles traveled. The sport fishing has been disappointing. The four fish I had hoped to add to the freezer just kept swimming by. There was a bear out front last night. Didn't see it but it dug up some roots to eat out of the front yard. Going to take the Internet antenna down this afternoon. No telling where the next posting here will come from.

We are in Whitehorse, Yukon Territory this morning waiting for the place that sells dry ice to open.  The dry ice will keep the eighty pounds of salmon I have in the cooler frozen till we get home. Yesterday the ferry from Haines to Skagway was a nostalgic ride.  Seventeen years ago Nancy and I were on our way to hike the Chillcoot Trail and rode that ferry.  I hadn't been up through there since then. Last night we camped on the shore of Lake LeBerge again.  There was one other camper in the campground.  Our site was right on the shore.  Lake LeBerge is part of the Yukon River system.  This year I spent many nights on the edge of that mighty river.  I'll miss it .

The lion turned toward me just as I opened the back door of the camper.  Louis was off to my right.  He was glad to be out of the back seat of the truck after a 600 mile day. Have been reading thriller novels for the last month.  Most of them start off chapter one with something to grab the readers attention.  I thought I'd try that too. It is Tuesday as I type this.  We got back to Boulder Sunday afternoon. The four day drive from Whitehorse was mostly uneventful.  This trip we took the Cassiar Highway down toward Prince Rupert but turned east near Smithers.  Next spring I will probably go back north this way. The next day we headed mostly east.  Outside the village of Tete Jaune Cache we drove back a logging road to set up for the night.  That is when the mountain lion appeared.  It was behind those Aspen trees in the picture.  These wildlife incidents happen so quickly.  The lion turned toward me just as I pulled the steps down from the back door of the camper.  Louis was off to my right the lion was on my left.  Louis was glad to be out of the back seat of the truck after a 600 mile day.  The mountain lion was so close I could see it look at me then at Louis then back at me.  I think it was trying to figure out how to get past me and have the dog for dinner.  It took a step toward me but as the volume of my protests increased it decided to slink away.  I stepped off the distance between where I had been to the cat.  Twenty five feet. The next day we drove the Icefields Parkway through the Jasper National Park.  The brochure the ranger gave me upon entering the park described that drive as "the most beautiful road in the world!"  I believe it.  I pulled this next sentence out of something I read recently.  "“Wildlike” vast and unpredictable, at turns gorgeous and tragic, isolating  exhilarating.""  The drive is like going through Yosemite and under El Capitan a dozen times.  My words can't come close to describing how tiny and awestruck I felt there on Alberta highway 93. Returning to civilization seems harder this year than in the past.  I'm feeling torn.  Torn between the feelings of doing what an old man is supposed to be doing and what I have discovered in the unspoiled vastness beyond civilization.
